GAME: Twilight Struggle
RANK: 4
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A couple of reasons why Twilight Struggle is amazing:
-Every game (even a blow-out) is intense.
-Players are in constant agony. 
-There's plenty of luck (card deals & die rolls), but skill still wins.
-Every game tells a story, with a proper beginning, middle, & end.
-It has an incredible learning curve, with many different levels of play.
-I still haven't had a single game of it that wasn't fun.

----
(via trade. End of The Triumvirate)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
[First impressions]
Too long and expensive for what it has to offer, despite its fascinating theme. Card driven in a perverse way: the cards make most of the game, not the players. You have to learn most of them, the phase in which they come up and, even then, you must consider if other specific cards have already being played or not, limiting your choices even more. Some rules are unnecessarily fiddly, others are just too luck ridden (the space race, of course) and having recently played Hannibal: Rome vs. Carthage has made some of this points even more obvious. It shares with Hannibal one of its biggest flaws, at least from my point of view: just too long for the amount of luck involved.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
Way overhyped but still an outstanding game. This is a good introduction to war games, and building games in general. Player interaction will make or break this one, and careful observation is a useful aid. Trust no one.

RATING: 7
I'm in two minds about this - I feel I should like it more than I do because the theme is excellent but I suspect to really enjoy it you need to invest the time that will give you a better idea of the cards in the game and truth is there are other games that I'd rather spend my limited time on. Catch 22?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Yes there is some luck involved in the die rolls, but the hand management and strategic elements of planning where to shore up your control far outweigh that (plus, the luck is largely done in thematic elements of uncertainty and I'm ok with that). One of the most tense games I've ever played, each card carries weight as to when to play it, where you opponent has, where they are trying to score, how they will crush you or lock you out of a region, etc. One of the few games where I really get into it (thematically) and like having a soundtrack on in the background (subtle, tense, classical strings), I just get absorbed into the game. It's a game where having an interest in the material is solidly helpful. One of the highest forms of praise I can offer is that it's a game that I just sit and think about in my spare time, and casually obsess about on occasion. It's a game that has refined (but not formed) my thinking in regards to many other game spaces; hand management, distraction, and risk management.

One thing that makes it over something like Matthews' 1960:MotP for me is that you now have much more granular movements and calculation of influence (instead of just the 4 regions, it's now regions with spots within them and your movement is restricted within the region based on prior influence placement). Second, I find the cards are much more circumstantial in their play compared to 1960 where it was much more cut and dry which cards I'd want to play for the event. In TS, it depends much more on what you want to accomplish since the board is much more granular and scoring comes around multiple times.

A bittersweet element of TS is that it's rules and design overall contain a number of sharp edge cases that ultimately have lead to a general plague of errata and clarifications (in similar ways to 1960, but many more in quantity). This makes it much more difficult for new players to learn how to plan and play properly, but does create some rather novel strategic and tactical plays, and is one of the reasons that I do just sort of sit and think about the game.

The greatest downsides are that new players don't understand the ebb and flow of the game (which makes sense as that comes with experience), it takes a while to play, and you have a ton of cards you have to learn (this part sort of blows). Second, scoring can be sort of convoluted to learn at first, and there are a number of times that doing anything outside of battleground spots just doesn't make sense which is unfortunate. Last; it's solidly not a game for everyone; some people don't like the card management of having 110+ cards to learn and understand the optimum placement and possibilities just to be competitive or at least solidly dig into the game (I dig that aspect, but I understand why others won't). All that said, I'll gladly play a game if I have the time and a willing opponent.

RATING: 8
A really well built CDG that covers it's theme like no other. It's very engrossing and overall a great experience for the quick playing time (experienced players). It's inherent flaw is that if you don't get scoring cards while you're opponent does you are at a disadvantage. It's a catastrophic disadvantage if you are not intimately familiar with the game and your opponent is. In other words both players need to be of equal skill level to compete in this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Quite simply the greatest strategy game created. TS is not for everyone, but for hardcore strategy fans, it doesn't get better than TS. Learning curve is steep and you will likely get crushed by more experienced opponents the first few times, but once you start to understand the strategy, there's nothing like it. 

Time investment wise, a game that runs to "final scoring" will normally take about 3 hours. However, the game can end much sooner than that as well (VP victory, defcon suicide, Europe control). 

One of the great features of TS is that there are several paths to victory. If you find yourself closed off on one front, you can pursue another strategy. For instance, I found myself dominated in South America, North America, Asia, and Middle East in one game. However, I noticed my opponent was thin in Europe and only controlled West Germany and Italy. I went all-in on a European control strategy and managed to win the game. 

This sort of dynamic is what makes it so great. You can't simply "dominate the board" and automatically expect to win. You have to be cognizant of bad events, hand-reduction cards, European control, etc, etc, etc.

Also fwiw, the game is pretty educational. A lot of the Cold War era events I was not aware of before the game (e.g. Yuri & Samantha, Aldrich Ames, Grain Sales to Soviets).

RATING: 10
Once we had a few proper games under our belts this established itself as a firm favourite, with the mechanics well suited to the ebb and flow of the cold war. I particularly liked the way in which countries with low stability numbers are prone to coup attempts, and the judicious use of realignment rolls makes these very powerful at the right time.

Provided you know the deck and some of the nasties hidden in there, it's an outstanding game. Really top-notch.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The Cold War can get a reputation for being a pretty long and tedious affair, not quite as exhilarating as the explosions and flying bullets of WWII or the Civil War. Twilight Struggle captures the tension of the Cold War and displays the gravity of the situation in which we were living during that time, making it one of the most rewarding board games ever designed.

The gameplay is both smooth and effective, not simplifying the history, but instead bringing it alive through global domination and three different eras. Due to the design of the card play, you'll have cards that help your opponent, adding to the theme of having insider information via spy tactics or that your efforts will trigger consequences outside of your control. 

A tight game that is more epic than you realize while playing it, Twilight Struggle is deservedly a modern classic
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
10 turns or less, each turn you'll have 8 cards (additionally the China card) to be played in 6 rounds per turn, most of the cards can be used to do either realignment/ space race/ trigger event/ place influence/ attempt coup, mostly to control some countries, scoring card is a must-play before the turn ends or you'll lose. If you use opponent's card for any action except space race, your opponent gets to play the event on the card, you want to avoid this as much as you can. Starting with headline phase then action rounds then military operations status check. The game ends if any player controlled all European battleground countries during Europe region scoring or any player gets 20/-20 points or highest score by the end of round 10 or any player trigger DEFCON 0. The most special thing about TS is the various way you can use the cards. Most of the time I just check the operation point on the card & whether the opponent's event will affect my territory badly or not then take the best action with the card without really paying attention with the historical events.

RATING: 8
Wow.  One of the best game designs ever.  I spent my first play in awe of how it all comes together.  I kept thinking to myself "This shouldn't work" and "This game should be terrible," but it isn't.  Somehow it all works brilliantly.

My two plays were great and I do hope to play it more.  You need several plays before you can hope to play it well.  Not only do you need to know the cards, but you have to understand the tempo of the game and when scoring can occur to have any chance.

RATING: 7.5
Good game with very subtle strategic elements. It's certainly rougher than 1960. Several design elements seem unnecessary at first blush - e.g. adding 1 more card in play after turn 3? Different roll values in the space race? The dice mechanic for realignment feels overly complicated - old school and unkempt. Of course, the GMT components are poor. Lastly, it plays a touch long and plods along - much like the years it portrays! But setting all that aside, the historic feel is just right and it has a grandness to it which I completely love. The push and pull of superpower's machinations comes off with great aplomb - a feat in itself.  So all in all, a great game that I willingly play - when I have the three or four hours required.

Es otra filosof√≠a pero que hubiera costado que por cada fallo, tienes por ej, un +1 en el pr√≥ximo intento? RATING: 10
2008
Twilight Struggle offers a great number of tactical choices every turn. At the same time, there's room for a long term strategy also. TS has a steep learning curve due to the numerous events on the cards.

Although, I'm not a big fan of area control games, here the interesting theme and the depth of the game keeps me playing.

2009 
After 6 played games:
After learning the cards and really getting into the game, I've raised my rating first from 7 -> 8, and now from 8 -> 9.

2010-03
9 -> 10
I just don't seem to get enough of this game. I love the theme and the strategic and tactical choices the game offers. I admit that there's some room for criticism but still TS is a 10 for me.

2016-11-23
Twilight Struggle has remained my absolute favourite for years now. This is actually a small wonder considering my background that years back I did not fancy confrontational area control games. The frustration caused by someone smashing your carefully built sand castle was too much for me. Moreover, the fact that a single die roll could have such devastating consequences was enough to label TS as a game of pure luck. 

However, I kept playing to give the game a chance, and more importantly I kept losing. This convinced me that a game of TS could not be decided by luck alone. There was no way that I would always lose by such a big margin if I was not doing something wrong. So, I became aware how the game is played on two levels, short and long term. In the short term it's all about crisis management and your goal is always in mere survival or delivering the decisive strike. But at the same time you must consider the trade-offs your actions bring you in longer term. Personally I find this trade-off between immediate gain and future benefits the greatest aspects of the game. Usually there are no obvious answers to your problems and it all really depends on what strategy you have chosen.

The Deluxe Version I have in my shelf is absolutely gorgeous. Beautiful art and good quality cardboard make the game a joy. The older editions with the flimsy board and tokens were a bit of pain in the ass to handle, to be honest. You also learn a bit of history while playing the game which is always a major bonus.

If there is something to criticise the game about, it would be the learning curve. There are numerous death traps in the game and losing because of a "stupid" mistake may be bad for the morale. You just have to toughen up and be ready to get smitten before you can walk with confidence.

I have also written a more thorough review of the game here:
https://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/636219/maturing-review-twilight-struggle-after-20-plays

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
First and foremost, this is a FUN game.  There isn't as much depth as other CDGs because of the strong possibility of wild swings of fortune - but there's enough to make it interesting.  And, this is a game whose trade-offs are exactly as the designers' introduction states - playability is good, realism/room for long-term Strategy is limited. 

The card draw and the die rolling can make things see-saw very quickly.  You can win in a flash or lose in one, too.  But, you know what, since it's quick and fun, that doesn't seem to matter too much!

The theme is well done and I like most of the event cards: Flower Power, Glasnost, Defectors, Casto, Iron Lady etc, though there is the occasional lapse into something more bland, but not often. The Space Race is nice and the Influence placement (borrowed from Hannibal) is fun.  I like the way nuclear war is treated, although Defcon can be a bit unforgiving.

Card management is critical, of course - and the game is clever enough so that you can't ALWAYS get that right, though there are safety nets.  Possession of scoring cards at the right/wrong time is the MOST crucial factor.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
A modern classic

Beautifully designed game with simple and, importantly, evocative rules. You really feel like you are influencing nations, propping up dictators and sponsoring coups in a global political struggle.

The cards are highly thematic, and although some are a bit too specific for my tastes (e.g. cards like Castro, Nasser, etc should be more generic for use in other countries) the game is really set in its place and time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Historical and the theme seems to work fine. It doesnt tickle my soft spot, though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.9
Thanks to the digital implementation I now have a way to try this game without having to find another live player locally.

This game absolutely deserves all of the praise it has received.  At around 350 games in, I find this still grabs my attention--the design is just that good.  The more I play it, the more I appreciate all of the little nuances that the game has.    

What's Great: the hand management and position management puzzles to deal with all of those unfavorable opponent events you will almost certainly be dealt; the integration of the theme; the overall board design and the way that it makes different regions play differently (sometimes to very dramatic effect); the sheer amount of depth available in the game despite relatively simple mechanics; the tenseness of the push-pull aspect of the game.

Why it Won't Get Played More (at least live):  It is certainly a game that requires equal skill at both positions, and an equal knowledge of the game (including not only how to manage a particular hand, but how the overall phases of the war are likely to be managed by each side, how to manage the overall game arc in terms of what cards will get reshuffled into what decks and when, etc.).  It's not exactly a game that lends itself to handicapping one side by a set number of victory points (due to the USSR early war advantage in that regard, but late war disadvantage), though you can of course use the standard tournament approach of influence-point handicaps (though not sure how much that would really help a very inexperienced player against a very experienced player).  I also find many people who are put off by the theme and the fact that, at the end of the day, it really just looks superficially like you are only putting chits on a map (the old Avalon-Hill of the 80s complaint of "that just looks boring").  I think a lot of people would find it very interesting if they invested the time to learn it given how beautiful and sound the mechanics of the game are, its just that some are disinclined to make that kind of investment for something that doesn't come in a pretty shiny package. 

If I could play this one more live, it could possibly ascend to become my all-time favorite. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I am making an effort to record every game of this that we play.

This is the only game I've ever played where for most of the session, both players feel like they're losing.  The game is designed very well, and makes me feel stupid.  I'm looking forward to playing this more and hopefully becoming a more competent player.  I'm rating it a 7 for now, but we'll see how that works out later.

The more I play this game, the more I like it.  I'm six or so games in, and I feel like I'm starting to understand how to play towards a goal now.  I'm bumping this up to an 8, but it's so mentally taxing that I can't handle playing it too often.

Update: Bumping back down to a 7.  I have this overwhelming sense of dread every time it's proposed.  I just have this "the horror, the horror!" feeling whenever I think about actually playing it.  It's just so mentally exhausting.  It is certainly aptly named, though!

Update: Back up to 8!  The more games I get in, the better I understand the board state and can formulate objectives.  Playing this isn't as painful now, leaving more room to enjoy the depth of the gameplay.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fantastic, fantastic, fantastic.

It's a time-sink of a game, with matches lasting anywhere from 2-4 hrs, but TS makes each minute feel tense, unpredictable, and exciting.

TS is an area-control style game, but with a significant set of card decks that dictate the flow of the game. Each card is assigned a superpower - the US or the USSR. If you use a card with your opponent's loyalty assigned to it, you get the points, but your opponent still gets the flavor text effect. This makes TS consistently intense and strategic.

I have a degree in Political Science, and I appreciate the level to which GMT has steeped TS in the theme. Both designers clearly know their Cold War history, and playing TS feels like reenacting it, rather than playing a game that just "looks" like it. Each card has a historical event, person, or thing on it, and the effect of the card mirrors this. It is truly remarkable the degree to which the historicity and reality of the Cold War shines through the gameplay. I have already recommended this to my old PoliSci university professor to use as a teaching aid during his Cold War classes.

I don't get this game to the table nearly enough, due to it's length and heaviness, but I doubt I'll ever get rid of it, as it truly deserves a top spot here on BGG. If you want a game that perfectly emulates the Cold War, that draws you in and creates inside your heart the self-same uncertainty and paranoia present during that Era, this is the game for you.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
There is beyond my comprehension WHY people say that a game that simulates the Cold WAR IS NOT a wargame (?!)

You have a War-THEME, a historical conflict simulation between two players, DICE rolling, and a good deal of aggression between these two players! THIS IS NOT A GERMAN-GAME!!
TS is a brilliant implementation of the "card driven" system that recreates the historical period of disputes between the United States and the Soviet Union, covering the post World War II in 1945, and the fall of the Soviet Union in 1991.
The mechanics are simple and the idea of "Low intensity warfare" "Control damage" and the "Domino theory" are excellently implemented with the card play and victory scoring.
An extremely intense and demanding game full of stress when played competitively.
TS is not just the Wargame most played among us .... perhaps because it lacks epic flavour of the cavalry charges and the smell of gunpowder :)

A game can last 1:30-3:00h



=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
I love the history this evokes and the alt-history it becomes. 

I love the area influence/control process although I only tolerate the dice chucking part of it. 

I love the delicious agony and timing of playing something that will hurt you. 

I love (although am not good at) turning a disadvantage into an advantage* from the playing of something that may hurt you and I tolerate that the knowledge of cards is an aspect that comes into play here.

I love the back and forth, you go/I go nature of the game and I can tolerate that this can bog play down (in the case of a fight over Europe for example).

*Thanks R. Fripp

RATING: 9

RATING: 10
An incredibly deep strategy game. The crisis management mechanic wherein players are forced to play their opponent's cards while trying to minimizes the negative effects is one of my favorite gameplay mechanics ever. Games of Twilight Struggle are always interesting and rarely go exactly the same way.

I am somewhat disappointed in the Collector's Edition of this game: while the gameboard and the new cards are a significant improvement over the Deluxe Edition, the miniatures are sub-par and the new influence blocks are completely unusable for several reasons. My current solution has been to ditch the blocks entirely and pick up a set of Deluxe Edition chits, which smooths over most of the major issues. Still disappointing‚Äîthe blocks were such a fantastic idea, implemented extremely poorly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
*Twilight Struggle takes the aesthetic of wargaming and marries it to the accessability of modern board gaming. The rules are exceptional; for a game of such scope, it's remarkably easy to understand. 

*Definitively captures the theme - not merely with accuracy, but in the dynamics; players are constantly engaged, jumping at shadows and trading punches, with the whole world teetering on something seemingly trivial like a turf war in Paraguay. 

*every card matters, every card feels like a kick in the guts to play. Yet play them you must - Twilight Struggle IS hand management. Combined with area control that values every single point of influence, you have a game where the complexity comes from the decisions made. 

*there may be better CONsims, but I think for the medium, this is a deserved #1 game and excellent standard bearer for board gaming. I consider the emulation achieved by the medium to be of the highest elegance. Given the component listing could be written on a postage stamp, that you can fit in 3hrs of intense psychological warfare for the fate of the world is art of the best kind. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I very much enjoy the theme (though it's too bad it can't go back to Lenin), and find the card-play tense and interesting.  I like the rules.  However, I don't find it as impressive as others do -- it doesn't seem to compare well to other games at that length and/or depth (I know I'd rather play Through the Ages by a lot, or Roads & Boats, or two games of T&E).

Also, my wife, who has sound judgment on many matters, loathes it after a third game (she won first two as USSR) -- too luckish, too long, no interest in the theme, and despises the asymmetry.

Not really for us, probably.  Interesting, glad to have played it, not very interested in 1960 now, though it's shorter and has no dice.

RATING: 10
:cry: :D After a few plays, I'm loving this game. If you own one and only one "modern" two player game, OWN THIS ONE. It's damn near perfect. 

Pretty much the only thing I don't like is when one side gets to use a really good Neutral card for the Event multiple times (such as Red Scare/Purge). 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Excellent game. Bit of a steeper learning curve than most games, but once you get used to it the mechanic is very well thought out. The game is balanced and achieves a fine balance between mimicking historic events, while providing room for the players to explore and act on their own accord. I am not entirely happy with some elements such as the China card, but those are just minor niggles.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
4 games played.  The game is simultaneously awesome and compelling, but also has unacceptably high variance luck and die rolls, for my tastes in a long strategy game.  I would be perfectly fine with the luck factor in a 1hr game, but in a 4 hr game it feels too swingy.  For example: Playing a War card such as Indo-Pakistani war, on an opponent who just took India, and has Pakistan.  The effect will be: 1-4: Nothing, 5-6: Gain 2VPs, they lose 3 Influence in India, you get 3 Influence, they lose a large positional advantage of access to southeast asia, you gain that positional advantage.  It would probably take at least 3 cards of placement just to counteract the effects of one die roll.  Coup rolls are similarly high variance and of critical importance.  There are also cards for which it is much, much better to draw the card than your opponent (nuetral large value cards, certain key events), and cards that are almost universally poor to draw (scoring cards and '1' cards in most situations).
That said, I do really like the game, even while the high variance of a relatively low number of 1d6 rolls annoys me.  There is a lot of tactical and strategic depth, and many things to learn and analyze about the cards and the game.  Highly recommended for anyone who will not be bothered by the luck factor in a long game.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Have always hated politics in a game, especially one that seem like so from the initial outlook.

Bought the game out of commitment but have never been too encouraged to play it due mainly to the theme that does not entice me.

After the first play with the insistence from a close friend, I was quite taken aback. 

Though not a war-ish bullet flying game, it does have quite a few good moments where the decision of your actions(cards) would make some global differences. The multiple ways in winning the game is a big plus.

After a few more tries, I find this game to be quite well done. If not for the theme, I would have rated it higher.

The near open-endedness of the CDG aspect was the flavour of the system that brought me into this game. Rated at heart a 3 now brought to light to a respectable 7. (8 if it was themed differently)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I recognize that this is a solid design and I honestly really like the core ideas. The deck management, the domino theory simulation, the tension around playing cards as events or ops and when to do so. That's all great stuff.

Unfortunately for me there are a few things that really get in my craw and drag down my enjoyment. I don't really like the back and forth of the influence play. To me it feels more like an irritating slap-fight than a tug-of-war. I can't really explain why. I'm also not crazy about the USSR coming out like gangbusters early on and the US having to play crisis management until the initiative swings to them. I don't mind this in other games, like No Retreat, but for some reason I don't like it here. The way the defcon system ties into this annoys me as well since a clever USSR player can make it so the US simply can't fulfill their military ops on some turns. I don't like the feeling of being handcuffed to that extent.

My other complaints are basically niggling personal preference things. I hate Red Scare/Purge and especially the possibility of it recurring. I had it played three times on me one game. Even Twilight Strategy says it can simply make you lose. Why include it? Quagmire and Bear trap are similarly loathsome. The cards are too one sided in their effects. They don't do anything interesting to the game state and they're no fun to be on the receiving end of. It's a negative play experience. In my last game my USSR opponent could have headlined Red Scare on turn one and Dominated Europe right off the bat because I had a poor hand. He didn't because we both hate the card but it leaves a sour taste in my mouth.

I also dislike the dice rolling essentially on principle. There are few enough rolls that a couple swingy results could impact play in an unpleasant manner. I would almost always prefer some kind of bidding or card resolution than a dice roll. When and how frequently the scoring cards come up is a similar issue.

All in all I understand why this is well liked. It's got depth of strategy with a non-insignificant luck element and it's quite replayable. It's definitely not for me, though. Every time I play it I'm miserable. The best bullet I ever dodged was when this was out of stock during the GMT tough economy offer and I got Combat Commander instead.

RATING: 4
Good game, but so not for me. I get way too irritated playing it. I hate the fact that most of the time, I'm choosing the lesser evil - there is no satisfaction for me in that. Some of my wargamer friends loved it, but I was hating it even when I was 3 VPs away from winning. I think I will stay away from now on.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Decent game, though I don't quite understand why it's at the top of the BGG game list. Effectively it's a 2-player Risk-style game with a few different slightly fiddly combat mechanisms. Granted, I haven't tried all the various Risk variants that abound, so maybe there aren't any/many that specialize on a 2-player experience?

From a game design perspective, there doesn't seem to be a strong advantage to using either coup nor realign. It feels like the designers had to add the military track scoring simply to force players to coup, or else there wouldn't have been any dice rolling in the game and it would have just been an abstract strategy. Even still, it feels like you could largely ignore the dice and play deterministically, to win (which I did and did).

On a thematic standing, I didn't feel like the game really accomplished something worth putting it in the top of the BGG ranking. The various tracks that go up and down seem too mechanical to really give me a sense of theme. When cards are played as events, they often seem to do nothing more than what one might do on a regular turn, but forced to make a specific move, exactly as the card directs. There's no greater world beyond adjust influence, realign, and coup.

The "battleground" countries, again, felt very mechanical. I would have preferred that these states provide resources or allowed me access to other states, or something, to make me get a real world/historical feel for why those particular nations matter and the other ones do not. I should want to hold them for strategic reasons not scoring purposes.

And I also sense that a player who receives more scoring cards is going to be the one to win the game most times, since they know where they need to target before the other player and can (largely) choose when to call in the bean counters. Thematically, this makes no sense and, mechanically, it renders a lot of the strategy moot.

It is a perfectly decent game, by all rights. I have enjoyed playing it several times now. But the only reason I can see for it ranking so high is that it lets you play a Risk style game at 2 players and randomness can throw the game either direction, so you don't have to worry that one person will win/lose all the time, but it accomplishes this randomness in such a roundabout way (the scoring card dispersal) that it probably does not seem to most players like the game was decided by chance.

2

Great game.  The theme is great, the dynamics are fantastic, the sense of the history is great, the swings in the control are great. RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Twilight Struggle is a miracle of game design. It's one of the richest and most interesting strategy games ever and certainly the best two player game I've seen. The brilliant mechanics of hand management and DEFCON perfectly capture the feel of the Cold War. You feel like you're constantly fending off crises, which might not sound fun, but trust me--it is. 

There are countless incredibly clever gameplay mechanics here. The scoring cards hidden in the deck with the rest of the cards--you are always paranoid your opponent might have one, and any aggressive play into a new region is taken as evidence. There's the way Europe stabilizes quickly and locks down into firmly entrenched battle-lines, so the conflict must spill out across the globe--just like the actual Cold War. In the Late War, the threat of Wargames amplifies the paranoia even further. 

The asymmetry between the two powers adds quite a bit to the game's replayability. The US starts with more influence scattered across the board, but a good USSR player will seize the initiative in the early war and make more attacks than the US can possibly counter. Throughout the whole game, the USSR typically starts off each round with an aggressive coup. The USA can only hope to slow the Soviets down at first, but by the Mid War has a strong counterpunching ability. The USA benefits from better hand management options, too, and is at less risk of blundering into a nuclear war. 

Some minor criticisms: first, the board doesn't stay flat properly. The game is a bit dependent on dice rolls--some "war" cards in particular feel too swingy. The game is slightly unbalanced in favor of the USSR, so that needs to be rectified by providing the US player 2-3 extra influence to start off. It's also true that knowledge of the cards is so essential that a newcomer, even one familiar with strategy games, will get killed by an experienced player 100% of the time. 

Once both players know what they're doing, though, this is a blast.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Twilight Struggle is a thematically rich and engrossing 2-person game.  It has a decently steep initial learning curve, but after a game or two everything suddenly makes sense and fits together very well.

The game is focused on positional contention, for 'influence', played out a world political map (Risk, Axis & Allies).  Turns are card-based (Command & Colors, San Juan, Race for the Galaxy).  Cards are either used as a historical event (printed on card) or for action points.  Both players are sometimes forced to play cards that favor their opponent, and minimizing the damage is crucial.

I really love the event vs. action point aspect of deciding how to use the cards, and also the various possible actions (coup, re-alignment, adding 'influence').  Some of these mechanisms really deserve further exploration in subsequent games.

One down-side, is that some cards (like Aldrich Ames) can unexpectedly end an otherwise tight game in some circumstances.  Perhaps that is part of the nature of card-driven games.

Overall I think Twilight Struggles is a very clever game with a fantastic theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
It would have been better if the natural flow of the game decides whether a country is a battleground or not. Of course you are a bit stuck to history, but couldn't Fidel appear in Mexico or Nasser in Israel, while maintaining a certain level of historical integrity. This would have made Twilight Struggle much less predictable, since you know from the beginning that Fidel will sooner or later appear in Cuba. 

I also wished TS has some military units in it. So they could provide players with regional powerbases. And where are the hydrogyn and neutron bombs!?

I found the scoring mechanism too complex and not wholly sensible. For presence you only need to control one country. For the next level you need both the most normal and battleground countries. That is a too big leap. The scoring mechanism is also too rough and doesn't have the subtleties of Paths of Glory, from which I believe it is derived.

I also didn't like the way the Afghan and Vietnam War - Bear Trap and Quigmire cards - are handled.

However TS is a good and enjoyable game. A bit blant, perhaps a little bit simple and abstracted to me. There is nothing wrong with that, but the game doesn't really capture the spirit of the cold war. And believe me ... those where scary days!

RATING: 10
You would think that I've managed to play this game by now, given 1) I've owned a copy since it debuted in 2005, and 2) it's the #1 game on geek.  But until yesterday (8/11/2011), I had not bothered to punch the counters.  What can I say, this is an awesome game! It is more fiddly in execution than a heavy Euro, but not much more complicated.  In fact, I would say it is easier to learn and teach than Agricola.  It is clear to me, even on 1 play that it is a very deep game and the mechanics are beyond clever.  It is as close to a a perfect combination of simplicity of play and richness of theme.  Simply brilliant.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
:arrowE: [u]Synopsis[/u]:
First off, why did I ever find this game? Because it was #1 on BGG when I joined the site. Is that a cop-out? Maybe. Does that make me a blind board game mob-rule poser? Maybe. You know what, though? I don't care. The visibility of the title is the only way I would have found it, and I'm glad I did. In essence, this is a game of "crap, I can't play this card... or this card... or this card... or this card." Spoiler alert: you have to play all those cards, Jim. Deal with it.

:arrowE: [u]What I like most[/u]:
Calling this a "hand management" game sounds so wimpy, but effectively this is the most grueling hand management game in existence. The fact that I might have a banner decade and play all of my cards and YOU play all of my cards can be entirely undone by next decade, when my USA hand is filled with USSR cards, and the careful progress I made before is eroded before my eyes. This erosion is further heightened by better knowledge of the cards as repeat plays take place, making choices even more layered and nuanced. "No, I can't play that scoring card yet, not yet, not yet, not yet. no no no, not yet... crap, now I HAVE to play it since I can't keep it until the next decade!"

I was born at the the very end of the Cold War, but this game captivates me and has truly renewed my interest in learning everything about the actual historical Twilight Struggle, as it were.

:arrowE: [u]What I like least[/u]:
A negative rating comment describes this as "Candyland for adults--draw a card, do what the card says, repeat. At some point, the game ends." It's a card-driven game, and the choices required to play which card at what point and do what with operations points in the meantime is excruciating... in a wonderful, wonderful way. At the risk of soundling like a campy, self-aggrandizing resume tagline ("my greatest weakness is that I'm TOO good at what I do..."), the agonizing tension of Twilight Struggle is both the best and the worst part of the game.

[hr]
Currently, my most satisfying and thematic victory was the result of my headlining "Cuban Missile Crisis" while my wife headlined "Missile Envy." She had to draw "We Will Bury You," and as the Soviet player, played it as an event immediately. Normally this would be a great boon to anyone, but "Cuban Missile Crisis" set DEFCON at 2, and "We Will Bury You" degrades DEFCON by 1, meaning that she inadvertently caused nuclear war, and lost immediately. But oh man! The interplay between the theme of those cards was amazing. Ach! What a game. I was sweating by the time that took place. Just incredible. 

[hr]
:arrowE: [size=13][url=http://coldwarsoundtrack.com/][b]PLAYLIST[/b][/url][/size]

RATING: 10
After 1 play: very interesting mechanics, rating is 8 due to the big amount of luck and the lack of means to manage it. A good card draw gives a player better chances of winning, bad die rolls can destroy one's strategy.

After 3 plays: I like the game more and more, it shows quite some depth that I could not see in the first play. It is not a 10 just because an unlucky draw can leave you without a strategy. If your opponent will have throughout the game all or most of the scoring cards and he/she plays well, than you stand almost no chance. It is in my top 10 games for sure

After 8 plays: rating changed to 10. Best strategy game!

RATING: 8
This game is absolutely great until you have a game where the luck of the cards and dice rolls do not balance out for the duration of the game and you are continuously left with the shortest straw. It captures the feel of the theme very well and can be very exciting. The flow of the game is great, but it does take 3-4 hours to play all the turns which is just on the limit of outstaying its welcome. For a feel and strategy I'd give it a 10, but the sometimes game-breaking luck dependance is too much and ruins the game from time to time. I think a game of this caliber and depth should not be quite as luck driven as it is. However, when the luck favours both players equally, it is great and tense with real theme.

Fun factor: 4/5
Strategy vs. luck: 3/5
Mechanics/gameplay tied to the theme: 5/5
Component/art quality: 3/5
Replayability: 4/5

RATING: 10
I like this one a lot !

Lots of difficult decisions to make keeps the players involved all the time. Where to put influence (like Go you would like to play in many places of the map but you will have to choose among them), how to play your hand of cards the most efficient way, what regions of the world to seek domination, and finally how much chances should you take with the dice. 

All that make the game a really interesting one to play.


I also own the french translation kit by UGG.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Hard to find any fault in this game.  It's a tense struggle to keep your opponent off balance, trying to maximize events that are favorable to you while minimizing the damage from the events favorable to him.  The Cold War theme resonates with me having grown up during that time.  That said, I didn't think I would like a game based on the Cold War, but this game proved me very wrong.  

Update:  the one fault I do have with this game is, in order to play it well, you need to understand all the cards in the deck.  What I mean is, if you cracked open the game and played it the first time and did not review the deck, you would not likely play it very well.  That is OK as it would be an interesting, chaotic experience.  But having foreknowledge of events that WILL come at some point is crucial to playing it well against an experienced opponent.  Since the game is replaying the Cold War, it would be a better game for me if the players could not see into the future, so to speak, and plan their play based on events that they know will come at some point.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Chock full of interesting decisions- but there is too much opportunity to get burned by bad luck in the cards and, to a lesser extent, the dice.  I found the spelling errors on the first edition game board to be embarassing at first, but they are actually not a big deal.  There is a certain charm to influencing Chili.  The spelling errors are fixed in the second edition.  Knowledge of the over 100 unique cards is very useful for correct play.  After repeated play, balance does not seem to be an issue.  The USSR player has an advantage, but it does not seem to be overly significant.  The theme is excellent for this game, the rules are simple and the mechanics are fairly innovative.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I'm really STURGGLING to understand why this game is so popular with so many players.

Yes, I understand that the die-rolls may even out over time, but if die-rolls fail/succeed on critical moments, such as right before a scoring event, it can be critically damaging to the game.

Also, the variability of card draws can be significant.  As Russia, I drew very critical cards like Marshall Plan and NATO and was able to deny those each time on my turn.  If a person gets a significant amount of "other colored cards" or the scoring is clustered and favors someoen who is able to place there, it can be difficult.  Central and South American were both scored on the same turn, and Russia didn't have any opportunity to even play any influence over there during the first round of the Mid Game, so it caused a huge point swing, which was literally unavoidable.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Most thematic game on its topic. Its a very interesting game design, which catches the cold war theme extremely well and offers a lot of strategical choices. On its basic its a really a mix of hand management and area of Control throughout the game, which has these incredible moments of bluffing and guessing what your opponent has on his hand and what his next moves are. There is a small minor point to this game, which is the the nessecity of knowing the cards as good as humanly possible. For the first games you may play cards in a way where it might seem useful, but the lack of knowledge of specific cards effect might screw you over (like putting a lot of influence as USSR into Japan and later in the game "Japan Mutual pact" event is played and cost you like 2 turns from previous turns, because USA immidiately regains control of Japan due to its effect). Some may mention, that the longer play time might be an issue, but i cant see that as a problem personally, because the theme as well as the game mechanics themselves are so catchy, that you absolutely lose your feeling for time. 
Last but not least is the concern of some people, that TS is pretty luck dependand. I can't fully agree on that. Yes Coups and realignements have some sort of luck, because of the nature of dice (even tho you can guess the equity of succes/failure, but these are sometimes risky plays and the quantity of these moves are pretty much capped by the DEFCON Track. So i would personally say, that out of the 156 Cards or so played, no more then 15-25 coups will be played throughout the game.
I highly suggest to get the Deluxe version, because of the better Balance due to the new Cards. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A really great theme very well implemented in the game mechanisms and the cards.  This is a top notch heavy two player game.  

Many heavy two player games are standard war games involving armies and such.  This is nice twist on the idea because while there are some abstracted wars, it's really a clash of influence and control of countries.

The one drawback is that you really need to learn the many cards pretty well to play competently, and if one player knows the cards better than another then that's a huge advantage.

But that's not that big of a deal.  It's worth working through.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Deleted review at http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/104292 (now wish I hadn't done that). I have a bit of a love/hate relationship with the game which, with thought and experience, may simply boil down to the existence of neutral events at all. If someone draws power-neutrals (Red Scare/Purge...) they have an advantage which isn't inherently offset by the, "if I'm drawing theirs, then they're drawing mine" kind of thing that the actual sides provide. Still, especially with updates, a well-produced and most impressive game which I think every serious gamer should at least experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
+ Tricky... On one hand it presents many different choices and strategies. Includes a whole lot of theme, bluffing and opponent reading. Mechanically, this game is a thing of beauty.
- Now, I don't mind imbalanced games, and this one is imbalanced. What stops me from rating this game a 9-smth is the fact that this 3-hour game can end in a luck swing. Get one or two really bad hands, and you're done, whatever you do.

RATING: 9
Now I understand why this is currently #1. Tons of fun to play thanks to the high tension between the long-term strategy on the game board and the short-term tactics of hand management (or more accurately 'damage control' in some cases.) Lots of theme - this game really made me feel like I was coordinating Soviet Russia's operations during the Cold War.

In case anyone cares about my opinion, I wouldn't consider this a 'wargame.' Good yes, war no.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
1
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The rules in this game are really obtuse for being ranked #1. The people I play against still wont grasp some of the core mechanics of the game three hours later when the game ends. I find my self explaining how coups work over and over. The theme is pretty cool, and this is a game I would pull out for some of my political junkie friends, but at the end of three hours of play I am often left thinking, that was it? I certainly have more fun playing other games than this one. 

Also, you have to know the cards and what order they come in to be good at this game. Card memorization isn't something a game should reward, and it has nothing to do with the theme. Nixon wasn't able to pull out his crystal ball and look into the future and say "Ah... around this time period of history NATO will be formed, I'll plan on that then"

Edit:

The more I play the more fun this game gets. I think it is because both my opponent and I know the rules better so the game flows. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
I love that this is a contemporary war game in a sea of (older) historical period stuff. Accessible enough for most people, and very rich in strategy. Elegant system, seems well balanced with the Chinese Civil War variant. Need a few more plays, but this may make it to a 10 for me.

I think it can still be a bit of a dice fest and lame card-drawing came on occasion. Strategy can mitigate some, but not all of this ... it'll never be a 10.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
1/8/14: Just a note that we usually give the US an extra 2 influence at the start to balance.

4/28/12: Haven't gotten to play this recently, but upped the rating over time.

---

The new 3rd edition board is really nice, but not enough to justify upgrading

Gut wrenching tension, trying to make the most of your cards, and limit their damage at the same time.  You both look at your hands, and know that whatever you do, you're going to be helping the other player, and afraid that his cards aren't as bad as yours.  You need to balance your play, because if you find yourself way behind in one area, it's a long road back.

A solid 8.  But I have proven that I suck mightily at this game, losing five straight games to new players.  My problem is that I don't balance the regions well, I start winning in one area and get excited, putting too much influence there.

It really does make the cold war come live, and plays very well to the theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.31
I really thought that I would hate this game, but I was completely wrong. I don't usually love area control games, but I enjoy how Twilight Struggle handles that conflict. I really love the elements of timing and finding ways to use cards in ways that minimize their benefit to your opponent. The game is driven by cards, so their is definitely a lot of luck involved, but the game is largely about mitigating that luck, which I actually enjoy a lot. The only major drawback for this game is the playing time. If this game took an hour instead of 2-3 hours, then it would rate much higher.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A gem without equal.

RATING: 9
Clever design with more going on than one initially might think. Replicates the paranoid competition of the Cold War as players sink resources into regions simply because their opponent does. A heck of a lot of fun to play.

Only slightly marred by a high luck factor. The game rewards smart use of the cards more than it does simply having a good hand. Having said that, there are occasions where a devastatingly bad hand can scupper your game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I just upped this to 10 (from 9) after 30 plays. This last play went down to the wire and my opponent won by 2 points difference. 

This is THE GAME. It creates so much tension and possibilities are endless, choices hard and both players are constantly under pressure. If you like that kind of feel in your games, TS is sitting on the throne.
Only problem is, you have to have a partner that is about the same level as you.
Our whole game takes about two hours now, and is an agonizing delight every time we play it. You also learn a lot from the cold war history and I see the potential of it being used in education (history major here).

Perhaps my best board gaming experience ever?

RATING: 6

Doesn't feel "wargamey" enough to be a war game and I'm not sure where else it fits well other than straight up strategy...

RATING: 8
My first impression of this game is that I need to play it a lot more. It seems like - for a card drawing game - there's actually quite a bit of strategy involved. 

Not only that, but the tension runs so thick... in my first game, Cuban missile crisis was played, and neither of us wanted to back down, so instead we continued to find ways to maneuver around each other without initiating global nuclear war.

Also, the cards can be rather humorous. I forgot which card it was, but one of the cards read something along the lines of "If you control more battleground states than your opponent, poke them in the chest and gain 2 victory points." Awesome.

-----

Second impression: Yes. This game is as deep as I originally thought. It's one I want to show off. I want to play it with my dad, with my friends, with my wife. I'm finding myself hoping for more two-player game days.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Elegant and tough, always feels like a boxing match where you're tethered to your opponent by a short rope. Brilliant.

RATING: 6
As a Eurogamer, rather than a wargamer, I found TS surprisingly easy too play, although I am sure we were not playing optimally - no realignments throughout the game and only one non-card induced coup.  Surprisingly quick end to first game on turn 7 with a US VP win. Scoring heavily in Europe topped with space race points (on which the dice were kind throughout).

Why do designers make games where high dice rolls are good most of the time then switch, as in the space race, with low being good?  Keep things consistent.  Absorbing game, happy to play again.  Recommended to heavy Eurogamers.

RATING: 10
One of my favorite games.  The theme is totally engrossing.  The rules at first glance may appear overwhelming to non-wargamers, but it's worth the effort!  The game does a fantastic job of creating tension.  It accomplishes this mostly by forcing players to make plays that will end up helping their opponent.  The trick than becomes figuring out how best to minimize the inevitable damage.

I can't recommend this enough.

If you're a war gamer or even just a history geek, this is one of those games you just need to try out.

RATING: 9

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Masterpiece. Intrigue at its best, this 2player game needs dedication due to its long playtime, but rewards you with intense strategic decision-making,turnarounds and a need for constant attention to every move your opponent does, especially since its on soooo many fronts. Very nice job with the real-events based cards and their history presented in the manual. Brilliant.
EDIT: If I had to find a downside, the game has a pretty long playtime, especially during first plays when players are not familiar with card events and pros/cons of USSR/US side. A major reason why this pup sadly does not see much table time.
EDIT: Got a regular-ish gaming frequency now (every few months). I LOVE the game, even though I am not the AP prone guy that likes to take every possibility into consideration and spend hours on the net getting the different strategies and pro/cons of all the cards down. It is maddening how a card drawn by your opponent instead of you or a wrong dice roll can sometimes make the difference between winning and losing. great game!!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My all time favorite.
Card driven political war game. Very challenging and intense, easy to learn, hard to master.

RATING: 8
I'm not usually a fan of more intense war games like Twilight Struggle. However, this game has something special. As a history fan, I love the theme of all the cards and how they resolve. The game can daunting at first. After a playthrough, the mechanics make more sense. Still, I can't play this game too often. It is incredibly intense throughout. The hand management takes great skill. It's definitely a game of stamina because a full game took over 3hrs. I enjoy playing Twilight Struggle, I just couldn't do it very often.

RATING: 8
Temptative rating for a complex game with just one game at my back.  The setting is interesting, the gameplay is tense, and the mechanics work fine.  Overall, I found it really interesting and fun, if played knowing that it is a long game.  It has quite a lot of nice details, like the space run, the Defcon level, coups, etc.  It has problem FOR ME, this is absolutely personal.  It has A LOT of information on the board, and I'm not good at getting such amounts of info from the map.  It was quite difficult for me to get the knowledge of who was winning where.
It has some amount of luck, but I do not mind really.

RATING: 3
Just couldn't get into it, the game seemed so luck driven which I didn't expect at all.

I found that the cards I drew hurt me far more than my opponent, while his mostly benefitted him.

The scoring cards were almost always in his contol whilst I got Europe at a time he knew I had to have it. This let him score more.

The dice rolling for coups and re education being based on a single dice with minimal modifiers caused massive swings.

Not what I expected and hope to never play again.

RATING: 10
Probably the most stressful game in my collection. You're constantly teetering on the verge of failure, and every move you make seems to help your opponent much more than it helps you. Tough decisions galore.

The only downside of the game is that it's quite brutal towards newcomers, with several "gotcha!" cards (f.ex. the DEFCON suicide ones) in the deck that can either end the game immediately or otherwise feel quite unfair. But then again, no-one said anything about the Cold War being fair in the first place.

RATING: 9.7
Truely superb game - looks intimidating at first but fully understood (though certinly not mastered) after just 1 play. Myself and opponent both a little AP prone, so can go as long as 6hrs, though I'm sure more regular folks could easily half that... even at our length though, it's full of tension and hair-pullingly difficult choices throughout.

Responsible for possibly my single best boardgaming experience - a game that went to final scoring and ended with a single point victory for my opponent, after several turns of teetering on the edge of a Europe domination loss. Awesome.

Kept from a perfect 10 purely due to some fiddliness... as bif 2p games go though, it's about as good as it gets.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I've played this a few times and haven't found the fun to balance out the time investment. I have begun to see the replayability and depth of strategy, though I'm far from knowing the cards enough to play it well. I simply haven't had enough fun to continue with the heavy time investment needed to get the maximum out of this game. I did buy the app after it came out and after the above-mentioned plays of the physical board game; I will likely continue to dabble in the digital game while on longer plane rides. Honestly, I've enjoyed my time with the app more than the physical board game (its great for a cross-country flight if I want a long game over a movie). I doubt I will ever sit down with a physical copy of this game again. There are simply too many other games, including other CDGs, I'd rather play.

Update, Sept 2017: after playing a bunch of other CDGs -- some of which I've felt comfortable enough to rate -- my thoughts on this game can be clarified a bit. Again, the fun to time ratio is way off in this game. The game is 2-3 hours of see-sawing, tense, event mitigation that also requires you to recognize an opponent's tell of an upcoming scoring card. The key to this game is knowledge of the entirety of the deck. Clever play of other aspects (e.g., realignments, etc.) is much, much less impactful.  Memorization of a card deck is simply not fun and is an artificial way for the game to inject supposed depth. While other CDGs also incentivize card knowledge, the level at which this game requires card knowledge is comparatively much greater, and that makes this game a CDG that I will rarely play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
After getting familiar with the cards, there's definitely been a strong USSR bias in our house.  We're trying out some of the additional rules suggested in the Deluxe Edition rulebook to address that.  But I still love to play it even despite this flaw: minimal rules offer stunning strategic depth, and the theme is conveyed very well.

RATING: N/A
Sleeved - 110 - Standard Card Game - Gray (FFS05)
https://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/164572/item/2915481#item2915481
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This game is very tightly balanced and interactive, and from that perspective it is a very well designed game. If I was looking for a game based solely on this merit it might even score a 10/10.

Where this game fails for me is (1) the connection between the rules and the theme often seems tenuous at best, and I find it hard to stay engaged in the game as I play (I find the theme itself to be not that great to begin with) and (2) the play time is extremely long for a two player game.  I would expect this kind of play time from a 4 player game, not a 2 player game, and because of the mechanical elements of the game it is not even conducive to socializing.

Basically what I am saying is that I respect the technical aspects of the design via-a-vis a close and interactive balance game, but I just don't enjoy playing it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I view this much like chess, with the right opponent it's a brilliant game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I love the theme of this area influence game. Learning curve is a bit steep for beginners. You really have to know the cards, keep track of the possible scoring cards, and watch what your opponent is doing to do well. By just looking at the board it is not readily apparent where the danger might be. While the game is not terribly complex, it is a bit unintuitive, and I found my first game a bit frustrating as I kept missing scoring rounds (which my opponent drew all but one). I was able to enjoy my second game though. I do not believe this is a wargame!!

As for component quality I have to give GMT credit here, I was satisfied. Sturdy cards, map looks beatiful especially after lamination, thematic dice were a nice touch, and so were the plastic baggies. Player aid cards are useful, and the box is sturdy and colorful, with interesting historical data. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
This game is full of tension, which is fun.  There is also a lot of planning to do, and the turns are structured so you never feel like you're waiting.  It's a bit heavy for some.  As someone relatively new to the boardgaming hobby, I frequently forget to do certain things, like advance the action phase chit or place the "no coup or reallignment" chits when defcon is degraded.  This causes annoyance when we realize we messed up the rules.  Until I learn the game better and can keep solid track of these things, the game is a 7.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
2P
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.2
Obviously it appeals to a wide spread group of people: the thematic gamers, the wargamers (This game is a clear example of a ConSim or Conflict Simulation thematic game), the historical gamer, even the Eurogamer.

Or so it seemed for a few years I was playing this thing with a friend a few times a year...

----

That being said: 

I want to play Conflict of Heroes or HP Lovecraft games or Wing Leader ANY TIME over TS.
The good thing about it though is that I can play it on my Surface 4 now. The AI is now tuned up so much that any casual player will get screwed every time by trics and a 1500 rated AI player.

Probably being the best boardgame EVER, it is too competitive for me. but I can recognise a masterpiece when I see/play one.

3 wins in 20+ games against the AI, which btw still made a programming mistake by keeping a scoring card in hand the last time I won ...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Played it only twice now, but... damn this game is fun.  The time just melts away when we play as there's virtually no downtime at all for either player once you get started into it.

I've gotten smashed into the ground both games, once by the US and once by the USSR, so from my perspective it seems relatively balanced so far.  :P

I have the second edition, and the components are fantastic for what they are.  Playing with a piece of plexiglass (mine is from a poster frame) is the *only* way to play this game.  I can't imagine even trying to play without one.  I also love how GMT gives you little ziploc baggies to keep all the chits in.  Very useful, that.  I only wish they'd give you something to hold the cards in so that they don't flop around the box, but I store them in bigger ziploc baggies to prevent that, which seems to be working so far.

The rules are exceedingly clear and well written, with plenty of examples.  They are also laid out very well, which makes it easy for quick-checking little rules.

Being a big fan of Command and Conquer: Red Alert games for the PC, I love the theme of this game.  I love how the gameplay feels very evocative of the theme as you play.  

The play time of our games have been pretty short so far  (2 hours for first game, 1.5 hours for second game), and imagine the time will get even shorter once we are even more familiar with all the cards.  Both games ended during the 4th or 5th turn, though, so we've never been close to going the full turn limit.

I hesitate to give this a 9 for now, because, at present, there's only one fellow with whom I can play this, and I'm not sure if anyone else I know would really be interested in taking it for a spin.  Unfortunately, that limits the amount of table time it can have, although we both thoroughly enjoy the game, so I'll try to bust it out as often I can.  :D

Simply put: great game.  Lots of fun.

****UPDATE*****
Finally played a game that went 9 rounds, and it took around 3 hours, which isn't too bad considering play slowed considerably towards the middle as we were trying to learn all the new cards we had available to us.  Like before, the time just melts away and you never notice the hours as they pass.

Every time we finish playing this, all I can think about is wanting to play it again.  That's a sign of a great game, methinks.  As a result, I'm bumping up from 8.5 to 9.  I'm always going over in my head what I did wrong in my prior games so as to improve for the next.  One of these days, maybe I'll even pull out a victory.

****UPDATE****
This game gets more fun every time I play it.  Increased knowledge of the cards by both players results in a superior contest.  Hands down my favorite game.

****UPDATE****
The updated mounted board makes this wonderful game an even bigger pleasure to play.  (No more plexiglass!)  This is still most definitely my favorite game.  I love it to bits.

W/L = 9-8  US/USSR WINS = 11/6

(April 2014)
I have had a lot of experience with this game by now. My rating remains an 8. The design is excellent...and I see what it is so popular, even if I don't personally agree with its #1 rating. The game seems to be all about counting cards at a high level of play. 

(July 2014)
OK, OK...upping my rating to a 9. This is one CDG where a player must absolutely, positively know the deck in order to succeed. I am not the world's best "card counter," but knowing which critical cards remain in play is a must. The game does reward one who takes the time to learn to play well - thereafter it has an entirely new feel. This is the sign of a great design and as I can now play competitively (can't say that about all board/wargames), I have to bump my rating up.

(December 2015)
Thanks to the immediate accessability of Vassal live games, my games of this are in the 100s by now. Thus, my upgrade to a rating of "10" is long overdue.

RATING: 10
Beautifully simulates the cold war feel. Constant grief about what the opponent will do to you and how you will respond in kind. Endless options, balanced game play, emersive theme, agonizing decisions and beautiful components (deluxe edition), and the perfect blend of Euro mechanics and war game stratgy  make this one my all time favorite two-player game. 

2015 Update: Still the best. No other game give me the sense of dread or anticipation that this game does. I'm still only playing about 80% of the game as I don't normally use realignment rolls or coups as I don't like to leave things up to chance. I'm sure there is more depth here than I've uncovered in 20+ plays. 

Personal note: my wife Jen gets extremely frustrated with this game. Not her favorite as there is just so much to know (or forget) which can really hamper the experience. I'm finding that she does not like games where one person takes the resources another needs to make their plan work. Worker placement games are all hit and miss as a result.

RATING: 9
AreaControl, Solo
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
OK, so I actually own the PC version of this, which is the same game but can be played in a shorter time because you have the computer to work out the fiddly bits. If I had the cardboard version, I would sleeve the cards to prevent warping from dripping sweat--this game is intense.

On a very basic level, you're playing a card for Operations Points, which you place in various countries around the world to increase your influence, or you're playing the card for its Effect, which in one way or another also affects the play of Operations Points. Now and then a region of the world is scored and you get points based on your influence there. There's also a space race going on and a constant struggle to control the DEFCON level.

This game has unimaginable depth, depth that can only be appreciated by playing the game a few times (it takes two or three games before you start to get a feel for how it works). Consider the fact that a fan published a 425 page strategy guide. I know, right?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I have purchased this game as a good friends Christmas present.

I think that I'll enjoy the game. That period of history is facinating and I certainly enjoy the genre of games that spawned it.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I like it.  Maybe a little more than it deserves.  It just seems to be a game that balances epic and orderliness quite well. I don't think epic requires a description, but "orderliness," "orderliness" covers a lot of ground.

Orderliness that borrows from Euro games, satisfying strategy existing without interfering with the enjoyment of the experience.

I'd like to write a longer review and analysis about what I think it does well, what it doesn't, and why I think it deserves the praise it gets, but for now, I'll just say of all the "war-games" I've played it has been the best at balancing playability with the thrill of carrying out grand "military" actions. 

Recently I've played a couple video games that have absolutely ruined their board game equivalents.  "You mean I don't need to hold all this supply line info in my head for the next three hours?"  *head explodes* More power to you if you can and want to, but the thought just makes me tired.  

My point being that I don't see TS being ruined by online/PC/IOS/Android versions.  The joy of playing someone in person is never (rarely?) overshadowed by extraneous (but usually vital) information.  And these days with video games being so cheap and easy, that's a mighty virtue in favor of TS's supremacy in my head-space.

RATING: 10
Believe the hype. Incredible tension. Extremely well thought out game. Played 1960 before this and liked it a lot, but this is definitely the better game. Number one on BGG for a very good reason.

One thing I've really come to appreciate about this game is how it gets better with each play. I'm the kind of guy who is often very impressed with a game initially and then after a few more plays, the initial exitement wears off. This is completely different. The better you and your opponent knows the cards, the better the game becomes. However, this is also a game where an experienced player will crush a newbie, so watch out for that.

----

As of 2016, this is officially my #1 game.

RATING: 9
Six plays now and TS is holding strong with a 9 rating and a spot in my top 10.  I am definitely getting more familiar.  However, I also seem to be getting a bit sloppy (not reading cards carefully, misplaying my hand) and I seem to be showing more AP, especially in the mid-war when I feel like the board is locked up.  One thing I've learned for sure is to not give up on a game.

In my 6th game (USSR), my opponent's 50th (USA), I got off to a great start but moved into Pakistan too early.  He couped (6) to flip Pakistan and my huge turn 1 advantage ended up not as huge.  For the most part, the cards really went my way this game but the dice did not.  I missed many key rolls and my opponent hit the biggest ones for him.  It was the first game of TS where I saw the dice so lopsided.  Still, my opponent outplayed me with the cards significantly.  Still learning.

I feel like the theme is well integrated with the game play.  It's been fun to watch an experienced player maneuver through some dicey situations while I struggled.

I feel like I say this a lot after finally playing highly rated games, but I really shouldn't have waited so long to play this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
In principle, the luck of the card draw and die rolls evens out over the course of the game.  However, Russia's first turn coup of Italy has a PRODIGIOUS effect on the game, since it basically determines who will dominate Europe.  The difference between rolling a 1 and rolling a 6 on that first play can decide who will win -- two and a half hours later.

If it weren't for that, I'd love this game.  It's a phenomenal design, tense, and very fun to play. However, there is simply no occasion in which, having a single opponent, I wouldn't rather play Through the Ages.

RATING: 8.1
Easily one of the best games out there. Not quite as complex as I thought it might be, but enough meat on the bone to satisfy my desire for a heavier game. The complexity of this game lies in the strategies needed to win and thankfully, not the rules. I found the rulebook to be above average, with most situations covered. The quality of the game and materials is outstanding.

My score of 8.1 is computed from the following criteria (1-5):

Setup - 5
Rules - 4
Simplicity - 4
Fun Factor - 4
Interest in Playing - 4
Depth - 5
Theme - 4
X-Factor - 4
