=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Twilight Struggle is a deep two-player area influence game that reeks with tension and seems to have infinite playability. It's rare to find such a meaty two-player game that isn't either an abstract or pushing armies around. As a two-player influence game Twilight Struggle brilliantly avoids the "one for one" pitfalls inherent in the genre (see 1960 for a game that falls face first into this problem). The card driven system is an excellent way to keep the game thematic and fresh from turn to turn, and the cards here are neither overtly chaotic nor overwhelming in scope (like the cards in your typical Fantasy Flight game). A few are clearly underpowered but most provide the right level of "one-of" effects to add great character and interactions to the game.

Twilight Struggle thrives on immediacy and angst. The quasi-random nature of the scoring cards isn't without flaws but keeps you on your toes with every card play. You're constantly forced to respond and push on the board, because the moment you don't is the moment an unfavorable scoring card will hit. There's a good sense of interaction in this, and plenty of room for bluffing and momentum. Pulling you in the other direction is having to deal with a fistful of cards that hurt you. It's the perfect shake-up factor as your freedom to place influence on the map comes directly at odds with trying to mitigate the cards in your hand. Tension and decision-making is in no short supply here. There's no doubt that Twilight Struggle is much more tactical than it is strategic. It thrives on its back and forth nature much more so than any long term planning. It's also a very calculated game where almost every decision is crucial. You just don't feel like you're making fake decisions in this one.

There are two common complaints with Twilight Struggle: randomness and imbalance. There are many, many points of randomness in Twilight Struggle. In fact, there are so many that they tend to even out over the length of a single game. That‚Äôs a good thing. With die rolls in particular it is quite clever that you are usually accomplishing something regardless of the roll, be it pitching a bad card, gaining military operations or dropping DefCon, although it‚Äôs obviously better to roll well than to not. Honestly, considering the thousands of utterly crucial decisions a player has to make in a typical game of Twilight Struggle I am skeptical of blaming losses on bad luck. What bad luck can do is make the path to victory much more unforgiving and challenging. Rarely will it outright hand you a loss.

I don't believe the game is perfectly balanced for all skill levels. Twilight Struggle clearly has a learning curve, much steeper than your typical Euro but much shallower than your typical wargame. As an experienced player it's easy to see where the uninitiated see too many die rolls or don't understand facts like coups drive the game but realignments are merely an advanced tactic. It's also undeniable that the US is tougher to play on account of being less forgiving in the early game. Even between skilled players it is unfortunately possible to draw certain hands in the early game that will lead to an unavoidable USA collapse. The big culprits are Red Scare and how the early scoring cards come up (in particular which double dip on turn 3). The Chinese Civil War variant tends to stabilize the early turns significantly, or spotting some influence to the US works as well, but bad deals can still occur. Still, in the long run the better player almost always wins and that‚Äôs really the important thing. I do consider myself to be a fairly skilled Twilight Struggle player, so understand my biases.

In any event, Twilight Struggle is an amazing game. Every decision is tense and every game plays out differently. It has a great sense of theme. The 2-3 hour playing time is reasonable for a game of this depth. There are great online implementations (wargameroom) that make it even faster and easier to play. In this age of Euros it is rare for a game to last through even a dozen plays, but after over one hundred plays Twilight Struggle is still holding my interest. That's an amazing accomplishment, and something I can't say of any other game really (shy of something like collectable like Magic or short like Dominion). Twilight Struggle truly is a modern masterpiece, and it falls just a few small tweaks away from gaming perfection. I‚Äôll be playing this game forever.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Pro's:

1) Thematically deep and rich, evoking the feel of the cold war very well.
2) Asymmetrical but well balanced. Playing each side feels unique, often it can feel like your opponent has the upper hand, but when playing the other side and being put into the same position there is a consistent element that you cannot win and that everything is hopeless.
3) The space race release valve, the military operations and defcon tracks are designed in a way that makes it very tense to use them correctly.
4) Learning the game as two new players.

Con's:

1) Does massively favour an experienced player, while this is common in many board games, it feels more punishing here.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
So I have played a few games F2F and on the app now, won a couple of times as both sides. What have I learned? In terms of the area majority part of the game, which I like, I have learned which areas and especially which territories are most important, the latter largely because of the cards associated. Knowing the risks around France, Bulgaria, W Germany, Cuba, Egypt/Israel, the Koreas and Thailand, amongst others, is a huge part of the game. However, aside from this 'learn the cards piece', I have discovered nothing in the area control mechanism which wasn't readily apparent at first play. 

In terms of the 'gotchas', the game is clearly designed to give you countless ways to generate an 'auto-lose' situation by lacing the deck with many events you simply can not risk playing at Defcon 2 (or even Defcon 3 at Headline). Some of these are obvious to the first timer, some less so and all require active hand management so you are not forced to play them. I have seen this mechanism before in several fillers and it works well there, but I really don't like it in a game you are investing several hours in. There is nothing worse than wining or losing that length of game on a silly mistake.

I am also not a big fan of the dice. Dice in a wargame? Yes, they introduce thematic randomness but get rolled a lot so any luck tends to even out over the course of a game. The dice in TS are too crucial and rolled too few times for the weight of game.

So, conclusions. Is it a decent game? Yes. Does it have depth? No, it has a requirement to learn the cards if you want to play well, but that is not the same thing. Strengths: it is undoubtedly one of the most tense games you can play. Weaknesses: randomness and overwhelming punishment of mistakes might make for tension, might be thematic but they don't make a great game for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Weren‚Äôt it a two-player only game, I wouldn‚Äôt hesitate to regard Twilight Struggle not only as my favorite game but also as the the best game ever made: sadly though it‚Äôs quite too demanding for a two-player game, since you need a very motivated opponent and quite a few hours to spend over one game only.

As such, it‚Äôs unquestionable Twilight Struggle is a great game - one of the best around - but I can't place it at  the top of my personal tastes. [i](March 2013)[/i]

[b]Update[/b] - Scores of plays later, I can‚Äôt but raise my rating from 9 to 10: Twilight Struggle is the best game around, period.
I just can‚Äôt get it out of my head.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I have owned the previous versions of Twilight Struggle, and enjoyed playing other peoples' copies, but I had traded and sold the other editions because even though it was a great game, the paper map of the original coupled with cheap looking graphics just didn't grab me compared to some of the amazing looks of other games I owned like Fury of Dracula, War of the Ring, etc. The second edition with its cardstock board was an improvement, but again, board gamers compare games to the best ones they own, and GMT just wasn't trying hard enough in such a competitive marketplace to put out a solid build for such a unique and quality game. But finally I took a chance on the new, 2009 edition of the game, and wow, what can I say. This is probably one of the best made and best looking games I own, not to mention being one of the highest rated games available. The board is just awesome. Thick card stock, mounted linen paper, great graphics, full color rule book, more cards, just everything you would want to play. I'm so impressed with the new version. It was high time GMT applied the same high quality production values of "Winds of Plunder," a game that came and went so fast you've probably never heard of it, to one of the best 2-player card-driven wargames ever designed. I'm just really glad to have this fine, sturdy copy of such an excellent product.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
One of the most finely-balanced and elegant games I have ever played. Captures the feeling of Cold War brinksmanship perfectly. Game play is at times excruciatingly tight (in the best way possible). I normally shy away from long (~3 hour) games and 'card-driven' wargames but this one might make me reconsider. Deluxe version has sumptuous components, though a counter tray is needed.

EDIT: Just finally had my first US win. What a game! I am constantly amazed by how tight this game is, and I think I'm starting to learn how to control DEFCON to rule out Coups and realignments - it's such a vital part of the game.

I'm loving how EVERYTHING has dual uses - even the China card can be used for good points or to allow you to keep back an extra card. So perfectly balanced!

EDIT2: I haven't played this for months, and have turned down games in favour of other games. That is indicative of something - perhaps not game quality, but in order for this rating scale to make sense I need to apply it consistently, so I'm downgrading its rating. This might change.

RATING: 10
My only "10" I've rated to date. I love this game. Really thematic, really tense. The games progression from Early, Middle and Late war is done really well. There are aspects of luck, (dice rolls and card draws) but much of the games difficulty comes from trying to minimize the damage from bad cards/dice rolls. The hidden scoring cards lead to some really interesting games of cat and mouse.

RATING: 7
A tense and enjoyable recreation of the Cold War for two players covering the period from the fall of Nationalist China through the fall of the Iron Curtain. While the rules are not particularly heavy (for a wargame), players familiar with GMT's other card-driven games will certainly have a leg up on the learning curve. Set aside a full afternoon or evening for this one.

RATING: 9
What else can I say? An awesome game that is incredibly fun and challenging IMO. I wouldn't pass up a chance to play it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This one is an epic game. You play as one of a great superpower (USA or USSR) in the cold war period. Your goal is to gain influence in countries around the world to gain control over the regions. That‚Äôs basically it. The rules are quite simple and you can get a hold of it quite fast. But game is not easy at all. The decision making is a key here thanks to great card-driven mechanic. In every turn you have to play a card either using its influence value or event it describes. But in the common deck there are cards with both USA and USSR player events (plus some neutral) and you will get both types on your hand. The trick is that if you play opponents card as an influence value you will also have to play its event. And that‚Äôs perfect! It makes this game an optimization of losses. You want to play opponents cards in the least favorable conditions mitigating the damage it will do.
There are also very important scoring cards that give you points for corresponding regions. Drawing one is a good and bad thing. It holds a spot for card in your hand but gives you knowledge on where the scoring will be this round (because if you have one of those in your hand you have to play it). So you can prepare for it, but your opponent will be watching your every move trying to guess where your focus lies. 
There is a constant race for control over the regions. You want to stay one step ahead of your opponent also negating every threat that he is creating. This makes this game extremely intense. Additionally, the cards events are the real events from that period and it all makes me really invested in playing. I can feel the tension and atmosphere of the high war council. I love playing it!
That being said it's not a perfect game. For me the theme and feeling of this game adds very much and without it it wouldn't be such a fun.
There are dice included and when performing some actions, you have to roll. And it adds randomness. You can most of the time tilt the odds in your favor some way but either way in the most crucial moment even when the statistics are favoring you the coup might fail and in a tight game it can be devastating. It also adds some flavor to the game but can be frustrating.
Worst thing for me is that on some turns you can end up drawing only opponent‚Äôs cards while he could draw "normal" hand. Then the whole round you will just try to mitigate damage while your opponent will gradually gain superiority. If this happen it can change the game and could be difficult to reverse.
For a long time, this one was number one game on BGG. I don‚Äôt think it necessarily is the greatest game ever but for me it surly is better than today‚Äôs top 3 (Pandemic Legacy: Season 1, Through the Ages, Gloomhaven). Now games make top 10 based on hype, in the days TS was #1 they made it because of value (and this is nicely indicated with number of votes ‚Äì TS have nearly 30k votes and has now rank 4 while Gloomhaven has 5k votes and rank 3).

RATING: 9.5
Awesome game system. Too bad it's a little unbalanced. Very tense, very reactive ("I don't know what he's really after, but I'll try to stop him, whatever it is"). Has a strong luck factor, but the card draw makes every match unique (considering that the events make a few of the locations on the map a bit scripted)

Even with its flaws (not completely balanced, luck factor in a hard and long game) this is still amazing. This game is just more impressive than anything else I've ever played. This game's design is so amazing that it feels like a work of art.

RATING: 8.7
I have only played TS face to face the once -  4 of us played 2 games in parallel, all playing for the first time, all seemed to enjoy it. I've also played this by email, using VASSAL. That works very well. Some Vassal games have to be "FTF", this one does not. Email gives you the pondering time you need, which is great.

I've just got to learn more about this one! It's a very strategic CDC game with a number of clever mechanics which bring a lot to it. Knowledge of all the cards is key as you have to try to work out what your opponent is holding based on what he's doing on the board at the time.

RATING: 8
I've always said that I am not a wargamer, but this game really appeals to me.  Too bad it is only 2 player and takes a reasonably long time to play...  I like how the designers have balanced the advantages from the card events, and leave it up to the player's to manipulate those events to occur (or be hidden) at the best time for them.  I really like this system.  Plus the multiple scoring regions allows for players to shift their focus and try to take advantage of unused regions.  I really am excited about this game!

RATING: 10
This is an incredible game. I'll admit that I haven't nearly begun to play this on the level it should be played - with a good knowledge of the cards so I can anticipate what is coming. Still, I can recognize that every moment is tense; every decision is just agonizing. The varied large and small mechanics of the game match the theme of the game so well; as others have said, I can't imagine another theme attached to them. It doesn't invite you in for you to be immersed, it throws you in and you don't emerge until the end of the game. There are very few games on this level.

RATING: 9.5
2pl

A complex ruleset, but rather straight-forward gameplay. I played the US and won by forcing a draw in Asia and blocking access of the UDSSR to Africa midgame. The game was very strategic/tactical and overall exciting. The board is well designed and it's very easy to get an overview about the board state.

Cons:
 - The Art
 - The first play feels random, because you don't know the events. This makes playing against a newb completely unfair. Forgetting a critical event may also be very punishing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Amazing historical strategy game. You have to find the right person to play it against...but it's so worth it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Just acquired at reasonable price. I am a big fan of CDGs and this one is so highly rated I couldn't resist. Not everyone is a big fan I see, so I hope to find out for myself soon. Rating (8) is tentative...
++++++
Finally got to play and it didn't disappoint. Quite the opposite in fact! As a retired "Cold Warrior" I was afraid it might turn out to be too much of a "bus-man's holiday" - but not so. The tweaks to the venerable CDG engine make this one of the most tension filled games of cat and mouse I've encountered in a long time. Despite the fact that you aren't moving leaders/units about the map this is very much a war game. And a game with one of the best ever implementations of a theme - right up there with "Dune" and "War of the Ring." This game showcases what can be done with the card-driven engine when firing on all twelve cylinders. Rating going up based on just one play. If this has the legs I think it may have, my rating will go up even further.
++++++
Well, for some reason this game is not getting the replay I imagined (likely because it's a two-player and my sessions usually involve more than two). Could also be the playing time is just a little too long for this type of game. I'm finding other CDGs (Hannibal, Washington's War, Wilderness War) are more likely to see play. It's a very good game no mistake but hasn't lit that "must play again" fire like some others. I'm not sure I agree that it should be rated the best war-game or the best board game overall. Maybe among the best as a war game (since it is two-player) but best overall? Rating fixed at 8.5 (good but not great)...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

RATING: 9.8
This is my second favorite game.  It is a CDW game thats plays out over 40 years of the US,USSR cold war.  

It is well produced however not exactly perfect.  What I would improve is simple board design edits to make "battleground countries" stand out and leap off the board.  

The game is intense.  Each time I play it becomes easier(you know the cards... the rules better...), and harder(you recognize subtle nuiances...) I like playing the Soviet side as I feel the third stage is less kind.  This game usually requires 2-3 hours and continues to teach me the history that very much still currently affects us day to day.

This game is different than any other- in the sense that it is all about mitigating bad situations for yourself in a way that can perfectly balance your position in the various areas of the world map against your opponent.  

When you finish you feel the feelings that the cold war gave a lot of us.  For me each game hangs with me afterwords a few days thinking of how I could have played it differently.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Bah, It's a wargame minus the war. Where's the fun in that? It's like a cross between any number of wargames and El Grande, but sadly not near as interesting as either of those.
I do like that it's pretty simple, executes the theme well, perfect depth, and it plays quickly, but it's still not that fun.

edit: I finally see why people like this so much. It has the card play of fare such as Paths of Glory but without the "complexity" of said title. That being said, I love the way the cards work in games like TS and PoG, but in games like PoG (in the end) it propels combat (which is cool). Whereas in TS it propels placing influence (which is lame). I'd much rather attack the enemy than sway the populace's mindset.

edit: I'm pretty sure a big reason I don't care for this game is that the rules weren't explained to me very well. Because of that, I'd like to give it another shot after learning it properly.

Also, this is NOT a wargame!

edit: Despite the fairly abstract rules, this game simulates the Cold War really well.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The greatest board game I have ever played. I don't think any other game has ever done so good a job of capturing its theme as this one. The game mechanics perfectly translate the rivalry, tension, and absurdity of the Cold War. You will constantly feel as if you are trying to manage a crisis and not quite succeeding. It's awesome.
 
The game is quite strategically rich, too. People are still discovering new styles--there's a robust debate about the merits of playing for board position vs. the merits of grabbing quick VP at every opportunity. You've got an interesting decision to make almost every single round of the game. Playing as the USA and USSR are entirely different experiences, which adds to the game's replayability.

There's almost no snowball effect at all, because players receive a random and completely new hand of cards every round. There is nothing that makes the player in a better position on the board likelier to receive a better hand. Even games that seem lopsided can rapidly swing the other way if the leading player draws a really terrible hand. There are occasional games in which one side draws far better hands all game long and coasts to victory, but more often it evens out.

Note that the game is a bit unbalanced in favor of the USSR player. This can be easily rectified by providing the US player 2 extra starting influence.

As an added little bonus, you'll probably learn some history from playing this game. I certainly did.

One downside is that this game is for two players only. Teaching it to a new player, moreover, is not always a pleasant experience, as any player who has decent card knowledge and understands the basics of strategy will simply crush a beginner. The luck element is nowhere near strong enough to give the new player a chance, and it will likely take quite a few plays before he or she is competitive.

But when two veterans of the game square off, I would say there's no better experience in all of boardgaming.


UPDATE: I will still give this a 10 rating, because I stand by my original assessment that Twilight Struggle is a miracle of game design. Nonetheless, recently I've been finding highly antagonistic games like this one less and less to my taste. I would rather work with other people than try to make them miserable. I am having the most fun either with cooperative games or with competitive games that have a relaxed and friendly atmosphere (think Caverna or Sushi Go). So Twilight Struggle is not seeing much play for me lately. Still, if you want a game where you can test your mettle against an opponent, you can't do better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Brilliantly designed area-control/CDG mechanic for a fascinating period of modern history.  It epitomizes the realist school of political thought with its zero-sum game play.  There is cause for concern due to lack of balance (so start US with 2vps) and card effects that are not historically accurate.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
DO NOT BUY THIS GAME!!!!!!!!!  

Okay, I love command and conquer strategy games. Axis and Allies, Samurai Swords (now called something else), RISK, Stratego, you name it... and that's what I was hoping for with this.

I will give them kudos for trying to create a game that offers more complicated possibilities to players like coups attempts and technological advancement. 

However, this game is quite simply a History Lesson.  There is barely and actual strategy.  Twilight Struggle's game play is dictated mostly by "events" that take place on a large number of cards that reveal themselves throughout certain eras in the Cold War.  The "events" are seriously in the favor of the US (as is the starting position of all the game pieces - which would be fine by me, normally) and one is not allowed to gain the upper hand on their opponent in any creative way by doing something unexpected OR, better yet, taking the lessons of History and no not repeating the mistakes both the USSR and the US made during the Cold War.

Instead, quite depressingly, one is forced to play out events exactly as they happened in the Cold War leaving no room to make decisions that are your own.

Axis and Allies is still the best war game I've ever played and NO, I don't work for whomever the hell made it.  

#bummed #theres$60Illnevergetback
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I think it is fundamentally true for TS though, if that makes any sense at all. First and foremost, I enjoyed playing it, which gains high marks from me.

RATING: 9
Fantastic 2 player card-based game.  A struggle.  At twilight.  Well, unless you play in the morning...

Upon further plays, I am starting to see that this game is fairly brilliant in its balance and the different strategies that can be taken with cards. 

My only reservation is that it does appear that this game is open to intense study, so that "opening strategies", etc could become very important against experienced players.  I'm not a huge fan of games that can be analyzed to death and certain scripted-actions memorized for different parts of a game.

Jan 2011:  On further plays, the game is growing on me even more.  I'm starting to appreciate the different strategies in playing or discarding enemy events, and the luck involved in coups makes more sense to me now.  Upped to a 9.

Dec 2011:  It's becoming apparent that the rules are complicated enough that it takes an almost rules reread if I take a few months off between plays.  So, this is n't going to get to the table very often.  Back to an 8.  Just too slightly rules heavy for my taste.

RATING: 10
One play and I'm already hooked.  An amazing game which manages to bring alive all the tensions of the Cold War.  I was on the edge of my seat from Turn 1.

The rules were a lot simpler to get than I expected too; after the first turn, we found it very easy, and rarely had to check the rules.  Obviously, though, familiarity with the cards is going to improve play dramatically.

Update: the more I play, the more I love it.  I may have to upgrade to the higher quality version, though, as the one downside is the flimsy, refuses-to-lie-flat map.  If I do, it'll be worth it.  Awesome game.

RATING: 9.5
With only 2 plays under my belt, I have to say that this game is MUCH better than 1960.  While it is slightly longer, I find the decisions much more interesting, and overall the system is much more streamlined than 1960.  At the very least, the map is vital to good play (unlike 1960) and the options for spending OPs are MUCH more exciting - how can buying media access compare with a coup attempt?  This thing is dripping with theme, and the play and theme are locked together in a death-grip of gaming goodness.  I don't know why I waited so long on this one (ok, yes I do... I wanted a mounted board) but this is indeed one of the pinnacles of 2 player gaming.  Can't wait to play this one over and over.

RATING: 8.5
OK, OK, the game is awesome. I was uninterested for a long time because I hate war games and tend to have very little in common with people who play them. But I was proven wrong: this is a great game.

The game is not fun, however. At all. It is utter misery, and four hours of it at that. Luckily it is challenging, stressful, and so nail-bitingly intense that I still like to play‚Äîoccasionally. Every card has both a positive and a negative effect upon you, so nothing you do is fully satisfying or enjoyable. This makes the game extremely tense, and really reproduces the "feel" of the Cold War in a palpable way. It runs about an hour too long for my taste, but I still think it's a great game.

RATING: 6
I love the way the board and the box art looks, hated the actual stock of the board, the cards, the typos and the errata.
 
I found it pretty light, easy to understand and fun to play.. for me it doesn't feel like a heavy game, more like a medium weight.  I think I have some serious problems with the game concerning the card combos that can suddenly end the game, and which you really have no control over without perfect knowledge of the deck and discards.. and even then, the most you could lower it to would be 1 out of 7 that I automatically lose in the eighth turn (for example).  The theme hits me in the right place, and I didn't mind the die rolls too much and I don't have any issue with the combat system as a whole.
 
Despite (and because of) some fundamental flaws, and dependant on if the playtime goes down (which goes a long way towards me accepting the insta-combo death situations), I give it a 5.  There's just too many flaws here, and I was blinded by the engaging theme (as I assume the majority of other people are).

RATING: 7

Its a fun and very challenging game, but I wouldn't want to play it more than say, once every few months. So I'm rating this an 8 based on the depth and great design, but it doesn't quite meet the 8-rating description of "I will never turn down a game."

09/06/11: Knocking this down to a 7. It's been completely replaced by Labyrinth to fill my CDG needs.

RATING: 8.5
This is the only game I have ever played where I felt smarter after the game was over.  Years of high school and college history on the Cold War, and this board game was able to offer me immediate and meaningful insight into this era of world history.  The fact that it's a wonderful and fun game almost pales next to its value as a teaching/learning tool.  Everyone should play this at least once.

I have a few card-driven wargames around the house, including We the People, but had never played one until I tried Twilight Struggle.  What was I waiting for?  This was a truly great game, and I thought so even as the Americans, through unfortunate card play, ended up having 7 turns to my FOUR on the fourth turn.  Terrific, terrific game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Easy to understand, very difficult to master.  I've played four games and they were all stunningly different.  This game is very hard on poor play, and you can find yourself dead if you make a major mistake.  

Bumped up to a 9 after further reflection.  The thing that I enjoy most about the game is that it rewards the doctrine of containment...i.e., your best strategy (particularly as the U.S. player) is to halt the Soviet advance, not reverse it entirely.  And it is possible to do this, though the Soviet player has cards that will let him break through.

RATING: 7
I've enjoyed the times I've played so far, and the time has seemed to fly by. Even though it's driven by cards, and the hands dealt are random, it seems historically pretty accurate, at least on the surface. In my games to date, the Soviets tend to do well in the early turns, only to be overtaken by the Americans in latter stages of the game. As such, a good strategy for the Soviets might be to try for a quick win, either by manipulating DefCon, going for control of Europe, or trying to score several times in a row.

RATING: 6
UPDATE (7/29): This online board is amazing: http://twistrug.jjt.io/#/
Perhaps combine with first page of this travel board: http://boardgamegeek.com/filepage/16990/tstravelboard-v1pdf

This game hurts my head. My fiancee and I learned this together. Our ignorance of the cards hurt us a lot. Afterward, she said, "Intriguing, but not fun yet." I agree. UPDATE: I really, really want to play this game again. But I do think it will require several "learning" games where we get surprised by cards the first time around, before learning to plan for them in future games.

For the next game, remember JohnRayJr's advice: I think it's worth explaining the relative frequency of the different kinds of operations: you place influence all the time, do coups once or twice a turn, and do realignments just a few times a game.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
The release of the iOS version of this has largely vindicated those of us who complained that the play balance on this is insanely pro-Soviet. Looking at people's win-loss stats as each side reveals a level of imbalance that is totally nuts, and yet which fans of the game largely continue to deny. You'll need to use all the pro-US variants available to make this work (the variant cards alone are definitely helpful but insufficient).

I thought the much faster play of the iOS version might help me get into the game, but actually it just reminded me how much I hate it. If it was only 6 turns, it might be tolerable, but at the length it is I am always bored out of my skull well before the end, when it becomes pretty obvious whose going to win but you've got another hour plus to go.
---
Another reason to dislike Twilight Struggle ... the narrative here is driven entirely by US right-wing fantasy. The rulebook sort of acknowledges as much, but the degree to which the game takes the many disastrous views of American hard right war hawks and makes it look mainstream is distressing. When you look at it with some discernment, this is not the Cold War, it's not even most Americans' experience of the Cold War. It's what the US political right wished the Cold War had been.
---
Well, I think at least I've finally figured out the obvious reason why Twilight Struggle has such appeal; it's right on the seam between eurogames and wargames. So wargamers who want something euro-ish but just aren't going to play Beowulf can play and enjoy this. Likewise eurogamers who just aren't going to play Battle Above the Clouds, say, can find this one accessible and interesting. But for anyone who appreciates both sides of the gaming spectrum, who can get a kick out of both Blue Moon or Pandemic *and* Hannibal: Rome vs. Carthage or Breakout: Normandy, Twilight Struggle really just doesn't have anything to offer.
---
UPDATE: OK, time to clean up my comment here ...

I kinda like Twilight Struggle just for the theme. It's fun to go back and forth and watch the events and get some vaguely historical fun.

But the game has a lot of problems. It's too long for what you get out of it (some commentators have said "quick-playing" is a strength of Twilight Struggle, but at 3 hours I find it wildly overlong for what it is). Several game elements are out of whack. Realignment, for example, is worthless - how does something like this make it into a finished product? Didn't some play-tester say "hey, you know, we never, ever use realignment?". Since the geography of the game largely exists only for realignment, this seems like an issue. And I really dislike how much the game rewards simply knowing the contents of the deck, which makes things unnecessarily hard to learn and needlessly punishing of experience (not skill) differentials.

I could rant on and on about niggling little details like this, stuff that should have been ironed out if GMT had any kind of development process, but the absolute deal-killer here is play-balance. The Soviets are overwhelmingly favored between smart and/or competent players. Sure, I've heard others claim the game isn't unbalanced, but the empirical evidence on my end has now become overwhelming. Once you focus in on the important stuff, paring away all the game elements that don't matter, we haven't seen the US win in 15 games, even playing back-to-back games switching sides, with other players, etc. This is jaw-dropping considering how much luck there is in the game. And I've even found myself pulling punches as the Soviets early in the game, in the hopes of generating a more interesting game and embarrassment of getting to play the hugely favored side, and still winning handily. If the game were anywhere close to balanced you'd think you'd see the US win a few just on pure luck. But no.

Anyway. A frustrating game because with some reasonable development I think it could have been good, even very good; but it's not. I had hopes that 1960: Making of a President might show some improvement, but sadly it seems to have most of the same failings while losing traction on the theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
Overly fiddly area control game with a Cold War theme. 

On the negative side:
Far too much luck for a game that lasts 2-3 hours. Repeated plays may mitigate this somewhat, but three plays of this could take six hours and there are plenty of other area control games that I can play that are so much shorter. 

Euro mechanics, wargame production values.

The theme is wonderfully integrated. Normally this would be a positive, but one of the main themes of the Cold War was that it was a long, tedious stalemate.   

On the plus side:
Excellent clearly explained rules and fascinating background information for each event.

RATING: 10
TS has been my favorite boardgame for quite some time now.  Like other CDGs, there is a bit of luck in how the cards come out and I am completely aware  this is not a simulation as historical events  sometimes occur anachronically in this game, but overall the feeling of a Cold War struggle as played out through event cards, coups, DEFCON restrictions, and operations, creates that tension I seek in a game about this period.  It deserves to be up there with the highest ranked games on BGG even if it is no longer number 1.  I have played some wild games of TS over the years and i keep coming back for more.

I still would rate several games like Agricola, Puerto Rico and others a lot higher than this but I would still put it in the top games.

RATING: 10
Updated 5/26/10.  Wow, that needed some updating.

I've only played twice, so I still can't say much other than I really enjoy this game and I think it has a lot to offer.  Although the game has similar mechanics to 1960, Twilight Struggle feels much more thematic (although I'd love to have 1960s little text synopses about what some of the events are).  Most importantly, the fact that the game could come to an end at any moment really ratchets up the tension in a way that 1960 has been unable to duplicate. 

I can't really speak yet to issues of balance or replayability.  Although it feels like you may need to memorize the decks to be able to infer from your opponent's action what scoring cards are coming, the game comes with a handy little cheat sheet, and it's not long before new players are up to full speed.  Among particularly experienced players, I can imagine this being a truly epic showdown.  

One nitpick: I don't like the lone die used.  I'm just not a fan of dice generally, but I'll tolerate them to resolve battles in some games.  Here, I would have preferred something a little more interesting (e.g., I love the cube bag in 1960).  

The quality of the components in the deluxe edition are what one would expect from GMT - solid, but not outstanding.  The game runs a bit long for me, but unlike something like Through the Ages (or even 1960), it doesn't seem to drag.  I'm fully engaged the whole time.

All-in-all, the game hovers right in the center of the 8 range for me.  I look forward to playing it again, and I hope that it holds up to repeated plays better than its sibling.

[b]My #2 Favorite Game[/b]

Let me voice two minor criticisms of mine:

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It's hard to believe this game was the designers' first game. It's a CDW (card driven wargame) that has everything I'm looking for in a game: depth, tension, long and short term decision making, moderate rules complexity, moderate playing time, and an entertaining theme that's backed by solid mechanics. It's an excellent hybrid game that's been very popular among members of both my grognard group and my euro group.

Ignore any controversy as to whether this game is balanced or not. Yes, this game does favor the Russians somewhat early in the game and the U.S. late in the game (this is by design), which results in a Russian advantage overall if both players are inexperienced. But balance issues resolve themselves quickly once players get 2 or 3 games under their belts. I've won several times as the U.S. against players with a wide range of experience.

Another point of controversy is the production problems. I'll admit they're excessive but it takes little effort to work around them.

My only complaints are the playing time and the luck. They're both just a touch too much given the level of game play provided. If there was a way to tone them down this would be a solid 9. 

UPDATE: Played many more games and these same complaints are getting to be more exasperating. Downgrading to a 7. Still a great game and I LOVE the theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
An elegant, wonderfully realized game. Thematically deep and engaging like no other. We really enjoy it. A very long game though, and one which doesn't make it to the table very often. Would like to play this more...

RATING: 7.75
From what I've played, I really like the inevitability of looking down at your hand of cards and knowing you have to play every one of them, no matter if they help you or not. Properly managing your hand really makes this game, and proper timing can lead to sudden victory. Lovely designed game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
How best to manage your hand is what this game is about. When to let your opponent have access to events. Which events. What you need to do as quickly as possible.

There's also an element of deck management/building as you want your cards to get reshuffled and your opponent's to be removed from the game so that you can enjoy a late game card advantage.

And for the board, paying attention to areas which are likely to score and which you know will be influenced by cards you will be playing later in the turn. Wanting to be in many places at once, but having to prioritise. 

However, the rolling of dice for resolution is very annoying. Kind of annoying for coups. Extremely annoying for the space race. It is the aspect of the game I enjoy the least.

While the cards do not evoke the cold war for me at all, I do really enjoy playing on a world map and watching influence spread. I also appreciate how neither side is presented heroically, but villainously. It helps for me to handle the game that way because it doesn't feel like propaganda. That being said, I would understand someone not wanting to play the game based on the subject matter (murder, coup, war).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
First things first. I really don't like CDG's, or at least I haven't really found one that I connected with yet. Playing events out of hand just feels weird and athematic. I don't get it. It probably has something to with deck-knowledge being the most important skill in a CDG, which is a gameplay skill that I have very little interest in getting. It drains the game of theme in favor of meta-power-gaming. I want history and theme, but the cards are just a thin layer of both over what is ultimately an area-control cubepusher. Dullsville. 

I'd rate it a one, but it isn't exactly broken. I just hate it. A lot.

=========================================================

Only a couple of plays, but I could see this score improving as I learn the game, but I could also see myself growing irritated as I get hosed by cards. As it stands, I love the historical tidbits (even though they are built on at least a few really screwy assumptions) and I am looking forward to playing some more. 

UPDATE: Still trying to decide whether TS is a love or hate for me. Card-driven area-control has never been my favorite genre; something about getting hosed by cards leads me to wonder whether it might ultimately be something of a crapshoot. I'm not super keen on the amount of card memorizing overhead that might be required to play the game well. I will need to think more about why I haven't found a CDG I've enjoyed yet.  

UPDATE AGAIN: The evolving rating. Good stuff first. The game is a tight, and mostly fun, area-control/influence game. Each hand becomes a puzzle to be solved, and the game has tons of guessing and bluffing as you try to puzzle out why your opponents is making his plays. It has a neat veneer of a theme with cool cards and a nice looking map. 

But the game is problematic in some ways:

THEME: Some parts of the theme feel sort of right. You're balancing investing influence against more aggressive options in order to win a victory without sending the whole world over the edge. The big picture abstractions feel very much like a Cold War-themed game ought to feel. But, and this is a big one, the details are as athematic as a standard Eurogame with take-that cards. What exactly do my cards represent? Does it make any sense temporally to have an event happen every card play? Not at all: I'm just playing out a script when I really want to be engineering a strategy and authoring history. What role am I in? An abstract Geist in a bipolar world?  Thematically it feels wrong, and that it is the ultimate deal-breaker for me. 

The more I play, the less thematic it becomes, as I start to minmax your hand and wait for events. What does it mean, thematically, to win in a region when only you know that it will be "scored"? It might be sort of fun from a bluffing/gameplay perspective, but it's thematically off. None of this theme stuff really matters. It's a game, so whatever, but no sense in all the fanboy droning about the Cold War "feel"". It's off. Way off. 

Gameplay: I'm torn. On one hand it works well. You're walking a knife's edge tug-of-war in a very cool and tense way, but shit there is a lot of randomness to the event draws. A poor draw can really set back one side or the other in a big, perhaps game wasting way. I haven't played nearly enough to really know for sure, but I wonder how much if finally comes down to card-luck and exploiting a good hand. Which is fine, hand-management damage control and hand-exploitation can be a lot of fun, but I'm just not sure that I want that in a game that takes 3+ hours to play. 

In Backgammon, the swingyness of the dice balances out over the course of many games; the better player will always win when the law of large numbers kicks takes over. This may be true of TS as well, but at three hours, can one really get in enough games to balance things? I'm fine with screwy card (or dice) luck in a 45 minute game or in a game that is Uber-thematic (ASL for example), but Twilight Struggle sits in weird sorta-themed over-longish middle-ground: too long and inelegant to compete with the best Euros, and too dry and athematic to compete with the best wargames or themers.  

As with above, none of this really matters if the game isentertaining, which it mostly has been every time I've played. But #1? Nah,not even close.

RATING: 6
Based on 1 play.

So I dig the the theme (though the components are equal parts ugly and flimsy - ick) but the length was really an issue for me.

There's hints of greatness here. The double use cards make for some excellent, tense choices but overall there were just too many small, fiddly things to keep track of. I'm sure they all tie into the strategy for those that play the game regularly, but for a first play it's just overwhelming.

The luck factor isn't huge, but comes up in some oddly frustrating ways. Certain event cards seem overly powerful and having to roll the die is fiddly and adds what feels like unnecessary luck to the game. Bleh.

Overall, I found what I was looking for in 1960 - shorter, more streamlined, no sucky die. I'd try this again but I think maybe it's just not for me.

Á•û‰ΩúÔΩûÂ∏åÊúõË∑üÂñúÊ¨¢ÁöÑ‰∫∫ËÉΩÊÖ¢ÊÖ¢ÁöÑÁé©Ëøá‰∏Ä‰∏™‰∏ãÂçàÔΩûÂÜ≤Á™Å‰πü‰∏çÊòØÂæàÊøÄÁÉàÔºåÂèçËÄåËÉΩËßÅËØÅ‰Ω†ÁöÑÊô∫Ë∞ãÔºåÂíåÊÉÖ‰æ£Áé©Ê≤°ÈóÆÈ¢ò
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
As a hard-core, hex-and-counter wargamer (I play Advanced Squad Leader, 'nuff said), I don't consider Twilight Struggle a wargame, in that territory is not conquered, armies are not in combat, etc.  However, the Cold War was not about fighting.  It was international politics ranging from brinksmanship to detente; creating alliances; convincing the non-aligned countries that your system of government and economics was better than the other guy's.  

I find the "1" and "2" ratings and their critiques, where the only complaint being "it's not a wargame," puzzling.  How you could create a traditional wargame, moving tokens representing armies, navies, air forces over a hex map, and call it a game about the Cold War, is beyond me.  In the context of international politics, the Euro-gamish mapboard, counter placement, and card-driven mechanic of Twilight Struggle just makes sense.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
1st edition:  1.5.  2nd edition:  9.0.  These ratings describe just how much I think care about production really matters for a game.  Great game or not, this is still about business to consumer.  There are plenty of great playing games that use pennys and a drawing on a lined piece of paper.  Doesn't make them $60 releases worth collecting.  I hate f***ing stupid people who say, "Still a great game.  Some words are spelled wrong, that's all." and "Just take a sharpie to it."  Anybody who got the 1st edition, I just feel sorry for you.  You got kicked in the junk by a company who could give a shit less about you.  Now with the 2nd edition, errors have been fixed and the product is at least worthy to sell to the public.  The production is still not worth the price they are charging, but whatever.  Matthews and Gupta have really designed something great with this game.  I just wish a worthwhile game company could have been the ones to release it.  It would look as good as it plays, which is brilliantly.

RATING: 10
The best boardgame ever created. Period. Its only flaw: being strictly 2p. Twilight Struggle is as complex as chess with a rulebook as thin as any eurogame. Few designs achieve this sense of immersion in the theme with such a streamlined and fastpaced game. It rewards a lot experience, true, but it involves just the right ammount of randomness to allow the odd defeat of a strong player by a newby.

The game is just too long for what it is though, so I slightly prefer 1960 to this since that runs in 90 minutes, which feels much more appropriate to the weight of the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A rating of 6, you say?! Burn the heretic! Well, hear me out. TS is a fine game, it‚Äôs just too long and involved for me. To be fair, I have to state up front that I have played this four times, and only one of them ended after all 10 rounds. So while I‚Äôve played this four times and have a fairly good insight in this game (yes yes, I know, it‚Äôs nothing like having played this game hundreds of times and know all the cards, but it‚Äôs better than having played it just once, and if you know me, you‚Äôll know that I rarely play a game a lot in a short time frame), I have only once experienced the ‚Äúfull‚Äù game going all 10 rounds. But I have to say that I‚Äôm quite pleased with that as my first three plays all took 2-4 hours iirc, and the one which went all 10 rounds took 4¬Ω hours, so with extra rounds it is way too long for me to really enjoy. And the playing time is part of what‚Äôs keeping me away from exploring the depth of this game more. It‚Äôs just too long for me compared to other games I would much rather play. Gaming time is a scarce commodity, so I have to choose which games I want to play, and a game I‚Äôve rated a 6 will not get to the table a lot‚Ä¶

Usually I enjoy the games in the top 100 quite a bit, but there are some big exceptions. To name a few, Android Netrunner, Pathfinder, Eldritch Horror have all received low ratings by me, much lower than TS. I think TS is a good game and achieves what it sets out to do, but to me it‚Äôs nowhere near the best game on the BGG. But, to be fair, TS is only the number one game because so few (comparatively) have rated it; those who have played and rated it have played it because they already knew they wouldn‚Äôt hate it. At least the majority. Most are probably drawn into it by the theme, which works quite nicely due to the tons of cards with flavor text and real events, and most who sit down to play this 2 player game will therefore probably like it (compared to the next couple of games in the top100). Oh well, I don‚Äôt really care about this, I just wanted to say that I think TS is ranked artificially high as it won‚Äôt get as many ratings and plays as for instance Puerto Rico which will be tried and hated by a lot of gamers. 

I think in order to really enjoy TS, you need to be interested in the theme and be willing to spend a lot of time learning the cards! In my first game I placed some cubes in Egypt only to have them removed by an event‚Ä¶ And I did this in a couple of other countries only to have them removed by events I didn‚Äôt know existed! This lesson cost me dearly, but I was prepared for this during my next game which I won handily. I lost my last game. Whether I win or lose doesn‚Äôt really matter, but it does matter if I didn‚Äôt really stand a chance because I didn‚Äôt know that such cards could appear. Yes, I could have read the cards beforehand, but that‚Äôs exactly the problem; I don‚Äôt have time to do that, especially not for such a long game.

Now, onto the game itself. As I‚Äôve only played it four times, and only one of them went all 10 rounds, I certainly don‚Äôt claim to be an expert! I‚Äôll just state what I thought about the game after having spent 12+ hours on it. First of all I enjoyed the mix of wargame and eurogame. There is a lot of ‚Äúin your face‚Äù actions going on due to the events on the cards and the coup actions etc., and that‚Äôs something I really dig. I‚Äôm not a wargamer, but have played some of the ‚Äúlight‚Äù wargames which aren‚Äôt really full-scaled wargames (TS, C&C, Battlelore, 2deMayo). I think it‚Äôs a genre that I‚Äôm going to explore more in the feature, but for now I‚Äôm a fullblooded eurogamer, and this is why I fancy the area majority/control scoring throughout the game. You can get a ton of points if you‚Äôre playing a scoring card at the right time, and it‚Äôs tense when you don‚Äôt know when a scoring will occur! The way you play your cards for action points or for the events and that the other player can benefit from an event is really a great idea and helps minimizing the luck of the draw, though luck certainly still plays a part considering the random draw of the cards and the random die rolls when attempting a coup etc.

The space race track is a neat idea too as you can play a card which benefits your opponent too much. However‚Ä¶ I have to say that the space track also introduces a huge randomness to the game. A randomness which cannot be mitigated and is 100 % based on the roll of a die‚Ä¶ And, to me, that‚Äôs really unacceptable! At least for a game which lasts this long and otherwise leave your brain burning when you‚Äôre trying to figure out which card to play and whether to use it as an event or not. I lost my one game which lasted all 10 rounds by 2 points ‚Äì but my opponent almost didn‚Äôt miss a roll on the space track and got a total of 7 points on me because of this‚Ä¶ And he also got some huge advantages! This really, really, really rubbed me the wrong way, because what if it had been the other way around? I cannot see how I wouldn‚Äôt have won in that case, so did it really just come down to a roll of the dice on the space track? That kind of sucks‚Ä¶ I know that there are cards which let you catch up, but it‚Äôs hard to do so if your opponent draws those few cards‚Ä¶ I know there is also randomness in the card draws and in the coup attempts etc., but the outcome of the space race track is something I whined and still whine about!

All in all, I just think that you need to invest too much time in TS in order for it to really shine, and even if you do, the game is going to run too long for my taste. The whole system is quite good, though, and I actually enjoy 1960: The Making of the President quite a bit which TS is often compared to. 1960 is more accessible due to its easier rules and gameplay and shorter play time (but to be fair I personally don‚Äôt think the game mechanics have that many similarities). I will definitely play TS again and hopefully explore all 10 rounds, but if I had the choice I would probably always prefer to play 1960. And, luckily, I do have a choice. So for now Twilight Struggle will only get a rating of 6.

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Well it finally happened - finally got to play the #1 game on BGG and to see if it's worthy of that title. The answer? Maybe...

It's certainly a fantastic game and definitely in my top 5. I think the mechanics of Agricola or Game of Thrones are just so good that they will remain in my top spots. But I digress - let's get back to this game.

When I first read the rules, I thought that this game was a luck fest due to the card draws. I also though it would be super tactical. I was wrong on the first point, and only half right on the second. The first game I admit that not knowing the cards kind of limited my play - but only to an extent. I slowly realized that just like real life, the game throws things at you and the best person to deal with that would win. And just like in real life, you can do a whole lot to prepare for those situations.

Ensuring you are within a fighting chance of areas you know will be scored during a round - or establishing a foothold in a new area - or keeping up with the space race - there are definitely a lot of things that demand your attention and keep your interest.

So even though playing the cards is highly tactical, there is also a high degree of strategy involved to make sure you are setup to deal with the unexpected. For example, if I know I am going to lose one area, I can try to sneak into another area that I know will also be scored. But maybe I can do it in such a way that the other guy thinks I still want to protect the area I know I am going to lose. There is a lot of interesting mind play in this game and I've only begun to scratch the surface of that. Just like in the real cold war, you can play with your opponents emotional and analytical side and attempt to manipulate them into areas of the board you can afford to lose. This is one of a very few games where my heart rate sped up during some points while I held my best poker face waiting for my opponent to make a move I knew would eventually help me.

I think the real brilliance of this game is that it hides very complex strategic gameplay behind very simple tactical mechanics. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
It really is as good as everyone says it is. The whole game is frenzied damage control. It seems like you never have a good hand of cards and your opponent is sweating thinking the same thing. Realignment and Space Race rolls suck, they never seem to go my way. Still, I could play Twilight Struggle all day long and never get bored.

RATING: 10
This is a fantastic area control/wargame. Identification of battleground states, structure political point-to-point connections and the event card effects, make this game really feel like it is recreating history.  I can always see the world struggle for dominance unfold.

I love how the game starts small with USA and USSR devoting their resources heavily for a few regions.  However, by the mid-game the whole world is up for grabs and you have to pay attention to so many aspects all at once. Balancing your need for Ops points with not activating your opponents weighty events is a tantalizing struggle.

RATING: 6
I can't figure out why people call this a war-game. It's a card driven game triggering on mainly political events. 
The game is quite complex and not easy to learn. Remembering all the cards is the only way to get involve into the atmosphere of the game.  
Thematically, to win in a region when only you know that it will be scored.  It's a massive text card drafting game with a board pasting a cold war theme.  Not my cup of tea. Give up my copy with no regrets!  I still give it to 5.5 because of its education value not the game play mechanism.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.1
6 plays

TS suffers from three major weaknesses: it's not very rewarding given its length of play, it's sub-par components make it difficult to attract newbies to the game, and finally the hand of chance in the form of dice has a huge impact given the game's length.  

To my mind, the die rolls of the space race make no sense, that one player could be three or four positions in and the other still not have achieve satellite orbit ... makes no sense.

I also found it to be one of those CDGs that aren't much fun once you know the cards.  Play becomes Chess-like, stilted and at times wildly ahistorical.

TS is a good game, worth its cover price, but don't expect to play it dozens of times or keep it for years.

RATING: 9
First playing revealed a wonderful light wargame.  Playing an ops card forces the event to happen in the case that it favors your opponent.  That was one of my main gripes with the single-deck card driven wargames.  Great innovation.  Very thematic game which captures the flavor of the cold war with minimal, basically no, chrome.  Rules are concise and functional.  I don't know if it will hold up to repeated plays, but right now I'm in awe.  If it holds up to lots of repeated plays, this could be a ten.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
:tobacco: :( :D A very well-designed game to be sure, but falling into the Elvis/Shakespeare/Beatles category of cultural artifacts that are both very, very good and somewhat overrated.

When people talk about [i]design for effect[/i], this is pretty much the very thing they're talking about. Twilight Struggle does not make more than a handwavey attempt at accurately simulating the complexities of the Cold War. All of this makes for a very entertaining game but not at all a simulation ‚Äì to its credit, the designers are frank enough about not even attempting such a thing. Which is a good design decision in a lot of ways but it does lose something if your goal is, at least in part, thematic immersion. Good players of Twilight Struggle (and books can and have been written about Twilight Struggle strategy) excel in part through mastery of gamey tactics that end up feeling like more of a jarring departure from the narrative than you would encounter in other CDGs. Likewise, the limitations of the bipolar superpower model -- allegiance being a more or less straightforward with-us-or-agin‚Äô-us thing, the implicit acceptance of the domino theory that pretty much every political scientist who‚Äôs thought about the matter (the game designer included) has long concluded is bullshit -- lead to some pretty wonky disjoints between game and reality. The idea of De Gaulle being some sort of philo-Commie (an assertion that no doubt has racked up some serious entombed RPMs in Colombey-les-Deux-Elgises) is ‚Ä¶ odd. Likewise, the complex and fraught USSR-China-USA love triangle getting reduced to a single card, the abstraction-to-near-nothingness (yeah, Quagmire and Bear Trap, but they just sort of [i]happen[/i], they‚Äôre not the result of hubris or overextension or what have you) of Vietnam and Afghanistan, etc., etc. And let‚Äôs just not talk about the ‚Äúyay, my opponent rained fire and cesium isotopes on my major cities, I win‚Äù thing.

I mean, whatever, right? The game works. It works quite well. And board games, especially the ones that are designed to be, y‚Äôknow, fun, are generally rotten simulations of anything. And I [i]like[/i] design for effect. But there‚Äôs something about the gameyness of Twilight Struggle ‚Äì and I freely admit this may be a knock-on effect of the many wise things that have been written about the strategy, which in turn is a knock-on of the game‚Äôs massive (by complex-hobby-game standards) popularity ‚Äì that takes me out of The Moment and prevents me from seeing the masterpiece that so many see.

Bitch bitch bitch. I still like this game. I‚Äôm not dissing Twilight Struggle, really. I would rather play Twilight Struggle than a hundred anonymous Euro cube-twiddlers or just about any Ameritrash joint you can name. It‚Äôs a good game, with difficult decisions that give you a frisson of genuine Cold War paranoia as you try to suss out whether the loathsome godless Communist oppressor is marching through Latin America because he‚Äôs holding a scoring card or just because he‚Äôs trying to mess with your head. I just feel like it‚Äôs worth elucidating why I think I‚Äôd, on balance, rather play Labyrinth, or the COIN series, or Wilderness War, or a whole mess of other CDGs, even as I appreciate the work that was done on this title.

RATING: 2
Rulebook is terrible; The main mechanics of the game aren't that complicated and we still struggled to figure them out.
Lots of randomness with regards to which cards you draw. I won the game in 2 turns by drawing two scoring cards and stacking the deck for myself.
1d6 die rolls determine important strategic outcomes. 
You can tell the game was designed by a couple of people w/out game design experience for their own recreation of history. It is not a very well designed game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My first and favorite CDG.  The game is easy to learn but difficult to master.  I find the individual actions to be remarkable accurate on such an abstract level.  I also enjoy reminiscing of the events being a child of the 80's - especially once the late war deck is introduced.

My reasons for not giving this the full 10 is that I am worried about eventual replayability.  With such a tight deck and more familiarity of the cards, I am afraid it may become too scripted.  However, I really enjoy it now and look forward to many more games.

RATING: 5
A very good game about the Cold War and the effects different events of the time had on the world scene.
It is a balance between choosing actions and denying the opponent the same actions.
If one is not interested in the history of the cold war the game is not going to be a hit. This game do not belong as a top game here on BGG due to the fact that the game mechanics is not that fantastic and the game theme do not attract the majority of gamers (IMHO).
For those that are interested in the theme (like me) both the game mechanics and the actual game is outstanding and is also a fantastic source of learning of the events that shaped the world during the 50 years after the second world war.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I really didn't think that I would like this game, the cards seemed to fiddily, like one bad hand could lose you the game, like in hammer of the scots. After playing it 3.5 times (the .5 was for a Russian turn 1 victory : hint if you are the US player always place enough influence to control West Germany during setup!, don't forget about De Gaul, and watch for coups in Italy!) Yes bad hands will happen, but it makes for lots of good choices as you try to make the best of a bad situation. The same can be said for the dice, as a few rolls one way or the other can swing the game, but I feel that these add "story moments" to the game, how an unlikely coup in West Germany succeed, giving the Russians a toehold in Europe after E. Germany and Poland have become dominated by the US. I really see now how this has shot up so high on the charts. Great game.

Update: I've played this probably 20 times now, it is still a great game, with a new layer of depth as I know most of the cards well now, especially the early and mid war ones and so I go out of my we to counter act them before they might be played.Raised my rating to 9.5 from 8.5

RATING: 10
The brilliance of this game revolves around its theme and the elegance of its design. After just a few turns, its mechanisms disappear and what you are left is a re-enactment of the global historical drama of the cold war. 

+ elegant mechanisms that serve the theme extremely well
+ exceptional hand management rules (no discards, keep 1, ...)
+ new nuances continuously unfold with repeated plays
+ simple to teach and play
+ evocative of a historical period that I care about

= you need to learn the cards to play the game well

A classic game experience that is beyond and above the sum of its parts. One of the best games ever designed, indeed.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My first playing was enjoyable. I have to admit, I'm pretty shocked that a gaffe like "Chili" made it through production, but I am willing to overlook that for the game play. Initially, the theme didn't grab me when others had high anticipation. But after playing it once I really enjoyed it. Now, after more play....I have to agree with those who say the luck is too high for this type of game.Positives: The complexity contained in a very accessible ruleset. The total playing time for the game was successfully kept in a very reasonable range. There are lots of interesting decisions. The game also generates a neat narrative as you play. The general pendulum of momentum...starting with the Soviets and swinging back to the US as you go.Negatives: For the amount of complexity that the decisions give you...the wild swings in momentum that can come from a crappy hand or even single cards (like Red Scare), combined with many die rolls that are all or nothing....and its not hard for a player with inferior play to actually win the game. I don't mind that aspect in some games, but here it doesn't seem congruent with the depth the game otherwise holds.I'd be willing to play again, and would enjoy many aspects. But given my choice I'm likely to suggest something else. 

Update: I've increased my rating to a 7.  After several games I'm starting to be familiar enough with the cards that the game is less frustrating. Every once in a while, the combination of card luck and dice luck can overwhelm the importance of decision-making....which is very frustrating. For some reason, that amount of bad luck in most wargames would seem to be negotiable, where here it isn't. But if that doesn't occur, the game can be enjoyable and satisfying. Played quickly, I can tolerate the occasional dud game. Still, given my druthers I'd much rather play Hannibal or Paths of Glory.

RATING: 10
Includes the Twilight Bunker Insert by Meeplerealty: http://www.meeplerealty.com/store/p34/Twilight_Bunker_%28compatible_with_TWILIGHT_STRUGGLE%E2%84%A2%29.html
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I don't generally play a lot of 2 player games, nor games printed by GMT, but I love the Cold War theme on this one, and the mechanics sounded interesting, so I gave it a go.

I think this is a solid 2 player option. The entire affair is basically an area influence game that is driven by heavily themed cards. For the 5 people that haven't played this game yet: cards are from a shared deck. Each round, each of the players gets a mitt of them, and they then can use the cards to put down more influence on the board directly, or to trigger events. Some of the cards have events for only one side, and if you play a card that has an event for your opponent, you must let them do it before or after placing your own pieces with it.

There are a huge number of thematic touches to this game even beyond the card deck itself (which is chock full of historical events). For instance, DEFCON is an extremely important thing to keep track of, and the threat of nuclear war keeps either side from executing too many direct power plays for much of the game. The Space Race is also present in a minor, though useful way.

I think this is a game that will gain with repeat play and added familiarity. For the time being, I say it's good, and I would enjoy playing it most times that I have the opportunity, but it probably isn't something I will buy. Good stuff though, and I could see my rating going up rather than down.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Œúost probably the best H2H game I played
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The essence of this game is one of direct confrontation and this is very much a core wargame characteristic. After all, this game does come from possibly the best large current wargame publisher GMT.

However this game has a lot to offer the non-wargamer.  The rules are simple but the gameplay is still rewarding this is considered a core characteristic of the best strategy  euro-games.  I would say that the rule book definitly comes from a wargame publisher and is initially less concise and clear than most equivalent Euro's.

The theme matches deceptively well with game mechanics and the historical context (its worth reading the design notes) there is no pasted on theme here.  The domino theory is used as a model which fits in with western geopolitial thinking from the period.  It may not fit all the current theories (or even match current mainstream wisdom) but places the players in a appropriate historical mindset.

2014
Even when the game hands me my opponents cards (not good in this game) I can formulate a plan to retain one, use the space race to flush another (two later in the game) and finally trigger the remaining cards when they are less dangerous.  A lot of the games that are compared with Twilight are mechanically similar and produce a good narrative but often give players less sense of power.  This is great thematic twist the great powers did not just react to events they also drove them even when they were less favourable.

In The Making of the President 1960 have a feeling the cards play me, in TS I play the cards.

This will be a must buy on IOS.

Darn fun - sort of like Paths of Glory where you feel a million things are going wrong every turn (and they usually are!)

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A tremendous piece of game design that by rights should go down in history as one of the seminal and significant games of our time.  There have been several excellent card-driven wargames precipitated by the now-classical Mark Herman designs (including real treasures like Wilderness War and Paths of Glory) but what really sets Twilight Struggle apart from its peers is its amazing ability to provide accessible, straightforward gameplay without sacrificing historical detail, richness, and narrative.  This is a game you can explain in 15 minutes to a complete newbie and within 2-3 hours you've burned through 45 years of tension, turmoil, and upheaval.  The game's systems are logical and remarkably stripped down yet never so abstract as to deny specificity.  The cardplay, as we've come to expect from the genre, provides not only a sense of playing through a timeline but also multiple decision points in each hand- what to play, how to play, when to play.  The theme is a knockout and the use of wargame mechanics to portray an abstracted war is nothing short of genius.  GMT's production is, as usual, functional and somewhat spartan but that being said the mapboard is probably their most attractive piece to date.  Folks, seriously, if you're interested in anything from hardcore wargames to middle-weight Euros, this is one to pick up and savor for many years to come.  The bar is set for wargames of this type fairly high by Twilight Struggle, and I can't wait to see if Mr. Gupta and Mr. Matthews are ready to push it up even higher in the future.  A bravura performance of economy, grace, and sophistication.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
There's a ton of fun and strategy packed into a relatively small package.  There's a bit of luck involved with the die rolling and all, but not to a significant extent.  A few good rolls won't win you the game.

Waiting to see how the game changes for me after more plays.  Once the Early War cards are very familiar to me, I'll be playing a different game altogether.  Right now, it's still hard to really plan ahead (with a few exceptions - DeGaulle, Blockade, Fidel, Nasser, and some others).

RATING: 9
I was initially drawn in by the Cold War theme. Now, after about half a dozen plays on the app (which is excellent) this game has its hooks in me.

There is certainly randomness, but much in the same way that poker has randomness. And much like poker, the better player will regularly come out on top.

Mitigation of the luck element IS the game. It is incredibly satisfying to be dealt a "bad" hand and to get through the round without giving up much ground to your opponent.

It seems that the game is somewhat tilted toward the USSR, but I am willing to chalk that up to my novice status.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Rating after 6 plays. The game feels like a cross-over between euro and ameritrash - maybe it is the reason why it has so high rating? It feels more ameritrash to me because the theme seems to dominate the mechanics more than it should in a euro and because of the element of luck, especially the luck in card draws. Nonetheless, luck does not play as big role in this game as some critics claim - you can lose the game because of bad luck but, in general, the risks can be managed. I rated the game high for three reasons: first, the game is tense and challenging: there are always many meaningful actions but never enough resources (rating +3); second, constant bluffing and reading 'between the lines' - you have to pay close attention to your opponent and you have to try to hide your own agenda (rating +2); thirdly, I like the theme -  the  game is far from being historically accurate but you can always relate your actions to some events in history (regardless of whether they are represented in the game) and make witty comments about your opponent moves :) (rating +1). 

I have some doubts about the replayability, though. If the game holds up after 10 or so plays, I will probably give it the highest rating.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
