RATING: 9
Excellent game. The rulebook is fairly short for a wargame, about 11 pages of actual rules. It is light for a wargame but fairly heavy by eurogame standards. The complexity is about at the level of Age of Steam. An area-majority game; not a traditional wargame.  

I love that it's highly educational about the Cold War. You play either the US or the Soviet Union, and it gives you a great feel the global dynamics of the Cold War period, as well as informing you about the major events of the time.

I thought the Cold War would be a very uninteresting theme for a game, but I was wrong in the case of this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.9
A fun sink of time.  Play doesn't seem to drag because players' actions are usually quick and there's always something to think about.  

Would give this game a higher score if it weren't for a few things: confusing connections between countries, vague descriptions on cards with no clarifications in rules, tedious need to know what cards have and haven't been played yet, unpleasant art design.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This can be a great game but it takes a lot of energy. If you're in the mood for an epic this can be great.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
#1, really? I don't get it. I own it, but it's hard for me to justify the time. Wheres as I love some equally long (or longer) games, like Dominant Species, in that game you at least know what someone is thinking about when they're thinking (which usually isn't very long anyway), but in this game when someone is thinking, you have nothing to do but stare into space. But most importantly, there's a LOT of work involved in learning how to play correctly. There is a 16 page faq, and still rules I can't figure out the answer to. Sure, I could ask in the rules forum, and then get chastised for not reading the 64 pages of rules first. Some people say only the rules lawyers really care. Well, excuse me for wanting to know what the actual rules are, you know, like what I can and can't do, and what the consequences actually are. You can just make up ruling, but that's not very satisfying, and usually the person who it's against feels cheated. For a sampling, just see [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/97390/collected-rulings]this thread[/url]. I think if I had someone who knew the game cold, I would be interested in playing more, but I don't have such a person, and I feel my motivation level is very low for putting forth the effort required to become such a person.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Influential and brilliant would be the best two words I can currently find.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.3
Great game for two players. It has simple rules which force you to make difficult choices. Whatever happens on a board, you are supposed to "trade" some benefits from your played cards. 

Absolutely amazing theme (at least for me since whole 20th century it's the least known but most fascinating history period for me).

With time it might become repeatable (since there are some absolutely crucial objectives during Early War). However, there's still a vast number of options for each played card and results are often dice-determined so that you'll rarely experience any routine during game.

Few (in any) other 2-player board games can offer you better fun than that one once you and your opponent master own tactics.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
An amazing 2-player game. The feel of continually struggling against a losing battle, even when your winning. The chess like knowledge required to pick the right course. Watching the balance swing back and forth in the world. Just wow.

RATING: 6.75
Two player game about the Cold War. Players take turn playing cards to establish presence on a world map. Lots of dice rolling, but this is moderated by uneven odds determined by the game state.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a simulation, not a game. This is a simulation of the Cold War, just as World in Flames is a simulation of WWII. Simulations do not need to be fair, balanced, or fun. They are required to have reproducible results. I've played many times and enjoy the simulation very much. On a lighter note, this simulation does remind me of Harry's Grand Slam Baseball in that cards must be played even if they are not in your favor.

S-A-2
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I have owned it for many years and have only played it a handful of times. Each time I have to go back over the instructions to remember the details. It is a 2 person game and almost always I am playing games with more people so it does not come out often. Its a long game. So to teach the game (and remember the game) and then play is a long game session.  These are the reasons I did not score it a 10.  

So why a 9?  The game is so much fun!  There are so many options and decisions to make. The way you play is also based on what your opponent is doing.  I always want to get the next deck and see what is next.  Considering the amount of pieces and trackers the upkeep is quick and easy. I love going into the manual and reading the additional historical detail on the cards. It deserves a LOT more play then I give it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
GMT Games.  Amazing, tense 1:1 Cold War card driven war game.  This is the best game on the cold war that I have ever seen or played.  The action is non stop.  The events on the cards play right out of history.  Brinkmanship and pushing your influence worldwide is present.  Coups are possible.  The scoring mechanism is neat.  Most players can learn this game in under 30 minutes and then have a blast playing it.  Twilight Struggle is even more satisfying for those of us that lived part or all of the cold war or are students of the cold war.  Fantastic game - enough said!!!

RATING: 9
This game was extremely intimidating when my wife and I first played.... that game didn't go so well. It was long and draggy.
But the second play.... oh man.... once we got that first play out of the way,... man was it fun. Time went quick, as did the turns between players. So much to do, so little time! Many options per turn, lots of tension on every action. But not overwhelmed with what you should do to get to the win. Plus lots of player interaction and internal player strategy.
An easy keeper for the collection, and a favorite our mine for those days I have the time carved out to play.

RATING: 8
Comments based on one full game; will definitely play again.  Time to play full game was about 2.5 hours including going through all the rules (short 8 pages).  Very good game with many interesting (and difficult) decisions.  

I can see this becoming one of my favorite games to play; an excellent meld of decent history (De Gaulle and Brandt notwithstanding) with good tense cardplay and agonizing decisions.  Highly recommended.

Further play has made this one of my top 5 games.  Fast playing, plausible narrative, and every decision is difficult.

RATING: 9.5
Nothing other than Grand Austria Hotel and this, but somehow maybe this a little more so, sucks me out of my life and into a game this much. These can literally change my mood. 

It still isn't my type of game, but I caught the scent on the breeze blowing by of what it is trying to deliver.

I like what I know of it, but I doubt that we know enough to fully play by the rules as far as carrying out the cards correctly every time. So I view our wins and losses with some distrust.

Yet it is still fun. I won by 1 point as the U.S. in turn 10 last game but I really was wanting to win in turn 7 with War Games but she played Iranian Hostage plus Terrorism and it discarded my War Games. Oh well. Still a pretty fun round but that was pretty lucky of her.

RATING: 9

Simple in its mechanic, but driven by the random nature of scoring cards and the gradual progression to late war, this game has you fighting over all corners of the globe in true cold-war fashion.  This is also an excellent game to get many Gen-X non-gamers into, as they likely remember the cold war and can appreciate how tense the struggle really was.

RATING: 10
Sleeved
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
What makes this a little less than perfect? There is a definite advantage to those who play this game a lot over those that are just starting out.

Everything about this game is perfect. I find it easy to teach and difficult to master. This is the game that brought me back into boardgaming after a long absence. what I like about this game (and some others hate) is that there are too many things to do and not nearly enough actions to do them. Then you need to make the important decision; do I use operational points and allow my opponent have a good event - or do I ignore my important event to use operation points? You also need to determine the order that you play your cards. The numerous amount of variables equates to a mentally exhausting but equally rewarding game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Originally Alex's copy, but having battered it about a bit I bought him a "Like New" copy and kept his original one. I can't say anything that everyone else hasn't already said. It's a very unique game that suffers from some [deliberate] balance issues and which therefore means I've rarely had the game last all the way to the Late War section. I think the only reason I can't give this a 10 is because of the wildly varying lengths games can be - which makes it a hard game to schedule - and because I think sometimes historical accuracy has been prioritised too much over playability. It's a minor complaint though, and I can't wait for the "what if?" expansion, or the hopefully eventual release on iPhones and not just iPads!

RATING: 10
This is an incredible game. An absolute masterpiece. Emotive, technically fulfilling, and promotes a keen interest in our modern history. Play this with my partner once every few months- set it up in a corner and play a couple of rounds before bed after the kids are asleep. Laugh about the game in between sessions and look forward to it as one of the highlights of the day. She's not a board gamer. I've got lots to do. It's just that good. For me Twilight Struggle is a celebration of what makes board games so relevant and necessary in the digital age- there's fantastic interaction when playing this game, a very friendly competitiveness, a profoundly deep sense of narrative and engagement that you won't find in many other mediums.

RATING: 7
It's claimed that once you've studied the strategies, the cards, the probability tables for realignment rolls and coup attempts, and the long FAQ, this game becomes "awesome."  As in, best board game of all time awesome.

That's a stretch. At the very least, DEFCON suicide cards should be notated as such. Also, while the rules are only moderately complex, a game should make me want to play and study it, not force me to play and study in order to like it.  Nevertheless, after several plays, I can understand the game's appeal, and I appreciate it much more than I once did.

RATING: 8.5
A tense strategy game where very rarely are your actions wholly beneficial to you. Everything you do has an impact and you have to carefully watch your opponent. Cards can quickly shift favor one way or another, but there is always a chance to right the balance of power.

All in all a blast, loved by everyone I've played it with. Even if I've never won yet! The downsides for me are its long playtime and fiddly nature. Not huge critiques, admittedly, but enough to bring it down ever so slightly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
This game requires an investment in time and study a lot of people (me included) simply can't afford. Playing at a satisfying level requires both players to DEEPLY know the deck and all the strategic implications of playing each single card. This require TENS of hours of gameplay on both sides. It's not a game you can casually pick up and play one night, even in a geeky game group (unless your gamegroup is made of 2 people and you have no other games). You need to know the game and you need a partner that does the same. I didn't play many games, but it was clear games would be very lengthy and plagued with analysis paralisis.
In short, this game is hard both to learn and to master. And it's strictly for 2 players. Also, there's way too much luck for my taste (rolling dice and drawing cards are the bulk of the gameplay). I traded this game out and I'm not regretting it. I don't feel it deserves being #1 on BGG.

RATING: 9
An excellent two player game that oozes theme - strangely enough, because the gameplay is pretty abstract. There are no boring mements because every decision feels really important and there is plenty of room for strategic play. It's really interesting how this game manages to make every single one of your decisions to feel like it can decide the game. twilight Struggle is a long game, but the lenght is more than justified by the content. I don't think I've played any other two player game as tense as this - maybe except Go.

RATING: 10
I put off buying this because it seemed heavy, and I had heard it described as a war game with cards. Very glad I went against my instincts - it's a _great_ game. Because the other players moves have direct consequences for you and can benefit you, you don't have a strong sense of downtime. On your turn trying to not benefit the other player, along with having to pick and choose where to deploy on the board adds tension. The rules will need a pass and it's probably worth a few dummy turns to get a feel for the game flow, but it's well worth it, because the game has genuine replayability and rewards expertise. Best modern two player game I've played

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The mechanisms work perfectly with the theme to create a very tense game. You are the head of one of the superpower and strive to develop your long term strategy while dealing with crisis. On the board it is a simple game of influence and areas majority, but the cards play leads to agonizing choices and add all the chrome of the era. Much more theme than the average Eurogame.

Not for everyone, the rules are 8 pages, but playing time is 3 hours and nerves wrecking. There is also a learning curve. It is not a military simulation either but a game of strategical planning in a chaotic environment. There is some luck in the dice and cards but the game reward skills and poise.

Very good replayability.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
After 6 years I finally managed to play this game. And after all the great things a lot of people kept telling me about this game it was a huge let down.

The game felt completely random, random draw, rolling of the dice. And had too much of "I play this card and all your efforts so far have been wasted".

Yes the game is full of tense decisions, but those decisions didn't feel fun at all. I was tempted multiple times just to force the DEFCON to 1 just to get it over with, but out of respect to my opponent I stuck with it until the end.

I am told that the game gets better (i.e: less random) after repeated plays and memorizing the cards and what not. But spending 4 to 5 hours multiple times while not having any fun hoping that one day the game magically becomes fun sounds more like work than a game.

RATING: 6.5
This game is like Chess. I respect it. I love it's thematic design. But it's impossible to play against anyone without your exact experience. Knowing the cards in the game gives you complete dominance of the game. And the game is pretty complex to learn unless you're taught by someone who already knows it. So like Chess, you can end up in a scenario where your only opponent is someone who will crush you some 20 times before you even give them a run for their money. Which is why despite wanting to play the game and liking it, I had to get rid of it -- I was never going to get to play it.

RATING: 9.5

If you are into near history and want to play a very tense game of politics, this is a must have!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
can NOT stop playing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
This is an awsome, awsome game!

In each turn of every round (and there could be 7x10=70 turns in a game), the player is faced with a series of hard decisions: Should i play a card from my side or should i keep it in the deck to use it later to a better efect? Should i instead play a card from the opposite side so that i can "burn" that event before it can gets even worse for my side?
Events that do happen are then discarded, but those who don't are reshuffled into the deck and can happen in one of the next rounds of the same historic period, a brilliant concept!
Also, at every time during the game, the player must take prevention steps so that he is not forced to launch a nuclear war, a reason to lose the game on the spot! - this is the reason because players new to the game can lose it very fast, it's vital to have some knowledge about the cards but, after 3 or 4 games, things began to make sense and become easier, as the game's mechanics are not really heavy. What makes the game really hard and interesting is the permanent need for a wise decision about the choice between lesser evils!
A complete recreation of the events that spanned over 40 years of the XX century (which i witness the last 12) develops under the finger tips of both players, with the great ideia that, in each game, only a fraction of the 110 possible events do happen, and are the players who define which do happen or not, remaking history and making all games different!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.8
My absolute favorite game

RATING: 8

There are a dearth of games on this subject, but even if there were more, I don't think my opinion would change.  I like CDGs, and I really like how events are triggered if you play your opponent's events for Ops.  This feature really helps balance things out with the unified deck.  The sapce race is an interesting mechanism to get rid of events that benefit your opponent.  US has a higher learning curve than the USSR, so let the new guy play the commies.

This is truy a game that matches your wits against your opponents' in a way that relies very little on chance. [29 Mar 2016] - 8.75 (5 plays)
Twilight Struggle is still a fantastic game after about a year of playing it. I find the theme incredibly interesting and the flow of the game makes sense after a couple of plays. The length gives the game that epic feel but also makes it harder to play now that I have a busy schedule.

RATING: 9
What a great game. So much thought has gone into its design; mixing in the mid and late war decks changes the mood of the game as you play through it, and the fact that you are forced to play opponents events if using 'their' cards for operations means that you are never completely in control.  Hand management and strategic influence counter placement are other factors adding to its richness and complexity. The mechanics themselves are light, and it is easy to learn in an afternoon. I see us playing this a lot in 2008. I also like  the fact that it is non-expandable. Hurrah!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

That said, it is not a true war game because everything is fully abstracted so no troop movement and such. It also has a fairly high amount of luck, if that bothers you.

RATING: 9
Very tense 2 player game. Most time you struggle for insignificant avantages, but they will do the difference.
It's my type of game, but I think it's too overrated on BGG; January 2011; 1 rank for wargame AND boardgame,2 rank on strategy games... It's not the ultimate game it's just an excellent game. 
The effect cards are not so balanced, dice rollings could be frustating, space race is pure randomness.
I love the historic background which reminds my childhood, I love the go feeling, I love to manage the uncertainty, I love the China card, I love to have yto occur negative effects when a card is played for Op. Points.
But I highly suspect than between 2 equal players, the winner will be decided by random. It's  happen to me, I won but my opponent could be the winner with my cards and dice luck.
I will remains a very enjoyable game for me.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I should have went with my gut instinct on this one. Prepare for rant.

Even after watching gameplay videos and reading multiple reviews of the game, Twilight Struggle just didn't look like any fun. But it kept gnawing at me... it's #1 on BGG; there has to be a reason. There has to be more to it than it seems.

Well, there really isn't. We've played twice now, plus one learning game where we stopped early.

Here are the things I was sure I wouldn't like (and I didn't):

- The area control mechanic. This isn't a favorite of mine by a long shot, but there are definitely some area control games I love (for example, Dominant Species). This one's area control is little more than the old Risk I-push-a-little-here-you-push-a-little-there. Some people love this, but my wife and I find it really boring.

- The theme. I grew up in the 1970s in the US, so I'm well aware of the feelings of the time (fear of nuclear war, political uncertainty, etc.). I have never been particularly interested in politics, war or military history... and this game did nothing to make the subject matter compelling for someone like me. Other games have succeeded in "swaying" me to their theme (for example, Loyang), but Twilight Struggle was direly uninteresting thematically. My wife has even less interest in politics and history than I do (she doesn't even read/watch the news), so you can guess her interest in the theme.

Here are the things I thought maybe I'd like (but I didn't):

- The Space Race. In the game, this is just a way to throw away one card per turn (sometimes two) and make a die roll for possible VPs and/or special powers. The amount of randomness there is really surprising (for the #1 BGG game). Flip a coin, maybe you advance and get points, maybe you don't.

- The cards. I knew that this game would stand or fall based on the cards. Well, the majority of them are simply "add 2 influence in XYZ country or remove 2 influence from ABC country" or else, "this round get +1 for this-that-the-other" or "your opponent gets -1 for this-that-the-other". I'm not a fan of most card games for this reason... but there are exceptions (like Innovation, which has excellent and unique card ideas).

Here are some things I didn't realize (and then didn't like):

- The scoring. It's basically just majorities... play a scoring card for a region, see who has more territories. (Some other cards and the Space Race offer some points, but boring old region majority scoring is the main scoring.)

- The luck. There's a lot of single-d6 die rolling. I roll, you roll... oh look, I just won the Olympics and got 2 points! Really? This is the top game on BGG?

There are some things I have mixed feelings about:

- The cardplay. This, I think, is the one thing the game has going for it. I never had a single hand I felt was "really good". My wife also felt that the majority of her hands were not great. So, this game seems generally to be about mitigating the disaster better than the other player (and, yes, this does fit the theme). You need to find ways to play your cards in the best order possible, adapting to what your opponent plays, so that the cards which help your opponent the most come out when they are the least helpful (or occasionally have no effect). There is definitely an opportunity for strategy here and some interesting decisions... BUT... that's nowhere near enough to save the game for us.

Meh.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Played over Christmas 2009.  Wonderful game, great components, perfectly balanced, I can see why it is #1.  I held off on buying this one because it seemed long and complicated. RATING: 6
- Like: 2 player game, area control is always fun, beautiful board and cards, great theme, relatively small rule set.

- Dislike: considerable luck factor, longish (3h), bothersome calculation rules for deciding the winner of "realignment rolls" and "coup attempts", big learning curve because you need to learn all the cards.

All in all it was the luck factor that made me sell Twilight Struggle. The game is too heavy and too long for the winner to be decided by chance. And yes, luck can be mitigated for a big part, but one of the players will get that small bit of extra luck in drawing and dicing, so with players of similar strength chance will decide who wins.

RATING: N/A
(2nd edition) Based on two half-playings, a lot of fun.  Every subsequent playing will be different, since knowing what the cards do will greatly affect the decisions you make (i.e., the US player shouldn't spend a lot of resources on Cuba unless it's getting towards the end of the game and he can guarantee that the Castro card won't get played).

Looks like a light wargame, but it isn't one.  It's actually a meaty Euro with a conflict theme.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Rating after two plays.

A CDG that Cold War fans will enjoy and combat-averse eurogamers can get into because there are no dice and conflict is highly abstracted. The relatively short playing time is a bonus. The somewhat chaotic nature of the game is a downer, however, and eight consecutive failed attempts at the space race have jaded my opinion of this game.  Knowing all the cards and their effects in advance will give experienced players a ridiculous advantage over newbies.

The most critical problem that has been smoked out is play balance. One need not look far for reports of the Russians winning in the first three or four turns because of a good hand combined with the right scoring cards. Not fun if you're the US. Mind you, I think some of that might stem from the TS sharks, so you probably won't experience that for your first few plays while you and your friends fumble around.

And, as others have mentioned, this game is seriously overpriced for what it contains.

PS - Twilight Struggle is not a wargame.

Update: After honestly giving it many more attempts via Steam, I've had to downgrade my rating. Given competent play on both sides, it pretty much boils down to the arrival and timing of those scoring cards. Plus, it's too easy to fuck up and automatically lose the game because of the screwball rules regarding the DEFCON track, which I've decided I hate.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.8
[September 2017 - 8.8]
Fine-tuning the ranking as 1960 edges TS at the moment.

[April 2017 - 8.9]
Still a great game, but drops a few notches for its lengthy games. 

[August 2016 - 9.1]
There are few games where you are so intently watching your opponent such as in Twilight Struggle. From what cards they play to where they go, you're on edge every turn.

The card play mechanics take a few turns to fully grasp for someone new, but then it becomes clear and creates some tough decisions. There's some luck in the card draw, but it all usually evens out pretty well. There's a lot going on the board, but the gameplay is pretty straightforward once you learn it.

Once you learn the cards, the game takes on a new level -- "he's probably doing that because he has that card" or there's definitely double guessing going on if you suspect a scoring card is coming up. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Includes: Custom Dice

11 live plays with my brother.  100+ plays on Vassal.

This game is truly great.  I have had games where I just knew I had it in the bag and lost...and vice versa.  This game is never over until it's over.

There is luck in the game, but the good player will nearly always beat the poor player.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Key is that game is NOT balanced within individual turns, so it feels one-sided, but balanced over time. Also, much of game is tension putting out fires that opponent starts, or that are started by your own cards! Finally, the gameplay requires decisionmaking regarding how to manage your bad cards - which is an ongoing mechanic. Note that the Cold War was about futility and stalemate so this is an excellent sim of that dynamic.

RATING: 8

Also, please remember that twilight means morning or evening, NOT just evening.  You may be able to use this information to defeat your opponent in this game, although I am not sure how.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Before you dismiss this based on the fact that I only have one recorded play, know that I don't record online/iOS plays and I have played it dozens of times there. And the more I play it the less I like it. Although I'm a child of the Cold War and appreciate the flavour, the game just isn't that fun to me or particularly fascinating. Maybe I'm just really bad at this game, but I don't see the strategic planning in it. I am honestly baffled that this game is as highly regarded as it is here on BGG. I don't really like the back and forth nature of it that often comes down to who got dealt the best cards. The game is most interesting in the early and mid war, but generally positions are pretty entrenched by the late war, so the last third of the game is static and kind of uninteresting. I can't stand the rule that can allow someone to cost you a game by triggering a nuclear war because you had to pass a card to them. I'm sorry, but that's just sloppy design. I find myself more annoyed than entertained while playing the game. I realize I'm in the minority on this one, but there is a very long list of games I would play before this one.

RATING: 10
A perfect 10.  Being card-driven, no two plays of this game are alike.  It's got a great theme, which is beautifully and realistically played out.  I love all the ways it mirrors the real cold war.  You're always trying to mislead your opponent while figuring out what he/she is up to.  The only negative thing I have to say about this game is that it's hard for newbies to win against experienced players who know the cards already.

Bottom line, if you are looking for a 2-player game to add to your collection: get Twilight Struggle.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[More than 5 plays on-line]

This game is hard to rate. At first it's awesome, so many options, act and react and all that but after a while it becomes a game of frustration. You get frustrated when you flunk your third space race roll in a row while your opponents make all theirs and captures a Nazi scientist on the way as well. You also get frustrated when you fail all your war rolls, roll "1" on all realignment/coups and so on. I know it should even out after a while but I still feel the game is too random to really portrait the Cold War. I'll gladly play it, but I won't take it seriously which perhaps was the intention of the game all along?

Update: The more I play it the more I dislike it. It's truly just a game of suck management where if you draw the right cards you win. Who needs planning? 

Update 2: Perhaps not really that bad so upped the rating somewhat again.

Update 3: Yes, it is that bad or perhaps even worse?

Update 4: If you take it for what it is, a light game with lots of luck it's all right and actually fun. Just don't do what I did and take it too seriously.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I've been wanting to play this for a long time.  Finally broke down and bought it and am really enjoying it.  It is mostly an area-influence game, but is much more thematic than traditional area-inf games like El Grande.  It can be a little "tit for tat", but there is a good mechnism in place to discourage one player from  shadowing his opponent's influence placemnt.  I'm not a fan of the "Wargames" card.  It should be mentioned in the rulebook so that 2 newbies will know, ahead of time, it is in the deck...and be prepared when turn 8 arrives.  It's basically a "kill card" that ends the game immediately under certain conditions.

All in all TS is a fairly simple CDW to learn and play.  Not as good as some others I've played but still excellent.  Starting at a 9.

Downgrading from 9 to 7.  As suspected, it is just too much "tit-for-tat".  One player ends up shadowing the other players moves.  The problem gets worse in the late war when most of the countries are controlled and the Defcon remains at 2 (except for USSR first action).  Still a fun game that I like to play, but there are much better wargames out there.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Twilight Struggle is in a class by itself, a crossover powerhouse that combines event and operations card driven wargame action with tense eurogame-style area control. The game is saturated in tension, as you must constantly balance attempts to advance your own position with efforts to stop your opponents advancement, without ever being quite sure what sort of nasty tricks that your opponent will be able to pull out of their hat. The fact that your opponent's events will trigger if you play them only adds to the tension, as you have to think about mitigating their impact on your position as much as you have to worry about what your opponent is going to do.

The game's depth is a thing of wonder, with each decision having an immense impact on what will occur as the game progresses and areas of the board being constrained more by the question of "When do I want to go into this area?" rather than "Why would I want to go into this area?" (though there are admittadly a few of those too). 

The games flaws are mostly in the form of the imbalances between the relative power levels of the Soviets and the USA. Despite this, the more experienced player should usually win, its just it is more dangerous to be the USA player. 


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.1
With only two plays in, this rating may go up in 2012.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
A card driven game where players try to exert their political doctrine across the globe.  A very similar game to We The People, without the armies there to reinforce your politics.  Some luck involved in the shuffling of the score cards into the decks.  I like the rules that force opponents events to trigger if YOU use the card for operations - this can lead to some hard thinking about what to play and what to junk on the Space Race.    My beefs are trying to determine level of control during scoring (and play) - I've plugged some spare red/blue cubes into the game to indicate control at a glance - makes the game situation much clearer to see at a glance.  The game can run a bit long too.

After revisiting the game in 2016, after an 8 year break, the game still feels too long, same-y (they got the struggle part right), unforgiving, and too often decided by factors beyond reasonable control.   This is essentially a three hour area majority game (this is not a wargame), and games have to be very, very good to get my interest for three hours.  The rule giving your opponent a cheesy win by allowing them to trigger a nuclear war on your turn after a couple of  hours of careful play is "interesting".  Happy to put this one behind me for good.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In my mind, Twilight Struggle was, for a long time, placed on a pedestal as some sort of gaming icon. Sure I'd played Labyrinth, but this was The Big One. The grandaddy of them all. #1 on BGG.

Months now after I've bought it and played it a few times, it's not the end-all-be-all I had made it out to be, but it is a great game, and I've had fun teaching and playing it with friends.

My only real problems with it are that, to be any better than novice at this game, you have to know the decks inside and out, and have a good understanding about when discards are coming up. This metagaming is fine, but it sort of takes me out of the spirit of the game by shifting the focus from the events and consequences of operations to hand management and card counting.

Still, like I said, great game that I'll almost always play.

RATING: 8
I can see why some people really love this game, but those people must have more free time than I do. The 3 hour play time is not accurate for new players. After my first two plays, we were only half way done after 3 hours. I actually haven't finished a game yet because of the length. That being said, I enjoyed playing this. The mechanics work, and the theme really comes through. My only complaint is with the dice rolling. I'm fine with dice rolling in general, but rolling just one die is frustrating. When I roll three 1's in a row, I really feel like bad luck is defeating a good strategy. I think more dice would help average out the bad rolls.

RATING: 2
Decent game, but clearly was released unbalanced as pro-Soviet.  Designers have made some progress in accepting that, as has the game's enthusiasts, in general.  However, too many editions have been released, old versions need update kits, and even newer cards issues (good marketing, but bad for people that buy editions 1, 2 and 3) that also add to the Pro-Soviet edge.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a great game of cold-war intrigue and manipulation. The game has many clever additions to the popular card-driven genre [aka 'We The People' series games]. It plays more like a two-player majority game than a GMT wargame. I am a little concerned about how much of the game could hinge on burying opponents good cards and cycling yours, but it will take a lot a fun games before the jury comes back with that verdict. Exciting to see a new designer create such an instant classic!On a side note, the typos and blatant errors in this game are apalling. No part of the game got printed without mistakes; the map, the game cards, the play aids, and even the rulebook all have errors. Was there a single editor, developer, or even a proofreader? 'Replublic of China'? Different scoring rules on the play aid versus the rule book? I'm patient enough to play a friend's copy for three years and buy the inevitable reprint rather than pay $60 for an error-riddled production.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
This can be an amazing experience if you enjoy the theme and this type of game.  The events, actions available, and randomness all mirror much of the tension and futility of the actual cold war.  The flip side to this is a steep learning curve and the frustrating nature of dice rolls and card draws which can make the game feel daunting at first.  However, this game rewards repeated plays and win or lose will have you thinking about the things you did wrong and what a better strategy would be in the future.  I think the luck element actually adds to the tension and theme in a positive way.  I love the pictures from historical events on the cards and the way the map reduces the fate of the world to pairs of corresponding numbers.  It turns world changing events into digestible values and subsequently makes your opponent's wooden "2" chit next to yours very meaningful.

-.5   For minor gripes such as the way the turn track is implemented and the use of nondescript tokens to track important events.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Not a collector's copy.  A little box wear, but otherwise good condition. Includes printout of 2nd edition rules and printout of FAQ/errata. Nice quality paste-up corrections to the game board to correct various errors of the 1st edition. Similarly, some game cards have appropriate edits written on them to update to current edition or correct errors. All corrections tastefully done in my opinion and facilitate easy play of the game as it should be played. Game materials are in very good condition although the game has been played a number of times. The two six sided dice I have with the game are not the originals.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
TS is one of those games that I'll play on rare occasions.  It's not [i]bad[/i], in fact I enjoy a number of parts of it as well as the overall feel.  There's just too many things it does that irritate me, and as long as its sister games are around, I'd rather play one of them.  I might play it more frequently despite this if A it wasn't 2 player only (2p games just happen less often) and B it didn't take so darn long.

Having finally played a few card-driven games, I've come to enjoy this style pretty well.  I like the tension of deciding how best to use each card, each hand.  I like the headline phase in the beginning, the space race track, the pseudo-deckbuilding element as you try to weed out your opponent's powerful events when they'll be least useful.  The area majority core is set up a little strangely, but still totally understandable.  Even the scoring cards, which can be a kind of wrench in things by showing up at random, I don't have a problem with.  So long as you know what's coming & what's already happened, you know where to focus your attention.

Where TS loses me is in most of the rest of the game systems.  First off, the defcon track.  This thing may be thematic, but it's also a huge pain.  It feels like a major portion of the game is just managing this one element and trying to make sure you get the first turn when it's low enough for you to pull off the move you want.  Having to remember these bizarre restrictions about where you can and can't do these particular actions is always a nuisance.  And that's before you get to the fact that you can end the game prematurely by forcing your opponent to push it to 0.  I find this both anti-thematic and un-fun, and dislike that rule intensely.

The military ops track is another piece of chrome that I think could've stood to be cut.  I never remember to try and meet that requirement, most of the time you exceed it w/out even trying, and it seems to serve only to encourage you to do coups even more than you ordinarily would (more on that below).  I just have no idea why it's even there.

Lastly, though, is the big thing: the action balance.  I've played this one several times with the experienced players, the ones who do this every week.  Now, you can do 4 things with a card.  You can attempt a coup or do a realignment, using the die.   You can play the event, or you can just use it to put out influence.  The people who know what they're doing seem to stick with just 2 of those: coups and events.  Events are self-explanatory, if those are good you'll want to use 'em.  But it really feels to me like you want to be using coups at every opportunity, as they're just stronger than the other 2 options.  Realignments sound cool, but I've rarely seen them be useful.  It would be one thing if coups were locked off by defcon restrictions, but the weaker realignments weren't, but as it is, there's not much reason to use them.  Placing out influence is likewise fine, but a very expensive way to break up control, limited by adjacency so you can't always reach the spot you want, and then the next turn your opponent can come along and stage a coup, undoing all your work.  

In the end, it's this repetitive feeling of how the game [i]plays[/i] (plus the general clunkiness and length) that really gets to me, and makes me wish I were playing something else.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.37
THE game. No wait, that is GO, but this is a close second. 1st place on BGG for years for a reason.

The first time I played it I said "this is what I always dreamed Risk should be.. and I thought my dream was too grand!". 

Choose between URSS and USA, throw yourself in 1947, and let the world be your playground. 
Use coups d'etat, spread influence around the globe, take advantage of historical figures, or minimise strategically the negative impact they bring on your superpower. 

But keep the balance and don't push too much or nuclear warfare will ensue, and you'll loose.
It's only for TWO players. Two Serious players.

RATING: 7
What can I say about it that hasn't been said before?
Is it a good game? Yes without any doubt. Is it the best boardgame ever? My opinion... No

First of all, I'm not a big fan of card driven games. There are a few which I like very much (like hannibal) and a few that I would call decent (like Twilight struggle). Most of them, I just don't play at all.

One thing that I don't like about card driven games is that knowing the deck is a big advantage and this is very true for twilight struggle. When playing against an even skilled opponent, this doesn't matter though.

Still a very decent game that you should have least tried once in your boardgaming life

RATING: 8
Superb!  Solid game, solid rules, solid design.  Truly recreates the feel of the Cold War.  Absolutely nails its goals.  It unfortunately suffers from wargame-quality components, but the surpassing excellence of the game transcends whatever disadvantage this might cause.  One criticism is the randomness -- too many things come down to 1d6 vs. 1d6.  I'd rather roll 3d6 and pick the median, but I haven't played with this yet.

Overall, a phenomenal example of simple rules combining with stellar board and card design to produce amazing complex and agonizing decisions.  Gets better with every play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
ESP
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Since the end of 2014, I have had an increasing interest in board gaming, specifically modern board games. This has blossomed into a fully fledged love for the hobby.

I have discovered many new games. Many average. Many fair. Some good. A few very good - yeah, so it's pretty much a regular bell curve. Fewer are exceptional. Five are beyond exceptional. Of those five, four of those I wouldn't find it too hard to describe the game, or the personal appeal. The fifth game is enigmatic and nebulous, and it might just be the best of all. Its name: Twilight Struggle.

I shouldn't like this game. It's a two-player game about the Cold War, and it typically takes 3 or 4 hours to play, sometimes even longer. These are not things that have particularly appealed to me in the past. I'm not the greatest fan of two-player games, or conflict games, although there are games that are exceptions to this. But really, I have never liked long games (especially those with lots of down-time); I have always preferred to play a number of shorter games instead.

Twilight Struggle is a depth-gaming game. What do I mean by this? Well, it is not a game that is necessarily easy to understand the first time you play. The mechanics and strategy aren't immediately apparent. Even before the first play, it becomes evident that this is a game that requires multiple plays to comprehend, to improve at, to master. Mistakes will be made the first time you play - it is entirely possible that you will accidentally initiate a nuclear war. It is a game that is designed to be played over and over, to explore the depths of the strategy therein.

"Oh", I thought. "A complex, heavy, two-player only game that requires not only to invest multiple hours, but many multiple times". What is more, I had heard that experience gives a stark advantage - a player of 5 games experience, for example, would have an big advantage over a new player, so they say. True of most games, of course, but particularly true of this, it seemed. So I also had to find an opponent of a similar skill level. It seemed like an investment to even get to know what was surely a niche game (how often was I really going to play a long, two-player Cold War game anyway).

Then, one day, I played my first game. 

What I didn't do, what I recommend doing, is becoming as familiar as possible with the game's mechanics beforehand. There are YouTube videos and a Steam version (which is very good) which can help immensely in that regard. That first game took a long time, a very, very long time. This was mostly my fault because I wanted to play well, and I didn't understand anything, and I wanted to understand everything. I was extremely challenged (and probably a pain in the ass). But I enjoyed it, apart from struggling with the mechanics. (Thanks Matt.)

Later, I got the Steam version, and played against the AI a bit, and got my head around the basic mechanics of the game some more. I read up on some strategy. I played have played the game twice more, over the board. And that brings me up to now.

Yes, it was an investment, and it continues to be. I think about this game, I talk about it, I want to play it. It is like no other game that I have played. It has emergent strategy; it has tactics. It has spatial management; it has bluffing. It has crisis management, oh boy, does it have crisis management. I want to plunge into the depth of it and wade there. It has rolling dice, and rolling dice is one of the best things about it. Really. I never thought I'd say that. I hate it, and I love it, because it's great to plan, but you never really know. Risk lies at the core of it all, of everything.

Not all of the games I like have a lot of player interaction. This game simmers in it. Is the opponent holding what they are representing? The decisions, the constant unenviable decisions of which it is impossible to fully know the ramifications. Do I benefit my opponent now, but thereby remove that card from the game and manage future risk? Oh, I drew a handful of my opponents cards - I have to help them out, but maybe I can conspire to help them out at least opportune time imaginable. Do I attempt to hold onto the card they need, and risk being forced to play it when I didn't want to? Do I play my own card for the ops or the event? I really need both. And so on, and on. Hours pass, and what a wonderful way to spend your time. Yeah, turns out there's a reason it was #1 for a long, long time.

In summary: it is okay
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Card driven strategy game, with a cold war theme that works really well. Players manage hands of cards, some of which can be valuable to opponents, most of which must be played regardless. The game plays out in a surprisingly different manner each time, but experienced play will make the best of card play and operation tactics and usually end the game in the mid war. An amazing feat, must be played a few times by anyone with a thirst for strategy.

90-120m with 2 experienced players. 50+ plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
What to say, what to say?  For full disclosure, I am talking about the games Deluxe Edition.  So, what's to like about this?

1) Tension!  This game has it in spades.  

2) Low set-up breakdown time

3) A low amount of downtime between players turns

What is this game?  Some would argue that it's a war game, however, the fact that it has VP some VP's are awarded through area majority some would say this is a euro.  Who cares what it is, just play the game and see if you enjoy it.

Let's talk about the games card driven mechanism since it's the heart of the game.  Throughout each turn of the game (there are a maximum of 10) each player will have 8 - 9 cards and will be required play the majority of them.  Each non-scoring card will be associated with you, your opponent, or it will be neutral.  When you play a card, it can be done as either an event or used for it's point value.  So, why would you play cards associated with your opponent as an event?  Well, you wouldn't in normal circumstances, but the rules state that when you play cards associated with your opponent for the point value, the event will trigger regardless.  Some events when triggered will be removed from the game permanently.  This makes things very tricky.  So how do you get out of playing nasty opponent events that are in your hand?  You can typically carry one card into the next round and once (sometimes twice per round) you can chuck a card towards the space race to avoid opponents events triggering but this means that your opponent might get it when the discard pile gets shuffled to become the new deck.  So, players will be forced to decide what to play, how to play, what to get rid of and what to hold.  Tension!

Out of the box there is a definite USSR bias especially in the first 1 - 4 turns but there are a few variants to try and negate it.  If you want to have a satisfying Twilight Struggle experience, I would recommend using the optional cards and the Chinese Civil War variant for the first 10 or so games.  After that, the optional cards alone should be a sufficient once the American learning curve has been completed.

So what would I say is the games weakness?  Well, the dice makes me feel as if luck can heavily swing the results of a game.  There is a fair amount of die rolling and while it does create tension sometimes it can be annoying when you roll high on the space race and low on everything else.  For once the die rolling randomness is less of an issue to me than the card randomness, and that's because inciting a die roll can have ulterior motives (ie lowering defcon, chucking unwanted cards to the space race, increasing required military ops) than simply trying to get the result of a good die roll.

Speaking of the cards there definitely seems to be a lot of luck in who get's what cards.  Particularly the scoring cards.  Who draws what scoring card, in what order and based on the current board position can have a huge effect on the outcome of the game.  While there is randomness in the dice and cards it doesn't detract from having a highly engaging confrontational experience. 

I no longer own it as I'd much rather play online via Steam.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Rating has climbed a bit after more and also after playing other games that fall into the same wheelhouse. The rules for this are actually only eight pages. Everything is balanced very tightly, which I have found a difficult task for other games in this genre. There is chrome here, but not too much. Some games of this type tend to add fiddly mini-games to increase the chrome. TS does not require such mechanisms, and that may be its best feature.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A great new entry in the long row of wargame-reviving card driven wargames. This one plays quick, is easy to teach to anybody (even non-wargamers), has lots of flair, and takes a lot of clever thinking to master. The freshness of the theme and the very balanced approach of the authors to the themes represented (critical to both Soviet and US historical power plays) makes this a real must have for any enthusiast of card-driven wargames or "epic" 2 player games in general. Be prepared for some frustrating plays as the US, though - one has to know the game well to play the US right, as the Soviets have more powerful events in general.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Games not bad, but not great? 

No idea why it's number 1? But still exploring it.

I agree with others that the game plays you as much as you do it!

Seems to lack a lot of strategy as you've not many choices and can't keep cards. Your main choice is when to play cards, which to use on the space race, and if your own nation/neutral cards, whether to go for event or influence. 

You can place influence, or take a dice roll to see if something good happens - this D6 roll can make a large difference! Which makes it a risk - especially when you're playing it and giving your opponent an event.

And I finally get why card knowledge helps - eg Cuba card means the US tokens are removed, and replaced with USSR to control. So an experienced player would NEVER put tokens in Cuba, till the card is gone! This knowledge can change a lot of the game play.

Maybe USSR has some better cards? Certainly seems that way (but I am currently US) as one of my 4 pointers 'gave me japan', which I already had, so my opponent got 4 points for nothing! Meanwhile I play a card as I have to, to give her access to S.America and Africa!

Seems to take a lot longer than the 3 hours, at least to start with. I have seen others say 3 hours is an average time. I guess if you know the cards and don't have to read them, it would be a lot quicker!

----

First game USSR won turn 4 on VP.

----

Second game looks equal-ish - we both think the opponent is better placed to win. US has VP, USSR has space race (6 turns and not a single die success for US! Still on starting square!) We're both a little over it, seems to drag on and on. Been two evenings and not done yet. Estimating 4-6 hours played so far and just on turn 7/8!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Probably the best board-based, card game ever.  Why? Because there are two different asymetric player cards which are almost perfectly balanced (perhaps West is favoured before removing the Shah of Iran card).  Add in an excellently done, tense theme where you fear falling behind in the space race or inadvertently triggering nuclear armageddon.  Incredibily intelligent and well-applied design and theming.  How ever many reissues and copycats have comeout, this remains the pinnacle - and alone kicked off the trail of Cold War card games. Relatively easy to teach and after a learning game, the impact of the 'knowing the deck' shouldn't factor in anymore, so disregard that unfounded criticism (which sounds to me like playing a game of poker and being surprised that aces are high).  It may not be the easiest game to learn directly from the rulebook and my main knock is that the scoring cards appearance can be just luck, but barring that, it's sheer elegance once the lightbulb switches on.  Almost perfection and worthy of its many accolades.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fantastic back and forth. You constantly struggle with whether or not to play cards that help your opponent more than they help you. One of the most tense games I have ever played. Fairly easy to learn and teach, and the rulebook is fantastic as many GMT rulebooks are.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The board, counters and cards are visually appealing.  Rules medium length, well written, but marred by a few ambiguities (primarily with respect to special card effects). 

Gameplay often feels reactive rather than deliberate, and it can be difficult to plan and carry out a strategy because of the exigencies of events.  While this inability to make long term plans may render the game an accurate simulation of international power politics during the Cold War, it also robs the game of that certain satisfaction that arises from a well-orchestrated campaign. There is room for clever card play, but players seem to spend as much time trying to avoid the play of cards that might help the opponent as they do playing cards for their own advantage. 

The order of card draws as well as a player's success or failure in particular die rolls can sometimes have a profound effect on the course of the game, and players have little ability to manage their risks. Luck seems to play a bit too large a part in the game for my taste. 

This game's strong point is theme - Twilight Struggle is steeped in history. Conclusion: recommended for players interested in Cold War history and untroubled by the substantial role that luck plays in the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Wonderful tug-o-war style game, where Risk meets politics. After a few plays, it becomes a bit too chess-like (as players become more familiar with the cards) and I wish there was a way to make each playthrough distinctly different (removal of random cards, slightly more random starting influence, etc). For the same reason, the game is very exclusive as it tends to force new players out, since they won't have the knowledge of more experienced players. However, if you find the right friend for this game you might not ever put it back in the box. I desperately wish that I could find that friend.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
See my review here: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/1088254

Thematic game - own the [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/422441]Deluxe edition[/url].  Video overview  [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/23763/item/479665#item479665]here[/url], comprehensive review [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/471953]here[/url]. Game length about 3 hours.  I do love asymmetrical games!  Russia has the advantage (can optional bidding to be Russia with US getting some starting influence)

Similar complexity to 1960, but more tension.  Comparison notes: 
* The theme has more appeal to me than 1960 (although I didn't mind 1960s theme, simply because the theme was so rich and it was so well done, and it's an opportunity to learn historical things I don't know).  
* I prefer the components of 1960 (although the deluxe edition of Twilight Struggle should help improve it somewhat).  
* I'm a bit hesitant about the game time (1960 is listed as 90 minutes on BGG, Twilight Struggle is listed as 180 minutes on BGG - hope that won't be an obstacle in my home!). As long as I can play it in an evening, but 3 hours is probably the longest that a game would get played here - if it's a good game that sustains interest of my opponents (example: Through the Ages)
* As for the difference in feel due to the forced play of opponent's events (in contrast to 1960), that can increase tension, and the only way I'll find out about that is to play.  This is the thing a lot of players don't like about TS - is that its not all about control, but in a lot of cases about "crisis management" - minimizing the damage to things that are out of your control.  

Note that knowing the deck allows you to play better -  you can make long-term plans and it becomes less of a reaction to the cards.  But don't study the deck before playing - there is huge fun in playing blindly, and discovering the cards as you go along, nothing like the first game as newbies, I'm told.

Game slightly favours Soviets (less so with optional cards included).  Ideas for balanced game for deluxe edition: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/527570
The 6 optional cards from Deluxe edition - suggest to include from outset, may help US slightly, see [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/545754/twilght-struggle-deluxe-optional-cards-review]this review[/url].

[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/362972]Videos[/url] to help get into the theme - also see [url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HpYCplyBknI]here[/url].

Ideas for new players: have them play as Russia and not worry about realignment; see also review on [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/630515/why-i-love-the-late-war-scenario-aka-luring-in-the]late war scenario[/url].  Late war scenario as described is for first edition, put space race markers on USSR box 5 & US box 8 (see [thread=759122]here[/thread] and [thread=476019]here[/thread]); note that USSR domination of Middle East is simply an error.

[gameid=26997] (now forthcoming from GMT) which adapts Twilight Struggle gameplay and mechanics to a different theme.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The game is very absorbing and fun. It is mostly of interest to people who lived through at least part of the Cold War. But...play balance is knife-edged and once it swings slightly one direction, the game rapidly becomes uninteresting for the losing player. It is also unbalanced to start and needs a minor adjustment to starting positions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Cold war themed political war game based on a map of the world - covers time span from the end of WWII to Glasnost. Probably my favourite game. It is let down by the quality of the components. I have made my own map and used pieces from other games to rectify this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The CDG par excellence, and a game every hobbyist should try at least once. It's a tense affair with interesting strategies and gambits. The card play is brilliant the way your opponents events activate when you play them and how scoring cards must be played. These stipulations make for agonizing decisions.

There is a barrier to entry as I well know. I hated the game at first, and it took several plays for my rating to climb to where it is. Finally, after a few plays I became familiar with the cards so that I had a sense of where I was in the deck and could make better choices. Until that point, I was just flailing and didn't see the allure of the game. Now that I'm somewhat skilled at the game, I've outgrown playing with local friends, but it plays great on Vassal.

I deduct a point from being a perfect 10 for the way bad rolls can derail a game. I had one where I got stuck in the Bear Trap for almost the whole damn turn. Not fun, and the rest of the game was pointless because I'd lost so many turns. As most of my plays are on Vassal, that's not a real problem; you restart quite easily, but had that happened on a day I scheduled off work with a buddy to play, that'd leave a sour taste.

Still, it's become one of my favorite games. I love learning which moves to prioritize while working around the "crappy" hand I've been dealt. I will say, as far as I'm concerned, this is a game of conflict simulation but not a wargame.  ;p)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A great game, lots of tension and an abiding feeling of problems exceeding available resources.

RATING: 9

RATING: 9
This game has been my favourite 2 players' game about 3 years! My rating would have been '10' few mounts ago, but at last I got the feeling that maybe I've played this game too many times... It's time to get to know other games better. 

Updated 2012-02-03: Although there are weeks and months I don't play this game at all, I still love to play it regularly. It's THE game I'd take with me to an isolated island. One of the few games I can say I'm good at it. It's almost the most perfect game for me: rating increased to 10!

Updated 2012-11-19: Still playing this game every now and then. Rating decreased to 9 though.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Every winter when I was a kid, the neighbor boys would build a snow saucer run in their back yard, which had a steep hill.  It was curved and banked, and it was terrifying to look down from the top with your saucer in your mittened hands.  When you finally built up the courage to sit in the saucer and push off, you'd be flung down the hill, veering back and forth, spinning and getting dizzy and (if you didn't wipe out) making it to the bottom still trying to catch your breath from the ride.

That's just how Twilight Struggle feels.  Of course there are some games that end almost before they begin.  Sure there are wild twists of fate.  But if you don't make it, you can walk back up to the top and try another run.  And when you make it to the bottom, it's an accomplishment to be proud of.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
I have been waiting for this game for a very long time.  

When, someday, as an even older duffer than I am now, I hear the young'uns in the hobby laugh at this game the way some of today's people laugh at, say, The Plot to Assassinate Hitler or Empires of the Middle Ages, I'll have to remind them that what made this game different was the mindset behind it, that before it was, effectively, nothing.

And of course they'll ignore me because by then political games will have their own subsection at Funagain, and there'll be more important arguments raging about whether an impeachment option for Bush is ever a valid game mechanism in a early "0h-0h's" game, or how to game for Third World Christian movements' dispersal and growth in North America and its resultant political effects, but hey, I'll have made my point.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is really enjoyable game.
I like the to-ing and fro-ing of the influence in the countries and the victory points although the latter are quite few and far between. The space race is interesting and is a good way to pitch the event cards you do not want your opponent to benefit from.  The events each being either factional or neutral means occasionally you have no choice but to play that card, allow your opponent the event benefit and then undo the damage with the OPs that you got from playing the card. I like that you cannot hold on to the scoring cards from round to round and thus cannot set up the big scoring turns that would win you the game but must scrabble for every point inch by inch, card by card.

RATING: 10
Highly thematic, exquisite, deep game-play, totally innovative systems, easy to learn but difficult to master... not much I can say that hasn't already been said about this instant classic.  One of the most original historical-themed games (notice I didn't say wargame... wink) ever to be devised.  Keeps both players engaged and on their toes at all times, every turn, with hardly any down-time... this game will certainly not bore you.  The physical presentation, even of my original first-edition version, is just fine, with an attractive and functional map and high-quality cards.  Easily one of the best 2P games I've ever played, or ever will play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Twilight Struggle is a deep game with a lot of moving parts. The design and mechanics encapsulate the theme very well. Each play is gripping, tense, and stressful. In all my plays, neither side felt as if it was winning; instead both players seemed to be fighting each other to stay afloat. 

(I imagine two brutes fighting each other underwater: if they try to get air too soon, the other will win the fight. If they fight too long, they will both drown.)

It helps to learn the game with someone, because knowing the cards might give an experienced player an advantage.

RATING: 4.8
An important game for Junior high & High school students to play (great way to pick up some history). Order of card play can be very involved, which if a player takes time to consider all the possibilities, can lengthen play time considerably.  Lots of things to remember to do.  Not a casual game.

If I were a teacher I would rate this game a 10.  However, I am an unlucky gamer.  Even though we have only one die apiece, it is heavily a dice game.  Throughout the entire game he rolled 5 &6's, while I rolled 1's.  I did well on the science track which takes a low roll but every intervention and 90% of the coups.  Also, as a gamer I don't like the down time of reading these great educational cards.  So considering it's downtime in card reading and resulting lengthy playing time and the heavy use of dice, I give it a low score.

RATING: 10
Note:  I pre-ordered the latest version to get the mounted map and it looks fantastic.  It looks better in person than in photos, you will be happy if you pick it up!


Bottom line:  It's a CDG that's easy to get into.  The more you know the cards, the better it gets.

 Great game... Lots of dramatic events happening all over the map and you have to manage your hand of cards as well as possible to make the events unfold in a favorable way.  You're always trying to put a positive spin on really bad news.  I like it more the more I play it and love it's model of the cold war in Europe and the Third World.  Lot's of neat cards and cool ideas in this game. It's a slice of history that relates to my life.  My rating for this games wanders from and 8 to a 10 at times- who knows?  It's very good.  With more plays it's getting faster, I like it best in two hours.  A great intro to card driven wargames.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
In most respects, I should not like this game.  Until you learn the cards, there's wild swings in luck and I suspect there will still be once I really get them down.  This can be a bit frustrating.  

Still, I think it's precisely that each hand can be so huge that I love this game.  In the long run, stuff generally evens out, but sometimes all you need is for things to go your way a couple times in a row.  It can be so critical that you grab just one more country before you have to play a scoring card and maybe you gamble on some realignments or coups, success or not, you'll remember the card you played there.  

Maybe that's another reason I love it.  The events in this are familiar and interesting.  Playing a card like NATO or Fidel Castro actually has some meaning to me.  I don't have a clue about 90% of the events in a game like 1960 and all the cards just seem the same. 

I also love the bluffing aspect of this game.  It's a bit of back and forth when the opponent assumes you have a scoring card, so it's big if you can get them to fight you in a region where you're going to score points with another method.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Everything they say about it is true!  A tense and exciting 2P game that my wife also loves.  However, the playing length somewhat limits its table-time, and we play without the 'Wargames' card...

(2nd ed.)
============================

Same great game, with a few additional cards, hard-mounted board, and a few new rules regarding the China card.
My only quibble with it is the incoherent design choices made in this third opportunity to refine the original map.  A coffee-pot stain on Canada; rippling 3-D flag photoshopped over the U.S.; mismatched graphical design of the various status tracks.  It's not that I'm a graphic designer, or that the map elements have been changed from their original implementation, but the lack of unity between the mismatched graphical elements strikes me as odd given that this is effectively the fourth edition of the game.
Still the same great gameplay, and graphical changes made to the country boxes and VP track are the distinct improvements one would expect.  Just a shame the new mounted map didn't get a once-over from a professional graphic designer before being rushed off to the printers...

(Deluxe ed.)

RATING: 9
Incredible game but I‚Äôm not sure why it works so well. The game is completely card driven which can mean that the game can stack against you, dumping a bad hand on you whilst your opponent gets an easy ride. I‚Äôve nothing more than a passing interest in the Cold War period. You‚Äôre just playing cards to control territories. It can be chaotic as you‚Äôre not always sure what you‚Äôre planning against ‚Äì THAT card could come out and scupper you entirely. It‚Äôs almost an abstract despite all of this theme on the board and cards.

It shouldn‚Äôt work but it does. It really does.

It‚Äôs the dual use of the cards: for events or op points that make decisions agonising at times. It‚Äôs the timing of the events, particularly the timing of playing your opponents events which really gets you really thinking. It‚Äôs the brinksmanship; the dicing with the DEFCON level in order to exert further control over the board. It‚Äôs the back and forth, tug of war over key countries; the timing of scoring cards, just trying to nip domination of a region at the right time. It‚Äôs the flavour of these real world events that you‚Äôre playing ‚Äì and in my case, had heard about but quite often didn‚Äôt know that much about ‚Äì that really hooks you into the game and makes you want to go away and read up on what was actually going on.

It just works. And its glorious.

RATING: 9
A very immersive game, mid-way between euro and american. An important part of the mechanic could be summarized as: "you don't want to play cards that are good for your opponent but sometimes you need to do so". This really creates a unique crisis-management feeling that really matches the thematic setting. Luck plays an important role, but it can be controlled. The best american-style game out there? I'd say so.

RATING: 9.1
Very easy to pick up, despite the size of the rulebook. Most of it is devoted to explanation of card effects which is kind of just added extra. Simple rules, but a lot of fun. There is a reason this is the top rated board game on the site. It's great. Vying for control of the various regions of the world during the cold war. It can take some time to play, but other times it can end in just 2 turns, but it is tense and exciting throughout.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Twilight Struggle is a tense game. The different winning conditions mean that 'game over' constantly looms on the horizon, and you need to be alert at all times to thwart the plans of the scheming mind on the other side of the iron curtain.

In this struggle luck certainly plays its piece, both in the die rolls and the card draws. With players of different experience levels, however, knowledge of the card deck and how the various events interact is actually a much bigger factor. It is fairly obvious that Twilight Struggle requires repeated plays in order to fully appreciate the complexity and to avoid the most egregious blunders in card play. In this light, the wild swings of fortune might actually be a positive because they are also responsible for much of the interplay variability.

With that out of the way, the game delivers quite beautifully. There is a lot of bluffing and posturing going on in an attempt to outsmart the opposition, and always that nagging fear that everything you do will just play into your adversary's hands. Needless to say, the thematic integration works here.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I want to love this game, but it is mechanically too dry especially considering the theme, and too reliant on rolling/draw/etc. that are left unexplained.

Still, it is bold and sociopolitically intriguing.

Dice luck can be important sometimes since some dice rolls may result decisive.

RATING: 9
jkoy
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A dynamic and engaging area influence game. The leader in an area can change quickly, so players have to be careful not to let one area slip irrecoverably out of control. This game has multiple counts of initiative you have to keep track of, one for each area. The event cards add an element of bluffing: they're strong enough to greatly impact an unprepared player but not too strong to seriously hurt a prepared one. 

I found the roll of dice in this game distressing, sometimes I felt like you could take the space race out. Not to worry though. Moderate players will realize that coups are risky and will use points on them accordingly. A good player will seldom lose the game because of bad dice. If you're about to roll a die you should be really comfortable with it having no result except letting you get rid of a card, and with this game its easy to get comfortable with that. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
