RATING: 5
Just think of this game as Hannibal: Rome vs. Cathrage with all the exciting parts taken out. You have Hannibal's political influence spaces and its card driven design. But you must play your opponent's events along with your ops points. Plus almost all combat is abstracted out. I also don't understand how the scoring points cards reflect reality. In the game, once a scoring card is played, and the scoring calculated, everyone immediately loses interest in a particular continent until the game ends. So, in game terms, the designer is saying that sometime around 1955 everyone lost interest in  Europe? And after sometime in 1968 everyone ignored Asia and only worried about Africa? Nor do I understand what dumping your opponent's events into the Space Race represents, especially in the early war years. Was there a space race in 1947?  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Fun game, takes a commitment to get together to play just this, as it is so long.  Odd that this is the number 1 game on BGG--says more about the raters on BGG than it does about this game.

Have started playing this weekly, with a friend that is at the same level skill wise.  Fascinating game to experience.  Love the recreation of the Cold War, having lived through it.  Would be a great history lesson for the younger folks--teach them why containment was so important, in defeating Communism.

USA wins about 40% of our games.  Can usually get 2, sometimes 3 games done in an afternoon.

RATING: 9
First play was with Dave Shaw (formerly of Avalon Hill) at the WBC. Mr. Gupta stopped by to observe us playing!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Twilight Struggle is a super-interesting game, where you must deploy your influence across the globe, while fending off the terrible events of history and utilizing the good ones.  The Cold War theme is amazingly integrated, using Event texts to change the rules of the game to reflect actual historical events.  To be good at it, you have to know the cards, and historically what is coming up.  Inevitably, I feel that enough bad roles and bad card draws can mean an ultimate loss.  There are ways to mitigate bad luck, but only if your knowledge of the game progression is solid.  I think TS is amazing for its thematic edge while the crushing mechanics (especially towards the Americans early on) makes this game often grueling.  However, TS captures the Cold War feel and the world domination mechanics are neat. It's fun to watch your Superpower spread its influence throughout the world. TS is not my favourite game, but for a wargame / card game it is one of the best. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Haven't got to the late war yet.

- I can see the immense strategic potential of this game.

RATING: 6
I really, really want to like this game and give it an 8. I enjoy the idea behind the game, the expansion of influence, events that let you get around your opponent, and trying to neutralize the danger in your hand. But in 6-7 plays with my brother, the USSR has won a dominating victory every time. No matter how we switched off or how powerful we thought the US's hand was, it turned in to a rout.

We're certainly far from good at TS. But we are fairly experienced board gamers, and we each read several strategy articles about the game to try and get better at the US half of the game. No luck. I give it a 6 simply because of the frustration that we each showed when trying to prove that the US could win. 

Be aware that you'll need to house rule the game to get much out of it.

RATING: 7
A card driven area control game. It is difficult to convince me that this is a wargame.  I contend it is NOT a wargame,  but if it leads people into exploring Hannibal, Wilderness Wars, Paths of Glory, WW2:Barbarossa to Berlin, Shifting Sands, ect. then I am a big supporter of TS.

Plenty of re-playability here. It is fun to learn the card interaction. I think the game will best shine with two experienced players.   Two newbs will feel it is luck of the card draw but as experience builds that will not usually be the case.

RATING: 7
The reason I don't rate Twilight Struggle higher is the same reason I don't play CDGs anymore: to really play the game well, you have to know the deck, otherwise you do things (or fail to do things) because you were caught unawares by a particular card that unravels a whole section of the map.  And to know the deck, it helps to play a few times.  And to play a few times, it helps to have a regular opponent, which I don't have.  This may sound like a personal problem, which should not impugn the game, but this characteristic of CDGs makes me less likely to suggest playing it.

RATING: 10
Admittedly, I am a big history buff and this includes the Cold War, which helps if you get into the theme, but once there, this CDG shines & sets the example for all other CDG's. Easily understood rules, nicely crafted components (Deluxe edition), and a steady tension combine to create a memorable experience. Like many games, it helps if players are somewhat at equal levels, otherwise one player will better usilise the cards coming out. But not many games reach this level, though there are many imitators.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
Review after 20 plays.

Gain influence. Your opponent undoes what you did. Repeat until you are forced to play a card that makes your opponent gain an edge. But don't worry, he will soon be forced to play a similar card to your advantage.

Can't believe that most interesting parts of the game are solved by a 50% odds on a die roll: 50% miss your turn/50% slight change happen. The very next round, the opponent undoes what you did.

You can coup and downgrade DEFCON by 4 times provoking your opponent, when it is his turn to do so he loses. Seems enough to quit this game.

(I could stand up to round 3 against the AI then I lost after it scored an insane amount of points in East Asia. It had 3 countries there, versus my 7. It won. Don't ask me why, I don't care any more)


Those who rated 2+: YOU ALL ARE WRONG.

RATING: 4
I really wanted to like this game.  It has a great theme, and the game mechanics fit the theme really well.  But the fact is, I find it to be both long and frustrating.  The dice rolls and the sets of cards that come up play a large role in determining the outcome.  I typically don't look forward to taking my turn, as it always *feels* like I'm trying to manage a bunch of bad events rather than a bunch of good events... perhaps that makes me a pessimist, but it is my perception nonetheless.

The rules are excellent. The map is graphically pretty good, but given the price I paid I'm really not happy that it takes the form of an unmounted cardboard fold-out.

I don't understand why the feedback on this game is so overwhelmingly positive.

RATING: 9
[Rating moved down from an initial 9;]

Pros: Addictive and fast; Gives great historical flavor while working wonderfully as a game.  

Cons: Upon repeated playings, some of the late war cards seem too powerful, leaving a long well fought game decided by luck too much for my tastes. Play balance issues are still not decided. While some CDG vets claim "it's perfectly balanced", the Ames card, as well as the US need to REALLY know all the cards to avoid a competent Soviet steamroller early on, will leave many finding play balance issues, at least initially.

RATING: 6.5

I love that it's a 2 player game, with obvious staying power, that interests my husband, that's got an authentic theme, and that we'll just probably enjoy more and more as we get more familiar wit the cards and anticipating the game play. I can see this being a pretty regular staple for us. The only drawback is that the game set up is Fragile - meaning, it will not withstand young kids hanging about and grabbing at things and messing with the tiles , so this is a save for after bedtime game, which will limit play somewhat. It will be a great alternative to just watching Netflix, however.

Update: We don't pull it out often enough to become familiar with the cards and get the full flavor of the strategy, so this is still a little dry to me. I would like to get it out more.

RATING: 9.5

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is an excellent game.  My rating stands; it is largely a cardgame in many respects.  It deserves its popularity.  Eurogamers now see the genius and color that the CDG format allows, which is great.  But it still fails to get into the top of my ratings because of the overly emphasized card game aspect but also because I feel that the card management itself is refined but still missing some tension.  Except for early war, you will not see many of the cards more than, maybe twice, which takes some of the "Do I play this now or space race it?" out of the game.  Space racing is very, very frequently the best option because you will never see that event again.  Nevertheless, I've played this game with a friend and if you want to get them into CDGs, this is it.

Really what sets this game apart is that it is so thematic.  It captures its subject, brinkmanship and paranoia, with very few rules.  It is baked into the game.  Deftly done.

Later:

Moved it up quite a bit.  Now that I've really nailed down the cards the games are going the distance and I am enjoying them more.  My comments still stand but I put the rating up to recognize my increased enjoyment.  A game getting better over time is a quality I really value.  This is my go-to 2 player game of choice, many years after I bought it.  I have the collector's edition.

RATING: 6
People are goo-goo about this game, and I love the idea and theme of this one.  When I did get a chance to play this, well, it fell flatter than a GMT thin cardboard playing surface.  I had no idea how dull and lackluster the Cold War was, or how arbitrary the Space Race was.  There are pictures and theme to the cards, but in the end, you are looking for card combos.  Since you pretty much empty your hand each turn, it's more like the cards play you.  There are some interesting aspects to the game, and I really want to play the game again.

Update: Serious kudos to GMT for the Deluxe Edition. They really did a bang up job with it. I can't wait to give this another go now.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A very good two player euroish war game.  Players alternate playing cards that allow them to do ops (e.g. coup attempt, add political influence) exercise an event (e.g. NATO formation) or call for a scoring of a region (e.g. Middle East).  The game has ten turns that are divided amongst the early, mid and late cold war.  Each later period of the war adds in new event cards.  The U.S. has to struggle early but it's a fun struggle and they can catch-up to and surpass Russia in later turns.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Perfect combination of rich, powerful theme with a wonderful, tight and deep gameplay.

You alternate turns playing cards to spend points or activate events. But amongst the cards in your hand, there are opponent's events, which are detrimental to you when you play them (and you'll have to).

Meaningful choices every turn, strategic and tactical thinking, non-predictable situations with preventable results.

A masterpiece.

RATING: 10
I need to play this game more but after my first real play of this, I knew it was all that it was cracked up to be.

It's actually much simpler than I would have thought it to be in terms of rules.  Sometimes I feel like GMT shoots themselves in the foot with their rulebooks.  If you are thinking of getting this game or playing it for the first time, I would highly recommend going to twilightstrategy.com and reading Theory's primer on the game to learn how to play.  MUCH simpler than the rulebook without leaving out many things, and I think it's enough to jump in and just start playing.

I look forward to playing this more with my friend who I learned it with.  Neither of us have played the game well, but still enjoyed it very much.

The hard thing, of course, is that it's two players.  So I generally don't play a 2p game at our game nights, particularly one that is this long, so the only times I've gotten to play it are when we schedule a specific time to play.

RATING: 8
Strong theme works well with the mechanics.  I may eventually raise this score with more plays, but the mechanic of having the opponent's event happen if you use the card for ops points really decreases your available options.  They did a very nice job of simulating the give and take with the military actions so that if one side goes for some the other is really obligated to do so as well. I understand that the lack of options is thematic, but it does detract a little bit from the game, IMO.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Excellent two player strategy game.  The depth of enjoyment of this game only gets deeper the more you play it.  Game can seem a bit overwhelming at first to new players (particularly to those players with euro boardgame experience and little wargame experience), but is very rewarding once you get a couple of plays under your belt.  The true enjoyment of this game really comes from playing enough times that you begin to learn the cards and understand how best to minimize the negative impact of your opponent's event cards.  The Warsaw Pact Formed card, as an example, can have a significant negative impact for the U.S. player if played at the beginning of the game, but that same card can have a disastrous effect if played towards the end of the game.  Learning how and when to best play the various cards and responding to your opponent are the really enjoyable parts of this game.  The depth of this game is amazing and worth the investment in time to play through several games to see if the game suits you.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Mechanically and thematically this game is great. As with all the GMT games that I have seen, the production quality is lower than you'd expect at the price-point and the rules provide a definite learning curve.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Hard to come up with words that haven't already been said about why this game is so great. I still feel a bit reluctant to play it because it seems daunting but it helps that I learned it at the same time as Chris. Strange that I should feel this way because, other than a few minor points regarding realignments and coups, the rules are not that complex. 

I don't know if it's fair or not but I tend to compare TS to Cuba Libre (and by extension the other COIN games I have yet to play) and I feel that TS is the superior game. There is still a fair bit of luck with dice rolling and some devastating cards that can, if they end up in your hand, completely wipe out an opponent's influence/control of a country. However, you know that your opponent is on an equally luck-based footing so it doesn't seem too awful. And if you end up with a card whose event is bad for you, at least you can dictate when it pops, space it, or simply hold it for the game.

I need to own this one!

RATING: 10
Truthfully, this game looked scary at first. After playing one round through though everything made sense and was very easy to continue playing. Loved all the thematic history. I almost took europe! Poland betrayed mother Russia! Barely took it with SE asia. Will play again!
On a side not, unintentionally, I know alot more about the cold war now. I never realized exactly how much this war influenced and exactly how close we actually came to nuclear war.

Another thing, do not ignore Europe newbies! Understand it's importance and the importance of score cards. if you do not attempt to keep even footin in Europe you've effectively lost.

There is a learning curve! Once you get throuhgh one round, itll make more sense to the other player. Everything is beautiful and great about this game, but it got lowered in rank to 9 because im hesitant to bring it out with new people because there is alot of tactics, plus if you played before you have the advantage of knowing the cards

RATING: 8.5
The USSR has an advantage, so it's probably best to bid either influence or VPs for sides.

Coups may be too powerful in Africa/SE Asia (from a game design standpoint - they're probably about right from a historic perspective).

The back-printed counters in the second edition are a major improvement.

Some of the randomness tends to be self-canceling, but the game definitely has potential for a small number of lucky events to determine the outcome.

Some cards' interactions could benefit from better cross-references or clarifications.

RATING: 8.63
Excellent implementation of GMT's card driven system. The game feels tense and makes you second guess your every move constantly. It perfectly fits the cold era theme, and gives a deep and clever understanding of the historical events happening at the time. I do not agree with the card stock used for this game, the gloss cards seem to get damaged easily and are harder to shuffle then standard cards. The board is thick, yet it has a hard time staying flat on the table. Overall the game lets new comers make interesting decision in the first few games, and rewards continuous plays with support to a range of strategies. A great tactical game, would recommend it to anyone with a friend who is willing to sit down for an evening and explore the history of the Cold War.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Since We the People and Hannibal, the cdg-style wargames have gotten increasingly complicated.  I don't like that direction, because I think the brilliant idea of these early games is that you have a very simple game system, and the chrome and complexity and flavor is added by the cards.  Twilight Struggle is the first cdg since Hannibal that has grabbed hold of this simple truth.

I've always preferred the single-deck approach to cdg games (Hannibal, Napoleonic Wars, Wilderness War, We the People, For the People) to the two-deck approach of games like Paths of Glory.  Having a deck for each player might produce a better simulation, but a shared deck for both players creates much more tension.  Twilight Struggle uses a single deck, but with one brilliant innovation.  An opponent's event will happen whenever you use its card for any purpose (with a couple of sneaky exceptions).  This puts you into a constant state of crisis management!  It also means there will be a [i]lot[/i] of events happening.  Gameplay revolves around the card events much more than in any other cdg I've played.

The focus on the events makes for a wild and woolly game full of turnabouts and high drama.  I think that's the perfect atmosphere for a game about the Cold War.  You're walking the razor's edge, with the constant threat of thermonuclear war hanging over your head.  What a game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

deluxe edition.hard mounted board.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Pretty darn good. With card-driven games escalating into ever more complicated forms, it's good to get back to basics and remember what a flavorful, breezy, and competitive experience a simpler CDG can deliver. Once you get your head wrapped around the differences in playing ops points for control versus realignments or coups, and once you understand how the events fire off, this one ticks right along. It's tense, has that wonderful quality of wanting to do everything, but having to choose to do only a few things, and it generates a good narrative.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Most two player games are either simple or pure abstract. I am glad that this one is neither. It has flavor and depth. It's hard to say if both sides are really equal balanced. I feel that in the early war USSR has slightly better cards and has therefore an advantage for an early win but then in the midwar, cards seem to be more favorably for the USA so that they can turn the game to their advantage if they survive long enough. As a player you can influence a lot but still there will be a significant luck factor as cards are drawn and dice are rolled. In my last game USA wasn't even able to send a dog into space and I tried to do so  every round until I lost the game... I love the 2player game ATON, if you know both then you understand why Twilight Struggle itches somehow (because it's heavier) the same sweet spot. So it's mainly for the balancing and the luck factor this game is rated 8 and not 9 by me. Maybe future plays will change the rating.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

One of the best two player games available. Most are either abstract or simple. This one is not. It has flavor and each round difficult decisions to take. USSR is slighty in favor to win, but you can easily fix balancing.

RATING: 9
Wow! This just gets better and better. I love the panoramic scope of this game. Is there a game where a complex period of history is so successfully realised, without being fiddly and overly burdened with shiny chrome exceptions?  There is luck but to be lucky you need to take risks.  In short, this is not for the faint hearted; you and an equally skilled opponent will be engaged in what is, in essence, a 10 round bout of psychological arm wrestling.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Tense, brilliant, thematic, and engaging game full of weighty decisions and plenty of surprises. The game has earned its accolades and ranking here on BGG. A relatively small set of possible actions each turn somehow turns into a desparate struggle where every turn has more drama and excitement than most other board games have from start to finish. What surprised me was how effective the thematic elements are: the card text and graphics cause memories from my childhood to well up, adding an unexpected emotional element to the gameplay experience. The game is actually very easy to learn but it's tough to make a decision, so the game that should take 2 hours will probably take 3. It's highly recommended, however, for boardgamers and historical simulation fans.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.99999
In response to the many challenges to this game's Play Balance and questions about its brilliant and highly innovative but idiosyncratically complex and resultant problematic card interactions many Standard Game advocates have long employed the dubious and comically transparent defense of "There's nothing wrong with the play balance and it will be fixed in next updated-rules-clarification/extensive-errata/additional-At-Start-IPs/Card-Ops-value-adjustment/unbalancing-card-text-and-function-rewrites/optional-but-never-playtested-China-Card-variation/optional-additional-cards (after correcting the cards' glaringly obvious omissions and errors)-originally-offered-for-a-fee-as an-"upgrade"-but-now-included-in-the-latest-version and anyone who says different is a heretical poopyhead!" 
 
Most ad-hoc fixes (of the Second Edition) are of the Static one time pre-start type such as, "Award 2-3 additional At Start IPs to the US" however a die roll of 5 or 6 on a USSR First Action Round Coup of Italy or Iran wipes that out in an instant and that type of fix doesn't adequately address the advantage the USSR enjoys due to some game mechanics along with some other consistency, logic and balance skewing issues. The following suggestions are intended to take a more Dynamic approach which in most cases continually affect the process and are listed in my own personal perceived order of severity. Some of these suggestions are my own and others are cribbed and amended from other TS enthusiasts. As always, the standard caveat, YMMV: 
 
 
1) Issue: Getting a load of Scoring cards at any time but especially in the first three or four turns when every Ops point is crucial can kill your momentum. This effect is compounded by the Third Turn reshuffle; it is entirely possible for one player to be saddled with six scoring cards in the first three hands or for one power to attain early Domination in one area and have it score twice in rapid succession. The problem is of such magnitude that the TS GM at WBC for 2009 implemented a fix that had been considered during playtest which is to remove any played Scoring cards from the Third Turn reshuffle and place them in the Mid War cards added on the Fourth Turn. There is a discussion of this on Consimworld in the TS folder starting on 26 May 2009. The Designers have utterly rejected the validity of this variation stating that the potential for Early War Scoring Card repetition is intentional and playing with any fix for this issue is not playing Twilight Struggle. That unambiguous proclamation would certainly de-legitimize my following proposed fix which is admittedly a little complicated, but if you've played enough TS to see a game fall apart due to the Early War "Three Scoring Cards combined with a couple of 1-2 Ops Cards hand" (or with the 2 Ops cards' value cut in half when combined with your opponent's play of Red Scare/Purge) situation you'll understand the need for some kind of fix. If you don't like my suggestion then find something that works for you. Advice from Standard Game proponents that when this occurs that you can "Just start another game" is jejune at best, sycophantic at worst and despite mocking assertions of statistical unlikelihood it amounts to a tacit admission of the menace this broken mechanic portends; your investment of time, money and effort justifies a more pragmatically constructive response.
 
Fix: A. Distribute the Scoring Cards in a manner similar to the method employed in Alhambra. Shuffle and divide the Early War Cards (less the three Scoring Cards) into six stacks of descending totals: 8, 7, 6, 5, 4, 2. Shuffle one scoring card each in the 7 and 5 stacks and place the third Scoring card under the 2 stack then combine the stacks to make the Draw pile placing the larger stacks on top of each smaller stack. Do the same with the Mid War cards (minus the 4 Mid War Scoring Cards): 9, 8, 7, 6, 5, 4, 3. Shuffle one of the four Mid War Scoring cards into stacks 8, 6 and 4 and place the fourth card at the bottom of the entire stack. For most situations this will release one Scoring card in each of the first four turns.
 
B. Eliminate the Third Turn reshuffle of Early War cards. When the Early War deck is exhausted simply start drawing from the Mid War deck. The re-playable Early War cards will reappear in the reshuffle of Mid and Early War cards which will probably occur on Turn 6 instead of Turn 7.
 
C. Allow a _voluntary_ option for a player holding two or more Scoring Cards at the start of the turn, before Headline Cards are played, to declare the total number of Scoring cards held (not which ones they are) in his/her hand and to then randomly discard Scoring Cards, which are then turned face up as each one is discarded, down to only one Scoring Card which remains concealed and which must be retained. Then replenish the hand by drawing face-down cards to refill the hand (any additional Scoring Card drawn while replenishing must be immediately revealed as such and discarded face up). The discarded Scoring cards do not go into the Played Discard pile but are shuffled into the Draw pile _after_ the replacement cards are drawn. The player using this option is not allowed to hold back a desired Scoring Card by not declaring it while discarding undesired cards (such as originally holding three but declaring only two) above the single Scoring Card required to be retained and if at the end of the turn is found to have had more than the one Scoring Card suffers an automatic loss. 
If the player holding multiple Scoring Cards likes his/her chances to capitalize on those cards he/she is not required to declare them and discard down to one Scoring Card but may instead make the best use of the hand as is.
 
 
2) Issue: Defcon typically hovers at 2-3 caused by first Action Round coups by the USSR and driven by competition for Mil Ops and a desire to prevent one's opponent from couping a vital 1 or 2 Stability BG of yours which facilitates some gamey uses of card combinations which end the game by Defcon loss; In reality most of the Cold War was not spent on the brink of annihilation and when it was at that precipice World Opinion frowned on a Super Power continuing to instigate regional wars and recklessly couping even backwater countries, not just (game defined) "Battleground" countries.

Fix: Each Mil Op in either player's total which is _greater_ than the End of Turn Defcon level causes a VP loss the same way each Mil Op less than the End of Turn Defcon level does. It is possible for both players to exceed Mil Ops and is resolved the way standard rules deal with both players having too few Mil Ops _or_ one player may end the turn with too many Mil Ops while the other may have too few, each is then compared, one for the excess and the other for the deficiency and the greater differential is applied as lost VPs to that player. The only way to avoid losing VPs in relation to Defcon is to exactly equal it in Mil Ops at the end of the turn. For purposes of this rule only do not stop the count of Mil Ops at 5.

Example: A turn ends at Defcon 3; The USSR has 7 Mil Ops and the US has 2 Mil Ops. Per normal rules the US would lose 1 VP for failing to meet Defcon by 1 Mil Op and the USSR would be unaffected because its Mil Ops met or exceeded the end of turn Defcon Level but under this rule the USSR would lose 4 Mil Ops for exceeding the end of turn Defcon status by 4 while the US loses the 1 VP for having less 1 Mil Op thus causing a Net Loss of 3 VPs for USSR.
 
2.5) Issue: The first Action Round is usually spent on a USSR coup to gain Mil Ops and protect Battle Ground countries.
 
Fix: Coup/Counter-coup: Allow the victim of the Coup (in any Action Round) of a BG in an area which normally would have been made ineligible due to Defcon being lowered to be allowed to stage an immediate Counter-coup of the same BG on his/her next Action Round following the first coup. For example: If USSR makes a first Action Round coup of Italy (lowering Defcon to 4) the USA has the option on his Action Round immediately following (unless blocked by Quagmire) to also Coup Italy (not any other European country). Defcon would be lowered to 3 and a Counter-counter-coup by USSR is not permitted. Normal rules providing for loss by lowering Defcon to 1 still apply.

 
3) Issue: Realignments are rarely available for Europe, Asia and Middle East.

Fix: Allow Realignments in any area regardless of Defcon level with a cumulative favourable DRM applied to the non-phasing player of +1 DRM for each Defcon level below what the Standard rules would allow. For example: Realigning a country in Europe when Defcon is at 2 (which is three levels below that which would normally permit Realignments in Europe) would give the non-phasing player +3 DRM in addition to any potential DRMs for controlling adjacent countries or more IPs in the target country. The same situation for a Realignment in Mideast would supply a +1 DRM to the non-phasing player. Thus, you can attempt Realignment anywhere, anytime but you'll want to be sure you have plenty of friends in the neighborhood.


4) Issue: USSR starting with the China card makes it too powerful and is unhistorical since in 1945 when the game purports to begin the Chinese Nationalists and Chinese Communists had not settled who was in control of China. The standard game does not deal with this uncertainty other than to assign the China card to the USSR at start which assumes the historical outcome with no allowance for a difference in the game's change of the flow of history from the At Start point. The designers tacitly acknowledged this game unbalancing mechanism by conjuring up the China Civil War variant with USSR being required to spend 3 Ops points to acquire control of the China card as a fix and game balance option, but this again assumes an outcome favorable only to the USSR. I offer a similar option but with what I consider to be a more coercive trigger.
 
Fix: Neither player starts with the China card but the first Coup/Realignment attempt of any country in Asia delivers the China card face down to that player's opponent available to play next turn with normal rules for use and acquiring the China card thereafter. For Events that reference which player holds China assume US possession if the card has not been put in play due to above requirement.

4.5) Issue: Korean War USSR victory too easy to achieve and again has no outcome beneficial to the US. Employing one fix or another of the USSR Starts with China Card issue may mitigate this but the two are linked.
 
Fix: A. There are two preconditions for this card to played as the Event and thus to trigger the war actually occurring: 1: USSR must control North Korea and 2: The USSR must have possession of the China card. Korean War cannot be played as the Event unless _both_ of these preconditions are met and if either or both conditions are not in effect the card can only be played for Ops and is then placed in the Discard pile. In a standard game both these conditions are in effect At Start but any change of initial control of the China card such as the Designers' or my variation of the Optional China Card Rule necessarily affects this.
 
B. US receives a +1 DRM for control of South Korea (the more the US directly invests the harder it is inclined to fight) the same as the DRMs for control of adjacent countries. This way the US is more likely to seize control of South Korea as soon as possible to tilt the odds in US favour rather than hold off committing IPs that can only bolster USSR control if the USSR wins the Korean War.

Note: The prerequisite of USSR control of North Korea for the war to occur eliminates the unseemly occurrence of US control of North Korea (thus gaining a +1 DRM) when the North invades the South. Been there, done that, got the Campaign Ribbon.


5) Issue: Red Scare/Purge can be a game ender if the same player (especially USSR) gets it twice in the first three turns (and you're not using the No Third Turn Reshuffle fix listed above). This issue was tacitly acknowledged by the Designers by their decision to raise the card's Ops value from 2 to 4 in the Second Edition but this actually exacerbates the problem. A 4 Ops "Scare" increases its likelihood of occurring in a Headline Phase before any possible cancelation by (admittedly unusual) combinations of other Events such as US playing Five Year Plan which could cause USSR to discard Defectors which would immediately occur and thus cancel USSR's Headline play of Red Scare; if Red Scare is a 4 Ops Event it will occur before Five Year Plan or any other 3 Ops US Headline Event can affect it.
 
Fix: Keep it a 2 Ops card as it was in the First Edition and make it an alternating Event. Whoever plays it first as the Event cannot play it as the _Event_ a second time unless and until the other player gets it and chooses to play it as the Event. If playing the Second Edition 4 Ops value it becomes playable again by the first player as an Event when the other player plays it either as the Event _or_ for any Ops purpose other than as a Space Race discard. Use a chit to flip indicating previous use as the Event.
 
 
6) Issue: Losing to "Wargames" on a measly (and fixed) 7 Point spread is a bummer.
 
Fix: A. Make the VPs to be forfeit a weighted variable. After the Event is declared (Defcon still must be at 2) make a 2d6 die roll to determine the number of VPs required to be forfeit thus making it an additional gamble if you're not at least 13 VPs ahead but allowing for a desperation attempt if you're only 3 VPs ahead (or you go even bigger and make it a 3d6 roll).
 
B. Allow cards to be played for Ops to be used to raise Defcon a maximum of 1 Level Per player Action Phase. Ops spent per Action Phase for this use must be at least equal to current Defcon level to raise it to next the level. For instance, if Defcon is currently at 2 then spending 2+ Ops will raise it to Defcon 3. If Defcon is at 4 it costs 4 Ops to raise it to 5. Ops spent for this purpose are per Action Phase and any Ops in excess of those needed to raise the Defcon level do not accumulate from one Action Phase to any later Phase. 
 
This allows a player who fears his/her opponent's imminent play of Wargames to forestall it by raising Defcon to 3 but with the obvious detriment of the loss of impulse. It can also be useful in other rarer situations, with the added peril of affording one's opponent additional Coup/Realignment options if the opponent has any cardplays remaining.

 
7) Issue: Bear Trap/Quagmire bad die rolls are a real drag. (The Designers have declared that the possibility of a lengthy series of 5/6 rolls effectively ending the game is an intentional occurrence and not a design flaw)
 
Fix: A. Allow (after any current aggregate Ops modifications) a -1 DRM to any roll made using a 3 Ops card and a -2 DRM to a 4+ Ops card (assuring extrication). Thus, if you choose to employ minimum resources to solve the problem you may still get stuck for a potentially interminable number of rounds but if, as in the real world, you divert more resources and national attention to the problem you stand a better chance of getting out.
 
B. Add +1 to the Ops value of the discard if the card's Event is exclusive to the phasing player. Thus, a 1 Ops card the Event for which is exclusive to the phasing player can be used to satisfy the minimum requirement for play (after including any aggregate effects such as Red Scare/Purge, Containment or Brezhnev Doctrine).
 
 
8) Issue: Space Race bad die rolls are a real drag. (And incidentally it throws the historic Timeline off since players rarely get to "Eagle/Bear has landed" by the end of the game when it actually occurred in the Mid War time-frame)

Fix: A. Give a cumulative -1 DRM for each failed previous attempt per space on the Space Race Track, starting a fresh count on the next space once successful on the previous space. The -1 DRMs can reach a guaranteed success level.
 
B. Add +1 to the Ops value of the discard if the card's Event is exclusive to the phasing player (after including any aggregate effects such as Red Scare/Purge, Containment or Brezhnev Doctrine).

 
9) Issue: The First and Second Edition Aldritch Ames Event is way overpowered and also potentially delays the game by USSR feet dragging to arrange the revealed US cards. After initially ignoring concerns about this Event in the changes implemented in the Second Edition the Designers finally acknowledged its game wrecking mechanism and attempted to address it in the Third Edition by changing the effects to have the USSR discard one card from the revealed US hand, but this still allows the USSR to dither about card choice. 
 
Fix: Require the US player rather than the USSR player to order the US's revealed hand (including allowing use  by US player of "UN Intervention" as the Event to cancel a USSR Event by indicating its position after the card to which it _may_ be applied, such play to be determined at the time the preceding USSR Event card comes due to be played). After all, Ames may have leaked vital information but he was not a Puppet Master.
 
 
10) Issue: OPEC, the gift that keeps on giving! The potential for OPEC's re-occurrence as a one-way USSR scoring card makes USSR auto victories too easy. A USSR player with OPEC and SALT is a lock.
 
Fix: OPEC is a single occurrence Event and is removed after the Event occurs.
 
 
11) Issue: Decolonization too powerful if it reappears in USSR hand in first three turns.
 
Fix: Essentially fixed by omitting the Third Turn re-shuffle (see above) except it may appear early in the Mid War deck. If it remains bothersome make it (and Colonial Rearguards) one time Events.
 
 
12) Issue: Flower Power ruling by the Designers that even if a listed dual use War Event card is played by the US for Ops (except for Space Race) it still inflicts the 2 VP loss.
 
Fix: Don't do it. The 2 VP loss would still be in effect for any USSR only war Event since the Event is required to occur (except Arab-Israeli War after Camp David) when played for Ops by the US but any dual use War Event card played for Ops should not incur the VP loss.
 
 
13) Issue: USSR first card advantage is devastating to play balance. This will be substantially mitigated if employing the the revised end of turn Mil Ops to Defcon variation.
 
Fix: The player with the Highest Ops Headline Event determines (chooses) initiative that turn; If playing an opponent's Event get +1 to Ops value for this decision only. Dice off ties.
 
 
14) Issue: Your luck sucks!
 
Fix: A. Alternating use of Re-roll chit which permits one re-roll by phasing player only. 
 
B. Allow the Active Player to purchase re-rolls with VPs, First Re-roll costs 1 VP, Second Re-roll costs 2 VPs, Third Re-roll 3 VPs and so on. Once the Re-roll option is declared any previous roll is invalidated and the VP(s) loss is applied before each Re-roll is taken and would cause Auto Loss if applicable.


Season to taste! 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
After 2 1/2 hours we'd only just begun the mid-war and we had to wrap it up.  Though I must say the early-war was very fun.  The best thing about this game is the way Victory Points are scored by the scoring cards.  It means one player will know which zone is being scored and the other one just has to anticipate based on their actions.  I also really like how players have to figure out how to best use the cards in hand for each turn, whether to use Operation Points or events, and how to make your opponents cards have as little impact as possible.  Would love to play this often enough to get the playtime down to the 3 hour mark.
---
2nd play was a "full" game, but ended during turn 5 or 6 when USSR hit the 20 victory point mark mostly by Dominating Europe and Controlling the Middle East.  Stupid space race eating up all my cards...Still a fun game.
---
3rd play was also incomplete.  When am I going to get to play a full game?!?!
We did finish the Mid War, but had to wrap it up due to time before shuffling in the Late War cards.  The USSR spent a lot of its resources trying to Control Europe, but I was able to build Victory points elsewhere while keeping him at bay there.  A very fun game, I just wish it wasn't so long!  Realistically, it's 4 hours for your first few games, and it might drop to 3 after 6 or more plays I'd say.
---
4th play - The US (my brother) conceded just as the late war began because he felt he'd made too many uninformed decisions earlier in the game and knew that his defeat (and soon, dinner) was on the table.  I really like this game, but it's just too long to play the whole way through!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great game, love the way the theme is depicted through the card-driven mechanism.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game re-enacts the struggle of two super powers to gain control over smaller countries during the cold war.
Its main mechanics are somewhat (actually: very) simplistic, but they do the trick of modelling the powers' influence in the regions of the world. The scoring mechanism makes the game somewhat unpredictable, which adds quite a bit of excitement. However, the scoring harbours potential for imbalance, as it is entirely possible that the same player activates scoring repeatedly before the opponent can tip the scales in his favour. 

The main attraction of the game are the flavour titles of the action cards that refer to significant events of the cold war. These historical references save a game whose mechanisms in themselves are rather dull from mediocracy. 

Edit: In my opinion, this game is OK, but does NOT deserve #1 board game by any stretch of the imagination.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

RATING: 9
Lots of fun, highly thematic and offers loads of agonizing decisions.  I wouldn't consider this the deepest strategy game out there due to a high random factor (especially scoring cards), but that very same element forces players to rapidly change their strategy and adapt to uncertain situations.  The trickiest parts of the game seem to be managing the deck for later rounds while keeping your opponent continually off-balance.

RATING: 10
2
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Wow! I mean: wow! This is so fantastic game, I really don't know from where to start.

Theme, even though this is [b]just[/b] a game of card playing and are influence, is ubiquitous, I mean, it's everywhere. Every single card is assigned to a significant event in history, be it assassination of JFK or Karol Wojtyla being elected for a pope. History is exuding from everywhere in this game.

The game itself is very tight, full of bluffing and unexpected swings of fate. Card managing is crucial for efficient play and this is something you won't be able to do until you play few games - you have to predict what your opponent can potentially hold in his hand and be prepared to counter it. Without knowing the cards, you just grop around.

One of best games I've ever played. Highly recommended, if for some reason you haven't given it a try yet.

Winter 2017: random and superficial. There are better games out there.

RATING: 6
NOT A WARGAME!

initial high rating reduced due to card/combo tricks that are not intuitive, and reduce the ability for someone with limited play to compete.  Can you say Aldrich Ames/Lone Gunman?

based on several games were each player knew the deck, the outcome depends on how you roll on the space race, and when scoring cards come out (and who draws them).  managing the rest of your cards is certainly important (and interesting), but it is very easy to lose for reasons beyond your control.

ultimately sold because I didn't enjoy winning because I knew the deck more than my opponent.

RATING: 8.9
The theme and tension in this game are fantastic.

Card driven mechanic works well and the balance of the game feels good for both sides.  There are lots of very tough decisions each round and every single play feels important.

The down side is that it is a very long game for non-war gamers to sit down for.  There is also a severe disadvantage while learning the game that, combined with the length, may scare some away or make it tough to introduce.  

It's fun, but not something that comes out to the table often.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
It is a rare game that I still think about even days after playing. Man, I really blew round 2, or man I really nailed that scoring card in round 4. This is the type of response that this game creates for me.  It really is the ultimate 2 player strategy game. I am generally not a fan of pure strategy games like Chess because you really need players matched at the exact same level to have a thrilling match. This game sprinkles in just enough randomness to make each game entirely different amongst even regular opponents, while adding luck in the way the cards are managed and the dice based elements. It is really a perfect blend, and the theme is is integrated perfectly.

Once you get to know the cards the real fun begins because the game becomes even more strategic and less tactical, while it leans tactical as you are learning. It is possible for new players to at least compete against a mid level player, and a winning strategy can be developed after just a few games if you are willing to learn the cards. For a heavy 2 player game there is nothing I would rather play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The game is a fun game with an interesting theme but there are some serious issues that go along with that detract from my rating of it. 

First, while not super complicated, there is a serious learning curve. This is not just rules, but also learning all the cards and combos. If you do not know the cards you have no chance at have a coherent game or strategy. This is a barrier to play and restricts who you can play with. If you have played a few times and want to play with someone new, the game won't be fun as they have no chance. You need to play with people of approximately equal skill.

Second, luck. I did not think going into this game, given that it is such a heavy game, that luck would be such a pervasive factor in deciding game outcomes. Certainly, card knowledge and smart play are important, luck can be overwhelming. If you draw bad card and your conversely your opponent draws well, you can have almost no chance. Say you get Red Scared twice in the first two shuffles of the deck you almost might as well quit. The luck is further compounded by dice rolls, but this is not nearly as important as card draws since this can be mitigated to a degree by better decision making.

Overall, the game is well made and the components are great, but its just that 1) its hard to get to the table so it would seem most people would be relegated to playing online, and 2) luck plays a tremendous roll in outcomes. It can be quite dissatisfying to invest so much time in a game at the end to feel as if you could have obtained the same outcome just by flipping a coin.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Number 1/2 in BGGs all time rated games - cold war shenanigans as the USA and the USSR duke it out over 44 years of history to see who comes out on top in the struggle of collectivism against capitalism.

Two players only so it's got a lot in common with chess and draughts in planning moves out and reacting to the other player rather than following a formula.  Little complicated to first get your head around but you'll be glad when you do.

The game is probably 75% skill, 25% luck as you need to know to do...something at a certain time.  Repetitive play definitely helps.

Game loses an entire point for a badly written instruction manual.  Can't you people afford editors?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A highly enjoyable game with simple rules supporting a deep game. Players from beginners to experts can enjoy this which is perhaps one of the reasons it is so popular.

If you enjoy a game with agonising decisions and the feeling of tension throughout this is well worth a look.

I have introduced it to about 5 people now and every one enjoyed it and would like to play again. This is the only game in my collection where that has happened.

The only reason it is not a 10 is because there are other longer games I would play given a choice. The short play time of this gets it on the table quite often.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
This game is absurd.  There is nothing to love here, and I can't comprehend the amorous feelings BGG has towards this game.  It has stood the test of time, with over 23,000 reviews so I know that it isn't just "oh some people like it, and some people don't".  This is a nearly universally loved title.

But I abhor it.  It's limited to strictly 2 players, which I thought might be great for playing with my wife.  Turns out its not.  This game is an exercise in futility and frustration.  Spend a card and an action to gain some influence in Europe, only to have the other player undo your action, repeat ad nauseum, until you unwillingly have to play the Europe Scoring card and give your opponent all of the points you were trying to earn.

The game takes forever too, which normally isn't an issue for me (I love Twilight Imperium 3), but for only two players, of which there is zero negotiating or bargaining, or really interaction, taking 180 minutes is unacceptable.

The components are utter garbage, and fiddly.  The game relies entirely too much on luck of the draw or a roll of the dice.  I own the physical version and the Steam version and have played a number of times on both platforms, trying to give this game a fair shot, and understand the hivemind.  But there is nothing fun, inspired, interesting, or engaging about this trash pile of card board.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A really great use of the CDG system and by far the best treatment of the cold war wargamers have.   This is a game thats simple, fast, but pretty deep.  You will not get tired of playing this.  It captures a lot of what makes card driven wargames great without all the rulebook flipping and exception riddled player aids.  Great production values, although the price point is high for only one map and one sheet of counters.  Also, at times an unlucky card draw can get annoying.  This is worse than in other more complex CDGs because in TS, you are often forced to use cards that will benefit your opponent.  Drives me crazy!  There is no worse feeling than drawing a scoring card for an area of the world the other player has locked down, knowing that you are stuck playing it even though it could result in your losing.  The game also has some little balance quirks as many have noted here.  It seems to favor USSR early and the USA late, which results in a net benefit for the soviets.  I don't think its a big enough deal to get excited about.  H:RvC is more balanced.  You can always bid for sides to balance things out.  The game is so simple and well-designed.  A definite for anyone who grew up in the Reagan era.

RATING: 5
Poor: CDG Strategic - Modern - Easy 

Plus:
-Theme
-Cards
-Accessible
-Time
Minus:
-Board
-Counters
-Cards of later decks used less often

The only things that bother me and takes away a point each:
1) The late war cards are not often played while the early war cards keep coming back often.
2) Space track is a casino ride: the luckiest wins
3) First edition map / counters but 2nd edition addressed this.

I immediately purchased the game after a friend introduced it to me. This was a fantastic experience with fast yet deep gameplay. The theme, the cards, the mechanics are very good at first glance.
Burn bad cards on the space programme, undertake a coup attempt before your opponent plays a scoring card, trigger events. A lot to think about and that with only 9 pages of rules This system promises more of these types of games in the future. 

After a while it takes a bit long before you rreach late war although experienced players who know exactly what to do can throw cards quicker than their minds. 

Revisited: don't care much to play this one.

RATING: 10
Power, influence, balance.  What more can you ask for?  This might become a 10 if I play it a few more times.  Alex did win as USA in the 7 turn.  I have won as Russia twice.  It seems if you can not use the event and let it recycle back, you get a higher likely hood of good event cards.

Also, don't forget to coup a lot to get those military points (these can add up against you if you don't pay attention.).

I had this game at a 7 for a long time. However, once the iPad app came out and I played it enough times, the richness of the game came out.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Wonderful system and lovely concept, but too much randomness has made me lower my rating more and more.

The VP track can see tidal changes in a single turn, especially when you get too many scoring cards or your opponent gets some powerful combos such as Red Scare+Blockade, Muslim Revolutions+OPEP, and some others.

Moreover, the first 3-4 turns are completely unbalanced in favour of the USSR. Thus, too many games finish with a Soviet automatic victory in an hour or so.

Finally, it's a game especially tough on newbies. Unless you know all the cards and their interactions by heart, an skilled player is going to wipe you out of the board.

IMHO, the 2nd edition tried to solve some of the above issues but this game still needs some serious redesign to reach its full potential.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3

It deserves a better edition.edit: does not deserve #4 spot I think. The first five or so games were much fun, but it still last long, much too long for what it is. The imbalance becomes more and more blatant, an US win is possible only when luck is on its side.

[url]http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/240085[/url]

update: I do not want to play again; in retrospect, I only like the idea of that game and none of the execution.
It all comes to this: do you like to memorize all the cards in a game?  Many games reward that, and if it is your cup of tea, and if you have a similar-minded partner, and if you do not mind the luck, than maybe you'll like this.  It's not for me anyway.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Rating may be a little low, as I've only played a single game as the US and was literally wiped out by the USSR player by turn #4, and he appeared to do so effortlessly...

It would seem that although we were both new (we were initially coached by a avid fan of the game), he grasped something I did not, which resulted in my demise.  The part I missed was how the cards get recycled back into the deck, and that one is better off not playing his events.  You see, the game is all about doing the right thing at the right time, and preventing your opponent from doing the same.  In order to have a good grasp of this game, one needs to be aware of all the cards, as well as their impact.  I'm pretty sure my rating will go up after I've played this a few more times.

Meaning there is a pre-defined way of playing this, from wich you can deviate only little.

Example: as the USA you need to know that there is a Japan card that gives you Japan on a plate.. otherwise you waste ressources on it. That is just one of many cards you have to know in order to make sound decisions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
(06/08/2014) Comment based on 1 complete and 1 aborted play.

This is a intense card-managment game, with a tightly knit geo-spatial element, that convincingly conveys the Cold War.

On the surface, the simplicity of expanding influence on the global map through operational points on dealt cards makes this game feel seemingly trivial. However, each card also has an actual Cold War event that can be triggered if the active player chooses, if the card is favorable to them, or acted upon by the passive player, if it is not. The card deck is divided into three periods of the Cold War, with a number of turns within each. Cards can be played for operation points (to get influence onto the board), which can potentially be recycled to be played later, or played for the effect of the event, where the card is permanently removed from the game.

Each player will be dealt a hand of cards, of which some will be favorable or unfavorable to that player. That is, the Soviet player has cards that are good for them, and likewise for the U.S. player. At some point in the turn, the Soviet or U.S. player will be forced to play a card that triggers an event favorable to the other side. The game then becomes a matter of setting up the board to mitigate the event, or timing the play to lessen the effectiveness. Additionally, one card could be discarded to make a random roll attempt at progressing in the space race.

More cards from the middle and late periods will come into play eventually, and the players will continually need to do "damage control", as the balance of power shifts back-and-forth on the global map. As such, actual events will be triggered, altering the game state substantially, although they may not necessarily come out in chronologically accurate order. Nevertheless, the feel of the period is conveyed nicely through events, equally dishing out jubilation and frustration for the players.

When distilled to the basics, one cannot help but feel this is a game of card-driven "pissing contests" all over the map. If the Soviet player grows influence in an area of the world, the U.S. player needs to react, and vice-versa, otherwise a potentially devastating scoring action card may occur, a number of which are randomly seeded throughout the deck. In retrospect, the Cold War was essentially a game of cat-and-mouse, and of tempo, much like Go. In that, the design succeeds providing lots of tension and as a historical simulation, but as a game, I found it somewhat boring because I could see right through the theme and see the rather unsophisticated game mechanisms underneath. Still, it was interesting to see how historical events sort of appeared chronologically, while allowing the players enough freedom to experience completely unthinkable alternate histories. Perhaps, if I was willing to let myself get lost in the theme, I would enjoy it more. Initial rating: "7", with room to move up.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
If any game I own deserves a ten it is this one. This game keeps you engaged and on edge through the entire game.It has near perfect amounts of complexity, strategy and luck. What I mean is it is just as complex as it needs to be, has just the right amount of luck factor to keep it interesting, but the luck is mitigated by good tactical decisions and strategy as well as knowledge of the game. This truly is a game you can play over and over and try different things each time. You can grow with this game and you find yourself wanting to come back again and again.

RATING: 2
My first play of this game was a mildly unpleasant experience leavened somewhat by winning big. My head was spinning due to unfamiliarity with every aspect, including, sad to say, much of the history. 

A very clever, well designed and produced game that deserves its many accolades, but is far from my preferences.  I detest the prospect of the learning curve against my likely opponents' honed skills; an issue I have with all CDGs, which by their very nature require deck-specific knowledge.

RATING: 10
This is the best game I've ever played!!

It may not a be a love at first sight. I bought it and it spent like two months on the shelf without being played. Then I discovered www.twilightstrategy.com and I started getting into it. Since then I taught many friends not only the rules but, most importantly, the strategy basics. Since then we organized between us leagues and championships and our love for the game started to grow stronger with every play. We even have like a top ten highlights and love to watch the games we don't play to learn from our opponents and see how they play! I won't ever forget games like the one were I was a bit behind on the score and strategic situation but then, outguessing my opponent, I put it against the ropes with a single move perfectly timed!!! 

If you are a heavy strategy or power gamer and you like to master games untill you beat every single opponent using different and clever strategies and also identifying those of your opponents, trying not to fall into their traps by knowing the game better than them and all that, give this a try. You may have to spend some time but, for me, is definitely worth the effort. If you are lucky to have some kind of mentor give him the opportunity to teach you and maybe, some day, the student will beat the master.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

With 2nd Edition setup and card tweaks, it is a much closer game now.

RATING: 1

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I realize I'm in the minority on this game. (I also don't think it is a wargame.) I think it is competent with some nifty mechanics (especially how playing cards triggers your opponent's events) but the theme isn't terribly appealing to me. Too often the game ends in mid-war. Knowing every card in the game by heart is crucial to half-decent play, leading to lots of "gotcha" moments that destroy your hour of careful planning. The realignment mechanic seems poorly integrated -- in my plays it has hardly ever happened.

And, like virtually all CDGs, the historical event deck leads to totally ahistoric play. I've never understood why CDGs and their fans think that is The One True Way(tm). "You can't have made up events!" But having Japan fall to the Communists in 1955 or Cuba taken by the Americans in the 1970s is totally okay. Make up your mind whether you want slavish devotion to historical re-enactment or a fun game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Close fight for best CDG with Labyrinth: The War on Terror.

RATING: 7.7
I enjoy this, but I think it is overrated.  Like all card driven games, the learning curve is steep.  Like all historical games, it works best when you're interested in the theme.  It is possible for the card draw to leave you at a significant disadvantage, but many argue that the game is designed to make it feel like that.  Despite this, the area control mechanics are very good and suit the theme well.  Some games can go on *way* too long.  Twilight Struggle is definitely an "experience" game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This sat on my shelf for almost a year, as I had no one among my constellation of gamers who would play with me. Finally deciding to set it up and play solo. While it doesn't really "work" as a solo game, in that the secrecy factor is a significant part of the game, I can say the experience was simply fantastic. What a deep, meaningful, educational, rewarding and fun experience!  My deepest worry was that a whole bunch of fiddly rules and constant rulebook exploration would mar the experience. This is not the case. The game is straightforward, and rules are very clean and easy to master. The tough part is in the strategic game play itself, and employing events to your advantage - optimizing your superpower's benefits while minimizing damage of events not in your favor. This is, simply, the best game I have ever played, bar none.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is the CDG that non-wargamers can be persuaded to play. Mechanically simple, the selling point is really the atmosphere generated by the superb choice of events: Missile Envy, How I Learned to Stop Worrying, etc., but they constantly generate lasting effects that are easy to forget when involved in the action.
The weakness of the design is the combination of a single draw deck with the opponent's-event-happens-anyway mechanism that makes the whole game massively random and swingy, especially so given the random timing of the scoring cards. Playing time is also an issue, this runs much closer to 5 hours than 3 if it lasts the full 10 turns and one side doesn't get an early blowout win.
That issue of balance is a bigger problem than it ought to be. Too many games are one-sided leaving a player to chase the game for turn after turn if the run of cards goes in the other's favour, indeed the WarGames card seems specifically designed to end such misery a turn or two early. Maybe one game in ten is close enough to go to final scoring.
So ultimately, this game is a triumph of theme over randomness. It's like a ride on the fairground dodgems: you get the illusion of control and enjoy the thrill, but where you go is almost completely unpredictable. History/politics/conflict is my favourite gaming theme and I really, really want to like this, but I keep my copy solely for those occasions when I feel like something lighter in a CDG and don't want to think too hard. In the final analysis this is a narrative game (albeit a good one) and there's no point in feeling disappointed about losing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
An overly complicated rulebook hiding a fairly simple game at heart.  Always leaves me wanting to play again and the random card distribution ensures that each game is different - although the same events will always come up, just not in the same order.  If you remember the time, the cards are very evocative of the major events, and if not, the game gives a good idea of the ideological Cold War fought on a global scale in the latter half of the 20th Century.

It's not a wargame, but it is a propaganda battle with the future of the world at stake.

Remember to win not with a bang, but with a whimper.

RATING: 9
The only thing keeping it from a 10 is the dice rolls: there are few enough of them that a bad run of luck (for example, on the Space Race) can have a disproportionate effect on the game.

PbeM suitability: very high, although in some ways the level of automation in the Vassal module is actually a barrier to efficient play (e.g. the need for each side to activate its own headline event, even when there's no actual decision to be made as to their effects). I guarantee someone will forget to advance the turn marker at some point.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Historical strategy game about the Cold War.  Not really a wargame, although some will call it that.  Simple game with amazing depth, excellent historical narrative, and outstanding gameplay.  Most historical games either fail to deliver a strong narrative or suffer in gameplay (if not both), but Twilight Struggle nails both.  Gameplay moves quickly while offering numerous decision points that have at least some connection with history.  The Cold War really comes alive when playing this game.  Even when winning the game, a player can at times feel like the whole world is about to collapse.  Gameplay is derived from the We the People system, but the military units are abstracted out.  I avoided this game at first thinking that this would not work, but I was very, very, wrong.  There are still plenty of choices, like placing influence (foreign aid, improving relations, and such), attempting coups to overthrow hostile governments, and playing event cards, which cover almost all of the major events of the period, including the hot wars.  Minor imperfections include a bit too much randomness, some of which seems unnecessary.  (The worst offender here is the die roll on the space race track.  I'm not sure what this brings to the table other than making a moon landing nearly impossible, which damages the historical narrative of this particular mechanic.)  I'm also not excited about the gaminess of the deck management, where players may delay playing historical events to keep favorable cards in the deck (shades of Paths of Glory here).  Still, these are minor concerns and easily rectified by house rules by those seeking a bit stronger historical narrative.  One of the finest historical strategy games ever made.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I have now played it a few more times and I have to say that I love the game.  It gives a great feel of the cold war, with the events, having to react to the opponent with out knowing exactly what they are doing, etc.

It is a game that I think about for hours after I play, which is a sign of a great game.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very strong strategic game, theme is also well integrated and historically informative. My major criticism is that it is not something you can introduce to someone new, it will take them many games to catch up and the whole time you will destroy them. So if you want to own this game, make sure you have a partner in mind that is your strategic equal and plan to play it lots.

RATING: 8

RATING: 3
So after hearing about the rave reviews and hype pretty much everywhere, I reluctantly gave into a game.  I'm a bit sorry I did, because what a BORING mess of a game Twilight Struggle turned out to be.  If you like card driven games about adding numbers systematically to a flow chart in the guise of a cold war themed "wargame," then look no further.  Area control has been done much, much better elsewhere and with twenty times the level of engagement and excitement.  I think this game was designed too much by the numbers and suffers for it.  I'm actually pretty shocked by how well it's been recieved and wonder just how in the minority I'm in.  I would have to be seriously talked into another game before I gave it a second chance.  The theme can't be that compelling to overlook the serious flaws in this game, can it?

I looked up boring in my Thesaurus and found the synonyms to fit my exact diagnosis perfectly.  Here they are in their entirety: uninteresting, dull, tedious, dreary, lackluster, monotonous, mind-numbing, tiresome, unexciting.

Maybe I was a bit too harsh...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Highly interactive game of tempo management. The parts that aren't about tempo management seem to be based around exploiting your knowledge of the card decks to build board states that will either add or subtract effectiveness from different events.

Conceptually, I love the game. It manages to feel historical by having callbacks to the big turning points of the war, without letting it devolve into flag waving for either bloc. Both sides come out looking like massive conglomerations of manipulative sociopaths. You will stage coups in countries whose names you can barely pronounce, purely because your opponent went there, and now you need to go there too.

I'm less than sold on the amount of random chance in the game. I like that each side will have hands that are awkward, and I also like that you can take some hits early on to sculpt the deck more to your liking in later stages. That said, some swings can end up robbing the game of tension, rather than adding to it. Specifically, I feel like one person getting significantly more scoring cards in hand can be a pretty big disadvantage. Yes, you gain some utility in being able to control when the scoring takes place, but if you get a hand with two or three scoring cards in the mid-war period, it can feel pretty horrific.

I have about 8-10 other games of this that I didn't log. I generally play with 2 extra influence to the US at game start, and optional cards added.

Sleeved in Dragon Shield Clears.

RATING: 6

It's a fun enough game but simulates Cold War power politics about as well as Agricola simulates farming, i.e. not at all.

RATING: 8.5
Brilliant game concept and design.  My sense after one game is that you need to put in a few plays to learn the cards (and some of the special situations that could be exploited by particular cards).  Once you learn what the game can do (and have an opponent who also has equivalent exposure), this game could have legs for a really long time.

The designer's ability to capture actual historical events and have them unfold at relatively appropriate times conveys a wonderful sense of the real Cold War.

RATING: 8.5

Maybe I'll become as excited as so many have been about Twilight Struggle after more plays; but it's hard to get this one to the table to be honest.

RATING: 7

Time ticked on rather than quickly passing by because of its immersive quality. While I can appreciate the design, I don't think I would want to play the game again which determines my low rating.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
This feels like a wargame, but one that may be very accessible to eurogamesrs because it plays like an area influence game.  It features a playing time of 3-4 hours for experienced players (faster if there is an early winner) and low rules overhead.  Game play is fluid and tense with the advantage swinging from side to side throughout the game.  The theme is excellently implemented and feels fresh in that there are only a few other games out there about the cold war.  The game is a bit luck dependent (for example, if one player draws the majority of the scoring cards, they control when the majority of scoring occurs, and this is a major advantage).  (I own the collectors edition plus an older edition.  I bumped .5 for the collector's edition version)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
I like some wargames, but I pretty much consider myself a eurogamer, and one of the things I love about Twilight Struggle is the elegance of the game's rules and flow. But mostly I just love, love, love the theme, and the way it is shows in the tension that you feel throughout the game. 

I rated this a 10 for years, but lowered it to a 9 after realizing that over-familiarity with the game (due largely to playing online) was taking away some of the fun; keeping track of what's been played gives a major advantage but reduces the element of surprise, which is one of the things I like about the game. The good news is that after taking some time away from the game and coming back to it, it's feeling kinda new again.

RATING: 10
Twilight Struggle has, without doubt, a great theme. It also has some very interesting and, it seems to me, original mechanics. The games I have played have been great fun thanks, in particular, to the cards which do a fine job of integrating the theme with the game itself. I have not seen any evidence of a balance problem between the USSR and USA. There may be an issue of balance between game length and the impact of chance, but even after several plays I can't say that it has been a problem. Anyway, Twilight Struggle occupies a previously empty niche in the boardgaming world or, at the very least, in my game collection. As such it has and will continue to receive some considerable attention from me.

The dice are a killer though, and on rare occasion can ruin a game.  The fact that I am giving a game with dice a rating this high is a huge testament to the quality of this game. RATING: 10
This one has taken me a few games to start realizing how to play it.  It is so well done that after playing and losing very badly, I bought a copy for myself 10 minutes later.  It is a dry-er game and only being 2 players, it will not be brought out in group sessions at all.  Overall, I still want to play it right now though!

The only problem with the game is one of its strengths (the cards).  One game I played my opponent had 7 points.  The next turn he drew 2 scoring cards, 4 of my events and 2 low ops cards for himself.  That turn I was able to score 14 points and never looked back.  The game can be over by turn 3 (I lost in the headline phase of turn 3 once) or go the distance of 10 rounds (with victory in grasps of both players).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My first foray into the CDG genre, this game was a very pleasant surprise that my non-wargaming wife even liked.  The cold war history is interesting and the game presents you with a number of difficult choices.  Those seeking the breakout of a "hot" war need not apply.  The game even elegantly incorporates the fear of mutually assured destruction by limiting players aggressive actions with a DEFCON track.  This tends to push players towards a more historic balancing act rather than the all-out nuclear struggle that often erupts in other wargames covering the period.


new 2/06
