RATING: 10
Destriparlo en 2018
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Print and play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
For me, this is one the top 3 or 4 two-players game. It has it all: complexity, asymmetric game, conquest, back and forth mechanic, highly thematic and, the one thing that I most enjoy, the fact that, throughout the game, you are going to play many cards that are going to trigger enemy's events that are going to be extremely painful for your interests but, no matter what, you need to play them. Let's sacrifice Africa for the greater good of Southeastern Asia. Amazing.
The game is the cold war in a box. That's it. I would say that it has every major event that happened during those years: from space race, to revolts, to particular war events to main characters that had major roles.
Positive:
1. How thematic it is
2. What do you have so sacrifice in order to achieve some benefit
3. The action-reaction structure of the game: if we fight for Europe let's put everything there, but if I go now to Asia you should be consider expanding your forces over the map
Negative:
1. Requires playing some games until you are really competitive. There are many cards that you need to know that exist on the deck and in which phase will appear (early, mid or late war)
2. Early war is mainly favorable to URSS player, if the American player does not know how to survive those years, the game may not get to Mid war
3. The tablet version works so well that it may replace the board version
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Mind-blowing...

Great mechanics, great climate, great emotions...

EDIT: After 20+ plays some issues start to bother me:
- cards with useless events - always played for VPs and (almost) never as events

Still, a very good game.

RATING: 10
This game totally deserves the accolades it receives.  Twilight Struggle was easy to pick up as a person who doesn't play war games but immediately I was overwhelmed by the breadth of options gameplay provides.  This is a game that requires knowledge of every card.  It seems chaotic at first but there's an internal logic that allows expert players to predict upcoming cards.  This is a fine, fine game and the only negative point is that I'm just not a wargamer at heart.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I love card and card driven games so I am already biased here. That aside, I do think this is a very well put together fun game but it might not quite reach top tier for me simply due to the amount of luck vs. time factor, maybe though, its close for sure. 

The luck in the space race really doesn't bother me (unlike some people) and seems to even out over the course of a game, really this is a dumping zone anyway and I find not critical to winning. The luck in the cards really doesn't bother me either as it is fun and agonizing trying to mitigate it through various ways which is more than possible, you can usually always find ways to slither out of trouble even with some pretty bad hands.  

The luck that DOES bother me is in the realignnment and coup rolls which can be quite important to winning, you could have things largely in your favour especially with a coup and then roll a lousy 1, this can happen a few times and it really sucks and brings back bad memories of things like A&A (also there isnt a lot of rolling here which is good but it also doesnt give the luck a chance to even out). These can be really important moves in the game with the timing of it as well so failing due to a few dice rolls in a 3 hour strategy game kinda stinks, I know my rating would be higher probably a 9 or even more less this one aspect. I might be looking at different ways to resolve these and if anyone has any good tried ideas please send me a geekmail.  

Other than this the theme is so well implemented and interesting, your strategic juices certainly get flowing and it is quite tense thoughout as you wonder what your opponent is up to and what scoring card he might have.  It can be tricky to be subtle but it is somewhat possible with some slight bluffing.  

One other note, I like the idea of bidding to be the USSR player, ie "I'll be USSR and give you 2 VP's", then your opponent must accept or go higher at say 3 VP's until someone accepts to be USA. It seems things are slanted a little too much in Russia's favour. 

[u]Update:[/u] I have some great ideas how to tweak the dice rolling, some I got from here like using the CC:E initiative card to re-roll but note for this I would say only to re-roll and NOT to make your opponent re-roll (to avoid too much back and forth). Also, can only be used for Coup and maybe Re-alignment, still need to test this and I have some others too.  

At any rate I am confident I can mitigate the luck factor of the dice 'just a little' and for me this will likely be rated a 9 with the dice aspect weakened (not removed). I really like the game but felt the dice were a little too important considering how strategic the rest of the game is, now I should be able to enjoy it to its fullest. On another note, after playing quite a few other wargames I realize how the luck here is pretty low in comparison! Give me card draws over dice anyday, really starting to hate dice.... :P

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Tense, simple but rich core mechanics, lots of variety from the events, epic clash between America and the Soviets, history come to life, stressful situations, never no whats coming, down to the last turn gameplay... what is not to like?

RATING: 10
Absolutely blown away by the design of this game. The rules are very light for a "wargame" and there is a lot of tension in every decision you make. The game is essentially an exercise in tug of war between 2 players to dominate the right regions in the right time. Most of these cards outmaneuver one another. The only con that I can think of is the long playtime when new players are involved (cards reading and what not). I hope they continue to develop this game in the future.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.8
In Twilight Struggle, players represent either the U.S.A or the U.S.S.R. during the Cold War. Each player attempts to spread his or her country's influence in key geopolitical regions throughout the world.  The game play consists of players using their hand of cards to stage coups, politically realign regions, increase their country's influence and/or trigger historical events, which may alter the balance in their favor or their opponents favor.  The action-point/event card mechanic creates tremendous tension, as you inevitably have to play a few cards each round that benefit your opponent.  The event cards really immerse the player's in the theme.  

This game is spectacular.

Weighted Rating: 9.8 (Fun 10; Gameplay 10; Components 9; Theme 10)
Formula:
[Weighted rating = (((Fun*4) + (Gameplay*3) + (Components *2) + (Theme *1))/10)]

RATING: 9.95
Keeper
An epic game for two players. After having only played one game, I had to pick this up when I saw it on sale. I do not regret my purchase.

Not many games can I say that I have won only once in 10 or more plays, but that hasn't put me off of Twilight Struggle. On the contrary, I feel challenged every time I play. I like to review my play in my mind after a game and think how I could have done things differently or seen an opening I had left for my opponent.

One of my top 5 games and I do not see it falling from there anytime soon.

RATING: 6.5
I want to like this game more than I do.  I really love the theme.  I enjoy the back/forth area control chess match... But I fervently believe the game is unbalanced in the Russian favor.  I've got double digit plays and have never seen a US victory.  Before you start shouting that I haven't done my 'homework' on US strategy, it's not true.  I have.  I've read ALL the threads, suggestions, and tips for playing the US.  I know them, I know what "not" to do, and the Russians still win every time.  I think you need to either 1)get a little lucky as the US or 2)play a Russian player who makes mistakes.  The game is SO heavily favored towards the USSR that autovictories in the first 5 turns are not uncommon.  I believe that the US can win, I just don't think the US can survive any bad luck... be it card draw (early Europe scoring is bad), or dice, or whatever.  Perhaps a bidding mechanic can bring it back into line.  A recent thread on consim noted a tourney where the USSR victories were a bit over 2:1 vs US victories among experienced players.  I'd wager that tally gets worse in the Russian favor if either side is not so experienced (not playing 'optimally' as the US).  Regardless, I think there's a wonderful game inside here, I'm just tired of trying to create a US victory.

HCTR
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Everything everyone else who gave this a 9 or a 10 already said...

If it weren't for the card learning curve, I'd give this a 10. You need to know what each one does and when they occur. Also, the playing time is just a tad too long, but I don't know any way around that without degrading the game.

Edit after playing a lot more: Yes, I get that there's skill--the better player will win most of the time-- but there are critical rolls of the die at certain points that swing this too much to the ameritrash for my liking. Probability still means a percentage chance, yeah? Momentum is hard to fight. Watching your opponent waltz down the space race track, while you don't move. Botching a key coup. Blowing three alignment rolls in your favor. Watching your opponent roll a 6 for his coup and then getting shut out of a region you would have had easily if he had rolled a 1. Each thing by itself is likely recoverable, but a series of them to a player of your own skill level or better not so much.  So even if the luck "balances" out, it may do so after it doesn't matter.

And conversely it doesn't feel gratifying getting too much luck either. 

Even some of the best players have made comments here such as "luck is king". So you have to know how much luck you can tolerate.

The cards have about the right amount of luck and hand management, although you can look down at a disastrous deal just as you needed a good one most.

Again, I'm not arguing this game isn't heavily skilled. It is. And I rate it a 7. I like it when the luck is even.

If you have a high frustration tolerance, you will love this game. If you don't, you'll still be ok if the dice are fairly balanced. If you think die rolls = tension, you will love this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
An absolutely great instant classic.  Can be a tad unbalanced (55% to 45% for USSR), but that's historical (and correctable with an experienced US player and/or bidding for sides). =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
There is so much to like about Twilight Struggle, but what keeps me from having loving it is the amount of luck it introduces in the form of card draws and dice rolls. While the mechanic of having to play cards to help your opponent is riveting, the random card draws that determine who has to deal with this and how much skew the game. The same goes for the random draw of who gets scoring cards. More critically, the use of dice in this game makes no sense. It's frustrating to watch a strategy fall apart because an opponent rolled a certain way. Twilight Struggle is certainly a fierce game of tug-of-war, but the inclusion of such a strong degree of luck makes it a hard sell as potentially three-hour game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
Ah, what a game. Growing tension. Careful contemplation as you formulate a strategy for dominating the map segment by segment and getting control of the right countries at the right time. The two and fro as you dominate a continent and then your opponent dominates another that you've probably neglected somewhat because your attention has been else where. It all keeps this one carefully balanced on a knife edge all the way through. The whole thing is wrapped in a rich and detailed theme that pulled a total novice like me into the history surrounding the events of the cold war. Someone really knew their stuff here and it shows. I rarely get an opportunity to play a 3 hour game of this but when I do it never disappoints.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Low-complexity card-driven wargame / euro'ish area-control game on the Cold War. Components are the usual GMT quality (which isn't really saying a lot), and there's about a page worth of errata (not clarifications, mind you!) already, including some really embarrasing ones. Despite this, the game looks cool and I am very eager to give it a try.

I have generally shaken my head in frustration at the direction the card-driven line of games was going since my all-time favorite wargame, Hannibal: Generally longer, fiddlier and more complex from one game to the next. However, Twilight Struggle is definitely breaking that trend, and for that I am very grateful.

I have now tried the game once and my first impression is "nice". Not the best game I've tried, but certainly entertaining. Our game clocked in a 4¬Ω hours, but we might be able to shave about an hour off that with experience. After reading the rules, the game felt like it would be very abstract and area-control'ish, but in reality the theme felt rock solid and the game came across as much more of a regular wargame than I would have thought.

My rating is of course extremely preliminary, but I can easily see it going up if the game holds up well to a few more plays.
----
Update: 8 years later. :-) The game still holds up fine, and the GMT deluxe edition is very, very nice...!

RATING: 6

Initial Rating: 6.0 (April 2011)

I really don't get the hype on this. I think it is a good game but it¬¥s not Top 1 material. I believe both opponents have to have around the same skill level to really enjoy the game. Also there is a medium/high randomness in the cards that can bother some people.

The components are rather low quality.

I want to give it another chance to reevaluate my rating.

I want to play again but for now I prefer to play 1960: The making of a President than this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I grew up addicted to Balance of Power on my Apple II.  Twilight Struggle is a perfect application of a CDWG mechanic to a political balance of power game.  Every game seems to feature tension you could cut with a knife from turn one.  The application of opponents events on your card plays is brillant and creates the damned if you/damned if don't mentality through the whole game.  Its a series of constant tactical choices and bluffing/counterbluff.  If you have any interest in the politics of the period, don't hesitate to grab it.  Its simple to grasp but replayability only suffers with difference in player experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I have played several games and it can get very intersting if you play with someone more than once.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
If this could be played consistently in under 2 hours, it would be a 9 or 10 for me. I enjoy the game, but it lasts just a little longer than I want it to last.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A game to be experienced, an oh-my-god-I'm-about-to-get-nuked thrill ride.  Slight luck issue with the cards, though skillful play can mitigate this to a great degree.  Space race rolls can be a worse problem -- need to play more games for those to even out.  (12/2008:  I'm convinced this isn't as much of a problem as I had thought due to the value of being able to discard 2-ops cards at lower levels on the Space Race track.)

For me this game's strength is its incredible complexity.  There are so many hot spots to manage on the world map.  Playing with experienced players the game takes on chess-like qualities.  Unfortunately I may have settled into a skill level at which I destroy newbies but lack the patience to maneuver with skilled players and suffer very frustrating defeats.

RATING: 8
Very cool. A coldwar game. With more play it may become a favorite. 

Not a heavy wargame, not even a wargame in truth, but it definitely simulates the competition for influence and ideological ways of life on the world scale. This game may have to much randomness for some players, but I think it makes a very dynamic game and gives the events a lot of flow and dynamism.

I have always been interested in spy novels, the cold war, and the history of these events. This game has kind of given me an overarching view of the whole thing. I'm a child of the late cold war and some of these events really sunk home in me and made me think WW3 was coming.

I like this one a lot right now and really wish to play it more.

RATING: 10
In my opinion, the best game ever designed (yet). A tense, engrossing 2-player game that keeps you immersed in it throughout. Played 9 games in 2 weeks, that's how good it is (for a 2-4 hour game). Games are usually unpredictable and "struggling" uphill against a stronger opponent is quite an experience. Requires some experience and knowledge of the cards in order to play a "proper" game. May look complex, but is really quite simple once you start playing it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Simplest of the card driven games - no armies to worry about, just political influence which is handled in an area control manner, which seems to have broadened the audience beyind traditional wargamers - lucky GMT! 

Reasonably short playing time for the genre, but still longer than most Euros.

Like most CDGs deck knowledge is useful (don't expect to win your first game against an experienced player), but very absorbing with a lot of tricky decisions and a great sense of history. A lot of fun - I like it.

RATING: 10
Simplest of the card driven games - no armies to worry about, just political influence which is handled in an area control manner, which seems to have broadened the audience beyind traditional wargamers - lucky GMT! 

Reasonably short playing time for the genre, but still longer than most Euros.

RATING: 7
When I want to play a two player game and I have the time, this is my choice. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I really like the way this game feels. You do get into the theme, USSR vs USA. The events on the cards add meaning to what you're doing. The Korean war doesn't just feel like you're adding or taking away numbers. It feels like a battle for an influential province. 

Every play is an agonising choice, but the choice isn't paralysing. I'm not quite sure how they struck this balance, but the game flows beautifully. 

My only slight criticism is the use of dice.  I prefer as little luck as possible in my strategy games. But I understand you need some level of chance to keep this game from becoming formulaic and I can't think of a better way to resolve those events. And you can limit the effects of dice rolls by playing in certain ways.

EDIT: The more I play this game the better it gets and the more I appreciate the dice aspect of the game. 10/10
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Big improvement over previous non-deluxe edition.  Awesome, high-quality, mounted map, expanded "space race" and 7 new and interesting event cards.  Very easy to learn the rules and very enjoyable to play!

RATING: 9
Simply a fantastic strategy game. I personally love the Cold War theme and love the historical notes in the rule book. The gameplay itself is enjoyable, with plenty of tough decisions having to be made and lasting roughly 3 hours it is nowhere near as long as other strategy games. The only two negatives I can think of are the seeming bias towards the USSR player, who can easily dominate in early rounds, and the fact it is slightly too difficult to fully grasp for the members of my family who I play it with.

RATING: 10
Just played five sessions so far...and i can really sense it's a deep game after more plays. Very satisfied with the quality of the board game and the agonizing decision making process during game play! Will likely to alter the rating after more plays and will update it later. Highly recommended to gamer who loves brain-draining and yet highly tension card-driven cold war-theme board game. I'm beginning to see why it is ranked so high up in BGG. But prepared for longer than usual playing time, minimum a 3 hour game until gamer becomes an expert in playing it and knows most of the cards.

[Update 2/2/2017: After more than four years since I bought the game, TS remains one of the most enjoyable 2-P game I have. It is still a great game to play, with lots of tension, excitement, frustration (due to the bad cards in hand), anticipation, etc, basically lots of emotions when playing it. This is one of the best strategy game around and I can't recommend it more. Learn about it, test play it, and you will find a wonderful game in TS.

RATING: 7.5
2017-04-16 - This is a really solid, card driven area control game. It's basically a multi-use card game with a very historical flavor. RATING: 9
A good game needs to have some decision anguish. Having to decide what choice out of your available options you will take is where it really gets fun. Too much of this just gets frustrating. Twilight Struggle doesn't cross the line, but balances it. You want to be aggressive, but at the same time you want to counter your opponent. After three plays I am still getting the feel for this game, as opposed to many other games that I feel I know after just three plays. While it was fun after just one play, it is growing on me after each try.

Only gets a 7 because I just am not always in the mood for it.
Upgrading to 8.5 as it has grown even more on me over time. It really is a 9, but I don't 'always' want to play it.

RATING: 10
Living in Washington, DC I have a lot of friends who like politics and history, but who aren't gamers.  Twilight Struggle is the PERFECT game for us to play.  The rules are fairly simple, but the gameplay is elegant, making it a good choice for non-gamers.  Everyone can relate to the characterful event cards, and we all have our favorite Cold War moment (Don't wait for the translation...).  I am very enthusiastic, and can't wait to play again!  UPDATE:  After a few more plays, Twilight Struggle has to join my small collection of 10s.  It's a fantastic game, full of theme, and I wish I were playing it right now.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.9
Amazing game and props to the devs for doing such an amazing job taking the real history of the largest bluffing and political game of all time (in real life) and putting it into a super fun, very playable epic dual. 

This game pits you as the USA or USSR against the other and completely has you on the edge of your seat. It's a constant roller coaster and the two players will be completely immersed in the gameplay. 

It's a complex and long game (think a timeframe similar to monopoly with children ~3hrs) however it is absolutely one of the best games of all time. It needs to be complex... You're recreating the cold war with Real Actual events people!!! WTF did you think it would be? Simple and easy to understand... Love what they did.

Only gripe apart from tedious setup and intricate rules (again, that was expected) is the sub par materials for the game. I actually recreated the entire board on a hardboard tabletop and bought chessex dice (red and yellow for USSR and red and blue for USA) so the gameplay wold be smoother and more clear. All I'm saying is a great game like this could at least deserve a collectors set with better materials and dice instead of the damn tokens :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Twilight Struggle immerses players in the Cold War era in a tense, relentless battle for political influence. Despite the many moving parts that fuel the game, the ruleset remains accessible and intuitive. The various uses of the cards provide limitless possibilities and an open decision space in which to formulate and execute your strategy. The timing and sequence of card play is crucial, and herein lies the beauty and angst of the game. The level of historical detail is dripping with theme, adding layers of credibility and enjoyment to the game. While luck plays a significant factor, it is an element both players must manage. This is a fantastic design that results in a memorable session every time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
Two-player Cold War-themed game in which US and USSR spread influence across the globe. Cards also let you attempt coups and win the space race. Easy to learn, strategy abounds... but a bad deal can really turn you off, especially when someone wins the game because of it.

PLUS: theme - history without being over-educational,  strategy
MINUS: luck in the card draw with a slight bias to the US

RATING: 10
This is an outstanding game, and manages to stay near the top of my heap. Kudos to Matthews and Gupta for all the research and testing they must have done to produce it. If you are into espionage, politics, and Cold War history, you owe it to yourself to try this game. A tension-filled exercise in mitigating disaster. 

I've experienced enough now to see the USSR advantage that puts some people off the game. However, I don't mind it. I do think the Space Race track is slightly awkward--even if you make enough attempts at it to gain a significant lead, you don't really gain a reward commensurate with the effort required. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Excellent and novel take on the CDG genre of games. The concept of the event getting always played is a welcome idea and adds a new level of strategy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Shoot. I really thought I'd love this game. I enjoy card-driven games and I enjoy area control games. How can I not love this game? 

Here, specifically are the aspects of the game that I think weaken the design:

1) Randomly shuffled scoring cards. The gameplay tends to gear up in a continent for an anticipated scoring card and then is abandoned because both players know the card will not return for a while. Scoring, and therefore gameplay decision making, is arbitrary.

2) Roll a die to advance in the space race? This mechanic is lame and feels out of place, and yet can bring strong benefits to the player that makes this roll.

3) Although you can play without it, the "instant win" card is another poor design decision that I need to mark the score down for. I did win playing this card my second time out, and we both looked at each other and yelled "LAME!" simultaneously.

It's not a bad game, but neither do I think it is as great as many here seem to think. I'm more than a little baffled by all the adoration, although I do recognize the impressiveness of re-engineering card-driven wargame mechanics into an area-control game.

Components? The board and counters are too thin, the cards too thick to shuffle and the dice too small. The box is sturdy and strong. Cheers for the box.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Este juego es espectacular, es un pulso continuo entre 2 jugadores durante 2-3 horas.

Los jugadores luchan por controlar tantos paises como puedan en continentes distintos, usando PO √≥ los eventos proporcionados por sus cartas.

Twilight Struggle tiene distintas maneras de puntuar, y eso es bueno. No puedes centrarte s√≥lo en una parte del mapa, ya que el juego te hace que tengas fijarte en todo... incrementando la tensi√≥n de los jugadores.

[color=green]
LAST PLAY: 2011
[/color][color=blue]
This game is awesome, is a continious pulse between 2 players during 2-3 hours.

Players fight for controling as much countries as they can in different continents, using OP or events provided by thier cards.

Twilight Struggle has different scoring mechanics, and that's a good point. You can not be focus on one part of the map, this game forces you to keep an eye on everywhere... rising players panic.

Very good game, but you need to know its cards deeply  if you want to win.[/color]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Highly regarded and ranked, TS is a very thematic retelling of the Cold War. Its use of cards, defcon/military operations, coups, and realignments result in a tense and engaging 3 hour experience. The only issue I have is the scripted feeling that comes from the deck separation; however, it becomes less so once you hit mid-late war. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I had a blast playing each time. Lots of tense game play which tends to move around the world in a very nice fashion. It is very nostaligic, like I would play the Pope John Paul II card and remember where I was when he was elected...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Rating based on about 20-25 plays, including four games in tournament play where you bid for side.  The game favors the Russian player in the early turns, but flips over towards the US player if you can survive that long.  The key decision a player faces each turn is how to handle those cards with opponents events on them -- play them to get them out of the game, dump them in the Space Race, delay the decision for a turn, burn the China Card (if you have it).  You are also forced to play the scoring cards, but often setting up for them telegraphs your next play to an astute opponent.  This is probably the best of the card-driven game that is kind of a cross-over between the wargame and Euro genres and while it's very good, at #3 on the current BGG ratings list, it's probably a bit overrated -- there's nothing truly unique or original there, just a good combination of mechanics from other games that truly replicate the era it's trying to simulate, as each turn you literally do seem to be on the brink on nuclear confrontation ...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.75
What a game.  
The mediocre components and a significant barrier to entry (i.e. learning to play/rule complexity) are the only things stopping it from a 10.

RATING: 10
I am playing Twilight Struggle on Steam but I would love to play anyone face to face.  In my experience, this is the best game to play with 2 people.  Seldom do you know who is winning until it is over.  The problem is, bringing a newbie up to speed.  They have to understand, they are likely going to lose 3 to 5 games before they understand enough to be able to win.  Just knowing the rules and the mechanics is not sufficient to play well.  You need playing experience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
When I first heard of this game I was totally uninterested - no interest at all in the cold war, or a game about it - give me wooden cubes and cards or dice and tanks any day of the week!  I even passed it up on a rare business trip to the US while browsing in a game store in Boston.
To humour a friend I played a game of it on-line on Vassal, where the implementation was a bit glitchy.
Despite the interface and my initial lack of enthusiasm for the subject, once into the first turn I was totally hooked - it was the game mechanics that hooked me, not the subject, but as a result of the game I have become interested in the history too - something I would not have predicted.  
The game remains rich in flavour, gripping in intensity and facinating in how some simple mechanics can feel like the second half of the 20th century unfolding before your eyes, even after 30-odd plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Absolutely worthy of the #1 ranking crown. The mechanics are perfectly in sync with the geopolitical bipolar super-power influence-struggle theme. I love the tug of war VP track. Love the space race both in theme and concept as a card sink. Very balanced design that forces you to consider all fronts in the "cold war". Neglect the military ops at your own peril, for example.

RATING: 10
**I own both the Deluxe 2009 Edition and the 3rd Printing from 2007.**

[b][url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/42288]My Favorite Game[/url][/b]

This is the heaviest, most difficult game that I play. It's fairly intuitive to learn how the game works, but to play well against an experienced opponent requires sustained focus. Closing in on 80 plays and I still find it intense, fresh, and engaging. I know of no game as deep and various as Twilight Struggle. 

This was my first 10/10 rating. Really "this one goes to 11."

RATING: 7
Rank: 3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The game gets better when you know what you're doing. The imbalance is less worrying. Eight games in and I've seen USA win twice. Both plays were against new players as USSR. I've yet to try the recommended balancing mechanism. For my 2nd edition it is 3 additional influence points for the US and allowing overspend (more influence in a country than needed for control).
---
After a two years' break I'm four plays in now. All games ended with a USSR win in midwar, still waiting for the first US win. Might be lack of experience but I'm wondering how this - at least perceived - imbalance has passed playtesting. Quite astonishing for the game ranked #1 on BGG. It also disturbs me that my 2007 edition now is outdated with the new rules and cards introduced by the deluxe version. Nonetheless, exploring the game system is intriguing and I'm up for the challenge to win with the US under the old ruleset.
---
Two games into it and definitely want to play it more. So much depth and diversity and yet easy-to-learn rules and complexity.

26 May 14 - Officially giving up on this game. So disappointing. My friend and I can only win when playing Russian. Stupid! Far too long. Takes 5+ hours to play. RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
As a non wargame player the presentation really makes a difference to me, and it just feels better to play with better components, especially the mounted board.  While it is not the most aesthetically pleasing design, it feels like the game has the type of components it deserves.

Though still nowhere near experienced as a player, I can appreciate the depth and strategy the game offers.  After having played some of Jason Matthews' other co-designed games I definitely feel like this is the strongest.  I like how the map in Twilight Struggle is highly important, whereas in 1960 it felt underused, as if the connections between locations were not as important.

The choices are always interesting, and I like how each round can present different frustrations.  It's so easy to think that your opponent is always getting the best cards but it never really seems to be the case, it comes down to what you're going to do with what you're dealt.  I also think the die rolls make sense thematically and feel right.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Wow. So much going on here. Not for the faint of heart.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I haven‚Äôt played this game enough yet - for want of opponents, mainly. At the beginning of my learning curve my opponent could not easily find the 3 hours needed. We played on line but unfortunately the brilliant, first-class implementation we used (Chantry) was asked to cease and desist.

The rules are no more tedious to read than any other rule book and a great deal better than some. The game is relatively easy to learn, though in my experience the first couple of games were a bit of a getting-to-know-you struggle with the rules, concepts and tactics - and especially the cards - rather than a fluid game - though they were great fun anyway. In the first, my opponent accidentally triggered a nuclear war, and the dismay was palpable. In the second I realised that one of the cards in my hands would allow him to force me to trigger nuclear war, and that card then hampered me for several turns, and indeed, caused me to lose the game in the end. It turns out I'm not very good at this game. I think I've lost every game I've played.

The game is steeped in theme - this is the Cold War and its tensions on a board. Each player feels that his hand consists of events that only really benefit his opponent, and each player feels constantly tense as the cards fall. 

I know from reading around that many players have spent so much time with this game that they play a tight strategic game. In my case, it is still a matter of floundering from crisis to crisis, and having to delve into the rules from time to time to clarify what happens next. But it is probably my favourite game of all, and I include in that generalisation my many precious war games.

Though this fast, tense, well balanced, absorbing game is not a war game. This is a political struggle between superpowers. Wars are completely abstracted; coups and revolutions, influence and the avoidance of nuclear armageddon are the nerve and thrust of this game.

The balance in the game is interesting, since the cards tend to favour the USSR in the first half of the game, and the USA in the remainder, so balance is a little dynamic. But that adds to the flavour and tension of the game, and the asymmetry between the two sides adds to the game‚Äôs interest.

Much of the system has been stripped down from that of an earlier GMT game, Roads to Glory (another of my top few games) and it works really well in its new environment. Otherwise this game is unlike any other that I have encountered.

Simple, clever, engaging, satisfying, tense - what more could you ask for?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

RATING: 10
I loved this game so much that I purchased the Deluxe edition.  :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The (sort of) bad: For one thing, Twilight Struggle punishes you for not playing it more often. My first time playing, I managed to wrest Japan from the grip of the U.S., not knowing that there was a card that would nullify my massive expenditure of OPs. Of course, the same thing happens to the U.S. from time to time, too, but it's usually via cards like Junta or Willy Brandt, which aren't as severe as Pope John Paul II or the Postwar Occupation card (or whatever it's called.) So there's a bit of a learning curve, and I'm not convinced that the game doesn't just go to whoever knows the wrinkles better.

I also have a big problem with cards like Wargame, which can nullify a LOT of careful planning, and Red Scare/Purge, which punishes your opponent by straitjacketing them for 1/10 of the game every time it comes up.

Also: "Chili?" "Replublic of China?" Really, GMT?!

The good: what a majestic simulation. The theme is strong, the Realignment, Space Race, Coup, and Influence mechanics allow for a wide range of strategies. There's a little luck involved, but over the course of the game (especially if you get rid of Red Scare/Purge and Wargame, as I would), the luck evens out over time. It was a real treat to play this for the first time and wince when my opponent dropped Missile Envy or managed to grab Iron Lady from my hand and play it - it's the best kind of pain (well, maybe not the BEST, but close.) The hand management is chaotic enough that it's anyone's guess at the beginning of a round how your own scoring cards and plans will interact with your opponent's, but there are still rewards to strong positional play. I will definitely buy this.

[EDIT: Now that I own it, I absolutely love this game. The gorgeous Deluxe edition fixes all the wonkinesses of the original game except for the unbalanced USSR problem, which is best fixed by variant. It's a fantastic game that does credit to the already swelling line of GMT classics. I can see playing regularly for the next few years. Well done, Matthews and Gupta.]

[EDIT II: With 10 plays under my belt (nevermind what my played games thingy says), I can say with certainty that this is a great game, but its unbalance is a serious issue that has to be addressed every time you play. Just 'cause GMT sent a game out into the world that needs to be fixed to be even remotely fair, no matter how elegant and well-made and atmospheric and interesting it is otherwise, I have to take this down a notch from 9.5 to 9.]

[EDIT III: a dozen games in, the cracks are really starting to show. Much as I'd like to think I usually win at this because I'm just damn good at it, which I am, there's a devil on my shoulder whispering that it's just because I usually make sure to play as the Sovs. Last two games, I've tried throwing an additional 3 influence to the Americans plus one in Saudi, and that hasn't helped. I'm not sure the balance issues are fixable. Down to an 8 now.]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Have played over 50 times in less than three months. A game with deep strategy. Some think it is dice-dependent, but that is because they do not know how to play this game. Had a game in which I roll only 1~2 and my opponent only 5~6, and still won the game with an auto-victory by scoring the right region in the right time. In another game I was screwed by dice, I won by dropping Defcon to 1 in his turn. In yet another game I grinded to turn 10 and won by a last action round Voice of America. This game requires you to know the deck very well to excel, but the beauty of it is that you will end up studying the cards by yourself after a few play -- because it is a great game that a gamer will want to master.
Play time: Some think it is too long because their first few games often take over 5 hours. But most of the games I play now only take an hour to two hours max. When you get used to the cards this game has virtually no downtime -- you are always watching the board and reacting to your opponent's move.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
At first I thought it was a fun game marred by overly-powerful and capricious scoring cards (and gave it a 7.5 rating here, I see). Then the more I thought about it, the more it came to annoy me. I'm more than willing to embrace the idea of a counterfactual game about a truly bipolar cold war where the domino theory worked, but my problem with this game is that that "cold war cartoon" premise is the basis for the mechanics but the cards are all based (often far too literally) on the events that happened in the real, not simplistically bipolar cold war where the domino theory did not work. So it ends up often mirroring actual history (and being praised by its fans for doing so) when if it really were a comic book version of the cold war it should not do so. In the end I can't help suspecting that the designers created the game not knowing that the cartoon cold war wasn't the real one, then when this was pointed out to them offered the "it's just a cartoon" argument as a post hoc, it's-not-a-bug-it's-a-feature rationalization.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 2
Very random area-influence game.  Can go to 2 to 3 hours if goes the full 10 turns (longer if with new players who have AP).  Usually ends earlier on an auto-victory for the Soviets, if the Soviet player is experienced.  

My rating has finally settled to a 2 for this game.  After the initial excitement due to the theme and how well it plays by email, the fact that the randomness of the dice and cards determine the outcome more often than the players' decisions makes this game one that I'd rather not play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Wow, a two and a half hour card game.  I've seen so much hype about this game here on BGG and it's so highly rated that I couldn't help being interested.  

Then I found out that it's really just a very long card game.  The cards are supposed to add flavor and I guess they're cool if you're into the period, but this game was dry and lifeless for me.  

And getting screwed repeatedly by the cards just isn't good in a game of this length.

Of course, there is area control, as well, but here I felt the game is rudimentary to the point of being abstract.  It could be on the moon or in medieval spain.  The little counters with numbers don't really help.  Pretty much every country is equally influence-able, which is absurd and shows the evident lack of depth.  

At least other card driven area control games don't pretend to have historical significance or last this long.  Scratch that, El Grande does at least to some degree and it lasts over an hour.

RATING: 6.5
Initially really enjoyed this game: it's a really well-made 2 player head-to-head. However, after a few plays...I can't understand the praise that there is little to no luck--I would argue there is a LOT of luck. From the control of a crucial region from events or whether I can coup a pivotal country or advance in the space race, it is entirely based on my rolling! There's been countless unlucky/lucky streaks myself and the opponent have experienced that would have had a great impact should something have succeeded/failed. Still, there's still something very immersive and enjoyable about the game, and the newest implementation is gorgeously produced. I just can't deny that I like it a little less with each play...

RATING: 5
Scattershot historical events add a nice theme to this area-control game.  The best history in the game is the need to match an opponent's influence in otherwise neglected regions of the world.   +1 if you're old enough to know that "defect" is also a verb.  Three plays, waning interest.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is no Euro or wargame. Instead, it is a fast-playing, 2-player, power-politics game on the Cold War (1945-1991). 

Unfortunately, there appears to be a play balance problem in that the USSR often wins within 4-turns. For the US player to win, he needs to play for the long game unless he can get an autowin in Europe. 

Some of the 2nd edition cards have changed and it is too early to tell if the changes have balanced the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A good game, but I just suck at it
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Most excellent 2 player struggle.  If I want to have the feel of a real war game in a playable time frame, this is a top choice.  The card play created constant tug of war since they come from a limited deck that contains half your cards and half your opponents.  Mitigating how you benefit your opponent is half the game (well maybe not if you are really good).

The side benefits of military actions/DEFCON and the Space Race provide interesting excursions and considerations.

CONS:  It's long? (though not so for a war game)  That's the only thing keeping it off the regular table.  Being a game based on real history, there are many timeline aspects that create exceptions to the rules, so learning the metagame (card interactions) is a must to play well.

I could see myself rating it a 9 , since I will be playing this for some time to come, but the time issue will keep it off the table.  Atleast it's easily finishable in a game session though, unlike typical war games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Great game, try and get the 2nd edition IP markers as they make it readily visible who has control of a country.

RATING: 8
I once rated this game a 10 because I enjoyed it that much and think it a wonderful design.  However even though the game is so fun its hard to find someone fun to play the game with.  They all either know the game way better than you ever will or just aren't interested in this kind of game.  So it's very chess-like in that regard because you need someone at your experience level.  Hard enough to find opponents and come to an agreement on games without that additional requirement.  I do have the Computer version now so perhaps that will allow me to gain enough experience such that this one complaint will become null and my rating will climb again.  I do really enjoy the way influence works in the game even if I am so very bad at it...

NOTE: I'm not really interested in the historical value of the cards in this game and that hasn't affected my enjoyment any so I think that's part of the success of this game as you don't have to be a History nut to see the beauty in the mechanics and the gameplay itself.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
(Rating based on tens of plays)

The best game ever. It is based on direct interaction between two players, requires planning and strategic thinking. It contains random factor but the best thing is that the randomness can and must be mitigated by player actions. It's the same situation as with playing bridge - you get random cards and have to somehow manage the game with them.

The mechanics of the game is very simple. It is easy to explain but takes a lot of play to fully grasp the nuances. Despite simple mechanics Twilight Struggle has incredible feeling and recreates the tension of the Cold War in a great way.

Added Nov. 2011: Although I thought this would be impossible, my girlfriend actually likes the game!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I haven't played that much Twilight Struggle, certainly not enough to understand how to play it well. Like Caylus and Through the Ages, expertise with TS only comes after many, many plays. But for me, much like Labyrinth (which I have played many more times), the fun in TS comes from optimizing my turn. What to play as a headline is usually straightforward, but the rest of the choices are quite difficult. And add to that the fact that the events and the ops are all just the means to an end in a complex area control game, and the depth of this game is just staggering. Add to this the amazing quality of the board and cards and TS is simply a gem of a game. It is entirely deserving of its place at the top of BGG's rankings.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Surprising didn't quite like this game.  A bit too dry.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Tense frustrating in a good way to the very end.

(November 2015)
A con could be how powerful some cards are, which means that for somebody not having a pretty good knowledge of the deck probably would waste unfortunate resources on something that anyway could fail the power of a single card. Even though dice mitigate some otherwise deterministic game play, it means that this game has to be played by:

- two who discovers the game together and hence both are victims to surprises, that might make the game even more fun
- two who have reached the same level of skill

Otherwise one player has to be very patient and willing to spend a whole lot of time teaching the game, probably holding back to not end the game not even reaching middle war.

Anyway, is this a con or not I don't know. Some abstract games with no element of luck don't forgive a single mistake.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I didn't expect to really like this one but bought it given the reputation here on BGG.

It turns out that it's really a great game! Normally, in my opinion, games with a lot of theme like doesn't work well because they tend to impose limit to the gameplay but this one doesn't have the problem. Another issue I feared is that the game would be too scripted if it did follow history but given how tight the design is, simply playing a card before the other changes everything. Finally, I also feared the randomness added with the dice would be problematic but in the end it doesn't really matter, it's how you play your hand that does.

The game takes a long time to play but doesn't feel too long since you have a constant stream of interesting decisions to take.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

An excellent game! Some have complained about balance in this one, but in games I have played it is pretty even.

Edit: I don't know why I didn't have this as a 10. It is definitely one of my favorite games of all time.

RATING: 2
If you remember the cards (because you did play before) you already won, if you are new to game you will be beaten badly every time. It is not a game which can be played with new people. It is not a tactic or strategy that will let you win, is is just a remembering what is in opponent deck, what he used already and what he can have at hand.  It is like poker, but you don't know what cards are included in deck. Bought it cos of high wargame ratind (1st place), but i found it to lack and aspect of wargame. It is a card game set is war theme.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
Why, why, why, why?!?!?  I will never understand the appeal of this game.  I have tried - multiple times.  I am so completely lost on why this is always hailed as the Citizen Kane of board games.  I love war games - both light war games and complex historical ones, so its not like this is outside my wheel house.  For starters, it is BORING - blah!  Second, the card play is so darn frustrating - on your turn you are essentially deciding what benefit you are going to give to your opponent.  It is rare that you will have a hand of cards that completely benefits you.  Teaching that to new players is such a grind.  Stay away, don't believe the hype!

RATING: 5
Interesting theme but takes way too long (+6 hours) and placing political influence is not as much fun as moving around armies and battling. I also don't like how the cards you draw determine what you can do; it's a too easy way to recreate history and only detracts from the game mechanic. Imagine if you're playing chess and there's a card "your opponent's towers collaps" - that's how I feel about the card system here. Strongly dislike the scoring system, where you need an "Asia scoring card" to get points from your great position in Asia. Why introduce such randomness in a war game, which should be about strategy and units?

RATING: 10
Really, there is every other game in the world, and then there is Twilight Struggle.  Nothing but Summoner Wars can compare.  The game is so wonderfully thematic, carefully balanced, historical, strategic, and just perfect in every way.  True, against a seasoned player the game will last a while, and true, it is a bit hard on new players.  However, the Late War variant that comes with the game allows for a better learning environment.

As with all GMT games, the components are very cheap and the board is more functional than beautiful.  Also, no thought is given to storage, and a GMT Storage Tray, while useful, makes it difficult to fit the components back into the box.  But the game is so wonderful that I am willing to overlook this!

The fact is, nothing is quite as satisfying as playing this game.  Win or lose, I always always always enjoy the experience.  I learn something new each time.  Probably only Summoner Wars can compare.

RATING: 8.85
I can definitely see why many think of Twilight Struggle as the best game ever but this game is not for me because I really don't like direct conflict, especially with my wife :P

+ Super thematic! Event powers and names are well connected.  
+ Real brain burner! I think the weight should be at least 4.0 because there are soooo many things to do and consider. Constant VP lead in the game doesn't mean that you are doing well in the long run. 

- Steep learning curve (some unintuitive base rules and a huge amount of cards that are often not very clear on the first reading)
- Takes a long time. People say 2-3 hours but it lasted about 9 for us. Though, it was our first time and we are always quite slow when it's only the two of us playing.
- Luck involved with dice rolls and card drawing. 
- Very hard to predict what your opponent is capable of if she blindly draws 8 new cards every round. It is exciting of course but it just gets annoying after a while.

Personally, I don't like direct conflict and unpredictability in games. If I wanted to play an intense area majority game, then I'd rather pick Dominant Species because it is less chaotic and can support more players.

RATING: 8
Twilight Struggle inherits its fundamental systems from the card-driven classics We the People and Hannibal: Rome vs. Carthage. It is a quick-playing, low-complexity game in that tradition. The game map is a world map of the period, whereon players move units and exert influence in attempts to gain allies and control for their superpower. As with GMT's other card-driven games, decision-making is a challenge; how to best use one's cards and units given consistently limited resources?

Twilight Struggle's Event cards add detail and flavor to the game. They cover a vast array of historical happenings, from the Arab-Israeli conflicts of 1948 and 1967, to Vietnam and the U.S. peace movement, to the Cuban Missile Crisis and other such incidents that brought the world to the brink of nuclear annihilation. Subsystems capture the prestige-laden Space Race as well as nuclear tensions, with the possibility of game-ending nuclear war.

A deluxe edition, published in 2009 includes the following changes from the basic game:

‚Ä¢ Mounted map with revised graphics
‚Ä¢ Two double-thick counter sheets with 260 counters
‚Ä¢ Deck of 110 event cards (increased from 103)
‚Ä¢ Revised rules and player aid cards
‚Ä¢ Revised at start setup and text change for card #98 Aldrich Ames

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[b]Twilight Struggle[/b] has sit on Board Game Geek's #1 ranking throne for quite a while and as such gained an almost legendary reputation that still makes people curious to find out why it is such a popular game. Like many other people, this is the way I discovered this game that is actually outside of my usual comfort zone of Ameritrash and a Eurogames, since [b]Twilight Struggle[/b] is wargame/area control game.

When I finally had the chance to learn the rules and played the game for the first time, I was not entirely sure how I would rank it in the end, because it is a game which demands repeated plays to unfold itself to the players, as knowing all the unique cards with their effects and also when they enter the game is key for developing a successful strategy.

The biggest surprise I had was finding out that this apparent masterpiece of a strategic game has a very intergrated use of random die rolls, and although I did like the game right from the beginning and immediately understood why it is so popular, this aspect left a bit of a bitter taste to me for a long time, as I was expecting way less randomness from such a high-ranking strategy game.

So yes, while this game is indeed a brilliant strategy game, it just so slightly misses the mark in my opinion for deserving to be calle a masterpiece of a game, as the random factors are indeed too prominent and often impactful. I am not exclusively referring to the rolling of dice (which happens quite frequently), but also the randomness of drawing cards, which can sometimes result not only in a frustrating game experience (if the player draws unlucky hands), but also in a premature ending of the game.

Having said all that, [b]Twilight Struggle[/b] deserves its accolades and won awards. It treats the subject matter in a respectful and historical way and manages to simulate the Cold War in an abstracted board game format in a fantastic way, including the inherent bluffing and mind games between players.

While the game is asymmetrical and has a real strategic depth, it's actually not that hard to learn and teach: the rulebook is 32 pages long, but the actual rules part is found on just the first 10, which are also well-written.

The biggest obstacle in learning the basic concepts and flow of the game is probably getting familiar with the somewhat "different" nature of it, especially for non-wargamers (like me). After that, the next challenge becomes mastering the game, because as mentioned before, knowing all the unique cards (that are this game's life blood and driving force) makes the difference between actually creating and following a strategy (also limiting some of the game's random card draws) and just playing from turn to turn in a strategy-wise incoherent way. As such, it is best to learn the game with someone of the same skill level, as a veteran will absolutely crush any newbie.

The production quality of this game (Deluxe Edition) is excellent. The rulebook alone is a highlight and one of the best I ever read: written in a clear an precise way, every new chapter is introduced with a fitting quote, every rule numbered for easy quick-referencing. The rulebook includes variants (including an option that allows players to start the game in the late stage), an extended example of play to provide a solid impression of the game's flow and also brief rundowns on all the historical events depicted on the cards -- just short enough for allowing curious and unaware players to quickly pick up the rulebook and get a quick summary what the card refers to. The counters are rounded (not an industry standard), the illustrations and colour scheme of the board and cards give the impression that the designer aimed for a fitting "dated" and minimalistic look.

It should be noted that while the game is thematic and attempts to simulate the Cold War, the designers made deliberate decisions in terms of theme and game design. Quote from the designers (found in the rulebook):

[i]"Also important for players to understand is that the game has a very definite point of view. Twilight Struggle basically accepts all of the internal logic of the Cold War as true‚Äîeven those parts of it that are demonstrably false. Therefore, the only relationships that matter in this game are those between a nation and the superpowers. The world provides a convenient chess board for US and Soviet ambitions, but all other nations are mere pawns (with perhaps the occasional bishop) in that game. Even China is abstracted down to a card that is passed between the two countries. Furthermore, not only does the domino theory work, it is a prerequisite for extending influence into a region. Historians would rightly dispute all of these assumptions, but in keeping with the design philosophy, we think they make a better game."[/i]

Furthermore, the game makes a very clear and important statement by defining one of the game's defeat conditions: the player who causes DEFCON 1 is considered to have provoked nuclear war and is declared the loser of the game.

Best game of all times ? No, not in my opinion, but I can see why others view it that way, as it is an indeed excellent and multi-layered game of strategy, simulation and history with a critical outlook on the dangerous nuclear poker game that the Cold War was.

[hr]
See also: [b][blogpost=45245]‚ñ∫Twilight Struggle as the #1 board game: Why I am fine with that, although I have never played it[/blogpost][/b]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
[2007.Mar.18] Twilight Struggle is an interesting interpretation of the Cold War. This card-driven game (CDG) uses historical morsels to populate the three (3) different decks of game cards: Early-, Mid-, and Late-War cards. I was a little disappointed with the quality of GMT Games' game components. For the price, the game's component quality should have be significantly better. (The cardboard map requires the use of a plexiglas sheet to keep it flat, while the bland game chits are uninspired at best.) Additionally, I was a little taken aback by the amount of dice rolling used to resolve many parts of the game; this was a bit unexpected for a CDG originally released in 2005. Despite the component quality and dice resolution, however, the game is good and should be played by all serious gamers at least once. I look forward to my next foray back into the Cold War.

[2009.Mar.10] The luck-of-the-die mars this game's elegance. If the designers were to propose an alternate mechanism for adjudicating the die-based resolutions, then this game would be (in my humble opinion, of course) a very good game.

:star::star::star::nostar::nostar:

RATING: 8
This is an excellent game. 

The event effects really serve to drive home the Cold War theme. It really does feel like you are fighting the Cold War.

In a sense it's hard for me to look at this game objectively. As a student of history I identify with the theme so much. The effects of Events for me are just so much more than their mechanical resolution on the board. The history is just a wonderful aspect of the game.

Fortunately there is a wonderful game hidden beneath all this history too. For such a thematic game I just can't fathom anyone playing it who didn't have a basic grasp of the Cold War. I recommend anyone interested in this game to do a bit of reading on the topic, it will only serve to heighten the experience.

Truly rewarding game here. I've a feeling i'll rate this highly after a few more plays...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The components are all cardboard, the colors a garish blue/red motif on plain white cards. There is no art in this game, only a map - a Mercator projection map which makes Russia and Canada look gigantic - and event cards featuring black & white stock photos from history. Many cards don't have even stock photos and instead just have a flat stock image (like clip art) of a flag, region, or seal (i.e. NATO emblem, or the Chinese flag).

I found the aesthetic to be surprisingly dull and lazy given the mythical #1 spot this game commands.

The theme runs deep in the game, and if you are a fan of the cold war, you will be pleased by how the game nails historical events through the card event system.

It's a typical Ameritrash game, with many thematic exception rules that you are likely to forget or screw up your first few plays. Very inelegant.

It also uses dice rolling as a principal game mechanic to determine outcomes of important actions. To further compound the RNG-factor, random card-draws are another principal game mechanic, which can lead to serious imbalance and snowballing early in the game.

Two evenly-matched players can easily have the game determined by RNG through bad card draws or bad dice rolls. For me, this level of RNG was torture. The stakes felt too high for the RNG to wholly determine outcomes with nothing you can do to mitigate bad luck.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I first want to say that there are very interesting and unique mechanics in this game. So I consider this game to be quite innovative, but I don't really think I would ever love this game and even enjoy playing in tournament.

The card mechanic is very interesting on one point of view, but on the other side it's a brain burner. Cards have multiple functions. Either you use the special ability, either you use the value for 3 different things, either you flush it for the space race(1 card) or either you do not use it(1 card). Which gives a total of 6 functions. That is a lot.

Now add that most value effects can be targeted anywhere on the map. Anywhere is a lot of place where you can do stuff when you play for the first time. So you get overwhelmed by the choices and you simply do not know where to go.

In most game, when you have multiple functions for each card, you can simply forget about the other functions you are not going to use. Here it's different, because if you play a card from an opposing nation for it's value, the special ability gets also played. So you cannot simply block the effect of the card from your mind, you must always consider all the special abilities of your hand which has the consequence of increasing the level of brain burning.
 
It's even more a problem when one of your turn, you get stuck with a hand mostly of opposing nation cards. Which means that all cards that will be played will have a negative impact on you. So you must consider both ability and value to play your cards. 

It also means that what ever is the hands of the players, all the events in the game should happen anyway. There is only 1 space race card and 1 un-played card that will not happen. So the history is dictated by the game, only the order of the events will change.

This means that YOU MUST KNOW ALL THE CARDS BY HEART in order to play effectively, else it almost impossible to win against an experienced player. Since each card has unique abilities, there are hundreds of cards and I have a very weak memory, I will never be able to remember what all the cards does.

Some actions during the game allows you to roll some dice, compare influence and remove tokens according to the results. Each action has a different way to compute the values and determine the results. I don't know it I was tired this day, but I found it very complicated to easily visualize the math behind. For example, how to find the best place to make a coup. So I ended being lost in the calculation, re-asked many times how it worked again and chose almost random locations to make my actions.

Another frustrating element is that some actions requires you to be adjacent to have you have, while other actions can be accomplished anywhere on the board. This is very confusing, and I often got stuck in a situation where I forgot adjacency, because most of the game consist influencing anybody anywhere on the world and not having a expansion or progression of your homeland territory. I would have personally clearly defined limits like event can occur anywhere, but the card select the location for you while using a card for it's value is always adjacent to something you have. 

Finally, the game is pretty long for what it is. We played almost half the game and it took from 1h to 1h30. We had to stop the game, but I already had enough of the game by that time.

So I don't think I will ever like this game because first, there is brain burning, second there is a lot of memorization to do, third it's a very long game for a not so fun experience and finally it is an historical game, so each game seems similar to each other. 

So it's really not the game for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
This has become a favorite although still a struggle to get to the table due to play length and two player limitation. Tension is thick in this one. I have come to really enjoy Card Driven games and this is quite a Cold War standoff simulation.

FIRST IMPRESSIONS:

My first GMT game that I have enjoyed.  Time required to play will likely be a detriment to seeing much play, but this is an excellent game for two.  There are times though that I felt the game was more about limiting opportunities for the opponent to "score" more so than playing to "win".  Second edition is purportedly better aesthetically and has correct spellings!  Tough decisions must be made consistently as you may have to play a particularly favorable event card for your opponent in order to use the operation points to maintain a standoff or get an edge somewhere else.  Battleground countries are important to gain influence in many cases - don't forget about them!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Even the graphics have that pre 90's touch to it. The only reason I do not rate it higher is that I haven't played it that often and will have to see how it stands up to time.

RATING: 8
2-player
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It's important to see how this game handles the victory conditions for both sides. As a child growing up in the Cold War, this game could really recreate the same atmosphere of the 80's that we all experienced with.  It is not strictly a wargame per se though. Tapping on the card-driven games market, the cards are divided into early, mid and late war eras, similar to that in Thirty Years War.  Lousy box cover, one of the worst in recent GMT games.  The game pretty much favors the Soviet in the early turns.  So beware to hold out if you play the Allied. Taking the U.S. side should be the one more experienced. I have raised the balance issue before in the game's forum but soon enough many people would say it is otherwise. I still think it is more challenging and, perhaps, more fun to play the U.S. because you have to play a more subtle strategy than the Soviet in the early period. 

A highly recommended piece to read "Let a Thousand Variants Bloom" by Jason Matthews for his Twilight Struggle variant. 4 pages of background to his China Space card from C3i issue #21. The article is to give a view as to why the Soviet was delayed to own the China card in the game opening (3 influence points should be placed by the Soviets before they can claim the China card). The article is excellent to give the background to the Chinese Civil War both before and after the Japanese invasion during WWII. The role of the U.S. in the China theatre is examined in fair details. A perfect companion reading to this game I believe.

RATING: 9
very interesting game, just difficult to find a friend can enjoy together.

BUD
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
After a test play of 1 round: I really liked how the theme is blended in the mechanics.  The turns went very fast.  Jane got bored when I tried my many realignment rolls, though.

Still wondering how deep/challenging the game is, which is a very important criterion for us.

What I like:
- Lots of varied events.
- Lots of theme.  I remember fondly this situation where I created a "false" urgency: I knew that the Mideast scoring card was somewhere in the deck, so I invested in the Middle East; my opponent though that I did have the scoring card, so he then started to get influence there; I then saw this as a proof that he had the Mideast scoring card!  Thus, my paranoia completely created a situation where what mattered was completely unfounded (investing in the Mideast) despite being seemingly "proven" by the course of events.
- The constant tension brought about by the scoring cards and the final scoring.
- The need to pay attention to what the opponent is doing, so as to guess whether we're going to be scoring or not in some regions.
- I like the feeling of progression, with more and more countries being influenced by one of the superpowers.
- I really look forward to a 2nd game: I already enjoyed getting back some cards; they were like old friends.  The 2nd game should be faster, and more fluid, thanks to our experience with a 1st game.  Knowing the game better also means knowing the political situation better, and enjoying the game more (next time, I will know that the OPEC can be created, and I may try to prepare for it, for instance).

What I don't care for:
- Finding the historical details about a card, in the rule book, is somewhat hard.  I wish they had numbered the card, in the rule book, or ordered them alphabetically.
- The score fluctuates around 0: this does not give a sense of achievement, or of progress.  However, the situation on the board evolves, and it too is important, beyond instantaneous VPs.
- The first game was more of a learning game, because I had missed 3 important points.

Rules:
- The rulebook is great: very clear, and precise.  Not perfect, but close (for instance, the rule for shuffling the various decks into the draw pile are strangely under "4.5.H. Advance the Turn Marker"; the second part of 4.5.H is also a repeat of 4.4).
- I missed a few important rule points, which kind of forced the first full game to only be a learning game, and not a competitive one.
- After a single game, I think I won't have much problem remembering the rules, or knowing where in the rulebook to find them.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

RATING: 9
Again another game with a lot of potential. The quality of the board is substandard - thin and unwilling to lay flat, although the rest of the components are fine. That aside this game is incredibly evocative and the theme really sucks you into the historical battles that took place and all of the power plays and countries involved in this game of chess with global consequences. The game plays out slowly and steadily with you trying to average out gains and losses over several rounds and win the "long game". Highly rated and would love to play more in order to develop some strategies. Oh and it's educational too. My 10 year old took it into school as they were learning about the cold war and we both developed a slimmed down (30-45 minute) version of the game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
How does the exciting time from after WWII, until the fall of the Wall, in 1989? Play it all!

Twilight Struggle is a two-player game simulating the forty-five year dance of intrigue, prestige, and occasional flares or warfare between the Soviet Union and the United States. The entire world is the stage on which the two worlds are fighting for their own ideologies and ways of life. The game starts amidst the ruins of Europe as the two new superpowers scramble over the wreckage of the Second World War, and ends in 1989, when only the United States remained standing.

Component changes:
Mounted Map (the graphics have been re-done, and the map is now fully mounted instead of cardboard.)
Card deck or 110 cards (an increase of 6 cards)
Two counter sheets (Older editions had one sheet, there is no increase in the number of counters, but they will be rounded with corners)

RATING: 10
The best 1x1 boardgame ever.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Still my favorite strategic/wargame, and pretty close to the best game I've ever played.  The depth of it is just tremendous, and there are so many layers of play that fit together so perfectly that it's stunning.  It rewards close play and attention, and while there's a limited number of variables, it never plays the same way twice.  

The design is pretty simple, but the depth of the theme is staggering, and actually having a chance to replay these old Cold War rivalries and rewrite history in a different order is thrilling.  It's hugely strategic, and it's got a pretty vicious learning curve, but once mastered, it's so rewarding.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Although it's not actually that complicated a game, there are a few little rules that you have to remember.  Plus the sheer length of the game can be intimidating.  [thing=27708]1960[/thing] is certainly more approachable---the components are nicer, the cards have better flavor text, and it feels like you have more control over the cardplay via the momentum mechanism.  You trade that for much more tension and angst in [thing=12333][/thing]---there's no more momentum mechanism involved that you can use to block your opponent's events, so if you have an event that benefits your opponent, you're out of luck.  You can't just toss it, so now it's a much more difficult decision to decide when to use it.  The map and area control also makes more sense than [thing=27708]1960[/thing], since neighboring countries affect each other, unlike the states in [thing=27708]1960[/thing].  Since there are three decks of cards in [thing=12333][/thing], there also feels like more of a narrative as the game goes by.  As a result, it appears to be a game that would just get better as you start becoming more familiar with the cards.

I would certainly recommend new gamers try out [thing=27708][/thing] before attempting [thing=12333][/thing].  Luckily my wife now tolerates it and I'm hopeful to get more plays in, but the time involved can be prohibitive...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
