=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
UPDATE2: Having now played 6-7 times adjusted the rating due to two blowouts due to the Early War score cards coming to the same player turn by turn. Maybe history could have unfolded that way but its no fun being on either end of a blowout.

UPDATE: Raised rating - 3rd game played very different from 1st 2 outings. Realignments played a large role this time - was beginning to think it was a orphan action.

Components: About standard GMT fare. Use markers to show control.

Gameplay: Excellent. Since I have lived through about 95% of the events portrayed it "connects". Hand management is everything - it is very satisfying when you are stuck with a slew of your opponents cards and come out with minimal damage to your situation.

The split of Early, Mid and Late War decks and their intermixing makes for some unusal history to develop.

I haven't played enough to see all the cards in play but have been on the giving & receiving end of Wargames which might be a bit overpowered (you yield 6 VPs and game ends) Other player should have one shot at playing a card to adjust the score IMHO.

Of the actions: Realingment, Coup or Placing Influence - have seen little use of Realingment. Maybe that is situational dependent or due to relatively inexperienced players. Given my dismal performance on Coup attempts last game, maybe Realigns are a better choice...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Complex and long... But fun with the right partner
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Low confidence rating/first impressions.

While I don't consider this the #1 game in BGG's database, I can see why it is ranked as such. It gives a very historical simulation of the Cold War with a stressful yet intriguing hand management that sometimes forces you to play cards that actually benefit your opponent more. Also, while being not a history buff the different regions were a bit abstracted and samey for me, there was still constant tension of I must react and ursurp all plans of my opponents to get ahead in e.g. Vietnam or the space race. This therefore made the game have a feel of escalating conflict and zero-sum game that fits in with the Cold War theme well.

It seems like to play this game optimally you have to do quite a bit of metagaming, as there are cards that target very specific regions on the board. Each card is unique; however, since you play a large sum of your cards for their operations value rather than their effect they don't add as much variation as I would have thought. Also more cards means more unique cards rule ambiguities.

In regards to my comment that the regions felt abstract and samey, I'm not saying there isn't differences from country to country. The use of stability as both to determine a country's resistance to coups and also how much influence it takes for you to take over a country is pretty neat, and the values seemed to correspond to actual historical stability. There's also some neat area control bonuses for controlling countries close to ones that you already control, and some regions are considered battlegrounds which make them have different attributes from others. However, it felt like a ton of tiny skirmishes rather than highlighting the major wars within the Cold War. Perhaps since the 2 superpowers didn't really care about individual countries that is kind of the point.

Timing of when you play certain cards can be very important, as you test the waters of what cards your opponent potentially has for the rest of the round. At the same time you need to consider what cards are left in the deck and better your board position for the future too.

More than any other game I've played so far, I had no idea what I was doing and hence the low confidence in my rating. I do know though that game definitely has multiple layers of strategy/tactics that I have barely scratched the surface of and that is not one I should play when I want to relax.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
a game i like but however can not find time to play.  It is a game that gets more fun with increased play.  You have to play it mulitple times with a consistent partner to truely understand and enjoy it.

RATING: 5.76
Comments entered on 05 Mar 2010:

The tenseness of this game is remarkable. As a student of history, and particularly Western history since the 1500s, this game is fantastic in highlighting some of the most important moments from 1945-1991. An absolute masterpiece of the Card Driven Game (CDG) system.

I purchased a copy from the first edition original print run in 2005. I have added a copy of the Deluxe Edition in 2010.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
There's certainly a lot to like about this game. The components (while a bit austere) are of first rate quality and durability. The rulebook is magnificent - uniformly clear, incredibly succinct, gorgeously laid-out, and full of neat extra historical information. It's possibly the best of its kind I've ever seen.

Nonetheless, I'm a  bit perplexed at how this game got ranked so high. The best contemporary games, IMHO, succeed because they manage to capture the feel of some activity (farming, say, or maybe settling Puerto Rico, heh) while at the same time abstracting enough away from that activity to ensure balance, ease of play and the possibility of long-range strategy and tactics. The designers of TWILIGHT STRUGGLE have been so determined to gamify absolutely every major world event from the Cold War era that they've made these other goals virtually impossible to achieve for themselves. 

All things considered, they come admirably close, but in the game I played after eight intense rounds of back-and-forth, my Soviets suddenly jumped out to an insurmountable lead because I got dealt two cards in the same hand that I played in succession with no opportunity for my opponent to retaliate. Something like this would never, ever happen in AGRICOLA.

RATING: 9
Great game! Alot of rich history on the Cold War that happened over a 45 year period right after WWII. I like the back an forth of the victory point struggle along with trying to figure out what your opponent is trying to do. I also like the cards that make you make tough decisions that can have ripple effects that are exciting or give your opponent an edge but also give you the reward. Basically what is worth more for your decision or plan? Is it the op points or the event?  
An absolute must have for strategy and history fans. Will be keeping this game for a long time if not forever.

RATING: 8
july 23 2014: A 7 based on just 2 plays. 

This game is very hard to learn. The rulebook is long and quite complex, but the hardest thing is that, as a newbie, you simply cannot grasp how to build a sound strategy. It will require some more plays before I can feel confident in my choices

On the other hand, when the board is out, and you're sitting with the future of USSR or USA in your hands, the feeling is just epic. I have never played any other game that felt so grand.

Updated to an 8 after a handful more plays. You can get screwed by the dice, and you will be crushed by more experienced players. But this game is the fucking business

RATING: 10

Great mesh of theme and mechanics.  Worthy of repeated play.  The rules in the box need corrections and are fiddly on a few points, but there is a set of FAQ that pretty well clears it all up.  So, why haven't you played it yet?Congrats on the Golden Geeks and other awards!

RATING: 10
Highly engaging 2 or 3 hour romp through Cold War foreign policy.  3-tiered deck allows for relative historical accuracy and enjoyable card interactions.  Nice, usable components on clean board.  Wonderful balance of strategy, tactics, and luck.  Very rarely will dice determine the result of this game, but they definitely have an impact on strategy.  Same can be said of card draws and their tactical impact, IF both players are experienced enough to be able to use cards to their advantage or minimal detriment.  Definite learning curve, although individual mechanic rulesets are simple enough to present and understand (after one lengthy learning game, folks should have no difficulty playing again in the near future).  Theme is integral and perfectly presented.  Only deterrent to playing is relatively lengthy playtime.

RATING: N/A
Outstanding game with great reviews. But at 3 hours, I doubt this would get played more than once or twice. Risk is about the most that my students can handle for a 3 hour gamefest with 1 game. Not a game that has much appeal for my students.

It seems that 1960 scratches the same itch that this game does. But does so in less time and with more fun. See: http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/278441/twilight-struggle-vs-1960-the-making-of-the-presi

Actual Playtime Poll: http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/512910/poll-the-real-play-time
NB: There's no question that it takes at least 3 hours (sometimes longer, i.e., 4-5 hours) for first time players and maybe 2.5 hours for seasoned players. These are only average numbers, but still reflect the length of the game. THEREFORE, The big question then becomes whether the game feels boring (i.e., repetitive, etc).


NB: Checkout this DIY option since it would be a good use for our extra A&A board: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/image/533059/twilight-struggle

Many have said the game is complex. Others adore it. Here's a teaching site: Twilightstrategy.com if you want to learn to play.



=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
4/2008 It's nice to finaly have played what everyone's talking at the moment.  It's a good game with many well integrated elements.  What brings it down is all the randomness.  To succeed you need luck to be on your side when drawing cards and throwing the dice.  Thus, each round you have to evaluate your new set of cards and then respond to your opponents actions, making long term planning difficult.  Although the cards might be balanced, a couple of (un)lucky rounds can make or break your game.  As for game length, for a game with so much luck involved it takes way too long.  Initial rating based on one game is likely to change after another game.

3/2010 Further game play has revealed several interesting elements and great depth, though the game type and topic seems to target a limited audience.  Rating up from 6 to a doubious 8 given several pre-requisites are fulfiled.

1/2011 Although war themed games are normaly not to my liking, this game has become the exception.  Rating up to 10, my "favourite" war game.

Bought 1/2/2010

RATING: 9
A deep game with surprisingly simple rules. Easy to learn, tougher to conquer, lots of fun to play. I find that having to work from the cards in my hand limits my tendency for AP, but there are still lots of tense decisions when you need that event but you also need the points but you don't want to give your opponent the bonus but you need to have control of South America so you can score it... The cards are awesome and the events really help to make the game for a history buff like me. I expect this to move up in my ratings if only I can find more people to play it with!

RATING: 9
Clever made card driven area control game with great historical theme!!! Lots of background information about the Cold War. Great work! First few games take easily over 4 hours. It takes a while till you have an overview of all cards and can optimize your gameplay. A card overview comes with the game. The USSR is stronger at the beginning, the US is better in late war. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I had disregarded this game for a long time due to the fact that it only accommodates two players, but I'm very impressed after playing my first full game. Agonising decisions galore, an abundance of cunning strategies at your disposal, this game is HEAVY in the best possible way. Our game took ages to play, and ended in a hugely dramatic tie... to some a tie might sound like a poor/null result having invested countless hours, but it was anything but. The only game I have given an instant 10 and I can't wait to play again.

Update: the following two games have been disappointing in terms of enjoyment. The first of these was a heavy defeat which I deserved due to bad decisions and ignorance of important cards - I can live with this, as I will improve with experience and avoid the same mistakes. The second, however, was an enjoyable and very even battle for the first 6 or so turns, before being completely bent out of shape by monumentally one-sided dice results. It was just so dispiriting to see a great deal of thought and astute planning completely undone in the final turns by lucky roll after lucky roll for my opponent (almost every coup, even longshots, seemed to yield a 6 or a 5) and dismal roll after dismal roll for my part. I have read words to the effect that it is 'exceptionally rare' for luck to determine the outcome, but this was surely one of those occasions. Perhaps you just have to accept there is potentially a large amount of luck on offer if things don't happen to even out, but I feel the need to take a point off my previous assessment of a '10'. Galling, and can't imagine wanting to play again for a while.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

Very, very good.  Theme and atmosphere, and loads of tension - could easily give you a mad fit worthy of Kruschev.  Quite a lot of luck, I think, but it seems to make the game better, not worse. The design is original and brilliant in too many ways to detail here.

Few games' mechanisms give life to their subject like this one's do (here the feel of trying to control the entire precarious globe) with the card names and graphics providing the historical chrome that's the icing on a tasty, tasty theme-cake.

Also - all games played out very differently.  That's good.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

[b]8: Very good game. Rarely disappoints me. High on my request/recommend list.[/b] 

Physical Game: Traded, came to the realization this wouldnt see the table much and would be hard to teach new opponents after having learned the game more and more. Long in the tooth and just not for me/our group. 6

PC Game: This is where the game shines for me, easy to play against the AI, the AI at this point is cleaning my clock and does not take too long. Rating upped. 8

RATING: 6

The reason for the score being currently only a 6 is the length of the game (the first time I played the boardgame version it took 6 hours) and the fact that due to its length it's unlikely to see the table often.  I look forward to seeing if by playing the online version I can reduce the playtime of this excellent game.

Saddly is a two players game.

RATING: 9.8
One of the two best games I ever played. What can I say more? ;-)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
[Played 8 times]
It's not a wargame, but a fiddly area-majority game driven by cards and resolved with dice.
Probably more appealing to wargamers or those not minding if, after 3 hours, the outcome will be determined by a die roll in the last action of the last turn (happened thrice to us).

Theme is original and interesting, but gameplay is very random. You roll dice to: realign, coup, the space race, several events (all the Wars, Quagmire/BearTrap, Summit, Olympics...); that's pretty much everything you can do in the game except for placing influence.
Distribution of cards can screw you (because you get cards of low value or the opponent gets those with high value or you get only those associated with his events or all these together!) or help you a lot (reverse the examples).
Handling the events of the opponents would be the most interesting part, if it weren't often pretty obvious (play last those with effects "until end of turn", use the Space Race, the ONU and the "held option" to neutralize the most dangerous, etc.).
After you know the cards, you'll start to play around them (knowing that Cuba will be taken by Fidel, etc.).
The overall result is that you don't feel rewarded by your decisions, but driven to a random outcome by the dice and cards.

There are some production issues: 
-) you'll need something to replace control markers (e.g. wooden cubes) as they are overlapped and thus cannot be read (alternatively you'll need to inspect stacks of counters every few actions); 
-) it's quite uncomfortable to determine the degree of control you've in each region (and since this is crucial to scoring, you'll need to do it often);
-) some cards aren't clear enough;
-) errata corrige issued about cards and setup (and constantly evolving...);
-) some spelling errors.

Average game length for us: 3 hours.
Expensive.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Deep yet not overly complicated. An elegant and theme-drenched game if I've ever played one. Though it's not hard to get started, it's like chess in that there is clearly do much more to it than you first see in terms of possible strategies, and that you find yourself playing to beat the opponent more often than the game. Simply amazing

Clean mechanics (not like e.g. Hannibal, where too many mechanics are mixed), LONG game, but enjoyed the experience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Played as US once and USSR twice... got smoked all three times.

UPDATE: Won as USSR, now have to beat "The Bear" next game.  Last victory points earned playing Middle East Scoring (for the second time) in turn 5.

UPDATE: Won as US, albeit against a less experienced player.  Auto-victory in turn 9;  last points earned with 4 Space Race points.

GAME 6:  Third win in a row, made a big push as the USSR in Europe, and was rewarded by the Europe scoring card coming up for the third time (and ending the game) in Turn 7.

Game 8 - Control of Europe in Turn 3 as US player!

Game 9 - My longest game so far... went 9 rounds.  I played several events that gave me Poland, then played Chernobyl and locked the USSR player out of Europe.  He had the Europe scoring card, and was forced to play it when I had domination, which led to an auto-victory.

Game 10 and 11 Online... losses

Game 12 - Conquered by Bruce the Bear in Round 7 (concession)

Game 13 - Warm-up for WBC

Game 14 and 15 - Wins (in WBC tourmey) as US and USSR respectively.  I was dealt good hands in both games, and had some very lucky die rolls in Game 15.  I didn't anticipate winning any games, so I had to forfeit in the round of 16, as I needed to return home.

Games 16-18 - Online. Quickly erased any hubris from WBC - I was demolished all three times, and I was getting pretty good hands in all the games.

Game 19 Back to F2F.  We simulated tourney bidding, and I got the US with 4(!) extra influence to place.  I just think that's too much of an advantage.  I was leading in VP's the entire game except for one action round in turn one, after my opponent played Olympic Games.
Autovictory in Turn 8.  Thanks for having me over, Alan!

Game 20 - Another game with Alan.  I got the US with 3 extra OPS from the bid.  My strategy was to blow out Asia, which I locked down except for N. Korea.  I also had an advantage in Europe because of my extra ops.  I changed course, however, and decided to not battle Alan's advances into Asia.  I'd already made my 8VP's from SE Asia scoring, so as he challenge in Asia, I turned an eye toward keeping either Saudi Arabia or Libya in the Middle East to prevent control, as well as getting started in the third world.  This was where the game was won.  Alan was never able to get an OP into South America, after an unlucky die role on a realignment wiped out his placed OPS after a Junta.  I also had the Panama Canal countries controlled.  It was too much for him to overcome.  I won an auto victory in either Turn 7 or 8.

Game 21:  An epic battle with Alan.  Alan took USSR for a 2OPs bid.  Die rolls for his space race were, as usual, terrible.  But I didn't dump too many cards there either, and I only ended up with a 4 VP edge there.  The scoring cards came in bunches, and both of us made some sub-optimal plays, missing out on points.  He was able to 5-Year Plan to throw away South American Scoring, which I'd set up for 9VP's by realigning him out every time he dipped his toe in 'The Pond'.  This hurt, but I was able to hold my lead in Europe throughout the game, and this paid off a couple VP's each time Europe scoring arose.  I had a great setup in the Middle East, but Muslim Revolution hurt me badly.  As luck had it, Alan's hot coup rolls went cold in the Late War, and I was able to stay strong in Asia and Africa.  After a late coup to send the Defcon to 2, I was able to use Wargames to score an auto-victory in Turn 9.

Game 22 - Alan's bidding has become more miserly, so I only had one extra influence to place as the US player.  I had Middle East scoring in my hand to start, so I put the extra influence in Iran to start with Presence and a Battleground, then sprung the scoring in Action Round 1 of Turn 1.  Alan sprung Asia early, which basically put us back to zero.  He also had Europe scoring, which he decided to burn in the headline for zero points.  I focused on the Middle East, gaining a strong position.  Alan eventually locked down the Iran-Pakistan-Afganistan triangle, and marched thru to SE Asia. I tried to be a hornet in the SE Asia nest, throwing some successful coups in Vietnam and forcing him to burn higher Ops valued cards to keep his position. 

He redrew Middle East scoring in Turn 3, but was able to burn it with Five-Year Plan, and prevent me from a big score.  However, I was able to play SE Asia scoring after an event allowed me to weaken his hold in the area.  He only benefitted 2 VP's.  

I was able to get lucky rolls in Central and South America, and by Turn 6 Alan had no presence in either area.  I scored Central for a couple VP's, and South for Control for 10.  Alan's rolls had been okay early, but went ice cold from Turn 3 on.  If the Law of Large Numbers is true, I'm in for a bad string of luck for die rolls in this game.

Alan wasn't able to recover after my score in South America - I was at 17 VP's when we reshuffled.  Alan drew South America scoring again.  He took three shots at 'getting in' but I was able to realign him out each time.  The game ended in Turn 7 - an autovictory for the US triggered by South America scoring.

Game 23 - FTF with Alan.  No bids... I rolled high and chose USSR.  Alan's first hand had 2 scoring cards, 5 1 OPS cards, and one 2 OP card (ouch).  I made a coup in Italy and rolled a 6, putting a virtual lockdown on the region.  I also made rapid advances in the Middle East over the next couple Turns, and Alan couldn't recover.  Oh, and the dice continued to be unkind to my opponent.  Auto-victory in Turn 6 for the USSR.

Game 24: FTF with Alan.  Bidding left me with USA and 1 extra Influence, which went into Iran.  I tried burning lots of USSR cards, which helped Alan gain a foothold in France.  However, I used the cards for successful coups (rolled 5's) and started to solidify Mid East and march through the "Iran-Afghan-Pakistan" triangle into Asia.  Alan burned China to lock down SouthEast Asia.

Turn 2 saw more lucky coups from me (rolled 5 and 6).  I locked down Spain and (since I'd burnt Nassar) took Egypt.  Alan used two big 4 Ops cards in his headline and first play to set up a realignment of West Germany.  Great move - terrible rolls.  He only decreased my Influence by 1, which was immediately replaced since the card he used was Marshall Plan.  I struck back in France and East Germany with realignment, and eliminated his presence in France.  He was forced to play defense in East Germany, which allowed me to take France for Domination in Europe.  This remained unchanged the rest of the game.

Turn 3 saw the scoring cards, and I ended up +2 VP's.  I got India, he started to balanced out the Middle East.  Looking ahead, Alan made a strong play into Africa at the end of the round.  I chose to keep pushing in Asia (South Korea, Taiwan).

Turn 4 stated with Africa and South America scoring, and Alan had a (short lived) lead in VP's.  I solidified Europe through Greece and Turkey, and started to fight back in Africa and SE Asia.  Alan had a tough hand, and used his Space Race lead to discard some of my cards.

Turn 5 saw several "bad luck" occurances for Alan.  Missle Envy didn't really help him, and my second play was "Bear Trap".  He proceded to roll 5-5-6-(scoring card)-5-2.  Ouch.  While he was spinning his wheels, I pushed in South America, and SE Asia.  SE Asia and Europe scoring pushed me to about 7 VP's.

Turn 6 saw our luck reverse.  Coups and a Brush War did nothing for me, but Alan was able to take back Taiwan and Iran.  He was also able to start to push his agenda in Central and South America.  The VP track was at 8 VP for me, but the board was starting to look better for Alan - domination in Africa and Central America, balance in MidEast and South America, domination for me in Asia and Europe.  I pushed into N. Korea in the hopes that I would get Asia scoring next round.

Turn 7, and I was dealt both Asia and Europe scoring.  In two plays, VP +16, then Auto Victory.

I thought this was an example of how Alan was able to survive a terrible run of luck, but found a way to start to push back.  I think he would have been hard pressed to win, but was on Space Race box away from 4 more VP's, which would have kept the game from ending.

Game 25: FtF with Alan.  I am US with one extra Influence.  I draw Middle East scoring, so pop Iran and play ME scoring in headline.  However, Alan anticipates and grabs Egypt in his headline.  This is a microcosm for how the scoring went until Turn 5.  In fact, I think entering Turn 6 I was up 1 VP.

My strategy was to put constant pressure in Europe.  With Independant Reds, followed by Truman, I took Yugoslavia.  With the Pope, I put him on the run in Poland.  With East Europe unrest, and a turn where I had big Ops and Alan had few, I was able to nab East Germany.  He was on the run in Europe!

An early key was Alan taking Iran, but not locking it down.  I couped and got control back, and was able to hold it the rest of the game.  Although he got some Ops into Pakistan and India, I used Indo-Pakistani war and stole Pakistan, then took India when he was forced to bolster Poland.

Alan never was able to revolt in Vietnam, and that allowed me to reach and hold Thailand throughout the game.

Central and South America was not much of a factor.

Alan usedDecolonization in SE Asia, and De-Stalinization in Europe.  He vener got his hands on South African unrest. I played Portugese Empire Crumbles, but after I scored Africa with Alan having no presence.  I used the Ops to lock down Angola even after he added 2 influence.  SE African States was a fine coup target for me later in the round to get my required Military Ops.  Africa ended up yielding about 10 points for me!

Notably, my roles were terrible throughout except for two coups and Indo-Pakistani war.  I didn't advance by die roll at all in the space race.  Even a bone-crushing attempt at realignment in Europe via ABM Treaty was a dismal failure... even with heafty modifiers in my corner, I was the one that lost ops!  Alan, on the other hand, advanced far in the Space race and only failed one coup.  

By Turn 8, I was at 15 VP's.  However, Warsaw Pact struck, and crippled me in Europe.  I'd never been this far ahead in Europe... so I'd never considered the power of that card late in the game.  Suddenly, things were looking up for Alan!  Alas, the Iron Lady chipped in a point, then Alan was forced to play Africa scoring once again.

This game went QUICKLY from tight and tense, to a blue board.  Alan's hands were generally low Ops, and he missed some opportunities in ME and Asia.  Luckily I made my mistakes in the first rounds of Turn 1, or late enough that I'd built a powerful board position.

Autovictory in Turn 8.

Game 26, face to face with my friend Alan.

Alan won the bid for Russia, giving me an extra Influence.  I had De Gaulle, so decided to stay out of France.  I went 4 W. Germany, 3 Italy, and my extra in Iran.  I would detail my initial strategy, but it would be too painful for me as Alan took control of this game from the first play, and I was relegated to a "catch up" position.

Turn 1:  Alan realigned me out of Iran with his first play.  I marched into Thailand.  Alan played Vietnam Revolts, followed by a coup in Thailand with the dreaded 6 Ops China card.  He went on to lock down 6 or 7 SE Asian countries.  My only success came in gaining Control of France.

(commentary - I spread myself too thin.  I tried to get fancy with France, Iran, and Thailand.  Alan punished me in two of these countries with solid rolls.  Every die roll went sour for me this turn, a pattern that sadly lasted throughout)

Turn 2:  Wow, what a crappy hand for me.  I'd controlled S. Korea in Turn 1, but now was dealt Korean War.  I also got Castro, Deconolization, Israeli War, Nasser, and Middle East scoring.  Alan was able to get into Africa in Nigeria and Angola cheap, and controlled the Defcon to keep me from having a coup.  He used his huge Ops advantage to start spreading communism through Eastern Europe (and Greece) and the Middle East.

(commentary - Alan did a good job dictating Defcon throughout, and staying out of countries I could have couped for Military Ops.  He chipped away 2 VP's per Turn)

Turn 3:  Alan makes a power move in Europe:  He headlines Socialist Gov'ts and knocks me down to 1 Influence in Italy.  Then he drops Nato for 4 Influence in Italy with his first play.  What is that feeling in my gut?  Oh yeah, desperation.

I headlined Containment, and had a hand full of 3 Ops cards.  I pushed into E. Germany.  I thought I could make him burn what little Ops he had left in Germany, then "make my move" (see next paragraph).  It was my best and worst move of the game.  Alan did, in fact use up his last two >1 Ops cards in Germany.

So I took my shot.  I pushed though the Middle East, taking Lebanon, neutralizing Jordan (action 3), and taking Saudi Arabia (action 4) and Gulf States (action 5).  He was forced to play Europe and Asia scoring as his last actions.  For my sixth action, I went for a realignment with 3 Ops.  I realigned Jordan at +2, but it cost a precious 2nd die roll to eliminate Alan's Influence and gain control.  This left one realignment roll in Iraq at +2 to knock Alan out of this area of the board, and open a path for me into Asia.  Any +1 US difference would have done the job.

Result: US-1  USSR-6  :soblue:

(commentary - Alan initially thought my play in E. Europe was a mistake, but I felt I had to be certain he didn't have the Ops to defend against my moves in Middle East.  I'd be interested in any opinions about this play)

Turn 4:  I knew it was bad news when the US school stared teaching the Pledge of Allegiance in Russian :laugh:
I made a wild play this turn in Asia, spending 2 Ops per Influence to try to sneak my way into India.  Alan saw it coming, and dropped enough Influence for control [u]before[/u] he had control of Burma (or Pakistan).  Ha, finally!  I played Indo-Pakistani War.  I felt certain that the dice gods would finally smile on me, after all of the trauma they'd inflicted throughout the night.

I rolled a 3.

Turn 5:  Alan was at 18 VP's.  He had many options to obtain victory - event cards, space race, a scoring card.  I had some things I could also do, but I held two scoring cards.  I had to hope for the best.  It turned out that "the best" was Alan trying the space race with his first action.  He rolled a success, and the game mercifully ended.

Twilight Struggle can be a tough game.  Alan outplayed me from the first card, and didn't leave me space anywhere on the board.  He kept accruing VP's, and I didn't have the good fortune of "hitting a home run" with either of my desparation plays.

Congrats, Alan.  Thanks for having me over for a game.  I'll bring Vodka next time ;)

Game 27 F2F with Bruce.  I was generally outplayed.  Bruce got huge Ops hand throughout the game.  He had domination of the Middle East the turn after the first scoring of ME occurred.  That scoring card never came up again.  I took Pakistan away with the War Card, and established solid presence both there and in Taiwan, Japan and some SE Asian countries to keep balance.  Bruce was solid in Central and South America, but only Central scored early while I still had control of Panama.  Bruce never got into Africa, I was able to spread quite a bit of influence in Turn 4, then scored it at the end for 11 VP's.

Europe was the difference.  I had 14 VP's going into Turn 5.  He headlined Europe scoring to get it out of the way.  I played Missle Envy, and his top Ops card was ABM Treaty.  I used the Ops (as per the event) to lock down two extra countries in Europe for Domination; 5 VP's instead of 1.  Although he held scoring cards that could have made big points for him, he was forced to use Missle Envy on his first action.  My next play was Olympic Games for the win.

Looking at the board, it seems like Russia should have been on its way to a huge win.  But the timing of the scoring cards was key.  I got some good luck with my roles, especially Indo-Pakistani War, and a coup attempt in Panama.  I also hit every Space Race roll.  Bruce's hands were much more powerful, and I had weak Ops throughout.

Game 28 - F2F with Alan. It has been about 18 months since my last play of Twilight Struggle.  Alan and I met up at a party at my sister‚Äôs place, and bemoaned our lack of TS‚Äôing.  This led to a play on Thursday, using the original tourney rules without any Deluxe add ons.  Alan bid two influence for USSR, which I dumped into Italy.  I also locked down France and W. Germany.  Alan controlled Poland and E. Germany.  He headlined Red Scare, which put a hurting on me as I didn‚Äôt even have an Ops 3 card!  Further, I feared Containment, but thankfully it did not come.  Alan failed a coup in Italy and Iran early, which allowed me to fortify Europe.  I also spread some influence in the Middle East - a risk in Egypt considering Nasser was on the loose.  Alan worked through the ‚ÄòStans, and into India in the next turn.  

Starting in the second round, I started controlling Defcon with my headlines - cards like Duck and Cover, etc.  Alan was a bit dismissive of the early, but started feeling cramped as the game progressed.  Alan took off on the Space Race, but I bounced back in Mid War but spacing some potentially terrible USSR cards and "One Small Step".  VP‚Äôs were hanging around even when the big action happened in Turn 5 and 6.
Alan had some big success in Asia, getting some good rolls and big Ops, but I struck back with Formosan Resolution and a HUGE successful coup in Thailand ‚Äì in essence crippling his advances (Korean War was out of the mix).  I‚Äôd rolled a second coup ‚Äò6‚Äô in Iran, forcing Alan to immediately remedy the situation when he drew ME scoring.  He had little access to Africa, and none to Central America after I‚Äôd realigned him out of Panama (he‚Äôd had a successful coup.  In turn 7, Alan drew three scoring cards.  An early play of CA scoring would have limited me to 4 VP‚Äôs.  However, Alan chose to hold that one until mid turn, while I poured in the influence and attained Control for 8 VP‚Äôs.  As of the CA scoring, I was up 16 VP‚Äôs.  

With Kitchen Debates and a poke in the chest, I was up 18 going into Late War.  We spun our wheels in Turn 8, with Alan making up a bit of ground with OPEC and entry through an action (Allende?) into South America.  It mercifully ended in Turn 9 with Wargames.  Alan felt he‚Äôd made a major error with the CA scoring.  I disagree - he was saddled with 3 scoring cards in one turn.  Had he played CA early, I could have easily made advances in another area and gotten ‚Äòpaid‚Äô.  

Game 29 - We played after a long layoff, late at night, and struggled because of a rules mistake made early in scoring.  Late in round two, Alan noticed we had scored Europe too high (for him) by 6 VP's in round one.  This had significantly affected his strategy moving forward, as he pushed for the 20 VP auto win.  However, being the gentleman he is, Alan insisted on correcting the score. He was unable to subsequently build board position. I eroded his +19 VP lead, survived an Olympic Games at Alan +18, and won on three scoring cards (from his hand!) in Turn 8.

Game 30 - Alan drove to Lancaster Friday morning and jumped right into WBC's Alhambra tourney.  He won three coterminous games to win the tournament (!), ate a fast meal, and settled in for the long Twilight Struggle.  

Surrounded by gamers, podcasters, kibitzers and designers in the Open Gaming area, joined by friends waiting for the Liar's Dice competition, we truly had a unique atmosphere for our contest.  Alan, as USSR, opened with a failed bid for Italy.  As I captured Iran, Pakistan and India, he built up Eastern Europe.  I successfully eroded his position in SE Asia, as he broke into North and Central Africa, and Cuba, Mexico and Panama.  

I had 4 consecutive coups rolling a 4 or 5, then a fifth coup rolling a 6.  I used my luck to run him out of Thailand, Vietnam, Mexico, and Panama.  He advanced far on the Space Race, but was unable to parlay his Headline or Two Spaced Cards advantage into any meaningful board position.  

I won with a Missle Envy - We Will Bury You combo in Turn 7, with the US at +13 on the VP track.  

Afterward, Alan observed a tendency he has as Russia to go for broke with Coups with big Ops cards, and feels this is a misuse of his first player advantage.  He also noted that I tend to burn his event* cards out of the deck early, and he tends to Space Race my event* cards.  By turn 3, he has been feeling the ill effects of this hand management strategy.  

Now that I'm contending with a decorated WBC champion, I fear my work will be even more arduous in game 31.


Game 31 - Alan and I got together Thursday night for a game.  I played with the US, gaining one influence.  I had Middle East scoring in hand, and used my influence advantage for a quick 4VP by controlling Iran.  As promised, Alan avoided coups early, choosing instead to place more influence and realign when he saw good spots.  Early, he had a good realignment in Europe, which opened the door to the USSR controlling West Germany.  I locked down France, and held on to Italy despite losing IP‚Äôs twice after realignment rolls.  I got away with playing Korean War (after taking Taiwan), and used the Ops to control South Korea.  I opened turn 2 with Marshall and NATO, and after taking Spain decided to do nothing more in Europe.  Alan continued to invest in Europe, so early in turn 2 I had gained an advantage in SE Asia and the Middle East.  He pushed back after I was forced to play Vietnam revolts, taking Thailand and Pakistan.  By early in turn 3, he had control in Argentina and Cuba.  Despite some further gains from me in the Middle East, the board looked grim.  I felt good about the VP‚Äôs, which had USSR at only +1.
The watershed event was my play of Indo-Pakistani War.  Alan had no controlled neighboring countries, and I was able to just gain control with a roll of 4.  I marched from India to Burma, couped Thailand, and took advantage of an oversight on Alan‚Äôs end to lock down Thailand.  Middle East started shifting red, but I decided Israel, Egypt and Jordan were enough to hold on to.  I moved into Algeria, Morroco, and heavy into Egypt, locking Alan out so long as he didn‚Äôt get an event on the Late War reshuffle.  Alan made some gains in Central America, but I was able to use a free coup in Argentina to eliminate him from South America.  I was able to realign him out of Mexico, and tip the balance of power back to blue in the Americas.
In turn 9, I was able to play a series of scoring cards (Kitchen Debates, South America, ‚ÄúThe Iron Lady‚Äù) to get VP‚Äôs to US +18.  I held onto Middle East scoring for my last card, hoping that Alan had a problematic event or scoring card.  He begrudgingly played Africa scoring to give the US the Auto Victory.

Game 32 - F2F with Alan, Turn 5 auto win for Alan as USSR.  Details to follow.

Game 33 - F2F with Alan at WBC in open gaming.  Turn 8 DefCon victory for me.  One of our best early games, but in Mid War, Alan failed on literally every roll, and I succeeded on every roll.  It was...unnatural. Details to follow.

RATING: 6
Played once. A grand design, that's for sure. But also one that I respect much more than that I actually enjoy playing it.
The see-sawing gameplay, resembling a tug-of-war, as thematical as it may be, is just not to my liking. Also has quite a big dose of luck for a strategy game, certainly one as long as TS.
There's certainly more to discover here, and I won't rule out playing again in the future, but right now I'm not willing to dedicate entire game nights to TS when there are other games I simply enjoy much more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
My rating is based from a purely wargame-historical simulation perspective. It isn't the cold war, adding historical text to cards and defcon track doesn't make a wargame on the cold war. Where are ICBM, bombers and boomers? Where is the tense decision making of the cuban missile crisis, the Kippur war, the Ryan incident or of the political bungling of the vietnam war?

It is simply a complex euro with pasted on theme. Not well done GMT!

Axing the possibility of a fought WW3 simply eloiminate one of the mayor rationale of cold war decision making (force correlations and efforts in modifying an unfavorable correlation). Working on the basis of the old Pax Britanninca game would have done much more good to the Cold War.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Here's the deal; you know how there's this weird "three episodes" TV shows out there ? Brilliant pieces of TV where the first three episodes aren't so good or only become so in retrospect ? That's Twilight Struggle. It's a brilliant game, that you'll only start to really enjoy in your third or so game.  It's not that the first ones aren't interesting ,but you'll probably feel like your drowning more than you're playing. However, by the third game, you got a good grasp of mechanics and know the early war cards pretty well. Because of that, the game unfolds faster and you really get to feel the grit of your opponent. In short, that's when the Cold War feel really sets across the table and the game stops appearing so overly thematic.

Mechanically, Twilight struggle is streamlined enough to allow deep strategy and stimulating duel play. There's not many things to do, mechanics wise, but there's plenty of strategy to choose from. Some people might deplore the luck aspects, but I think that really helps to capture the uncertainty of the cold war. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My first few games ended quickly, but can see the potential when both players are experienced. Look forward to playing this over the years with my dad, a history buff.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
What kept me from trying out Twilight Struggle for the longest time, in spite of all good things I heard about it, was one glance into the deck of cards that revealed the card of Willy Brandt, german chancellor. His election is handled as an important benefit to the USSR within the game - an interpretation that I find hard to swallow, especially as it resonates strongly with the more primitive criticisms of the Ostpolitik of the social democrat/liberal coalition both then and now. This little peeve of mine was not enough to make me consciously avoid the game, but with the gaming glut upon us, not actively trying to play a game usually means it will pass you by.

A good thing, then, that I recently had a chance to finally swallow my leftie pride and play the game. And lo, it was great - marrying the operation/event card motor to an area majority chassis works very well here, and the added twist that makes it hard to avoid good things happening to your enemy is brilliant, since it inflicts difficult strategic choices on you and nicely ensures that eventually, the Warsaw Pact will form up.

Compared with other games of similar weight, good or bad luck in die rolls can be pretty influental and a bad hand can be crippling (try surviving Europe, Asia and Africa scoring as the US in Mid-War for some fun). Since extreme chance also tends to early victories, this is not really a bad thing (as much as I might curse it when it befouls my plans), especially since it bolsters the replayability and serves to even the odds with players of differing experience levels.

RATING: 9
After hundreads of plays i discovered that this game is a complete luckfest when 2 equally experienced players are playing. It all comes down to who gets the better cards and when. Even a noob can defeat an experienced player by round 3 if he gets the right cards. The die also adds to the luck factor. Surely, strategic thinking and timely playing of your hand reduces that factor. However those facts don't change that Twilight Struggle is one of the best games out there and the game that i play the most.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of the best examples of a game whose mechanics and theme are perfectly intertwined.  Twilight Struggle thrust players directly into the tension and intrigue of the Cold War - all while avoiding the war game characteristic of direct combat and conquest.  The card-driven mechanics not only allow a player to change history - but also has the byproduct of whetting a players interest in the events described on them.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Don't know where to begin describing my love for this game. Played it between 40-50 times if I had to hazard a guess and each game is still as exciting and fresh as always. The game gets much better and more interesting the more you play as you become familiar with the cards and know how to play around them/structure your turn with them in mind, even if they're in your opponents hand. If there is any weakness to the game it would be precisely that which makes it so fun - due to how crucial it is to know the cards to play well, it is difficult to introduce new players to the game as they will consistently lose their first 4-5 playthroughs vs. an experienced player, guaranteed.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Twilight Struggle is brilliant.

Everything about it is fun, tense, and engaging. Turns are short but freighted with import; every decision is difficult because it depends on so many variables, changes the terrain for the rest of the turn, and involves giving up options even as you select one option to execute.

There isn't an ounce of fat here, either. It's not bloated or chromed out; every element is important and has its purpose. It's got lots of depth, too, and I can see why people play this one dozens or hundreds of times. Length (first play: 1 hour to cover the rules for two newbies, 2.5 hours to play) seems like the main stumbling block to getting this to the table often.

It's also beautifully designed, conveying lots of information in clever and understated ways and looking good at the same time. Just a fantastic package overall.

A classic in the making - now it is!  Solid strategy with card-driven mechanism.  Real game tension.  Tremendously enjoyable. 2014 update - at this point I have 50 or 60 ftf plays of this classic. Approaching 10 years and still not tired of this one. Looking forward to the small expansion that is coming.

RATING: 9
2017 Top 100 Favorites of All-Time: #19

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Too long. I LOVE 1960, and I'm also a huge fan of Founding Fathers--both games using the same card-based system as TS.  think I might like TS the least of the three. Don't get me wrong, the gameplay is great. There's definitely some crunchy decisions that have to be made. I also greatly appreciate (being a historian) the clever implementation of historical content. The game is also very well-produced (deluxe edition). The board is beautiful, the box and card stock are thick, and the chits are good quality. The game is just too long. Any game that takes 4-6 hours to complete is way too long. We played 1960 in just under 3 hours our first time. That was a learning game. Founding fathers took just under 2 hours (with 2). Our first game of Twilight Struggle took over 4 hours and we only finished 5 rounds out of 10! That's crazy. We're not super-quick players, but we typically play pretty close to the estimated time on the box, which is 3 hours with TS. I could see that once you know most of the cards and you have played the game 5+ times. But who has time to play this often? Not me. So, in rating this game, I have to consider opportunity cost. If it takes me 6-7 hours to play a game for the first, and about 5 hours for the next few games, is it worth the investment in time, and if it is, how much does the long play time take away from my overall enjoyment of the game? I'm not sure. It's clean, it's incredibly well-designed, it's strategic yet oh so tactical and it's fun, but it's SOOOOO LOOOONG!

A few side notes: The game is not as atmospheric as I thought it was going to be. Despite the rich history and the evocative board, I didn't feel completely immersed into the period. 1960 has more theme, IMO. TS felt a bit like Risk--dry and calculated in many ways. There was a lot of tit-for-tat territory swaps throughout. Also, there is a HUGE, HUGE, HUGE amount of randomness in this game. It definitely swings both ways, so I won't call the game "unforgiving." However, I will say that certain cards will frustrate you, and expect two equally-skilled players to have their game decided by dice rolls. Neither one of the factors is really a sticky point for me, but I thought I should mention it. 

All in all, my initial impression is that this is a superb game that's too long. But because it's so good and because I like the card system and history so much, I'll hold onto it. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I respect the tension and historical text in this war game. But at the end of the day it's a territory control game where you just flip numbers over, there's just a little dice action, but no real fighting or miniatures to hold a real visual appeal. Its gameplay is very monotone throughout, so it's not exciting persay. But what it does, it does very well, the tension is great. This isn't one that i will bring to the table too often, but will reserve it for special occasions as though it were a fine bottle of wine, to occasionally order just to remember its goodness. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
5 / 5 - Great

This game has potential flaws, which might bother you if they're the sort of thing that puts you off a game - it's a 2-3 hour game which sometimes turns on random factors and it's asymmetrical with a slight imbalance. However, the game is just so exciting and tense to play that I couldn't give a hoot. It has astonishing depth and historical flavour and gets awfully tense and difficult. Has appeal for any gaming style - there's analysis, history and adrenaline galore. Only major downside is that an in-depth knowledge of the 100-plus cards is required for good play. See my review for more details: http://fortressat.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1873&Itemid=0

RATING: 8
Update after 11 plays: There are things that keep this game from becoming more than an 8: Playing time can be too long, the events lead to very unhistorical scenarios (the US avoiding Cuba before Fidel etc), the randomness can be frustrating and some victories are not very fun (winning on a Nuclear War after playing for board position for two hours). But I really like the atmosphere, the tension and the mindset of Domino Theory. With the right opponent this is a game I look forward to playing many more times. My most recent play was a USSR victory at 20 VP in round 5. At 13 VP I scored 6 VP with OPEC, lost 2 VP, regained them with Indo-Pakistani War and then topped it off with Willy Brandt f√∂r 1 VP.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The cold war theme is an excellent choice for a board game. There's some complex card rules which makes the experience a bit confusing in the beginning. There's also lots of hard decision which really fits the theme. A gamer's game, a war game, and really not for everyone.  

Pros: Simple but deep card mechanics. It takes a couple of games to see some of the intricacies in the cards and how to best play them. The theme is deep and very satisfying. 

Cons: Action paralysis (AP) is common due to all hard choices. Hard to catch up if you do too many mistakes. Lacks great catchup mechanics. Hard to keep track of scores for each regions on the map. Hard to assess chances when rolling. Randomness can mess up your tactics. 

Sleeved and in mint condition. 

In Stockholm.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.1
Played 5 times, very decent game. Mechanics are incredibly well-done (elegantly simple), and do a very nice job of intertwining real history into game mechanics. Probably our favorite right now for a quick, painless couple hours of gaming (replacing Wilderness War). Where this game lacks, IMO, is in replayability. All games fall into the same arc, and with the card decks segregated into eras, the phases of the game start to feel repetitive. And, as with almost all CCGs, there really isn't any strategy aspect to the game, just the tactical decisions of what order to play your cards in. Finally, the scoring mechanism, which is very creatively designed, adds too much luck to the game (for my taste).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of my favorite heavy games.
Definitely captures the cold war feel - VERY tense and thematic game. It has pretty steep learning curve, new player will lose first few games pretty automatically, because you got to have at least some idea of the cards to do well. Other than that (and maybe the long-ish playtime) it's very deserving of #1 spot on BGG. I personally prefer lighter and more social games myself, but when I think of my favorite heavier strategy games Twilight Struggle usually comes to mind. It's one of the few heavy games that can be called fun, unexpected things can happen. 

2-Player Comment:
* Twilight Struggle is designed for two.

RATING: 7
Great mechanics, well written rule book and dripping with theme. So why only 7?
It will be hard to get a game with someone. It's 2 players only, 3 hours long and probably the biggest problem is that the theme appeals most to over 40 year old Americans. If I find someone who doesn't mind those three things it's a 9.

(Its interesting that in the designer notes that they say they wanted to make a shorter game to get away from those 8 hour games. It strikes me that this was developed for war gamers who are used to 4-8 hour games.)

Sell for $60, played once

RATING: 9
A really special game.  Loved it on first play.  

A game driven by event cards, with tough decisions, different strategies, great card combos.   An excellent insight into the history of the period.  Area control with card driven action points.  No direct combat, but boy is this game tense.

Plans can crumble due to bad dice, bad card draw or to events stealing cards. No room for complacency at all as the 2 superpowers square off against each other.   Makes things all the more satisfying when leading ones side to victory.

Definitely a game for those who are used to complexity and willing to invest the time to get across the rules. 

An easy 9 on first play, suspect it will reach 10 after more plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Love the cardplay, which is similar to Baseball Highlights (well, vice versa) in the physical mechanics of it as well as the tactical timing game.  Instead of building a deck to manage risk there's the play on the map.  It somehow feels wrong to compare these two games but I think they have a lot in common wrt overall feel and experience of play.

I don't understand the game on the map very well, but I think this is a function of not having played enough to get the gist of the decks.  Having an idea of what scoring cards and counter attacks are still present will prevent some really dumb, immediately reversible moves.

RATING: 10
I had avoided Twilight Struggle for ages because the theme seemed like a real snoozer.  A friend really wanted to play it on VASSAL so I read the rules, and to my surprise they really sparked my interest in the theme.  I even went out and got a book on the Cold War from the library--and have read lots more books after that.  The rules encouraged me to buy the game.

I rated this a 10 after my first play.  Why?  The fact that my opponent and I both had yelling, swearing, namecalling tantrums when our plans went awry.  I have never been so emotionally invested in a game.  Our hands were shaking from the tension.  My opponent says that he doesn't think he could play Twilight Struggle every week because the emotional rollercoaster would be too much.  (Quote from my opponent after our third game: "This game makes me angry even when I win.")

If you don't have it, get it.  If the theme doesn't grab you, read the rules and see if that changes your mind.  If you have it and haven't gotten it to the table yet, you're missing out!  Give it a play and pretty soon you'll be swearing at your opponent too!

Always, always, always want to play this.

RATING: 3
By BGG criteria a "3" is:  "Likely won't play this again although could be convinced. Bad."  I have played the game and these are my opinions.  Play is both counter-intuitive and, ultimately, quite gamey.  A card-shark's paradise, where new players have no prayer of lasting more than a turn or two.  Similar to Atlantic Storm in that the cards can create a lot of historical flavor, but outcomes can only coincidentally be mistaken for actual history.  As others have said this is really a Euro-style game with a tacked on conflict simulation theme.  Note, however, the design is definitely NOT "broken" - the 200+ ratings of "1" do not adhere to BGG ratings criteria.

RATING: 9.7
Played this one time and i loved it. Feels very overwhelming at first and you need to know the cards in order to play well. But i think this will come with more experience. Very complex and thoughtful but so good. 

Edit: Played a second time and liked it even more. Where with most games i dwindle away into a deep coma whenever it lasts too long for what it is, this one i can play 3 hours no problem. Every decision is VERY meaningful, the tension is real. This is the feeling you have when you are making a great play at poker... but then not 1 time a evening.. but EVERY play you do. 9.7 it is!

Reedit: Quite possibly the best boardgame ever made. This is on par with Puerto Rico qua elegance, replayabality and depth. I will keep Puerto Rico (elegant strategy for 4 players), The Castles of Burgundy (casual and deeper than it looks point salad) and Twilight Struggle (deep tense, 2 player strategy) Until the end of time :D
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Going into this game, I knew the pedigree it had and had the nagging feeling "C'mon, this game can't be THAT good!"

After the most recent reprint, I was able to get my hands on a reasonably priced copy... The game is good. Really good.

The good:
- Cards all have great flavor and translate well into in game actions. I was surprised at how much theme and tension and flavor the cards and gameplay were able to impart given a 100+ card deck and a d6.

- Managing your hand, resources, keeping an eye on your opponent, and furthering your own agenda mean that there is always a million things you want to do on a turn. Again, this is a great implementation of theme without introducing a ton of mechanics or complexity. Coups feel huge and impactful, spreading influence feels "right", and crossing your fingers during the Space Race all have a connection between what you're doing on board and what it represents in the game world.

- Multiple paths to victory without it being a point salad. I love the corner case victories of forcing your opponent to degrade DEFCON on their turn, winning out of nowhere with Wargames, capturing Europe, or just getting +20 VP over your opponent. Again, it's a lot to keep an eye on, but it all makes sense and does a great job or adding to tension.

- Speaking of, the VP slider is a great idea for this game and I love the tug of war aspect it adds to the game.

The bad:
- The rulebook is a great reference if you already know how to play the game. It's not, however, really well laid out for teaching two new players the mechanics or how to play. (I think it took our third playthrough to finally get to the point where we didn't feel like we completely missed a major rule, even then there were still little mixups we made).
-- With that in mind, there are a lot of great player aids available on BGG and other sites.

- I'm worried about the skill disparity in future games causing uneven matchups. The inherent randomness of the shared deck helps this a little bit, but could also really punish an inexperienced player who might not be able to play a poor hand optimally to mitigate damage. On the flipside, a really good hand could also be "wasted" for this reason.

- Games can be quite long. This may not be a problem for some gamers, but it can be difficult to get somebody to sit down and play the game for 3+ hours.

- I'm not nuts on the packaging and components. The map, while big and sturdy, doesn't unfold flat and is very busy. The game has a lot going on, but I feel like something better could have been done.

- The box is also very small, especially if you want to organize your chits in any substantial way, sleeve your cards (which I highly recommend for any game like this in which decks are used at different points through the game), or include any additional references or guides.

Even with those considerations, the game is worth checking out even if you have an inkling of interest in it, this style of game, or just to see what the buzz is about. Rare is the game that I leave the table and think about what I did, what I could have done, and what I would do next time, but Twilight Struggle tends to stick with you even after it's boxed up.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
[2011] I've only played once so far and we got a major rule wrong, which probably accounts for the fact I thought it was meh, with the USSR severely overpowering. After this one way, my feeling is that I prefer 1960: Making of the President. Oh, what heresy!

Looking forward to playing it again, but correctly this time, at which point I'll no doubt revise my opinion and decide I prefer this one to 1960.

I bags Soviet Union, Andy...

[2015] It's possible I've not played this enough for it to click with me. It's also possible that I'm just not that thrilled by this kind of game (though I found 1960: Making of the President quite involving); or maybe it's just that this kind of sequenced-history game just doesn't grab me. I love history, but I dislike revisionism. Maybe that's why I preferred 1960 - because it's more like a knife fight than grand strategy, and doesn't feel like it strays from history too much, therefore the "what if?" feels more plausible.

I think TS is a reasonable game; but I can't understand what makes it so popular.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Probably my favorite of the CDG designs, just ahead of Wilderness War. I love how the complexity is kept low, this is a game approachable for anyone. And still has a load of historical feel, without rules load. I especially like how, for the most part, enemy events can't be avoided -- the 'OP or event' thing usually doesn't pass the giggle test for me in other CDG designs. Not for everyone, but deserves its accolades.

Edit: I lowered this to an 8 after playing a ton of games via the (excellent) digital adaption. It's a good game, but there is just so much luck involved. I am a wargamer, so dice don't bother me, but you truly can get diced horribly in this game, because there aren't a ton of rolls. If you get a couple of turns in a row with lousy cards and end up on the bad side of every die roll, it is just completely frustrating. I'd probably prefer a chit roll system, where the luck evens out.

I hadn't played the game enough prior to the digital version to notice how much the die rolls affect the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
I like this one, more than the rating indicates - but I'd never get to play this sufficiently to really get into it as much as I'd like to, if that makes any sense?

The constant tug-of-war, planning and contingency planning, the tension from pushing forwards with a thousand small plans, hoping that one will sneak through and wreck your opponent with something unseen. It's great! It feels like you can always sort of counter the opponent, to some extent, but I haven't played it enough - with full card-knowledge I could see this turning into a more conventional style of eking out incremental advantage, slowly building to an unstoppable momentum.

Too bad it takes too long for me for being a game that only plays two. It's rare the opportunity I can or feel like I want to play a game with one other person for two hours or more, but if I were to, this would be a great choice! 

A very good game!

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Game in a Nutshell: A Cold-war replication where you manage hands of cards and throw some dice around over several rounds as you attempt to gain influence over regions of the world. 

Pros: I like how the game always feels like you're playing damage control which keeps things tense throughout. The atmosphere of the game gets an 'A' due to the implementation of the theme down to the seemingly minor, but really major, add-ons like the defcon level and space race. I also highly enjoyed the different victory conditions and the balance it creates of juggling your own goals while trying to fend off your opponent from theirs.

Cons: The game is fiddly.  All the little chits all over are a nuisance. The quality of the components (with the exception of the cards) in the version I played (non-deluxe) were among the most disappointing I've seen and hardly warrant the asking price in my opinion. But the biggest downfall as I see it is the length of play for the game when dice can determine so much. The best laid plan can seemingly fall apart with a few bad roles.  That's fine in a sub 45 min game, but not one that goes over 3 hours.

Other:  It's probably not that bad when compared to a lot of strategic wargames out there that take much longer to play. I have a good respect for the game and wouldn't mind trying it again if someone threw it down in front of me; but, given my choice, I'd probably rather play 1960.

Best Use: Maybe the best game when you have the time for an epic dual.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I love the interaction and the struggle that is seen in this game. I love how the cards are implemented in the game and find it quite innovative. The only downside for this game is that I am not able to get anyone to play it at the moment because of the length and complexity required to play (complex only because I play games with non-gamers at the moment). Otherwise I really can't find a flaw in this game, see it as being highly replayable because of the variations in strategy your opponent can use.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
After two plays (ass kicked as U.S.A. and lucky win as U.S.S.R.), I like it. It has a good mix of strategy and luck (die rolls and card draws). It is very accessible and easy to get into, and the rules really make sense.

It's very long, and it's not an area of high interest for me, so I can't see wanting to play it more than, say, twice a year. And that's just not often enough to learn the cards and master the strategies. That's not a flaw of the game, just a personal preference that's going to affect my ability to find opponents of comparable skill and experience.

I think this has many very clever mechanics, with the DEFCON track, the military ops and the choice to play a card in multiple ways.

If you love the theme and want to play often, you might reasonably conclude this is a great game. You would be able to learn the cards well and develop deep strategies. Games between experienced players would be titanic struggles.

I've taken it off my want list, because someone in my game group has it and I realize that it's just not something I need to own.

I have now lowered my rating to a 5, because as unique as the mechanics are and as well as they work, it's just not a game I want to play ever again. If I don't want to own a game and tend to shrug when it is brought up, it's just not 7 material for me any more. This is one of those cases where an excellent design that does what it sets out to do just doesn't light a fire under me.

Also, as I believe is now required by law, I must say that this is not a wargame.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
What a great game!  Played my first one, took us three hours, and I won a sudden death victory by one point as the Russians.  The next two both finished on turn 3: one with a 20 point USSR win, the second as the US caused nuclear war.  So cool!  Great back-and-forth, lots of nail-biting tension, and I really had to watch what my opponent did in this cat-and-mouse thriller.  So many options, so many things to do, so much management of hands, some good, some bad.  A real winner.  As play time decreses, I realize this 2-player game will be on the same timescale as Starship of Catan, for instance.  And how much better is this?  The board is great, well laid out and clear.  Every detail immediately visible and at your fingertips.  Enough gushing?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I enjoyed my first play of this very much. My favorite mechanic is how you have to play events that benefit the opponent in order to get command points for yourself. You can avoid playing events for the opponent by using the Space Race track or holding on to a card between turns, but the forced military actions each turn prevent you from hiding every event from round to round. This causes game events to occur no matter what; it's just a matter of choosing which events to give to the other player. Despite this, the game loses points for some brutally-historic event cards that make it virtually impossible to hold certain regions because that's what history said was to happen. This can make playing the game seem more of a recreation than a alternate-history game. It's a little frustrating to invest into an area only to get kicked out because a card said so. Dice rolls can be swingy, too. This game deserves more plays so I can see how many of these worries are unfounded.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Amazing game though I hardly ever get to play it due to lack of opponents.  It does take a good 4+ hours at least for the first few plays.  And it's a pretty heavy strategy game which I love, but again, most of my family & friends do not.

But the game itself is about as good as it gets.

RATING: 3
When I first saw and read about this, I immediately assumed I wouldn't like it.  It's a long, historical area influence game, all strikes against a game in my book.  So, I didn't play it.

Nearly a year later, everyone continues to rave about it, and it seems to have nearly universal appeal, so I decided to give it a try.  I read more about it and become more inclined to think I'd like it.  It's a card-driven system, similar to We The People which is a rare long, historical game I LIKE.  I was really looking forward to trying it.

Finally, I tried it.  It was interesting, and I didn't dislike the experience, but mostly all of my initial concerns turned out to be true.  It just doesn't do it for me.  Under the right circumstances I could be convinced to play it again, and I understand why some people like it, but I can't say I understand the overwhelming positivity toward this game.

RATING: 7.5
This is what a card-driven two player wargame is all about.  I love the cold war theme, the fluid mechanics and the balanced system.  Certainly some tough decisions to make and there's a little luck with the dice (space race, coups, reallignments) and the card draws but it just seems to add to the game.  You never quite know what situation your opponent's going to put you into and you don't always know when scoring's going to occur so one must really be on his or her toes.  Worth multiple plays trying out both sides.

RATING: 10

I did not care for how important events, such as the Korean War are boiled down to a mere die roll, but I can understand the thought of keeping the game as simple as possible.  Another drawback is that a fairly intimate knowledge of the cards will help decision making, but I imagine that applies to any game of this type.  The gameplay, though, is elegant.  A great game that I am eager to play again.

RATING: 8.5
Enjoyable game. It can be done solo, but, as with all CDGs, it's not the ideal way to play. Playing face-to-face exposed me to all sorts of strategies and tactics that I hadn't realized in my solo plays. It also taught me the extreme value of having a great poker face in games like this (something I have difficulty managing). Good game overall, with some interesting mechanics, and--the production errors of the 1st ed. aside--very good components.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Oh my.  

This is almost everything I've wanted in a game.  It's meaty.  It's dripping with theme. It's incredibly involving (it lasted 3.5 hours but I never realized it).  It requires a beautiful mix of tactics and strategy.  It makes me pace the room worrying about the end of the world as I wait for my opponent's action.

This is essentially a beefed-up two player version of El-Grande.  If you've always thought that El Grande was a bit too simple, this is the game for you.

This game is based on the cold war.  One player plays the US and the other plays the USSR; both are fighting for domination of the world (low stakes, ya know).  The game is an area control game at its core (you're trying to control countries to gain points), but it has lots of additions that make the game stressful, highly variable, tactically diverse, and extremely fun.

For instance, there are at least four completely separate ways to gain (or reduce your opponent's) influence in a country; some rely on chance, others don't.  The cards that get you influence points (to place influence markers and gain influence in a country using one mechanism) also have actions on them, and (if the action is beneficial to you) you're faced with the maddening choice of either getting the influence points or taking the action .  But if the action is beneficial to your opponent then you can still play it to get the influence points, but your opponent gets the beneficial action.  This makes choosing which card to use at any particular time extremely stressful.  Scoring occurs in sub-areas of the map at not-precisely-predictable intervals, adding tremendous stress. 

Probably the thing that I most enjoyed was the variable victory conditions: there are (at least) four ways to win the game.  This means that at any moment your opponent might try to trigger an action that could lead to one of the victory condition being met, and thus you have to be constantly on your guard on multiple fronts.  This led me to be entirely stressed out the whole game ("Oh no, what about Europe?"  "Ack!  Now he's becoming dominant in SouthEast asia"  "Oh geeze, we're at defcon 2" "Oh no, the space race!"), which I think seems quite appropriate for the cold-war era "On the knife-edge" feel.

There are so many neat mechanics in this game that I can't list them all.  Suffice to say that I love it.  

The only major downside is the length: our first game took four hours.  But I loved all four of them, and I haven't been able to stop thinking about what I want to do differently the next time I play.

The only other downside I can see is the possibility that the game will come down to one game winning card, which could be frustrating.  But at least from what I've seen that shouldn't happen often.

RATING: 10
Ah, Twilight Struggle, my new flavour of the month.  I'll tell you this, any game where you can be down 19 VP and win in the next turn is great in my books.

There are so many options available each round that both players sit in silence as the review their newly dealt cards.  Then once the cards start flying, it's on like Donkey Kong.

There is a learning curve associated with knowing what cards are avaiable in each deck, but nothing to detract from the exceptional game design.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Play cards to trigger events and place influence to dominate the world in the cold war.

Plays: About 50, counting online.
Type: Area control game = a game where you compete for control of areas.
Complexity: Medium strategy game.
# of players: 2.
Playing time: 120-240 mins.
Player interaction: Competition for scarce resources - countries and regions. Conflict.
Randomness: Medium - card draw, but you control the timing of card plays.

Replayability: This has depth and becomes a min/maxing exercise after only a few plays. You have to memorize all the cards and keep track of where they can be in the deck to be any good at it. Once you got that down, the skill lies in prioritizing regions and the timing of card plays. You have to trigger opponent events to perform operations, increasing both thematic feel and hand-management difficulty. If this sounds like your cup of tea, replayability is high, otherwise not.
Fun: The fun lies in the agonizing and AP-inducing decision making of hand and board management.
Memorability: Decent, for a VP engine. This does create some stories as you fight over the minds and hearts of peoples all over the world.

Thematic integration: Good. Definite cold war feel.
Components: Functional.

Who will like this: Analytical gamers. Bonus for those interested in the cold war.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of my favorite games, definitely deserve the 10 rank. TS has everything, tension, strategy, replayability, learning-curve and its all in one small box. Even better it is played in a reasonable amount of time, and requires only two players. Since I got this one all other two player games started gathering dust. This is the first game that I can truly say is close to being an equal to Diplomacy.
