=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Upping this from 9.25 to 10.0 as this is my favorite game still, by far, almost 3 years after my initial rating.

What can I say, really? This game is perfect. The core mechanic is twofold: a card-driven wargame requires strategic piece placement on the board, sure... but the cards and by extension your hand is solely the management of mostly bad card draws, each and every turn. And the cards are filled to the brim with historical theme and VERY real effects on the board. Stuck with playing every card but one, and with a handful of outs (eg Space Race), the game builds on itself in scale and complexity, and the deck grows at predetermined times. SO. GOOD.

Jim's discovery here on BGG of a themed YouTube playlist with era-specific content (speeches, songs, newsreels, etc) that you can start or skip as needed, while playing, made it even better, last time we played.

(Written 4/26/16)

RATING: 9
Only three plays thus far but yes, this appears to be a great game. Among its greatest virtues are that it's easy to learn/teach yet satisfyingly complex to play, and it can be played to completion in a reasonable amount of time. I love the crisis management aspect of the game: you know you're going to take some serious hits, some of them self-inflicted, but when and where? I have the "deluxe" version of the game, which is okay overall: nice cards but very busy board with a not so great color scheme; requires constant tracking of controlled states because they don't stand out in any way. RATING: 8
Deluxe edition.

This game is brilliant - extremely tense back and forth. I think out of the box it's a bit too imbalanced in favor of the USSR and so in the future we'll probably either play with the Chinese Civil War variant or bid OP to play USSR. Otherwise, there is a depth and strategic complexity to this game that will only be unraveled after future plays. I  truly look forward to doing so.

---------------------------------------

Second play - four hours of vicious and intense tactical tug of war that only barely ended with a U.S. 9 VP victory - and only because the U.S. was able to prevent coups with the Cuban Missle Crisis, gain 4 bonus VP from the space race, and squeak by with European domination in the final turn. A work of genius with two major limitations that will keep it from being even higher rated than a '9' - it takes a damn long time to play, AND it's only two player. That means it won't see the table as often as I would like. Still, when it does, wow.

----------------

Rating revised downward after getting Hannibal RvC to the table. Although I think TS is deeper and requires more and careful planning, I don't like theme quite as much as I like Ancient Rome, and ultimately, I feel like the integration of theme and mechanics in Hannibal is tighter and therefore strategic choices are also more meaningful thematically. (By comparison, I often find myself doing things in TS that I know the U.S. or the Soviets would never have done, simply because of my metagame knowledge, or because if an impending scoring card.)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Whew! My opinion of Twilight Struggle, like playing the game itself, has been on a roller coaster. At first, it blew my mind; I love area control games, and took it to a global scale while marrying it to a gnarly and thematic card play mechanism.

Then, after playing the same opponents a few times repeatedly, frequently introducing it to new players, I became a little frustrated with the game. None of my mid-range plans worked out; opportunities to win the game early dissipated in a cloud of smoke, leaving my final board position weaker than it could have been. Every additional play was telling me "You can only play for Final Scoring," implying that the previously tense endgame conditions were a mirage. Was there really just one way to play this game?

But then I went online and have been playing over at Chantry, and what a difference that's made! Veteran players have schooled me. Even modestly experienced players put up a tough fight. No, mid-range plans can't really win you the game, but there are [i]a lot[/i] of tricks you can pull to give you a significant edge, many of which aren't as obvious as "Oh, I have Wargames. How can I get to +6 VP [i]right now[/i]?" (Hint: You probably can't. But your opponent doesn't know that.)

In any case, Twilight Struggle continues to hold my attention, even after over 20 sessions (60+ hours!), which is far more than can be said for most other games. I probably prefer it online at this point, but I doubt I'd ever turn down a face-to-face game of it. Despite a brief period of thinking otherwise, I find there's still a lot to learn here and look forward to future plays.

RATING: 8
Is it as good as everyone says it is? Probably not, but it's still pretty darn good. I really enjoyed it. I like the card system, the area majority mechanisms, the tug-of-war scoring, the way Def-Con limits your actions and forces you to walk a tightrope, etc. Great tension, and the luck of the draw is easily mitigated by skillful play. All in all a really well-crafted and finely-tuned game. I'm not sure it quite lives up to all the hype it has received over the years, but it's definitely a very good game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.2
Twilight Struggle is not a controlled, cerebral, deterministic strategy game - it‚Äôs not like Go or Chess.  Instead it is an epic, thematic simulation of the Cold War.  It‚Äôs a deep game with a broad, open decision space, but you are strategizing against the chaotic and swingy events of these years as much as you are strategizing against your opponent.   Events happen in this game, big and small: triumphant events, tragic events ‚Äì sometimes you can see them coming and prepare for them, other times they come without warning like a terrorist strike or an assassin‚Äôs bullet.   

My main complaint with the game is that the physical presentation of the game makes it a chore to count influence and control.  Other than that, I think it does what it sets out to do very well.  I am personally not in love with this game as I prefer a game where there's more diversity in what you are doing.  In this game, you are finding various ways to put influence on the board: that's it.  Every turn of every game is about adding and removing influence tokens and that gets a bit samey to me when the game takes 3 hours.

I don't feel it's a heavy game more like medium-light game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Twilight Struggle is a fun game, but it is very dependent on the players having equal knowledge of the game.  It takes a while of playing to get to the level where you can play competitively.  I felt like I had to play it several times before I was really PLAYING it, and even then a person knowledgeable of the cards could cut me down fairly easily.  The frustration is finding opponents at your level.  I either demolish or get demolish.  There are so many individual cards to learn, and while you can easily make plays based on what you have, it seems that most of the game strategy involves understanding what your opponent probably has.  And that means knowing the decks.  I'm just not willing to put in the time it takes to become competitive at this game, and be able to enjoy it the most.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Good game. Played ~4 times. Only played my actual copy once but have been playing it on wargameroom.com (very good online implementation). If you are interested in cold war history it tells a good narrative. Main problems are that success in the game is so dependent on knowledge of the cards that a fair matchup is only possible between people with similar experience (will probably level out after ~20 plays or when you know all the cards by heart).

Sin duda el mejor juego para dos jugadores. Es largo pero se hace corto de lo metido que estas; otra prueba de como te sumerge en el tema es que siempre se acaban las partidas mirando el tablero de pies; imposible contenerse sentado. El unico pero es que en algunos momentos el azar es muy determinante bien por las tiradas de dado o bien por las manos de cartas. Un juego genial, sin apelativos.

RATING: 7
I really enjoy this game, but it rare for me to have only two players, so I often play this using the fan-made solo rules.  While this game is better and faster with two, I prefer coop games if there are only two players anyway.  The TS app has great audio that I'll use, but my phone screen is too small, and I prefer having the chits and cards in-hand.  My memory is better than most, so I like the fact that learning the cards gives you an advantage against others.  Due to the cards, however, there are definitely best strategies that remove play variability.  I like the strong Russian beginning and initial influence bid to level out play.  I can't wait to try Labyrinth, as that appears to run more smoothly as a solo game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Deluxe reprint 2014: finally, it's mine (and in italian!).
A long, wearing battle of minds; this is not a casual game so don't take it lightly, even if the core mechanics are quite simple; you use a card over 6-7 rounds per turn to:
A- use its OP points, or
B- use its Event
Basically you try to arm-wrestling nations with your opponent (area control), with the twist that when you use OP points you also activate the enemy event on the card...Pure evil!
Con: this is an almost flawless game to me but it requires long-term stamina, you must keep your focus for hours to achieve victory and in the late turns the fatigue is felt.

It may be the Cold war, but the struggle is Hot. A classic.

Rate: :star::star::star:

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Definitely has a learning curve (familiarity with the cards is necessary to play well), but has depth and high replay value. 

I have played a handful of times so far, and my enjoyment of the game has grown with each subsequent game. The first game may be frustrating (it was for me, even though I ended up winning) since lack of familiarity with the event cards can cause a player to lose control of an area unexpectedly after investing their resources there.

This game definitely requires a little bit of commitment to get into, since the strategy (even basic strategy) is not at first obvious even to experienced gamers.

The flavor and theme of this game is perfect and reflects the Cold War well... I found the atmosphere very tense and noticed that different areas on the map gain and lose importance simply because they appear to be important to your opponent.

At any rate, I would definitely recommend this game, and will be trying to teach more people in my circle the basics so I can play more often.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10

Admittedly, the game does seem to be weighted towards the USSR, though this could just be my experience with the game. I'm okay with it, since 1960 is similar with how Nixon has a slight edge over Kennedy, so it makes it a little more likely that an alternate timeline will emerge. Really the only area this game lacks in is its presentation, which is still very clean, for the most part. This game gets a bad rep for being #1 on BGG, but I think that this is one of those games that more people would enjoy if given the chance.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Initially I had concerns about play balance but I no longer think that there is an issue there.  A highly entertaining game, with plenty of scope for skill and lots of replay value.

A few minor niggles to counterbalance my generally positive impression. 

1. Few of the events are sufficiently valuable to play as events. So the mechanism means that you will use them for movement and hope that they later end up in your opponent's hand and that he will be forced to use them for movement and thus trigger an event in your favour. This is okay, but there are ways to prevent having to trigger an event for the other player. So events can either fail to happen or turn up at peculiar times. A Marshall Plan or the creation of the Warsaw Pact in the 1980s? 

2. Some of the events, such as NATO, are utterly pointless.

3. The DEFCON track is too drastic. It spends the game hovering over the nuclear threshold which means that coups are too difficult to mount and that much of the map is usually invulnerable to coup or realignment attempts. In four games, we only did a single realignment option.

4. The typical GMT production which is generally okay but let down by slipshod minor details like incorrectly printed map, cards, play aids and instant errata on some rather important points.

RATING: 4
This is a 2 player euro game with area control mechanics.  If you don't take it seriously it's fine to play.  If you want to be good at it and win, well you can be frustrated by the luck involved with the randomness of scoring cards and the die roll in coup attempts which is a high variance in outcomes and ususally things hinge a lot on them.  Doesn't put you fully into the frame of mind of the conflict.  Gameplay detracts from the theme.  I will avoid play of this over something like 1960

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is fantastic.  There's definitely a learning curve when it comes to knowing which cards are in which eras.  I haven't played enough for strategies to be repeated or real optimization to happen (and I don't know that I care to), but I'd like to be familiar enough with the cards that the list of where all the cards are by era is useful to me.  Right now I use it only for scoring cards (when does SE Asia show up?  South America?)

I really like how the game organically grows out of Europe in the middle of the game, to puppet governments and commy sympathizers as the 60s and 70s pass.  The pacing and tone of the game are all perfect- growing from a concentrated struggle in Europe to a vast, sweeping conflict all over the world by the end game.

RATING: 10
Upgrading after further play and analysis/experimentation of how to win as the US Player.  This is a great game.  The 'Cold War' is a great theme for a game and I love the hand management aspect of a card-driven game. Errors on the map and cards have been fixed in the Deluxe Edition. It IS impressive the amount of research that went into this game in terms of game play and wide array of actualy historical events. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Very good game. My one quibble is that sometimes a single die roll can have a gigantic effect on the outcome of the game. Sure there are lots of rolls, but the value of any one particular roll to the outcome of the game can vary from next to none to absolutely critical. It's hard to explain what bothers me about this, as I'm very tolerant of dice. It's still a great game, though, which I will play anytime.

UPDATE
Boosted to a 10. Despite my earlier quibbles, I still love this game, play often, and am always happy to play.

RATING: 10
Really, I cannot say enough good things about Twilight Struggle.  I am learning to love the card-driven system, but the way everything comes together in this game is fantastic.  It is so simple, yet so incredibly rewarding.  I really enjoy the way the scoring is done, the way better play is rewarded, and the way the theme is so tightly meshed with the mechanics of the game.

Some may complain about the length, or the randomness of the dice, but everything about this game is perfect to me.  Infinitely replayable, always fun, and always a tense, fantastic time.  A truly great game.

RATING: 8
The theme works fine (feels like you are watching the History Channel) and a lot of things are going on, so you have to stay focussed on multiple issues and unforeseen moves by your opponent if you want to achieve victory. Strategy at its best! The only negative remark I'll have to make about TS is component-related. I say it's a pity that the gameboard doesn't show proof of good quality. Nevertheless, TS makes a great full of strategical suspense! Very nice to play if you have some old typical Russian communist songs playing from the background... PS: "The China Card".
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The pacing in this game is fantastic.  Frantic tension that accumlates over a 2 hour period!  There are just so many ways that regions can spin out of control, and you never quite have the resources to keep your opponent's mischief at bay.  Just as you've managed to (temporarily) secure Europe, South America is going down the toilette.  I will agree with those reviewers who write that knowing the cards is crucial.  Fortunately, Twilight Struggle is a good time even when playing through the cards for the first time. For example, in my first game I was in bad shape in the late-war thanks to ignoring the Middle East in the mid-war, but I thought I had a chance to even things out by the last turn.  Well, suddenly my opponent played a card that "ends the game if DefCom is 3 or less" (or some such).  Boom, game over.  After 2 hours of back and forth play, I felt I'd been robbed as I had NO IDEA such a card existed!  But 5 minutes later I was thinking ,"O.k., so the next time I play I'll be sure to ease DefCom back up in the late war."  The only card that I REALLY don't like is the one that produces -1 Ops for the course of a turn.  I wish this card disappeared after one play.  It strikes me as too powerful.  If one player gets to play it twice, it severely punishes the other player (i.e., up to -20 total Ops), and in one game I had it popped on me three times!

RATING: 7
An absolutely fantastic game. I love the way the theme is implemented in the mechanics so brilliantly, for example the brinkmanship that goes on with the DEFCON track. Absolutely oozes theme whilst also being a brilliant strategic showdown with your opponent.

The only things I dislike about this are the dice randomness and the Red Scare/Purge card which, to be honest, massively reduces the strategy space of every turn in which it is played. I'm very excited about Imperial Struggle which should resolve both of these issues as well as introducing a superb Renaissance/Colonial Era flavour.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
[floatleft][IMG]https://cf.geekdo-static.com/mbs/mb_834_1.png[/IMG][/floatleft]
[b]Twilight Struggle[/b]
2 players

Cold war strategy card game. Highly rated.

I find one issue very problematic with this game, which reduces my desire to bring it to the table despite loving it.

The cards frequently lead to conflicting interpretations as to how their effects are properly applied. The rulebook and FAQ do not always cover the various situations that arise. This can lead to arguments and lots of time wasted in seeking an answer. I am surprised that after so many editions/reprints and such broad appeal they are still not covered in the official rulebook and official FAQ. Future editions should update the rules and fix card texts to remove all ambiguities, which have been documented on BGG. I am surprised this game is rated #1 despite this annoying problem.

Next time I come across such an ambiguity, I will document it here.

Strategy tips:
http://twilightstrategy.com/

Online play (Real-time or async)
https://chantry-games.com

Game sleeves:
http://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/102880/card-sleeve-sizes-for-games-a-not-yet-comprehens/page/13?

110 cards (Deluxe Edition)
Fantasy Flight Sleeve Size: Standard Card Game (FFS05) 2 1/2" x 3 1/2" (63.5 x 88 MM)
Mayday Sleeve Size: Card Game 63.5 x 88 mm

[IMG]https://cf.geekdo-static.com/mbs/mb_23954_0.png[/IMG]Check out this TED talk:
http://blog.ted.com/2008/03/27/clifford_stoll/

RATING: 10
I'm again very positively surprised by a Matthews-game. We already loved 1960 Making of the President even when the theme seemed stiff-boring for those who have no keen interest in 1960s US politics (everybody in my game-sphere except me), but the apprehension was even bigger for Twilight Struggle, because it looked like some kind of derivation of a war-game, which is the only game-category my wife refuses to play (most 2-player games I play is with her). But lo and behold, it was an instant success, partially because the gameplay is similar to 1960-MotP. It does not feel confrontative -the theme is still fantastic- and there is much more depth in the gameplay that in 1960MotP and easier rules, also first game I've ever played where I like really the dice-aspect. Great game, one of a few CDGs I love, only downside is the long playing time.

RATING: 9
Game to game play is subject to wild swings depending on the cards drawn and die rolls.  This translates to a high luck factor. Some very interesting new concepts including when you play an opponent's event as OPS, he gets the event, the whole area control approach, and the "headline event" that starts each turn. A true virtue is the short play time.  It is harder to play the US, especially when the cards drop against you early.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Area-control game with an exciting theme, plausible narrative and deep strategic decisions. I don't like card-driven wargames, but in this case it works very well. Very enjoyable,a masterpiece in its genre. The only problems is that it is very chaotic, andthere are some card distributions where the US player cannot win. For example, if the US gets the three scoring cards and has Red Scare played against him in Early War (which should happen 6.25% of the time), it's probably not worth continuing. The game is also very unstable from turn to turn, in the sense that there can be huge reversals of fortune. You're always a couple of cards/die roll away from defeat. For example in one game, on turn 7 my opponent had something like 80% chance of winning the game and three turns later I won the game.

RATING: 10
Received this from my Secret Santa 2006.If you check up on me and read this then I can only say, "Thank you, thank you, thank you."

***I hadn't played one of the new card-driven 'wargames' yet, so this was a pleasant surprise. Clocking in at around 3.5 hours for our first game, the time frame wasn't quite as short as I was hoping, but I'm sure that we'll be able to shave it down as we learn the game.

***4 games played now. I'm still totally thrilled by this game. I played it three times in one day and can hardly wait to play again.I don't know if the thrill will wear off, but I'm sure enjoying riding the high while it lasts.

***10 plays into it and still loving it. Clearly not a wargame, but not a Euro either. Reminds me of the innovative American games of old...

***22 plays logged and I'm not tired of it yet. I'll play this game every chance I get and am happy to say that it has become a staple of my gaming diet.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Probably the best 2-player game out there.  Highly complex strategy, seamless gameplay mechanics, fun card drafting, war gaming style area control, and various events like the Space Race and DEFCON tracks enhance the tug-and-pull elements of the Cold War theme.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Hands down my favourite game so far. It gets better with each play.  Having recently been gifted the Collector's Edition for my birthday as well as my old Deluxe Edition copy.

Edit: Having now owned this for a year and notched up several dozen plays I can without doubt say it is my favourite game to date. There is a superb amount of depth (I'm still learning, every game) and re-playability matched up with tension unrivalled by any other game I've played. I love teaching new people as it is relatively easy to  get stuck into but hard to master.  I tend to give newbies a 5-10pt start so we can make it through to the mid-war and they can really see the fruits of their earlier labour. I'm impressed with how quickly people become competent opponents, another strength of the game. I think it will be a while before the shine wears off on this one!

RATING: 2
I wish this game was fun, I really do. I like complex games, I like war games,  I even have a special place in my heart for US vs Russia games (thanks Red Alert!) but their comes a point where there is just too much. Where you're spending all your time keeping track of tokens, markers, tracks, and which phase of the game you're currently in. At that point I'd rather that game be digital, where I am not forced to deal with all that.
Be prepared to spend 4+ hours learning the game before even setting up, then 8+ on your first round. I would be OK with this is the action was exciting, if the strategy had some flow, or if anything about this game was intuitive.... but it just feel like I'm playing accountant for the cold war, not president.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.55
I'm not an expert, but the game doesn't seem to be as complex as people says. But it's imperative to memorize the cards, their effects and when they might appear. Once you do that, it's just a matter of playing a few games to get acquainted with the usual moves, moves that fans have optimized during the years.

They key of the game is optimizing the cards you get dealt, priorize the actions in the areas than can be scored this round and minimizing the damage the enemy cards you draw will do to you and adapt your strategy in order to react to your opponents actions.

The historic background and the theme of the game it's a brilliant 10. It's a perfect reflection of the geopolitical situation of the Cold War era, with all the struggles of both superpowers. The cards depict events that took place in our history, but they might or might not take place in yours.

The graphic design is OK and the components are OK too. You miss some high number influence tokens, but it's a minor flaw.

I enjoy and like Twilight Struggle, but the fact that to truly master it and enjoy it you need to play it regularly shots me down a bit; as I said, I usually don't play 2 players games and I also don't want to focus on one only game.

In other card driven wargames you can at least move your armies without rolling dice. Maybe I‚Äôve just been incredibly unlucky or just don‚Äôt know how to overcome these situations.  Twilight Struggle is a good game but I‚Äôve had bad experiences with it.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very rich in content and atmosphere, Twilight Struggle reenacts the Cold War giving a rather thorough, balanced overview of its more relevant facts (with further information about them in the rulebook if needed or wanted), that have to be used by the US and the USSR players for their own interest. 

As for the mechanisms behind the game, there are no complications: Twilight Struggle is driven mostly by cards (add a roll here and there) and although it seems at first to be a mostly tactical game, the absence of massive luck in the drawsmakes it increasingly strategic play after play (with the events distributed evenly for both sides a good draw may influence a round, but not two in a row); dice rolls can sometimes spoil a good turn's hard work, though. At least until now I haven't found any serious bias towards either player apart from the obvious streaks of luck dictated by history (South American upheavals, NATO/Marshall Plan, COMECON, Perestroika and so on). Playing for the US might involve a steeper learning curve, though.

Thus, Twilight Struggle is a perfect introduction to wargaming. No player can get lost with the aid sheets and one of the very best organized boards I've seen in my life. Plus, the duration of a game is kept reasonably below half a day, and every second of it is just as intense... even for peaceful players who can't stomach more than a coup per turn.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Eccellente gioco di simulazione della Guerra Fredda, probabilmente il miglior gioco in scatola (scacchi esclusi) per 2 giocatori e secondo molti anche il miglior gioco di sempre. Il gioco √® molto impegnativo e una buona conoscenza delle dinamiche e delle carte aiuta ma le meccaniche di base sono molto semplici. La forte interazione offre partite molto diverse tra loro e richiede, oltre ad una buona pianificazione, anche la capacit√† di adattarsi e rispondere alle mosse avversarie. Il gioco risente molto anche del fattore aleatorio con lanci di dadi e pesca delle carte il che non toglie nulla alla bellezza di questo gioco. Ripercorrere i principali eventi della guerra fredda rende il gioco stimolante e avvincente. La durata media di una partita, specie nelle prime esperienze, √® elevata anche se in determinate condizioni la partita pu√≤ terminare molto prima.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
Is it a terrific, atmospheric, thematic card-based 'war' game? Of course it is. Wonderful historical flavours and very, very evocative of the Cold War.

Does it justify its ranking as top game on the Geek? No.

First and foremost, this is not a suitable use of multiple-function cards: surely there must have been a better mechanic than this? It's demoralising and dull trying to effectively rid yourself of a hand of poor cards. There appears to be a runaway leader problem, especially during the first 10 games or so (and, really, who has enough time to get as far as the 11th game?). Too many key decisions are down to the roll of a d6. The board and tokens are naff and poor quality. And it's hard to justify a 3-hour 2P game on the majority of gaming occasions. 

[i]Traded for Galaxy Trucker in October 2011 UK Maths Trade[/i]

Cheap         :star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: Quality

RATING: 10
Best game ever - really tense
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Enjoyed my first play more than expected, but there are too many points against this one for me to ever call it a favourite: given the serious competitiveness of the game, there's too much rolling a die to determine outcomes (eg. coups, and it's especially annoying to miss a few consecutive space race rolls and then watch your opponent pass you in one roll); there are a lot of cards to read, and read again ... and again. I appreciate the amount of flavour on the cards, and the amazing number of historical references packed in, but I don't think I could even remember all the cards that might come up, and this is pretty crucial to playing well. It's also a personal weakness of mine having to deal with a fairly large hand of random text-filled card like this - AP sets in as there are soooo many options in any given hand of TS cards, so many potential combos. Also, luck of the draw is so huge a factor that I felt several of my hands were completely unplayable. I understand the argument that this will "balance itself out" over the game, but after a few hands like this (some coupled with my opponent being dealt a great hand), it's really hard to come back from such a major setback (or the game is already over with a 20 point win). Oh, lest I forget to mention - this game is longer than I'd normally want to sit and play any game. It took 4 hours - not including teaching.

Would certainly play again though. Some of the mechanics are excellent, and really capture the feel of the theme attached. Tension is high, and it does feel like both sides are "on the brink" when DEFCON = 2 ....
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
After playing this again and also playing "Wir sind das Volk" again, I can't see myself going back to this one too much. It seems for me it has been replaced before I even first played it or maybe it's because I played "Wir sind das Volk" first but for me WsdV simply does many things "better" (or at least better for my taste) than Twilight Struggle, while still giving me a similar feel and theme. 
I know in the end they are still quiet different games, but in the end both give me a similar feel and I simply like the mechanics of WsdV a lot more. 

I do however still think it's a great design, but I'm not sure how much I see myself playing this.

RATING: 5.5
I like the cold war theme and area control games. I love CDGs. I play wargames. My geekbuddies like this. But I hated each game more than the last, and so far I can't be bothered trying again. It's not the tension - I like feeling gripped by a game - it's the sense that there's damn little you can do. It's [i]frustration.[/i]

Every turn is spent putting out fires, "undoing" rather than doing. I'm sure with experience it would be possible to mitigate the effect of catastrophic hands, or poor dice rolling in the space race, but there is too much luck for a game that takes this long.

The most enjoyable part was reading the rules, the background, and the cards. The game made me feel like Damocles, except waiting to be snuffed by a hand full of score cards.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Simple rules from which emerges complex strategy. Yes, it's best to learn the decks obviously--but it's still pretty darn playable right from the start, as managing a small hand of cards is challenging in its own right. Mitigate your opponent's events, maximize scoring opportunities--this is one of those games that demands you manage a dozen things at once, while only giving you the resources to do maybe half of them if you're lucky. Tight, elegant, enjoyable.

Sadly, a touch too long, and it can feel dry. You're just placing numbers on a map after all. Playing people of different skill levels is not an option here either. I ended up trading my copy because it's so hard to get a F2F game going.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Wonderful and realistic simulation of the cold war. Especially suited for older players who have lived many of the events! Its only drawback is that you have to know the cards quite well to play it quickly with a working long-term strategy, otherwise you'll spend a lot of time studying carefully your hand and which scoring are going to come. New players better choose Soviet Union or they will be wiped out from the board by 1955...

UPDATE April 2013: The game is addictive. Current rating of "9" reflects that. It keeps me mentally busy even after the sessions are finished, despite the fact that I haven't been able to win even one single play.

UPDATE August 2014: There is BY FAR no other game of comparable length that I have played more often than TS during the last 1.5 years, around 40 plays. 

UPDATE October 2014: Now around 50 plays. Always tense, always exciting, never boring, thematic as can be... It's a 10.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
An excellent adaption of CDG's into an area majorities format. The rules complexity is a little daunting for your average Eurogamer, but it definitely has crossover appeal to many. The decisions on which cards to play and how to play them are the main appeal (events vs action points obviously), working out the best way to provide the biggest threat to your opponent with minimum expenditure. I love how areas previously ignored suddenly turn hot and of interest just because your opponent has started playing there, in the expectation that they're playing there for a reason (score card to be played?), which captures the thematic essence of the Cold War to a tee.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The first card-driven wargame I've played. Not a normal wargame, I suppose, as conflict is abstracted, but very well done nevertheless. It's going to take quite a few games to get the strategy figured out. After starting as an '8', a few games in I raised this to a '9', but I'm now raising it to a '10' because of my PBEM experiences  - it's that good, and getting better!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
And here I thought I'd never find anything more tedious than Arkham horror. I tried to like this, I really did. When at first it seemed dry and boring and the opposite of 'fun', I re-read the rules hoping to find something I was missing that would make it click.  Horrid/contradictory rules in the 8.1, 8.2.4 layout of old AH rulebooks, some cards are events that can be discarded and they are printed 'remove from play', and at the same time, they are underlined to mean 'they stay in the game. All this on the same card! Reminds me of the worst of the Avalon Hill rulebooks. Drier than ginger ale; tedious gameplay/setup; miniscule thin cardboard chits and cereal box game board should be outlawed. How can this game cost $45!!!??? These kind of crap components were already tedious in the 80's when AH was doing it all the time, and here it's 2008 and we still have games that have a game board that makes AH components look like they were produced by 'Days of wonder'. I talked my wife into playing this, using every trick I knew to cajole her past the 'politics theme' and I've never seen such a glazed look of utter boredom within five minutes of playing a game. It was like looking at the Medusa. I think my arm turned to stone. At first I was upset with HER, like she was missing something of this great game, but I realized that my anger was because I was trying to convince her the game was good, when it wasn't. I was upset because I bought this game, and I was duped. 

This is supposed to be strategy, there is supposed to be a reason to plow through the opaque rules and the endless errata for cards/combos on BGG, and yet, you get dice with the game! You rely on card draws! It's luck based! It's like MTG without any of the cool art or engaging cardplay, and takes 50 times as long to play! What a deal! And did I mention this game takes even longer than Arkham horror? There is no excuse anymore for 5-7 hour games, especially not for two people. I overlooked the cheap game components in spite of the fact that this game is roughly ten bucks cheaper than Agricola', a game which actually includes fun gameplay along witlbs of quality components.   (Update: I hate Agricola because it also takes 4 hrs)

You really have to be seriously into cold war politics and US/Russian history to appreciate this game at all, but really, being a history buff for the cold war should not be a pre-requisite for getting something out of the game. This is another inexplicably highly rated game on BGG, like Arkham horror, where I clearly expected its ranking of '3' to deliver some amazing gameplay. Biggest gaming disappointment ever. And I traded an OOP 'Ace of aces' game for this? 

I have tried, but can't find any incentive or joy in playing this game. I'm almost tempted to burn it for the satisfaction. If this is the best the US can come up with in 2006 game design, Europe has clearly won the board game war, and that was with 'Bohnanza'. 

Update ten year later: bought the app. Solved all my problems. Rating up to 9.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
With the digital version out, Twilight Struggle has been cemented in my mind as one of the greatest board games of all time. It has downsides: learning the cards takes time, only 2 players, familiarity leads to better games, realignments feel a little wonky, etc. However, the depth of strategy and the push-pull mechanics are awesomely integrated into the theme. Every card play feels like it matters and you'll have to make a handful of really tough decisions in each game.

It's a tremendous design that deserves all the accolades it gets.

RATING: 9
This is a great mix of tactics and strategy. I love the posturing for the scoring cards while still keeping an eye on overall control of the various areas. The decisions of when to use events is agonizing. This would get a 10 from me but the dice can occasionally have a little bit too much influence in the game for my liking. I will play this whenever I get the chance though and as I learn the system more, perhaps I will mitigate that luck better.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
1 play - I definitely liked this a lot, with the scoring cards that are built into a draw deck determining where the next flux of battle and coups will occur. There's a lot of 'back n forth' in this game, which can begin to feel a little like a dull game of tennis, but is frequently interrupted by sudden historically thematic swings, which drive a well crafted narrative of its time.

It is a good game, but not necessarily something that I had a tremendous amount of fun playing, unfortunately. Perhaps with some similar minded friends it might improve.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
A constant battle for power! The mechanics are simple enough, but the cards bring the game to life, since there are endless numbers of combinations. It is heavy, but if you can handle it, it is a must play (and purchase), just wish I could play it more often. The seesaw point system is perfect.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I wish I could find the time to play this more, my only real issue with the game is the length. I never notice the time going by when I'm actually playing, but knowing that it is probably going to take 3 hours puts me off breaking it out as for two player games I tend to only have 2 hours max.

The game itself is a truly remarkable design, the fact that when you play cards with your opponent‚Äôs events on them triggers the event is brilliant and creates a lot of the agonising decisions that the game throws at you. This really does a good job of creating a political atmosphere, nothing is black and white, a lot of your actions will help your opponent as well as you so you have to weigh up how much you can give your opponent each card play. The turns where you end up with a hand of nothing but your opponent‚Äôs cards can be brutal, but I love them, ending a turn like that and not losing out too badly is a great feeling. Hoping that you can weather the storm and that the scoring cards don't come up while you're not in a strong position is what makes this game for me.

I do think that knowledge of the deck is essential so the first few games will be learning games. As soon as you have an idea of what is coming in each of the phases of the war, the better of an experience this will be. It also helps if you can find a partner to learn the game with as someone with a few games under their belt can have a massive advantage over an inexperienced opponent.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Twilight Struggle really does a good job of embodying the tension of the Cold War.  As in many games of this type, you're trying to advance your own goals while stopping your opponent from advancing his.  While this game is asymmetric, the types of things you're trying to do are similar enough that you do get in each other's way.  I really like how the scoring is card-based--you know what scorings might be coming based on the stage of the game, and you might be able to guess based on your opponent's actions, but really it's up to the players.  All around, this is a really deep, rewarding game.

(1 play)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I never imagined that a two-player game, with strong historical theme and including dice and cards could be so tactically fascinating and satisfying. I have played this more than any other game since buying it, largely with my brother. What amazes me is that although I have beaten him every time, he always comes back for more - the game is that compulsive and gripping. The multiple paths to victory can give it a 'knife-edge' feel sometimes which I find in very few other games, with one player on the verge of control in Europe (which gives an automatic win) and the other racing to dominate the rest of the world before the 'Europe scoring' card comes round again. Can't recommend highly enough.
Drawbacks:
a) Playing time (2-4 hours) is quite long
b) Knowing what cards are out there gives a huge advantage to experienced players

[c]Rules Complexity:.....:star::star::star::nostar::nostar:

Replayability:........:star::star::star::star::star:
Component Quality:....:star::star::star::star::star:
Player Interaction:...:star::star::star::star::star:
"Take That" Conflict:.:star::star::star::star::nostar:
Theme Integration:....:star::star::star::star::star:[/c]

Playtime: About 2-3 Hours depending on how the early game goes.

Comment: This game really benefits from multiple plays. Each time you play and learn what's in the deck you have a much better shot at controlling your hands and guessing what your opponent has. Really tense game and a ton of strategy. 

Extras: FFG Standard Size Sleeves, GMT Counter Tray and a set of Deluxe Red/Blue dice.

Optimal Player Count: 2 Only

RATING: 10
I had initially rated the game as 8.0/10.0, but after getting to know the deck and played more, it's a solid 10! The Cold War theme and the Mutual Assured Destruction doctrine are brilliantly themed in the game, with players juggling between multiple crises.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I can hear my heart beating in my chest and get all jittery every single time I play. The tension is palpable each time.

The greatest innovation is that most cards are explicitly beneficial for one party in an asymmetrical distribution that evolves over the course of the game. This truly characterizes each side you play with a certain approach. However, both players draw from a shared deck, leaving you with some of your opponent's cards. Choosing when to play cards that explicitly hurt you and attempting to mitigate a disaster every turn is the greatest element of this game‚Äîyou don't know what cards your opponent has, and what they might be able to do this round. Any decision your opponent makes leaves you paranoid and afraid that a card you know is about to drop might devastate your presence in a region or disrupt the plan you had for the rest of the round. This ludo-narrative harmony with the Cold War is just truly exceptional.

This is a wonderful game of second-guessing and faking out your opponent. There is a very nice range of exceptionally useful cards, and a great degree of anxiety that can be driven over cards that have the potential to lose you the game if played incorrectly. There's an interesting degree of hand management, too, where it's important to be prepared for cards your opponent can play that leave you playing into a nuclear holocaust. Every hand you draw can be played excellently or poorly, and it's all down to how you place influence, plan ahead, and manage disaster. Everything seems critical, everything is vulnerable, and every move is terrifying.

I strike half a point off for the small elements of luck in this game when dealing with realignments and coups, but even that fits thematically with the true uncertainty that marked every move made during the Cold War.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This game is dripping with strategy and theme.  I enjoyed this game every time that I have played the game and is definitely a keeper!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Amazing 2 player cold war game! The players spread their influence around the world, overthrow governments and realign countries using clever card play, so they can be the dominant force when scoring comes. They also have to keep an eye on the defcon level, because a nuclear war equals an automatic loss.

This is an area majority game with a lot of theme. All the cards represent real events that took place during the cold war. These events are very cleverly implemented and force the player to make really tough decisions. Hand management is crucial but the overall positional strategy on the map also plays a major role. Forcing the players to execute an opponent's event when they use the ops value is sheer genius and really enhances the hand management aspect! 

Why is this not a 9.5? Because I haven't played it enough, but I suspect it will be in a not so distant future.
[Update]: This is a 9.5!

RATING: 5
Had some very tense and interesting games. But also some extremely frustrating ones. This game is a CDG, but the D sometimes seems to stand for Dictated instead of Driven. 
4 scoring  Cards in one Hand is killing, some Cards in a US hand are mandatory to play, and with a agressive Russian play result in an unavoidable Nuclear War. Russia goes first and can often set DEFCON @ 2.

So will play and with at least a decent draw will enjoy. But if the deck is against me, will again avoid it for some time.

RATING: 9

It just seems a bit too long. Perhaps they could have scaled the map down a bit to make the same experience move a little faster.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
It took a long time before I had a chance to try this game. It truly was worth the wait!
This is like a stripped Paths of Glory, only the juicy core is left. Playing time remains in ~2 hours and the number of exceptions is minimal.

The cards are a chapter of their own. You really have to know what can be expected, otherwise it's too dangerous to play certain cards. Well, it's not a prerequisite to know those cards, but it helps. I had a great deal of fun in my first game even though I knew nothing what to expect.
And yet again you depend a lot on the card draws you make at the end of your turn. This game could have used something else than space race to dump the cards with your opponent's symbol.

At some situations this feels a bit too luck-based game, but if that's the price to pay from otherwise non-heavy and yet working system - then so be it! 

I'll always prefer this to 1960: Making of the President because of its theme and also this one is preferred to Paths of Glory because of its simplicity and sensible playing time.

This one I'll definitely buy immediately when I have the chance!

RATING: N/A
This has become an acknowledged classic. Card-driven, the mechanism allows players to make some use of cards that would otherwise only benefit your opponent. Players vie for influence over countries in Europe and the rest of the world.  An elegant design means that this works surprisingly well as a historical simulation. I may draw on this when I finally come to launch my game simulating the 'domino theory' and incorporating actual dominoes.

It may be sacrilege to say so, given the popularity of this game among serious gamers, but it is surprising how luck-driven the game can be - not just over the choice of cards but in the luck of dice rolls. I appreciate that this is a game about managing and mitigating damaging cards and events but still...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
The definitive Cold War game that is easy to learn but hard to master. Anyone born during the cold war period should definitely consider trying this game out. It does a fantastic job of putting historical events into their proper context of how they swayed influence between the reigning two super powers of the time.

From a war gamer's perspective this is a light card driven war game essentially about area control but it should not be easily dismissed if you have not played it simply because it lacks military units. Twilight Struggle will have you pondering strategies long after a game is over due to its depth of play.

Pros:
* Greatly implemented theme.
* Strategies are conditional to your hand of cards each turn.
* The deluxe edition improves the game components to what I would consider a modern day average quality.

Cons:
* It is easy to incorrectly keep track of action rounds and counting the cards played will not always be accurate.
* Slightly wonky change to the number of action rounds mid-game.
* Games are more likely to end before the late war period even begins.

I do not consider any of my complaints enough to subtract anything from the rating. I find the game too intriguing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
The number 1 of BGG (still on 25/05/2015). Somehow this game never appealed to me. But as Jan wanted to play this and it is number 1, I gave it a try.

So impressions after 1 play: why is this number 1 and gets such a high rating from so many players? 

First problem I have with this game that it is even stated in the rules (according to Jan who explained the rules) that you have a better chance of winning with the US then with the USSR. Then again I won with the USSR as a newbie and maybe the USSR-part is just harder to grasp? In Mr. Jack the role as Jack is also harder for new players to play good then the one of detective. If this is the same for this game, I suppose that's something I can live with.

What for me however is too annoying for me is the dice part. The equations to calculate the 'coup'-result reminded me of some Italian games, something I dislike. But just the fact that such a long game can be decided with 1 good or bad dice roll, just makes this not worthy of playing for me. I for example won our game by reaching 20 victory points because I had the luck of rolling a 1 on the space track and so score the 2 points I was missing. 

The third part that annoys me in this game is some of the cards. You can try to built up something and 1 card played by your opponent can sometimes just take away the control you needed and you can't do anything against it.

Jan likes the game about the fact that you have to take care that you have to play the cards you get as smart as possible so that the advantages you give to your opponent are as reduced as possible. That is indeed the clue of this game and a mechanism I can't say I have seen in other games. Then again, if you get 8 US-cards as the USSR-player, you won't be that happy with this gaming mechanism :s

Conclusion: the Ameritrash-factor in this game is too high for me.

RATING: 4
This is a mildly fun game for casual play, but I consider it being one of the weakest CDGs available, too long, too many rules and too chaotic for what it gives.

I'm stunned about the hype this game has reached.

Board Game Rank 1? I accept this - De gustibus non est disputandum

Wargame Rank 1? If there is a wargame here then it is well hidden. Chess, an abstract game, (the cover of the TS-box implies relation) is ten times more a wargame but has no Wargame Rank at all.

Strategy Game Rank 1? Strategy admittedly helps winning, but this game is so saturated with chaos, rotates about thousand things here and there and then the really important space program is purely driven by chance!! There are card combos that can kill you almost immediately like a smart-bomb - that make it strategy #1?!?

"Go", another abstract game, breathes strategy, but alas, it has no Strategy Game Rank at all!

C'mon! That's unreasonable.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Highly reviewed (2)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
At first I bought into the idea that this was the best game out there. But when I got around 50 games, I realized that this is a hugely overrated game. Its biggest merit is the quality of the components, the theme and how every event and country connection work well together - which on the deluxe edition really makes you believe that you are playing a top ten game.
The early war cards script the game a lot (when playing with someone who makes intelligent choices and maximizes the events and points). With only 34 cards in early war played three times, it gets easy to count the cards and to figure out things you should never do (ex: USSR take over Japan or Australia or US taking over Cuba and Egypt during early war). This is the big limitation of the game: since you are always playing with the same cards, events and values, a player that knows the cards and the odds of certain events to happen acquires an definite edge on empire expansion that has less chance of being thwarted at certain stages of the game (early, middle and late war). But despite this, the most determining factor of winning or losing are the results of your die rolls when doing a coup or realignment. If you lose too many, your opponent will quickly nail you to the ground. Worse, getting played Red scare 2-3 times in a game can also make a comeback impossible if you are the USSR. It boggles my mind that a game with so few die rolls manages to make those same die rolls override all other factors (skills, card play, strategy etc...). The second big killer is being dealt bad hands. Many noobs think that a couple of bad hands may not affect the game that much, but what they fail to consider is that if the end result of those bad hands cause you to lose certain key countries, the game will only slide towards an inevitable victory for the player with average luck on his next cards received (which to me is not the hallmark of a great strategy game). When a player has a death grip on certain continents and the only events that would allow a special event have passed, some feats become impossible. Another downside is the concept of scorecards: since there is no balancing you may end up holding so many that you end up losing valuable influence points you could be placing on the board while your opponent gets an edge on you while you often only end up giving him more points. I was once dealt 3 score cards in midwar which made me score 3 out of 7 turns... ridiculous. Another comment on score cards: you never know when a score card will come into play or not. Sometimes Europe comes 4 times in a game sometimes 1... scoring becomes more a question of lucky timing than overall strength in the world or real strategy (which makes no sense when you think about it). If someone dominates a high point zone and that score card pops up two times in early war, they will have to work very hard to lose that game. 
Also, experienced players will eventually end up playing games that will end up resembling themselves: Preventing control of Europe early on, dodging events of a couple of specific opponent cards, making coups in the same continent choke points and players eventually memorize the different cards of each phase (early, mid and late war) and know by heart the boons and pitfalls that are coming. Finally, there are ways that you play certain cards that allow your opponent to provoke the end of the world by going to Defcon 1 and declaring him the winner (yeah, that makes no sense either) and can undermine an otherwise compelling game - can you recall a game that spontaneously combusted half-way through and that you wanted to replay right away?
This game stays fun until you learn all the cards, odds and strategies the game has to offer - which is usually the point when you are supposed to love a game more- but in this case, you only realize that the game's entire core mechanism is luck. There is a clear storyline: USSR starts strong in early war but Mid war offers the US player some very powerful cards to catch up. However, if you are USSR and you are not ahead after turn 4, you can only win if the US player`s strong cards are never played. If the US player gets his cards, you are slowly sinking deeper and deeper. 
All in all, I enjoyed TS a lot when I thought that my wins and losses were dependent on my skills or lack thereof. But once I mastered the cards, I realized that luck played such a major factor in this game that experienced players can lose simply by rolling 3's or less and having bad cards in his hand on the wrong turns. I would of liked a deep strategy/wargame but hardcore gamers quickly realize that this is a classic American game: good cards and good rolls win the day. The only time this game feels great is when it gets a euro flow (tight scoring) and no player has an outrageously good hand on the same turn the other has to manage a horrible one - you may then feel for the duration of a game that strategy actually exists in the hand management. It is unfortunate that this game is very unbalanced when it comes to cards played, cards not played and the story arch. If there existed a way for players to counter the dumb luck of the cards drawed, this would be a perfect game. I would personally suggest to remove Red scare after one use and if a player has three score cards in a turn there should be a reshuffle.

RATING: 8
I know people love this game, but I sometimes find it difficult to play with people. It's excellent when two experienced players are playing against each other, but it's very difficult to keep it interesting for players of very different skill levels, as familiarity with the cards and strategies is such an integral part of the game. 

Also, it can be a bit fiddly; in a few games, my opponent and I have forgotten to adjust the track every time someone has played a card, and it can be tricky to "back-track" the game and figure out how many turns have been played.

In spite of all that, it's a great game with a ton of Cold-war theme, and I can understand the praise it receives.

RATING: N/A
pl
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My all-time favourite. A belter, oozing with theme and gripping from start to finish.

Suprisingly for a game attempting to simulate the Cold War, its mechanics are rather simple. The whole game revolves around either adding influence, reducing the influence of your opponent in countries or both - all this through four basic actions: event play, direct placing of influence, coups and realignments 

What makes TS a brilliant game is the features that guarantee its balance. First, the nature of card play.  You will often be teared between using much-needed ops points, on one side and benefiting from a favourable event (if it's a card marked as yours) or prevent the unleashment of an event favourable to your opponent (if it's marked as his).

Secondly, there's DEFCON. DEFCON starts at 5 and each coup d'etat in a battleground country reduces DEFCON by 1. Should DEFCON ever get to 1, Nuclear War ensues. If that occurs in your action round, you lose the game on the spot.  This makes all the the difference, restricting the use of coups and some powerful events and increasing the tension.    

TS hooks you as and makes you feel like you are in the  a White House or Kremlin, trying to sway countries to your side through every (usualy shady) mean available and  second-guessing your opponents next move, while standing on the edge of nuclear disaster. 

This is an outstanding game, worthy of all the praise you can see throught BGG.   
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Awesome game! The learning curve is a little more steep than a deep euro. The faq is longer than most rule books I've read.  Simple enough once you play a few turns. Seems simple in that you are only playing one card at a time, but there is a LOT to consider. No chance for a beginner to beat an experienced player, but the game is so riveting you won't mind.

A little pricey when you consider that the map is just flimsy cardboard that won't lay flat. But the quality of the game is good enough to overlook that. 

Plan on 3hrs for a full game. 

Update: After losing a 3 1/2 hour game because the Soviet player got the Aldrich Ames card, I'm dropping this to a '7'. Luck swings a little too much for my taste.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The mechanisms in this game are beautiful and elegant, the history is interesting and plays back into the theme and mechanics, and it's not super heavy. This game is about two world powers fighting for influence across the planet. On a player's turn they play cards for either the cost of the card in action points which allow them to play tokens and take actions or they can play the card for it's effect. At the start of the game, the communists have the advantage, but the longer the game goes, the more the capitalists take hold and grow in power. Fascinating game.

:star: Art, Iconography and components functional
:star: Clever or interesting mechanisms
:star: Reasonably low downtime between turns with mildly AP players
:star: Multiple plays stay interesting
:star: Low or mitigatable luck elements
:star::star::star::nostar::nostar: Raw enjoyment
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Twilight Struggle was the last game in the top 10 I hadn't played, and since I've always been interested in that period of history I'd been really looking forward to getting round to it. I swapped my copy of El Grande for it in a UK math trade and played a couple of times face-to-face and four times online (using the excellent wargameroom app) in Jan '09. It has got inside my head more than any game I've played in a long time. I absolutely love the multi-dimensional hand-management and the way each turn is almost a mini-game (which works particularly well online as you can play episodically). There's something about 2-player games that make you really care about winning or losing, and playing the same opponent repeatedly has allowed us both to develop our skills a lot, especially avoiding early war wipe-out when playing as USA. Our latest game has just entered turn 7, poised on a knife-edge, and I can't wait to see what happens! I have slight worries about the flat dice rolls, and it can be a really long game face-to-face, but those are minor quibbles about an undeniable masterpiece.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Still, a very worthy game for a very interesting period in history.

RATING: 6
1 playing
1-2 hours per player

Chrome de la chrome. Every card alters the rules. Very random and out of control (so very much on-theme). Strategy consists of somewhat arbitrarally deciding to build-up influence in a particular region (Africa, Asia, S. America, etc.) in hopes of a scoring event occuring down the road for that area. Tactics consist of deciding which cards in your hand are the worst and how to ditch them (which appears to be the basis for the space program mechanic). Feels more like watching a movie and waiting to see how it turns out rather than being a player shaping the events.

The way is using playing for operations or events. Very much like the way opponents events happen whenever you use an opponents card for operation points. 
Timing and bluffing are important as you try to figure out your opponents plans, while masking your own. 
Include Space race and other victory point events you have a rich game with a lot of options for your play. 
Finally it feels that is does capture some of the flavor of the cold war.

RATING: 6
I have only played via iPad with the app but ultimately I don't think this game is for me. I'm quite willing to give it a few more chances but thus far I'm not a big fan. The game is very complex and much of the early games is spent reading cards and trying to understand what they do. This also makes it very hard to plan ahead strategy wise since I don't know what cards are in the deck. Repeated plays may help in this regard, but that does not make for a very inviting game for the first few plays. 

But even without all that, the game just wasn't that interesting to me. I think it's quite smart and can see the appeal for some. But it seems to require far too much study and practice to get competent for me to ever want to spend that many hours just to get to a point where I may be able to enjoy it. As is currently I feel hopelessly lost on what to do and with all the competing systems and mechanics it doesn't seem streamlined or intuitive to me. Taken together, this game isn't one I'm rushing out to play.

RATING: 4
Having played the game, I understand WHY people find this game interesting, I really do. However it is an excruciating example of everything I hate in board games that I hate. First off to play well, you really have to understand the entire game and know how the cards break down into positive and negative actions and how to play off them the best which means a lot of memorization which is an instant way to turn me off a game. I like the exploration of a game and the joy of that rather than feeling like I have to do homework and memorize strategies. Secondly it is far too deck driven as in its only real mechanic and literally no way to mitigate bad hands whatsoever. You may get lucky on a hand or two over the game but my experience was ok here's one card that helps you and 7 that do nothing but make victory assured for the other player. No mitigation at all and they just seemed to be matching up with exactly how my opponent was playing. It's the same reason I hate Pandemic and that one has TWO decks that can easily cost you the game no matter how much planning and problem solving you do. So if I were not able to see the game underneath what personally turns me off in a game this would easily be a one but I can see its value to a percentage of gamers out there so it in all honesty deserves the 4.

RATING: 10
Deep, engaging, challenging, but not too complex. There's a lot going on between the players that is left unsaid and you're sometimes not sure what is motivating a move by the other player. You may waste effort countering a move that is a distraction. Very much an action / reaction type play experience. I'm not a big fan of two player games because I like the human dynamics in game play, but this is a great two player game (and I don't think there are many that qualify). I would love to see a 3-5 player game with similar mechanics.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Update: This is one of those games that I admire but have no desire to play again. I simply don't like the idea that in order for me to play well, I have to know the deck.

Also, I think I'm too stupid for the game. All the methods to acquire influence in a country I simply do not fully comprehend.

As for issue [1]: I find the scoring mechanic quite thematic. The idea that you are obliged to score for one area on the map simply because you got dealt the scoring card corresponds well to the paranoia and pointlessness of the Cold War.

=====

The most important thing for me when it comes to war games is theme, and I think it fails for the following reasons:

[1] Scoring. I don't know much about the Cold War or the goals of its main participants, but they could've found a more thematic scoring mechanic other than area majority. Worse is how these scoring rounds are triggered. If you are dealt a scoring card, you must score a particular region during that round. So you're thinking how to best play the cards in your hand to make the most of that scoring card. However, because scoring in this manner is an essential part to winning this game, all you are thinking about is making points -- you totally lose sight of the theme, which makes TS feel "gamey."

[2] The card driven war game format. In a typical war game, all significant actions are mapped to a unique mechanism. For example: moving units, you move your counter on the board; battle, you roll dice. Also, the number of possible actions are quite limited. Move, attack, reinforce, and build. Here, the CDW mechanism allows the designer to add almost any historical event to a game. The problem is that regardless of event, you're basically doing the same thing: draw a card, add/remove an influence marker, etc. What happens is that no one bothers to read the name of the event. Instead, players read the consequences of each event.

[3] The mechanisms for coups and realignment don't feel very elegant in relation to all the other mechanisms in the game. You're very restricted in your actions in terms of the kinds of events each card features and how you add influence markers on the board. But with coups and realignments, you can do them almost anywhere on the board.

Despite these glaring flaws, I'm still willing to play this game again. The game moves quickly, and it's easy for me to find willing opponents.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

may be not the best game there is , but high class in it's own category

RATING: 10
Best 2 player game in the world. Period.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.8
Twilight Struggle is incredibly well designed.  The deep layers of strategy are implemented with only cards, influence markers, and dice.  In fact, this game is far and away the most strategic game that incorporates dice that I have ever seen.  They add the perfect amount of uncertainty to the world-scale game of influence, striking a perfect balance of fortune - but fortune that can be weighted one direction or the other.  

Also impressive is the deep and understated balance this game delivers through the randomness of its elements.  The shuffled cards, much like the previously mentioned die rolls, are not nearly the game-swinging implements of other games. The dual op point or action mechanic inherent in the cards creates a nice tension of which ability to use vs. what helps my opponent the least, but the understated mechanic that really swings the randomness back toward strategy is the fact that once a player-aligned ability is used on a card, it is removed from play.  The implication is that even if you happen to draw a handful of cards that help your opponent, you have the ability to control when they are played and removed, which leaves the deck more heavily stocked with cards that help you - ready to swing the game back in your favor!

Overall, this is truly the most deeply strategic game I've ever played, and each play carries the weight of history with it.  It is a very rewarding game to win and a profound learning experience when you lose.  Also interesting is the fact that I have learned far more about the Cold War and its political intricacies through playing this game - a first for me.

Truly the only downsides to this game are the playing time and the fact that it is only a two player game.  It is long (at least 2 - 3 hours), and if your play group is larger than yourself and a friend, then this game is not an option.  

To conclude, I very highly recommend adding this game to any collection.  Our group is usually 4 - 6, but on the occasions that only one other person is available to play, this is the game we most often break out.  There is a reason it's number 1, and it is a genuinely rewarding experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
So, everything from the above post, but the added production values, Turn 0 expansion, and gorgeous wooden game box combine to make this one of the highlights of my entire collection.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
TS is an interesting game to be sure, and once mastered can be an extremely tactical beast... but ONLY once both players have reached the point of having memorized the effects and potential timing of every single shuffled card in the game.
If you haven't done so, then TS is just going to feel completely arbitrary, random, and devoid of strategy.

It really feels like someone took a methodical and intense area control game that requires expert planning and foresight, and stapled Fluxx on top of it.    
Multiple turns of careful containment and thoughtful maneuvering on the board are routinely made pointless by randomly drawn cards that massively swing the game state without player input.   The only meaningful counter-play is to just straight up memorize every card in the deck and attempt to plan for the deck's unpredictable nonsense.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I am a good loser, but WOW what a game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I must admit that I was a late comer to Twilight Struggle. I had the Deluxe Edition and played it a couple of times, but I wasn't able to "get" it. Sometimes it happens.

Then, after almost one year, I played TS again with a passionate friend, and somehow this time things "clicked". I understood both the spirit and the beauty of the game. 

Since then I didn't play a lot of games - maybe a dozen - but the variety of strategies, variables, lucky breaks and dire happenings... and not to mention how TS shows how the Cold War was a big Poker game infused with paranoia... well, I can see myself playing both the tabletop version and the digital one for the foreseeable future.

A side note. Some gamers whine about the "luck" factor. IMHO, that's the very point: the "illusion of control". Many people involved in the Cuban Missile Crisis later testified how sheer luck was a key element in preventing a thermo-nuclear war (among them, Robert McNamara). A sobering thought from one of the best games I ever played.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Own the deluxe edition and have the collectors edition on pre order

There is some debate back and forth on the wooden blocks, all I will say is they sure do look nice on the board. I will need to see how they function after more plays. Glad to own this edition of a great game.

RATING: 9.9
Capolavoro della GMT Games e uno dei migliori "card-driven" mai realizzati. Gran bel gioco dalla ambientazione fantastica in grado di ricreare perfettamente il clima della guerra fredda tra USA e URSS. Le tensioni sono palpabili ad ogni pesca delle carte associate ad un evento, poi via con Eventi, Influenze, Colpi di Stato, Corsa allo Spazio e tenendo sempre d'occhio lo stato del DEFCON. Tantissima tattica e strategia. Il gioco √® inizialmente molto difficile per gli americani nella prima fase e pi√π difficile per i sovietici nella seconda. Per questo motivo, un consiglio, se giocate con un nuovo giocatore, lasciate a lui l'URSS. Abbastanza scacchistico, nonostante i dadi, con una presenza aleatoria marginale. Una sfida intensissima per due giocatori che si conoscono bene e che vogliono impegnarsi per almeno tre ore incollati alla partita con costante febbrile eccitazione. Un plauso agli autori che hanno dato vita ad un giocone... fedelissimo al contesto storico di riferimento, con uno scenario su cui si gioca: il Mondo (da spartirsi)! Peccato che un gioco cos√¨ ben fatto sia solo per due giocatori. International Gamers Award for 2-Player... 2006.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I love it, for many reasons.

First of all, it's deep, but not complicated. The rules are quite straightforward really, but the gameplay... wow, there's a bit to think about here! One of the games that are (I know, it's cliche at this point) "easy to learn, hard to master". I don't play it often enough (it's time consuming, which is the only thing I hate, for personal reasons mostly [kids etc.]), but after each game, I know very well that there were dozens of things I could have done better. And that's why you want to play it again and again - to hone your skills, try different approach and so on. 

"Twilight Struggle" is the reason I fell in love in CDGs. While it can feel random at times, there are many ways to mitigate bad luck and just wait for a good hand to counterattack. And my god, is it thematic! A good lesson in history too, and a game that made me appreciate historical themes.

RATING: 10
An utterly sensational game. The tension, the thrill of a big coup, the bluffing, the management of the military ops, the space race - it works extremely well.

I like one deck CDG's like this (though it has three phases) and Wilderness War. Both have similar time frames, card decks and complexity levels. A big hit for euro gamers and those looking for low end war games. Who knew the Cold War could be so much fun? Easy to learn, but entry level is difficult as knowing the deck is a BIG advantage. Expect a few early exits, but don't worry too much.

There are too many other games out there (two-player included) that can provide depth and enjoyment, and you could play 2-3 of them in the time it takes to try and get through this one.
