RATING: 9.5
The best card-driven two-player game I've ever played, GMT Games' Twilight Struggle is set during the Cold War Era pitting the USSR vs. the USA. Great strategic depth and infinite replay value, even for veterans. I own the 2010 Deluxe Edition with the mounted map board.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I'm actually upping the rating on this one after playing it more and more - probably the first time I've done this. I just love how the game emulates cold war and the whole brinkmanship of the era - even up to actual moments in the game where you manouver around defcons, try to figure out of the opponent is just bluffing or actually doing something soon - the constant tug of war between action and reaction.

Sure, it's most enjoyed with an overall knowledge of the cold war (especially the early stages and how it was a global conflict instead of just about the berlin wall) and for sure it requires a few games under your belt until you can truly start 'playing' it, but that "easy to learn, hard to master" is true for other great games as well. Sure, it's a little opaque for beginners and that creates the hurdle, since you need to persevere through the first couple of games to grow a bit of skin, but after that you'll either love it or hate it :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
From 2009: I've played this about four times, and have liked it better each time.  I was initially off put by the poor components.  I was also surprised at how apparent the "right" play seemed and how unbalanced the card set seems.  Maybe I just don't understand the US strategy yet, but the Soviets have won 3 of the 4 plays, and this looks like it will be close to the ongoing story.  Given that it takes about 2 hours to play, it is unlikely to get many sessions where we change sides and play again.  I think it would be improved with either unequal victory conditions, or a more balanced card set.  Still, it has very interesting game play, great use of an intriguing theme, and it is deep enough that it will be replayed often.  From 2017:  OK, I get it.  now one of my favorite games.  A close game can be a tense, epic 3 to 4 hour battle, but then again, it can be a 45 minute blitzkrieg.  Always willing to give this one a go, and one of the best 2 person games I have ever played.

RATING: 10
What a game. The game is really about the cards you play. The cards allow you to do certain events, do certain moves or you can toss them if you don't like them. The game is pretty tense as you go back and forth trying to do your plans as you foil your opponents. Unlike Labyrinth, the game is easier to learn and teach. The game can take a long time though and won't be easy for a new player to get. Knowing what cards are in the game is a huge advantage to have. This is a game I really want to play, but I doubt I'll be able to do so. The board and box art are very, very cool. The big, broad colors show a sense of urgency and seriousness - reminiscent of that time period, and strangely enough, relevant today.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I still don't think that I've played Twilight Struggle enough to comment on it properly. I love that the cards have multiple uses.  Most of all, I love the work with what you've got aspect of Twilight Struggle.  I've been on the look out for a game like Pinochle that you start with a bunch of something (cards, resources whatever), and as the game progresses, you've got less and less until you are finally forced to spend everything. Twilight Struggle is like incredibly deep, themed Pinochle with area control.  Each time I play a card, I wonder what my opponent will do in response.  Does he have something to counter that?  Would it have been better to play something else sooner?  All of these questions are going to keep me playing Twilight Struggle for a long time.

RATING: 10
+excelent and strong theme that will take you right in the middle of the Cold War
+number of winning options and posibilities 
+easy general rules with nice cheat sheets
+a lot of thinking with little to none wating for other player

-kind of too random and snowballing space race track for a heavy 2-player strategy game
-very low quality of third polish edition (don't know about any other versions but this rly was a great con to this one for me)



Truly outstanding game. The only 2 things that made me not to give it a 10.  
First thing not rly connected to the game itself, terrible quality of polish third edition, board is not flat after deploying and cards are not good at all taking into account mechanic that makes you use some cards 10 times more than others. Sleves are a must.
The other thing is a small thing with a gameplay, when you are behind in space race at the very beggining and you don't get the only card that may help you soon, you are doomed to loose like 6-8 points from an unlucky roll at the very beggining. It's not a huge deal but still the one thing in my opnion near perfect gameplay.

Update:
After ~10 more games i think the space race is not as important as i though, however wars and dice rolls in general seems to be too random for my taste. the difference between 1 and 6 is huge. 1-you wasted your turn, 6-you have taken control over a country with stability 2. The fact that after planing and trying to outmind your opponent you have to say "YOLO" lets roll this, and you have no idea what will happen is kind of out of place for me. 

I am just neatpicking here. Game is great. I just wish it was perfect.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A classic outshined by its more streamlined "successor" (1960: The Making of the President). Having played both in the inversed order of their year of release, it's clear to me that 1960 takes advantage of Twilight Struggle's great design to bring it to an even higher level of achievement: first, 1960 is a faster game; second, while much of TS complexity revolves around memorizing the entire deck and knowing all the intricacies of card interrelations, 1960's goes to a different direction, bringing difficult decisions from an amazing card design (with so much information crammed in) that makes TS cards seem dull in comparision; third, the brilliant compensation mechanic of the "rest cubes". As a Cold War simulation, however, there's none better than TS.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.95
Very involved 2P game set in the cold war.  Kinda like Risk on steroids (but it's card driven control of areas, rather than dice battling for domination of areas).  There are 10 turns...each turn you get a hand of ~8 cards and take turns playing the cards as you try to secure control of various regions of the world.  The scoring cards are shuffled into the deck so you don't know when you will be required to score various regions of the globe.  Nice theme/history contained in the game.

Some frustration as it feels most of the game you are trying to minimize the damage of 'bad' cards in your hand.  You can use each card for the special historical power printed on the card, or just use it to get action points to directly increase your influence on the board, or reduce your opponent's influence.

Long game!  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fun CDG. Elegant adaption of the CDG system to combine political and military power in the setting of the Cold War. The three decks describing different periods are well balanced and designed.

also, its full of dice rolling. never a good sign for balancing

RATING: 7.8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I can understand how people like this game - it's just not for me.  This is the kind of game that you are going to need to invest in the entirety of the game to get the full experience.  You will need to memorize each card.  You are going to need to understand how everything fits together.

To build a strategy in this game you are going to need to have realizations like: "Ok, I see that X1-CARD hasn't been played yet, so I know X2-REGION is getting scored soon.  I need to play X3-CARD to ensure..."

I'm sure the game is well balanced.  I'm sure it has a depth of strategy that allows for repeated game play.  I'm sure it's every bit as fun as people say it is once you grok the system.  I'm just not even remotely interested in devoting that much of my attention to a single game (or game system).

:star::star::star::nostar::nostar: [b]Components[/b]
:star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar: [b]Artwork[/b]
:star::halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar: [b]Mechanics (general gameplay "fun")[/b]
:halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: [b]Rules (well written and easy to learn/teach)[/b]
:star::star::star::star::star: [b]Replay Value[/b]

RATING: 5
Very big disappointment for me. I gave this game two tries, but both the randomness and the amount of reading you have to do made me not enjoy this game. One central aspect of avoiding playing cards from which your opponent benefits more than you, also made me feel miserably through most of the game. I also cannot see how interesting gameplay should emerge from this.

For a card driven 2-player game with dice based conflict resolution which takes quite some time to play, I would always prefer War of the Ring. To me there  is no other example of two games occupying the same niche and one beating the other so clearly. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
A superlative card-driven area control game that replicates the Cold War between the US and USSR from 1945-1989.

The game is full of tough, agnonising choices that often has my head in my hands trying to figure out how to analyse, deal with, and respond to multiple theatres, multiple threats, and how best to utilise my cards to resolve all the above.

The cherry on top is Playdek's app implementation on Steam, iOS and Android: from the early 80s electronic theme music, to the historical news-reels and soundbites during each round, and how slick and easy the UI makes playing the game. 

It is testament to the game that the cardboard version is on my 'Want to Buy' list.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Card driven play to apply and remove influence in scoring regions, with a variety of "event" cards to add some spice. However, a number of subtle restrictions (e.g. when and where coups may be attempted), subplots/subgames (such as the space race), and ingenious balancing rules (realignment, the military track, DEFCON levels) give players much more to think about. A game of area control, positioning, timing, strategy and counterstrategy. A player can quickly escalate the game into a military conflict to detract from his opponent's strategy or mitigate luck of the draw.. A game of action and reaction, where dedication to a long term strategy could just as easily lose you the game as win it. The theme is fully immersive and integrated into the mechanics.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I enjoy the political theme of Twilight Struggle. The game is smooth and plays relatively quick. There is an element of luck with the single die roll and the draw of the cards that sometimes overcomes the best of strategies. However, these shortcomings are minor and do not distract from the overall enjoyment of the game much.

RATING: 7.8
enjoying this game.   Its a card game that has conflict but doesn't feel like nasty conflict...so far.  Lots of thought can happen if you get the right combo of cards.  The Space race roll can be unforgiving too. Very well thought out game with lots of historic information.  Lots of Strategy but can be a bit foiled by luck of the draw and bad die rolls. Can feel a bit more like work and analysis paralysis can really slow this long game down especially with newer players.

RATING: 10
EXCELLENT! I have the newly published 2nd Edition. Nice improvement of the control markers and the HEAVY CARDBOARD box. This game has a lot of dice-rolling, but it requires good judgment and decision nonetheless. The theme is well represented over the three "stages" of the COLD WAR, and gives you many strategic options every turn. You will be overwhelmed with all of the tasks you need to accomplish, but you must focus on the immediate goals at hand, and respond to your opponents actions. Even when you have a bad game, it's still enjoyable to play.

The cards very cleverly capture the key events of the era and abstract them into game play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.2
I have played this game 11 times.

This game does not deserve to be
rated #1 or anywhere even remotely close
to it.

As a GMT production it has been very
heavily over-hyped by a largely US 
audience.

The physical production of this game 
was extremely poor with warped map
and flimsy box.

The artwork was passible but not better
than normal.

Game play tends to be programmed by
the cards and thus is less subject to 
player skill/choice as the vast majority 
of these cards will definitely occur. (And
player choice can usually do little to 
modify the results of cards being played.)

However, the most significant historical
events which are the most important to 
include in any historically accurate game 
are the Few Cards which are most likely 
to remain tucked away by the opponent
to prevent enemy use.

The game also lacks historical accuracy 
in having China Flip Flop back and forth 
Irrationally between the 2 sides; as if they
were a confused puppet in a bipolar world
instead of being a power in their own right.

The War in Vietnam also is underrepresented in
the extreme and is inaccurately portrayed as a
minor episode which the Americans can Easily
Win just by allocating a few more points to.
The dedication of this small country, absorbing
a massive US attack, defeating the US and 
Gaining Liberty for its country are no where to
be seen. The trite and wishful treatment given here in this game is completely inaccurate historically
and devoid of any Reality.

Finally the game seems to lack play balance
as the Soviets seem to have a significant
advantage.

While I do consider this to be a reasonable
Game it is not a great game nor is it an accurate
Historical one.

When one gets beyond all of the American hype
And the hype from GMT expect a solid but NOT 
an Outstanding game.

RATING: 10
This is an amazing game. Rules are long and tricky to get right at the start. But once you do - you have an absolute cracker of a game on your hands.

The game is deliberately unbalanced to the point of being very nicely balanced! USSR holding an advantage in the early game, but this swings to the US the longer the game goes on. 

Games can take a while, but I never turn down an opportunity to play.

One of my very favorite games!


23/11
I've taken the time to read a few of the negative comments about the game - to find out what people don't like about it. I'd like to address a couple of them.

1. Length - yes, it is a long game. Even a game where you steamroll your opponent, you will still probably be playing at least an hour. However, there are people who like a longer game. I feel I get more invested in a game that takes some time to play. And a victory or defeat means something. 

2. 2 player only. - Um, yes - it's a 2 player game. It says it on the box. Why mark it down for being "only 2 player"? Do people mark Solitaire down for being "only 1 player"?

3. You roll dice, the game is just luck. - You can get "unlucky" with the cards you draw and you can get unlucky when with dice when you go for that critical attack. I played a game online, where I felt that the dice were always screwing me and my opponent was always getting what he needed. In the end, my dice rolls averaged 3.6 and his 3.5 - my dice rolls were better, but both were pretty much average. We all remember when things go badly and forget when they go well. With dice in this game - I play this game hoping for the best, but preparing for the worst.

4. Just draw for killer card combination and win - This is the real kicker for me. Yes, there are some cards which are quite harsh on the other player. But there are ways around just about everything. The biggest strategy point in this game is when you have a horrible opponent card. Most people just try to space them, but this can be a mistake as they'll come back later. If you can play your opponent's card at a time of your choosing where you can minimise/eliminate the damage - then the card is gone forever! Likewise, prepare for similar cards your opponent is holding (always keep a 3+ strength card in hand until late in your turn as US). Often in this game, all your choices of cards to play might seem to be bad - but that means your opponent probably has similar nasty decisions to make holding "your" cards.

Overall - this won't be a game for everyone. For me, it is an incredibly deep, strategic and well balanced game. As I basically mentioned, I love it!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3
This game is very thematic and at times playing the USSR I found myself wanting to say "Nyet Nyet" when I was not happy with a USA move.

The map and components are ok, game has some dice rolling when you perform coups whilst adding some randomness does not detract completely from game. Game takes too long for what it delivers and can be a little fiddly with all the influence counters. I will play this game again but will not be purchasing a copy.

Notwithstanding, there is no way this game should be number one as there are loads of other games about.

RATING: 8
Excellent two-player game. It has very good replay value, but the learning curve can be a little steep. The rules are simple, but how to translate that into how to play the game is not obvious. Wide-open decision tree, too, so people who are prone to taking a long time are more likely to.

However, definitely worth getting for me. When teaching new players, go easy on them, or else they may never show up again :)

RATING: 7
My experience:
3-5 games.

I love it.

I like:
- The theme. Not only it is very interesting but it is also very well translated into the game. Evocative and sensible cards.

- Simple rules that lead to a myriad of options and decisions.

- Tension. What is on my opponent's hand? A scoring card? How am I going to get rid of all these enemy events? Or should I?

I don't like:
- The game could be shorter.

RATING: 9
Once I went to visit my best college buddy Dave when he was just getting out of this shitty divorce. I came out during my spring break for a week to visit him, in his crappy sad divorced-dad apartment, with boxes full of his crap that he'd didn't have the heart to unpack, an inflatable bed, and an upturned cardboard box for a dining room table. The place stank of despair. I showed up with no plans and a copy of Twilight Struggle, which I'd never played, in my suitcase. He thought it was his duty to "show me New York", and we kept trying to do touristy, but every day, we'd just stop at some point, look at each other, and say, "You wanna go back and just play Twilight Struggle?" 

We played game after game on his kitchen floor, in his empty kitchen, in that sad dreary apartment, and playing this game was the first time I'd seen him happy in about a year.

RATING: 5
rating after 1 play 6/7
rating after 2 plays 5

Massive dissappointment. Had very high hopes for this. Played it twioce with 2nd game lasting 6hours despite a 7th turn win. It does feel very random but this isnt the problem...the problem is it feels dull. Despite the obvious theming it feels like you're just addong red and blue counters to spaces just before they are scored...the timing of which is semi-random. The fact that u pretty much have to play all the cards in your hand removes any tactical decisions and instead of the many tension-filled fraught decisions i was hoping for u just get this sense of dull inevitability. Add to all this the fact its alleged to be bias in favour of 1 side and i fail to see the appeal of this game at all. I would try and recommend an alternative but i dont know of 1 so if anyone does please let me know! i would love to find a long 2pl immersive game that feels like you've done something constructive with your time but this isnt it

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fast playing wargame of the Cold War that is a well balanced mix of using operations points for expansion/removal of influence markers and the event effects--the forced use of an opponent's event works well to provide the necessary tension.

Although the cards cover most of the events/situations of the period, a few events could have been present:  building of the Berlin Wall (there is Reagan's "Tear Down this Wall"), "Ich bin ein Berliner", Watergate, "The Premier has a cold", Challenger Disaster, Eastern European Crackdown (on Hungary or Czechoslavakia), Stagflation, etc.

Funny seeing all the comments saying the game favors the Soviets, in my first seven games the Americans won.

RATING: 9
I've loving it so far.  It has all the delicious agony, bluff, and flavor of a card-driven wargame with much less weight (save perhaps for We the People).  I have seen both the USSR and the US win in 3 plays, so I not so concerned about play balance.

One feature I really like is that playing the other guy's event card for ops points triggers his event -- and it is hard to avoid playing a card.  That ensures that lots of events will happen, which is a big reason I play CDWs.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
 This is a difficult game to asses. The game mechanics are very simple, basically an area control eurogame (very much like El Grande) with wargame components. It's also a bit longer than other eurogames of similar complexity. The theme is terrific, no doubt, even with didactic value. 

 The main mechanics: influence placement and events plays often very smoothly, but unfortunately, the rest doesn't and seems pasted, like realignments (rarely played) and the space race (lame and completely luck based and disconnected from the rest). I enjoyed it, because of the theme, and the fun that comes from discovering the deck and seeing how the game events unroll. But, you must accept the fact that the luck component in the game is huge (often decisive), heavily imbalanced (the USSR have substantial advantage) and where most of the skill in the game comes from the deck knowledge and card counting.

 I think of it as an OK game, if only because the theme, enjoyable (if you can live with the luck factor) until you know the events, but from that onwards I cannot see very much play. Similar games, as El Grande are far better designed, more intense and balanced.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
The Cold War with all it's historical events in a complex startegic game with amazingly simple rules.

The action has its heart in the card deck which forces players to play events even when harmful to them. However, clever hand management can delay or reduce those events.

In addition to seeking direct political control of the worlds regions, players seek to avoid plunging to avoid Defcon 1 while being forced to foment military clashes. Brinksmanship is the name of the game.

RATING: 7.5
12-08-2015. Rated after 1 play. Going into a game expecting a lot from "the best game" on BGG is probably stupid, but hey.

In TS you play cards, until one of a few victory conditions trigger. Either USSR or USA controls Europe during scoring, gets 20 VPs or at the end of round 10 via scoring.

You achieve this by playing cards from a shared deck of cards, there are USSR, USA or shared cards. Each turn, you play 6 or 7 cards. First, in the headline phase you play a card for its event. Then, you are allowed to play cards for the printed event OR for operation points. With operation points you can add influence tokens in countries, if you ever have the majority in an area and exceed the 'treshold' and the treshold + your opponents influence you 'control' that area. 
A lot of cards also allow you to play events, often these allow you to remove influence or add influence in specific regions. If you ever play a card for operation points that is from your opponent's faction, then your opponent gets to play that event.

I mean, I like TS. It's not broken or problematic or in anyway less than 'good'. I just feel it's disappointing, the components are poor, the artwork on the cards is.. just meh, the theme is meh. I think I'd enjoy the system more with a more interesting setting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Sleeved with Ultra Pro Standard (66mm x 91mm).

There seems something off with the voting, 15000 times?!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I can see why this is so popular, but I was quite a bit underwhelmed after wanting to try it for so long based on its BGG rating. My opinion is after only 1 play, so take it with a large grain of salt, and I would be willing to try it again, but no great interest to do so.

It is a good mix of Euro and wargame mechanics, but my main issues were:
Game length - it's seems like playing 7 out of a hand of 8 cards each turn is excessive; trimming this down could have shortened the game significantly with the same epic feel.  

Lack of historical theme - Clearly the designers worked hard to put as much history into the cards as possible, but IMO there is not very much integration of theme and mechanics.  This was evident when most times we would not read the title of the card when playing it.  Most wargames are a much closer simulation of what happened, with a mixture of scripted actions and player decisions. After a good wargame, I want to go read about how the battle actually went historically to see how it differs from what happened.  Twilight Struggle does not really produce this narrative, since the game is just a string of events and operations, that only very loosely fit the normal timeline through the structure of the 3 section draw deck.  I kept wanting to see the alternative event occur a la Chrononauts - it would have been so cool if each event had 2 possibilities - one if played by US, alternative if played by USSR.
  
2 player area control with # tiles is pretty boring - ultimately the game is area control, with you vying for majority in each country.  # tiles are intrinsically less interesting than piles of cubes a la El Grande, and when it's just 2 players, it creates a tug of war where you add 2, I add 3, you take away 2, I take away 1.  That's an oversimplification - there's a lot more strategy over where and when you fight or cede control. We hated We the People, and while Twilight Struggle improves the area control play a lot, it wasn't enough to hold my interest.

At the end of the day, staring at the map for 3 hours just makes me want to play multiple games of Pandemic in the same time.  Same board (pretty much) but more thematic feel and tension.

RATING: 8
----------

After only 2 plays, I'm simply in awe of the depth of gameplay in this gem.  There are so many options and so many considerations that must be made every turn.  It can be overwhelming to first-time players, but I'd say that the first step to success is to learn the cards.

Due to the intense brain burn, this isn't a game I could play every day, but it's one that will continue to provide an amazing experience as I play it more.

This is my #5 game.

RATING: 3
Twilight Struggle is not a game for the casual gamer. This game requires an investment in time to memorize and or develop a system such as excel spread sheets in order to be competitive.  Yes this has been said many times before, but I'm stating it again because the new buyer, player needs to know that the number 1 rated game on BGG should not be rated number 1.  In my opinion, the top 10 rated games should be games that can be played by the casual/ family gamers.  After all, the game rating system is made to attract people to boardgaming.  Twilight Struggle is NOT one of this games!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Imagine the tension you get in something like Lost Cities, where you are constantly debating doing something that helps your opponent to do something you really want to do. Now, stretch that feeling over a grueling 3 hour+ session and you have Twilight Struggle. Simple ruleset, but somehow manages to capture the paranoia and tension of the Cold War era.

10-21-16

RATING: 10
Great game. Tense and atmospheric all the way.
I love the fact that all the good cards can only help you a bit and all the bad cards help you a little, it has a great balancing effect. You just have to use them to your best advantage in your overall strategy.
Constantly shifting situations keep on at the edge of your seat. You really have to keep tabs on your opponent. As a bonus the (2nd Ed. at least) rulebook has historical background for all the events in the game.
Even my SO is eager to play this (DISCLAIMER: She will also (among other games) play Arkham Horror and she loves Adv. Civ).
Highly recommended.
UPDATE:
Rating raised to 10 after more plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Tremendously fiddly, it takes forever, and the dice combat element seems like something I might have designed at age 12. The tug-of-war Adding Of Influence Chits is a puerile design mechanic.

It is embarrassing that this particular game sits bizarrely atop the rankings on our website, a strange fact which surely sells many copies of the game...to many naive, trusting buyers. I don't really know what to say about that, but I know that it doesn't make me feel good.

UPDATE: I've given this numerous tries now. It is an Ameritrash dice fest. Experienced players (I've only played with fellow amateurs) will surely beat the uninitiated, which is normally the sign of a good game. But in this case, I think it is mainly because they know the deck, and so can manipulate the timing of things. To those who think that this "skill" is what makes for an interesting board game encounter, I say "have at it." When two similarly experienced amateur players are pitted against each other, you have a four-hour affair that comes down to who rolls more "6s", and who draws the cards in the order that better helps them. That's the sort of nonsense that is utterly forgiveable--and even sometimes fun--in a thirty-minute game. But...

I've dropped my rating on this every single time I have played it. Enough is enough.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Half the time we seem to be to & fro-ing in South America.

RATING: 10

Mechanically, the Card-drive system is one of my favorite game elements. This game strategic, well-balanced, immense in options, and, in one word, terrific! I give it a perfect ten and assure you this is never changed.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
After some ten games of Twilight Struggle, a couple of things impress me. First of all, I'm amazed how well it implements not just the events of the Cold War, but also the emotions. There's a sense that you must mirror the other player because you just must, that's why. And you always feel like you're losing, even when you're well ahead. 

Secondly, this is a very complex game without being very complicated. By which I mean the game is challenging and nuanced, but not very rules-intensive. I know with my head how to play, but my experience is still green and raw. I love that I'll be able to play this one for years to come, and it'll keep revealing depths to me. Really a masterpiece of lean design and theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Somehow this game isn't my cup of tea... and my rating reflects this (although it's no bad game by any means).
I have to admit that I don't really fancy CDG, and this game is no exception: My problem is that I really think that the choice between OPs and Events is totally gamey here ("So, do we launch the NATO or try a coup somewhere), specially when it comes down to cards management ("Comrade, let us activate the NATO now, so that it doesn't come to life later in the war")
I liked 1960 better because there I could somehow understand (or relate to) the OP/Event choices there.
[Besides: in TS you sometimes have the feeling that you are not really playing the game: the cards are]

Essentially, TS fails the "Simulation" test, which is my main interest in political games: might be a good game, but I'm looking for a good simulation.

RATING: 10
I had read a lot of history regarding the Cold War before playing this game and Twilight Struggle captures it perfectly; the promotion of ideals through deception, aid, posturing, armed struggle... it was a battle of minds and will that encompssed the globe.As in the real conflict there's a fine line to tread here; be too aggressive or weak in your stance and you will lose. As a side note, if you are studying the history of the Cold War then play this game. It will put you in the midst of it unlike no book ever could. Also watch the film Thirteen Days.

RATING: 3
Played this once teamed up with someone else against the organizer of the Toronto Area Gamers meetup group. We won by going for a risky victory point jump in turn 6 (I think) after 2 rounds of horrible cards which caused our board position to decline pretty drastically and realizing that another scoring card would have put us in a position that would have been almost impossible to climb back from. I like that there are multiple win conditions but it took a while to understand all the turn possibilities.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
To make long things short, i love this game, but sadly i hate playing it. It can't be helped: i love the many moments of headbreaking tension that this game offers you, but after countless games i can't shrug my head off the deep certainty that most often that not this game is decided by drawing the best card at the best possible moment (being Destal, or Decol, or Grain Sales, or RS/P, or simply a scoring card), and, extensively, by having overall better hands with better cards than your opponent. By playing this game, you accept that you may invest two hours and more in trying to get the upper hand after a weak start, only to fail miserably to do so simply because cards does not swing in your way. Conversely, you may be on the brink of win or defeat, and then either you or your opponent will get all the most powerful or weakest Mid-War cards, which can singlehandedly fix or break even the most dire or best situation. This turn the game into basically something like "endure turn X hoping that turn Y you will get luckier", which is not the way one of the supposedly best games ever created should put you on. Such game should give it's players a more cohesive and rewarding way of planning a strategy, not just being a streak of tense moments that, yes, are interesting, engaging and all, but that you have to pay for by accepting that the game may be doomed from the start if you don't get better hands. Yes, you have to learn the basics to play to win, which are matured out of experience and by reading some guide. This is actually another weak point of this game: you can't possibly play it to have fun or to unwind or to try some fancy move, by doing so you just take useless risks that may undermine your shot at victory. Same story if you play with someone who is less experienced than you: either you give him an edge by playing softly, or you are doomed to win a game after another. I'll say that TS is one of the rare games that somehow become less enjoyable the more you play it, because more and more things becomes an auto-play and the great variety that the game seems to offers at a first glance simply disappear with experience. 
I strongly thing that the game could have been better with some additional mechanic, and sometimes i wonder what was the first draft game that JM and AG turned into TS because it was considered too long and slow.

As a final note about a long and still much debated charade, i don't really think that the game is broken in favor of the URSS unless the USA is given an uncoupable stronghold in Iran (which is considered the best "fix"). Again, it's entirely possible, given bad rolls and bad hands, for the URSS to lose her starting edge, which, in itself, allow the URSS to roughly win 60% of all games, which is not really that big deal to begin with.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
ugh. Long, slow and pointless sluggish tug-of-war involving the most agressively tedious and posturing time the west has ever known: the cold war. I would pay to NOT play a game about the cold war. Plus over-reliant on few die rolls. Watch one side win a bunch of straight space race rolls while you don't, to understand how crappy this one can be.

I've always wanted to like Twilight Struggle. #1 BGG game and all that. I don't...cold war stuff bores me to f$%^ing tears. I was a teenager in the 80's, and all I wanted to do was listen to the Dead Kennedys and Corrosion of Conformity (and other assorted rage punk stuff) and shut out the goddamn whining about Russia (or even worse, that asshat Regan). That whole era just disgusts me even still, I want to revert to my punk teenage mindset and tell people where to get off when that political theme comes up in convo. Needless to say, TS is like claws on a blackboard to me. 

even with a different theme, I'd probably rate it a 3, however (I rate 1989 a 3). It just doesn't mechanically come together as an enjoyable experience. I hate the lack of long term planning, the forced play, the lack of control, the random timed scoring, the stuck feeling that never lessens.

I play Washington's War instead--similar style CDG with better theme, better mechanics, half as long playtime, more immersive, more theme evocative, more controlled scoring.

RATING: 7
Have played once. I'm still trying to get the hang of stringing influencing, coups, and realignments into some semblance of an effective strategy. I *think* I like it, but there seem to be quite a few features that will drive me up the wall after a few plays, like the purely dice-driven space race giving out lots of bonuses and VPs. But I'm scared of the game length. It seems that a lot of other games I like compress everything I like from this game into a smaller, tighter package. I'll shut up now till I've played it a few times.


After my second play (with proper rules), I felt *much* more in control of what I was doing, with much more understanding, and managed to win as the US. Some of that is due to reading some of the tips written here, some due to the experience of a whole game under my belt. I do enjoy the game, but I'm very slow at playing it. Also, I don't get very excited about the game.

RATING: 10
I find the subject matter a big draw, and I am a sucker for the production of the deluxe edition, which is very shallow of me. Gameplay is tense and engaging. The main drawback of the game is that the players need to have about the same level of knowledge of the cards for the contest to be fair; but tht is where the long-term strengths of the game appear to lie, in the depth of strategy as the potential of card and board play are explored. Playing out the last century's struggles of the Long War that have shaped this one is an engaging way to spend an hour or two, especially with a glass of single malt whiskey to hand. May not be the greatest game of all time, but it does deserve its spot in the top ten.
Edit: It occurs to me from my misspelling whisky above that the US player really needs to be drinking Bourbon and the USSR player a good vodka.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I can't believe how good this game is. It gets easier to play with familiarity, but strangely it just gets more enjoyable and not samey as other games might get.  The theme is amazing and gets you into history.  I highly recommend watching the Cold War documentary series on YouTube as you progress through your many plays.  It seems perfectly matched to the game. 

Not many reviews indicate the bluffing nature of the game. This comes through when you have more experience with the cards as each player is deducing what your motivations are from observing your plays and "counting" the cards in the discard pile.  Mind blown. Perfect 10.  

I've moved to playing this on vassal with a non bg friend. He's addicted.  My wife doesn't enjoy the confrontation so much, partly due to time to play is lengthy at first. If I could encourage her to play more she would probably get over that it feels like a chore for her to play.  There are overwhelming choices and decisions for first timers, for quite a few plays I think. It took me a good 4-5 plays before things started to click.  I'm still trying to explore the late war portion more as my play seems to suffer greatly without knowledge of those cards. 

Playing regularly via iOS app with another non bg friend who is addicted to it and has become a tournament player!  Waiting for iPhone version to make my moves faster.  Come on playDek.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The designers have done an excellent job of creating a well themed game with relatively easy rules. Plenty of flavour and agonising decisions to be made, which makes it rather fun. Still, although there's enough die rolling to balance out most of the luck, it does feel as though the dice have a little too much influence in the game - especially in the space race. (Personally I feel there should be a -1 modified to your die roll if you failed your last space attempt.) At a three to four hour commitment the dice outstay their welcome a bit. Still, fun and flavoursome.

Example of the power of the die rolls and how they can make for a dud game occasionally: Things are running along pretty even, then the Quagmire event is played on the US. The US then goes on to discard three cards rolling five or six each occasion. All remaining cards are one value and therefore US has no action rounds this turn beyond headline event. US routed in Europe that turn = game over. That's a lot of power to the die roll! I did this to an opponent once and victory felt completely hollow.

For all the attention I focus on poor die rolling I have to admit that there's enough of it in the game that rolling usually even out to produce a wonderful experience - much like they do in ASL. So, although I go on about the dice a bit much, I still think it's a wonderful game full of character. Must play it with my kids one day under the guise of a history and geography tour.

This is a game that's going to reward repeated plays and knowledge of the cards and when they're likely to appear. For a balanced game it really needs players of about the same experience, otherwise it should be over quickly. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

WOW, never have I enjoyed being so frustrated for several hours and still having loads of fun!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A brilliant 2-player game, players represent the USSR and the USA trying to vie for other world power to side with them.  Using cards that have both points and a special ability, players *must* play cards that help both themselves and their opponents, maximizing gains while, minimizing losses.  The game is nicely divided into early, mid-, and late war, which feel historic and we end up looking up the events on the appendiz to learn more.  The biggest disappointment is the obvious bias toward the USSR.  We need to try using the "extra influence points" for the USA during set-up to see if this mitigates it, but even without doing so, the game still is an absolute blast.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
One play and I bought it.  This game certainly makes an impression.  Plus, learning more world history is quite entertaining.  I'm up for a game whenever, and think that while the reasons for that may change, I'll pretty much always be up for one if there is only 2 people available.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is just an outstanding use of cards, and is about as intense a hand management game as you can get.

Every card and every action can both help and hurt you like no game I've ever played.  The contrast between hand management and board control creates the perfect balance of strategy and tension.  Knowledge of the cards is important, and mis-matched players could pose balance problems.  

Overall a fast paced game that creates the decision making of a wargame despite the lack of battles while capturing the theme of the time period which makes it far more rewarding than your average eurogame.

The more I play it, the more I want to play it even more.  It is a must own for any gamers collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Very disappointed with the game that's been the top dog for so long.

The advantage an experienced player has over a newcomer leads to a high degree of frustration as the new guy is outmanoeuvred at almost every turn. I was surprised too, for a game that is allegedly such a tight affair due the interplay of the cards, by the amount of luck brought in by the distribution of those cards and die rolls (so, I had one influence, you've run a coup from half way around the world and now you have six influence, huh?). Even if I had the inclination to sit down and learn the cards, the luck factor alone means I won't be going back to try again.

I don't think it's a "bad" game as per the BGG description, but I've rated it 3 to fit with my lack of desire to play it again.

RATING: 9
Feltem tole mert egy kicsit kirandulasnak ereztem a wargame-k fele es olyan tipussal (Memoir gondolom nem sorolhato ide) nemigazan jatszottam. Egyetlen erv szolt mellette folyamatosan, a tema. Gyerekkent nem eltem meg annyira kielezettnek a nemzetkozi helyzetet, jol ereztem magam a langyos vizben amit a szocializmus utolso evei egy tizeneves forma gyerek-kamasz-fiatalnak adhatott. Ezert (par generacioval ellentetben) nosztalgikus erzes fogott el, amikor a kartyakon kulonbozo hires/hirhedt esemenyeket veltem felfedezni (ilyenkor mindig elkalandozok, hogy eppen mit csinalhattam akkor). Szoval a jatek, van benne egy egeszseges szerencsefaktor (dice, dice, mice), aki ezen tultudja tenni magat az egy rendkivul szorakoztato es porgos jateknak lehet reszese. A ket nagyhatalom folyamatosan probal teret nyerni a kulonbozo zonakban az esetleges kiertekelesnel tobb pontot szerezzenek az ellenfelnel. Noveled a jelenleted az adott orszagban, esetleg gyengited az ellenfeled neadjisten puccsot szervezel aminek elegge kiszamithatatlan kovetkezmenyei lehetnek, de az is lehet, hogy a kijatszott kartyanak a specialis szoveget hajtod vegre (mar ha valaszthatsz, mert ha az ellenfel kartyajat jatszod ki, akkor a szoveg automatikusan letrejon). Ki fogja nyerni az urversenyt (itt lehet a szamodra kellemetlen kartyakat ugy elsutni, hogy a hatasa ne tortenjen meg). Mennyire voltal agressziv az adott korben (ez akar VP pontokat is hozhat), de vigyazzal!! Nehogy a te korodben erje el a DEFCON szint a kritikus 1-es erteket mert akkor azonnal vesztettel. Az igazsaghoz hozzatartozik, hogy a jatekot csak a feleig sikerult lejatszani a kesoi idopont miatt, de elore latom, hogy nagy kedvenc lesz. Lehet a 10-es osztalyzatnal fogja talalni magat egy ujabb jatek utan?
Update1: Kapitulaltam a 8-ik korben, USA megint nyert.

RATING: 7

RATING: 4
First play was VERY disappointing.  Honestly not sure why this game has such a following.  It's simply an area control points scoring game with a Cold War theme stamped on it.

Things I don't like...
-contrived requirement for "military operations"
-DEFCON status was not even a minor player in the game
-random arrival of scoring cards degrades the historical aspect of the game
-shared deck means many of the cards in your hand CANNOT be used for the Event.  This greatly limits your options for card usage.  
-Limited actions available.  Played the entire game without need for re-alignment...
-Shared victory point track didn't seem to create tension, excitement, interest.
-The way the game handles conflict seems to come up short.  The most aggressive one can take is institute a Coup.  Other than that you are waiting for a handful of cards to show up such as the Korean War, India-Pakistan War. 
-With the above shortcomings, one might expect the map to really shine.  It doesn't unfortunately.  The main playing pieces on the map are a pile of red or blue chits with numbers....not very engrossing.

Things I do like...
-Theme
-Card driven

Was really hoping for more with this game.  I'll give it another play just to be fair.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Tense in the best possible way.  The sense of narrative and the balance between tactical reaction and strategic setup are superb.  One could quibble with some of the historicity or topography, but why bother?  The game works as is and hits pretty much all the sweet spots asked of it.  My first two plays were knocked off in a little over 4 hours each, so it meets the "single sitting" requirement.  Definitely not a Euro, but not a wargame either - more of a "historical" game.  It pretty much does everything I expected of it when I pre-ordered it lo these many moons ago.  Can't ask for more than that.

[b]Update:[/b] Once you more or less know the contents of the decks and how to play them, the interest in the game shifts to min-maxing the anticipation of certain moves. The early game, while not completely stereotyped, gets fairly dull. The midgame is more exciting since the possible spread of cards increases an order of magnitude. Still, knowing the game well means it takes too long to get to that point, and its possible the game "scenario" has gotten too unbalanced to save by then. The game still works, but it's less fun when you've explored most of it.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I knew all along that I would love this game and it'd be a top-5 for me, since I do like 1960: The Making of the President, and something even better sounded too good to be true. And I wasn't disappointed.

The board feels dynamic (this is a key ingredient for majority games) as there is a lot of opportunity to make pivotal moves that completely change the landscape. In 1960, the scope of your move is usually limited to Gathering Momentum, but even that isn't much of a swing, because all the scoring happens at the end. The varied timing of scoring means you're constantly in a knife-fight in the midst of several fires, and trying to eke out enough leeway in the main battlefront to set yourself up in another region.

I thought I'd miss the momentum system in 1960, but I don't at all. The forced trigger of unfavorable cards means it's an extra thing to take into account in terms of setting up your hand and managing the timing of your cards. And the ticking time bombs in your hand fit better with the salvage-what-your-hand-gives-you feel of the game, because you can't cop out of a bad card. You have to play [i]around[/i] it. The trigger also means events happen much more often than 1960, which means the board is more dynamic, and you have to be more deliberate and careful. Every card play becomes a challenge in controlled chaos.

I wasn't 100% sure of a game that boils down to you-play-a-card, I-play-a-card. But each card has 5 uses (3 options + 3 branching options with the Op Points), so you don't feel handicapped but are instead brain-melted by the myriad of approaches available to you (and I thought I'd be well-prepared since I can plan out what order to play my cards in 1960 in 10 seconds). And this game is so tense, you're more worried about coups and nuclear war than trivialities like cards and counters.

I had thought TS would do board positioning better while 1960 would do card-play better. Nah, TS wins hands-down.

5+4

[b][color=gray]Favorite 2-player Long - Runner-up[/color][/b]

RATING: 8

I was playing the commies and he was playing the capitalists.  Both of us were newbies so  we kind of muddled through.   By turn 5 (as was reported in most of the reviews) I was working him over pretty good.   Then the bastard plays a series of two cards and the weasel wins.  Oh well, it's still a great game and well worth the cash.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One learning game of it. Hard to evaluate though I suspect I'll end up liking this a lot, I just have to play it frequently (it is fairly long). Also of all long "epic" games this one offers me conflict and interaction immediately. And also features a good narrative with an atmosphere I enjoy and a reasonably slow pace. 

Played it 4 hours for first 4 turns and USSR won as I, the US, made a mistake in opening set up of influence tokens. I suspect the game will give the please Diplomacy does - that it takes some time to learn the irregularities of the game and how some things are better than others and it's only fun when everyone knows what they are.

RATING: 4.6
The low score is purely because I am finding it incredibly difficult to find opponents who have liked the game enough to play it again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[41 plays] Afterwards I usually dream of not only the game play, but also of the leaders and events depicted in the game and my associated memories of growing up in a Cold War world.

I'll get my 2 minor gripes out of the way first. 1) Some have told anecdotes of playing this with their wife. No way in hell my wife would tolerate the length and depth of this game. It took us 5 hours to learn and play it the first time, and we did not go past turn 8. However, I do expect/hope that on the downslope of the learning curve it will regularly play in less than 4 hours. 2) The USA is really up against it. It is very challenging for them to survive well into the mid war, where the cards finally swing over to the USA's advantage.

I've tremendously enjoyed the experiences in this game. It has the card play and hand management aspects of games like Lightning D-Day and We the People. It has the area control scoring elements of games like El Grande, Bootleggers, San Marco, etc. It has the point to point expansion, map adjacency analysis, bluffing, and challenges of many a good wargame. It has the angst of always wanting to do one more thing than you can, or worrying that the thing you are doing to help yourself will end up helping your opponent more instead. The theme is very strong and well integrated. It all works for me and I always have a great time, win or lose. I really do feel like I've "fought" the Cold War after each game.

Update Dec. 16th, 2016. I am lowering my rating to an 8. Much like I have done with my rating for Chess, I realize that this game can only be enjoyed over the long term by fairly evenly matched players, and that to play well, there is considerably more investment in learning all of the cards, combinations, and traps than in most of the sophisticated Euro or War games. It can be a 10 for two experienced and dedicated players, it will not be like that for more than a few games between players who do not approach that equity.


Most recent play Sept '17.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
1st edition
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A short CDG that's not really about war or troop movement? Wow. 1 to 3 hours? WOW! Count in me in. If only there's a multi-player version of the game!

Update: Someone describes this game as El Grande. It's stretching it a little but in a sense it's true: cards drive the game. You want to place influence in regions/countries. Well, I think this game is more a Euro than a Wargame.

Update: Knowledge of the cards is essential as you want to play cards to YOUR best advantage. The 'luck' of the card draws, die rolls can be frustrating especially since this isn't a 1 hour 'lets go again game'. To play it for 2 hours only to crash out owing to a bad draw isn't my idea of fun. Still, the designers have done well to try and encompass such a wide scope in this game. I fear my experience may be along the lines of Brian Bankler...

Update 2: Sure, bad card draws can hose you but I suspect that experienced players can overcome the draw with smart play. The game rewards patience, knowledge of the cards and a little bluff. I've had 4 games so far and find it to be a rewarding and tense 1-3 hours. Haven't felt this way since I played War of the Rings!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I want to play this more. Incredibly deep and interesting. The theme is practically dripping off the board and cards. Incredible and well designed are the words I would use to describe this game. Play it but only if you have someone willing to commit the hours for multiple plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Surprising amount of variety with different clusters of US and USSR events being triggered, delayed, or suppressed on different games. What is interesting is that players will often play their own one-time events for ops delaying the core effect for later when the opposing player has to trigger them, often giving the opponent a problem with a hand full of them other country's events. The character of the game can change quite a bit depending on how theses chains of events are triggered.

RATING: 3
Monstrous area control game with average components (in the "deluxe" version.)
The theme is not badly implemented, but it feels a bit random at times and it feels like just counting points too often. There surely are more thematic games.
Would be better if it was shorter. The 180 minute tag is *very* optimistic. We did not have under five hours. That might get shorter if you know the game very well and have memorized all the cards, but I dont think that usually one is going to get there. Not a good game for everyone who is not a hardcore fanatic for this sort of game and willing to do the time investment.
Plainly, I do not get why this is so high up in many peoples opinion.
My rating might seem a bit harsh, but it accurately depicts my desire to play this game. Also, I fail to see anything particularly original or inventive in this game mechanics-wise, that should cause me to rate it higher.

RATING: 10
Initial rating. This is the game I was hoping for when I bought Valley's reprint of Hannibal. It's an asymmetrical, exciting, well-themed strategy war game. Our first play, muddling through learning the rules, took around 4 hours, but it was glorious entertainment.

Okay, about 6 plays in - these may be the ultimate 2 player game. It's gripping, involved, and satisfying. There are strategic and tactical choices to make, and each game plays out like a different story. I can't believe I waited so long to get into this. Now...I just need to get my significant other to give it a try! Game length can really vary, but to be safe give yourself 3 hours once you know the rules. It's an awesome 3 hours though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Twilight Struggle at times can be a frustrating gaming experience, especially for the US player, who must constantly react to the actions of the USSR player. Also if you constantly have a hand full of your opponent's event cards, you get that feeling that you didn't achieve anything that turn, because you only tried to mitigate the outcome of these events.

Nevertheless, this is an amazing game, that features highly thematic and strategic gameplay, even though the game's mechanics are incredibly simple.
It fully deserves its top spot in the BGG rankings.

RATING: N/A
2
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.24
There's way too much Eurogamer excitement for this one right now, but if Twilight Struggle can get some Eurogamers interested in some other card-driven games or some type of wargames that would be a good thing.I've only played it once.  My Soviets were behind in the beginning when they should have been ahead, but I was ahead near the end during the Reagan/Thatcher era.  There's no combat involved in the game, although the India-Pakistan War card was played about three different times.  I essentially won the first game in a complete blow-out, and without knowing what I was doing, by playing the very powerful Aldrich Ames card at the beginning of the last turn.NOTE: I have a few problems with the game.  First, certain coutries are given a higher-rated importance in every game even though the importance of some of those countries appears to be questionable.  Second, it's difficult to imagine a country like Israel or Britain joining the Soviet Pac; that should be an almost an automatic victory for the bad guys.  Third, there's no luck with countries easily influencing neighboring countries; Murphy's law is not only present in combat.  Fourth, the idea of scoring continents and regions seems quite artifical.  There must be a better way to handle this scoring.  Perhaps scoring through groupings such as oil-countries, high-population countries, and other such groupings would be a better method.  Fifth, naval power seems to be largely ignored, although the planet is about 70% covered with water.  THIS GAME COULD HAVE BEEN SO MUCH BETTER WITH SOME OPTIONAL RULES.   
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
F
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.8
2 players
Wt: 3.5

I will play this game any time I can. Near perfection. It's the only game I've pursued playing digitally, and I consider it to be sort of a gold standard for drama, tension, theme and strategy. I would give it a 10, but the fact that I can't play this with someone new (and expect both of us to have fun) means it is less appealing than some other games at times. For me, a perfect 10 will be a game that gives me what Twilight Struggle gives me, but allows me to share it with others more freely. 

Plays 10-20

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I am an ex Magic player who turned to boardgames. There is a learning curve to this game and after initial play I admit I was disillusioned with it and its number one rating. Read some strategy, found out what I was doing wrong in the game in that regard as well as rules mix-up, and now I am can confirm the rating. The thing I liked most about Magic was the attrition battles between two control players. However, those battles only last so long and then its just a painful inevitability of one player winning. This has the same feel (minus the painful inevitability) only it lasts the entire game. I am never not enjoying play even when frustrated with a bad hand or a crummy die roll from time to time.

RATING: 8
I'll never understand how this arguably unbalanced, relatively derivative design (where the only really innovative idea is the card driven scoring), on an interesting but somewhat grim subject, got to bgg number one. Also, how is it the number 1 "wargame"? This thing is not a wargame. It is about the cold war that was not a war, and it is an area control game, with no direct conflict.

Having said that, I do like it too. I'm just surprised by its outstanding success and wide appeal.

RATING: 9
Decisions feel meaningful with serious consequences. Learnt a lot about the Cold War by playing this game -- gives perspective on many historical events.

Minor negative: DEFCON dropping to 1 because of hosting the Olympics. Edit: or maybe not after the Rio Olympics.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
After scrutinizing the rules and getting ready to play, I was already excited - but the game was still completely unexpected. The rush it creates and the sense of reward after performing a successful coup in East Germany... This is a trully immersive experience, one that no true gamers can miss. 
I was taken aback by the existence of dice at first (everyone knows I don't like luck in my non-luck games), but the implementation of this mechanic fits the theme well, not to mention luck has to be mitigated in order to succeed. 
DEFCON & Military Operations are pure brilliance in effect, opening up so many lanes of relevant decisions. 
At first I wasn't convinced by the Space Race track, but started to value it; it's not only a safety valve for dropping opponent cards (which still leaves them in circulation) - it's also for dropping your own useful cards so that THEY would remain in circulation in case they are not useful enough now. 
All in all - this is a true masterpiece. I will rate it after 5 plays, but seems to be a solid tenner. Cannot find anything wrong with the game.
Except for the fact that it really takes the right opponent to play.

RATING: 8
Excellent area-control game marred only by the crappy quality of the components (the board is flimsy cardstock, and the influence markers are the typical 1/2 inch cardboard counters found in wargames).  Don't let that scare you off the game, though.  You'll learn a lot of history and have a terrific time in the process.

Warning--can be more than a little tense!  But then it's the Cold War, what do you expect?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A deep and rich game based on real events from recent history. Since I've always been very interested in 20th century history and geopolitics, the theme itself draws me to the game. Having previous knowledge about most of the events or people mentioned on the action cards, the gameworld will already be richly populated with characters and history even on turn one. However, should you be playing an opponent who doesn't share you passion for modern history, there is still an excellent game with multiple paths to victory and tough choices to make on every turn. On the downsides, I do feel like the game is a bit tilted towards the Russians, it is not that great for non-native speakers or casual non-gamers (who I mostly play with) and it is only a two-player game. However should you find someone good to play with, the game is excellent.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
This is probably the best intro game into the Card Driven systems.  Everything is clear and feels familiar enough to pick up exactly what is going on in the game, yet the decisions are abound.  The game constantly forces you to chose to put out the fires from a number of minor dilemmas that all can add up to swing your game one way or another.   The game is just bursting with color and chrome, but isn't overwhelmed by it.  Certainly, there is quite a bit of luck here, but you never feel controlled by it.  

That said, what I do feel controlled by is the heavy odds against the US.  This game might get a 9.5 from me if I thought that the US had a decent chance of winning.  As is it just feels like a game where the contest is to see how long the US player can hold on.  That said it is a fun ride.  

UPDATE: It runs a little long for what it has to offer and the US really has to get lucky in the beginning for the fun to kick in.

RATING: 9.5
exhilirating ride, this.  the tension created over the three to four hours it takes us to play is terrifically palpable.  every decision is fun to make and feels drastically important.  not a history buff, but the theme seems to crawl up off the game board, manifesting itself as beads of sweat dripping off your forehead as you deliberate in the war room which continent you are forced to concede to the commies this turn as part of the greater plan.  this game definitely gets my blood flowing more than any other.  could do with greater modifiers on the dice rolls, or preferably some other system altogether to better reduce the role luck plays in the game (for example the way 1960 uses the political capital bag for support checks.)

rules complexity: 8/10
strategic depth: 8/10

RATING: 9
Plenty of give-and-take to this one and lots of interesting decisions on how to use one's cards.  The only downside is that it seems that there are a few idiosyncrasies that may initially turn people off, but being taught by an experienced player or reading some information on the game should fix that.  I need more play before rating it higher, but I was impressed with my initial play.

UPDATE: Having played it again, have to bump the rating, as it's just a wonderfully tense and challenging game; a mental tennis match.

RATING: 4
There is no doubt that this game is extremely well thought out.  The mechanics are incredibly well matched to the theme.  The Cold War event realism is fantastic and the tension is palpable.  I can see the intelligence that went into the game so it is with extreme reluctance that I rate this a 4.  Even though I hugely *admire* the game, I just don't find it fun.  It seems academic (?).  

In fairness, military/war themes are probably my least favorite (in a three way tie with fantasy and space - oy does that limit the field!).... so realistically I should have known better.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
I played this game 3 times and I would be happy to never play it again. Now before I say anything else, I want to say that this seemed very much like my kind of game before I even started playing and I was very satisfied with the push and pull gameplay and many aspects this game had to offer. 

The first game was an early (turn 5 or 6) win by the soviets. The second game we switched sides and was a turn 10 win by the soviets. Both of these were significant victories and had me really wanting to play again.

The third game the allies won on turn 10 because of one die roll. The allies went last on turn 10 and had to roll the die to win or lose the game based on gaining a certain amount of victory points. We literally played for 2 hours to have the game determined on the roll of one six sided die. This is not to say the gameplay was not fun, but I much prefer to have my decisions be meaningful and to be able to play or strategize around the luck of the game.

This was over a year ago and it highly influenced my opinion of the game. I haven't wanted to play it since and I don't think I ever will. I give it a 3 because it was enjoyable in some of its design but was an overall disappointing experience. There are so many games out there that are either more fun, more strategic, or both.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Great simulation of the Cold War. There's tension every turn. Each card you play must be carefully considered. After your opponent makes a move, paranoia grips you. Why did he make that move? What's he planning? These are the questions you'll ask yourself. In fact your opponent will be thinking exactly the same about your move, reacting to you as much as you're reacting to him. If that's not great storytelling, I don't know what is.

What's more, Twilight Struggle is remarkably rules-light for what it is, proof that there's lots of room for strategy amid dice-rolling and theme-heavy event cards. It can be long, but it can end early in the war as well as late. That's up to the players, who'll create their own story with each play.

My only complaint is the round counter, which is annoyingly fiddly. That's a minor issue, however, for an undeniably great game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Grandioso juego para una tarde entre 2 amigos.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of my favorites! It's a very thematic card-driven area-influence/majority game for two. Tension comes from the constant back and forth of trying to spread your influence (only to have the other guy counter!) and from the anticipation of the Score Cards, which _will_ be played but possibly not at a time of your choosing! Also, you have to make a few key choices every turn: 
- Ops or event? Some of your own events are really good but if you use Ops instead, you can hope that they'll come up again after a reshuffle and ideally in your opponent's hands, so the event will trigger automatically!
- Which card to Headline, losing ops but triggering a good event early in the turn?
- Which card to hold till next turn?

You would think that there is too much randomness/luck (card draws, d6 rolls) for a game of this length and weight. But actually, the game seems to be VERY well balanced, at least in the cards: nice balance of Ops values vs. events (for the most part; some cards seem to clearly favor one or the other most times), and although having a Score card in hand means one less Ops card to spend, you do at least get to control the timing of the scoring.

To play well, you really do need to know the cards; probably best if 2 people learn the game together. 

[b]--- Summary ---[/b]
USA vs. USSR in the Cold War, divided into 10 turns (Early War 1-3, Mid 4-7, Late 8-10). There are 3 decks of cards, one per stage. The board is a map of the world, divided into continents -> countries (the key "battlegrounds" have purple banner). Each country has a Stability rating (lower makes coups easier), and space for influence markers from each player. Start with a defined distribution of influence + several discretionary influence points (IPs). 

Each turn, players are dealt a hand of cards (8 Early; 9 Mid and Late). Cards are either Scoring cards (score a continent based on control of nations) or have a value (1-4 Ops points) and an event which may be a Neutral, USA, or USSR event. Some events, when triggered, remove the card from the game. At the start of the turn, players simultaneously choose an event to Headline -- resolve in descending Ops value order (ties = USSR first). Then, alternate (USSR first) playing through 6 (Early) or 7 (Mid, Late) rounds. On your turn, play a card for either Ops or event, except: if event belongs to other player it WILL trigger; you decide whether to spend Ops before or after event.

Ops may be used to place influence (adjacent to IP already on board), coup (modified die roll trying to change control of country; earn Military Ops points equal to Ops value of card), realign (modified die roll trying to reduce enemy influence), or to try to advance on the Space Race (each step requires 2 or 3 Ops value card, and a d6 roll; event does NOT trigger). At the end of all the action rounds, lose VP if you don't have the minimum required Military Ops (= Defcon value).

When a Scoring card is played, score the appropriate region. Score is on a VP track going from USSR 20 -> 0 -> USA 20; earning VP = moving marker towards your end of the track. The Early War has 3 Score cards, Mid has the other 4. These award VP based on area majority (presence < dominance < control) -- countries in that continent. The deck is reshuffled in turns 3 and 7, so some regions will score more than once; if game goes to 10 turns, all regions are scored again. 

You win the game immediately if any of the following occur:
- you get to 20 VP
- you control Europe when it is scored
- the opponent reduces Defcon to 1 (coups in battleground countries reduce 1 step; several events also can change Defcon status). 
You win at end of 10 Turns if the score marker is on your side of the VP track.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I love history and read a lot of historical non-fiction. The setting and mechanics of this game are just sublime! You are making agonizing decisions turn-after-turn, many of which benefit your opponent more than you. The key is the timing of when to play these, not that I'm an expert player.

Another one of my favourite games of all time. As with most 2-player, lengthy games I just don't have to opportunity to play face-to-face that often...hopefully that changes once my children grow older! As for now, I'll settle on the iOS asynchronous implementation.

[i]*Update Dec 2017*
Dropping my rating from a 10 to an 8.5. I still love the game, but after dozens of plays of the iOS app (both vs AI and live opponents) I just find the game to be a bit too swingy at times to rate that high.  
[/i]

RATING: 10
Owned: Deluxe Edition

Excellent game -- If the stars align and it's a suitable choice, it's THE choice, so there you go.  Truly epic stuff.

Used to own the regular edition; gave it to my ex's brother... she's gone, but now I have the deluxe edition.  Upgrade!

Edit 07/26/09:  Having played this half a dozen times over the last few weeks, I can safely say that learning the cards is absolutely essential to having any chance against a decent player.  There is so much more going on than it initially seems.  Amazing depth.  The luck factor can be frustrating, but it can also be incredibly memorable.

Revised 08/01/09:  Up to a 9.5.  Just can't give it a 10 for the reasons above, as well as the fact it really does take a lot to learn the nuances of this amazing game.  It's not for everyone, though it's certainly for me.

Revised 01/30/10:  Who'm I kidding?  This is a 10, all the way.  So it isn't all things to everyone, so what?  No game is.  And for what Twilight Struggle [i]tries[/i] to do... well, it nails it.  Perfection.
