=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
So I finally got to play the number 1 game on BGG since I've started in the hobby and the verdict?  It's pretty damn good.

Granted, this is not a game that intrigues me at face value past the curiosity why it is number 1 and by such a large margin and for such a long time.  I wasn't sure I was ever going to play it because I don't know anyone that has a copy or would really fit into the game's demographic either.  And it's not one that you can just impulse buy or pull out to play for 3-4 hours with one other person at a convention.  I added it as a want in a Math Trade though and finally got it on my shelf and it didn't take that long actually to get it to the table.

My opponent in this game had the perfect one-word description for this game.  It is the euro game made for wargamers.  The actual game play is a card driven area control affair.  There are no real battles or troop management so you couldn't really classify it as a wargame.  There are quite a few wargame trappings to it though.  First of all, it is incredibly rich with history.  There are over a hundred cards in this game and each one represents an event or news headline from the Cold War time period the game takes place in.  Half of the rulebook lists each card with a text block that at first glance I thought was rules clarifications but nope, they are little history lessons explaining what exactly happened in history that the card represents.  GMT has also fashioned the rulebook and components in the way they know best, like they were selling a wargame.  The rulebook contains almost no diagrams and explains the game through section and line numbers and lain out on a table you would swear it were a war game with a map of the world covered in tiny, square, numbered, cardboard chits.

I will say though that even diagram-less, thanks to being extremely well-written and tons of "designer's note" blurbs and examples the rulebook is excellent and explained how to play the game and resolve strange interactions very well.  The gameplay itself while being pretty fiddly is actually quite simple.  Each game turn is made up of 6-7 card play rounds where you either follow the event text on the card or use the card for its "operations value" to maneuver influence in different areas.  This continues for 10 turns and the points are a tug of war with the winner being whoever has the most at game end (there are also specific objectives that can achieve an immediate victory such as taking complete control of Europe or having your opponent cause global nuclear war).

I think the most interesting thing about this game is how all of the cards relate to either the US faction, the USSR faction, or both.  Events of your opponents faction only help them but you can draw them into your hand.  You can still play these for their "operations points" but it also  triggers the event as if they had played the card.  There are a few ways to prevent this but you will still end up giving your opponent free benefits several times throughout a game.  This introduces an incredible amount of depth as you try to use these cards in ways that mitigate the benefit your opponents get form these cards.

In the end this game is one of the most intriguing I've ever played.  I lost horribly in my first play but it is one where I definitely view the first play as a learning game and it took that whole first game to really understand all the moving parts.  I really want to play this game again, which is a good thing.  The problem is though that being 2-player only and incredibly long really doesn't offer the opportunities to play it again I would like.  Most of my game time is with groups and when I do hang out with someone one-on-one the 3-4 hour play time is a big deterrent (BGG lists play time as 3 hours, my first play which included rules explanation, eating, and socializing took about 3.5-4 so that's probably close to right).

It's not a huge box (which is more than I can say for other time sinks, I'm looking at you Merchant of Venus) so it is definitely going to live on my shelf, at least for a while, but I'm really not sure when or how often it will get played.

I will conclude by saying the game is incredibly fiddly, maybe war gamers are used to the little, square, different-numbered, chit management this game requires but I'm not.  The guy who I got my copy from put the chits in a couple of those daily pill boxes which is a great idea in theory and awful in practice because human fingers were not meant to grab chits out of those tiny containers.  Also, trying to put them back in any kind of organized fashion takes a long time.  I'm considering buying 4 different colors of those boxes of 36 12mm Chessex dice and using them to represent influence instead, I just need to decide first if I'm keeping the game and if it will get played enough for that to be a worthwhile investment.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Cuidado con la tension generada por el TS, puede hacer q los dos se enfaden durante mucho tiempo por una partida

RATING: 10
This is a superb CDG! The game is tense, fun, and frustrating. As with many of the CDG's, you never have enough resources to do what you want (and be prepared for your opponent to thwart you at any turn). I've played this game many times since its release. I've taught several players to play it and they're all addicted, just like me. Don't look for historical accuracy; CDGs don't do this well. However, you will experience more than a bit of the flavor of the times. Great game!

Cards are sleeved.

extraordinario juego con un motor de cartas, muy interactivo y con alta dosis de tensi√≥n. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
It's so hard to rate this game.

I love the theme and I think this could be the most solid themed game in my colection. And that could result in a higher rating once I'll play it more.

The victory conditions are very well balanced, the inicial cards make it a bit easyer to USSR but the middle and late war cards equalize the results.

Very clever and, last but not least, my first card driven mechanic game. Because of which I became a huge fan of the "system".

edit #1: I still like the game very much now that I've played it a couple of times more. I have a complaint. Some cycles of cards could make the game too easy or too dificult for one or another player. They could even determine the victory for either nation in a couple of turns. Meaning that some games could last 3 hours and others less than one. Also meaning that some games are interesting and others don't.

edit #2: Too much luck involved. It's very difficult for me to spend 3 hours playing and even controling a game and then, with two bad hands of cards loosing it. And it has nothing to do with bad playing! It has to do with luck. LUCK!

I don't mind games with lots of luck such as Thebes or Conquest of Paradise. But playing three hours, burning the brain, and everything is resolved by the card draw and especially the dice, is not for me. It could be for me now and then but only because I love the theme. And it also helps the fact that now I know that I could actually win or loose it if I'll have more or less luck than my opponent!

I still love the theme though and that's why I rate it a 6.

Edit #3: I've rated it a 4 because it is one of the most unbalanced games I√Ç¬¥ve ever played. It doesn√Ç¬¥t make any sense at all. USSR wins almost everytime I play it and that makes no sense to me. I do not have fun at all when playing with the US because it√Ç¬¥s all about damage control. And if the USSR player has some luck (dice luck) the game is over after 3 turns! I√Ç¬¥ve seen Italy being taken in the first USSR impulse with a coup attempt because the player rolled a 6 and took US 3 starting OP√Ç¬¥s of influence! After that and adding all the USSR events that are favorable to USSR, an Europe scoring is more than a safe run to the USSR player. Adding the fact that the China card and almost all asian events give USSR a great boost in Asia. So, this is not a balanced game and I almost sugest that this game could be broken.
I do not understand why so many people likes such an unbalanced game! 
(ME INCLUDED!!!)

(I)

RATING: 10
A fantastic influence game that draws the best from both the european and the wargames families. The unbalance exists, but only because it is easier to win early with the USSR. I you end up in the middle of the second pack without a strong USSR lead, you will probably see a US victory, and this puts a lot of pressure on the Soviet. It's nice that they play differently.

The game asks for a few plays before one gets an idea of the general schedule of events. Do not pass on this one, as it is both accessible and deep.

RATING: 8.5
The push-pull tension hits on turn one and stays at full throttle, the cards and the area control aspect provide two very different and interesting strategic sets of decisions, and the thematic applications are clever and quite entertaining. Late in the game, it can all become just too much as you try to keep an eye on so many different fronts of conflict--and the optimization miniutiae really bogs it down at the end if you're playing seriously--but if you can take that level of choice, this one is rightly admired. To me, the key to it all is the designers' decision to settle on the one thing they perceived the Cold War to be about--spreading influence--and set aside everything else so they could keep things wonderfully lean. Utterly absent are resource management, combat, etc., and it was a brilliant choice. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4

And Brian Bankler is right: the luck of the draw is heavier in this game than in most card-driven games.  Feh.  I'm looking forward to Free at Last - hopefully that'll do what this game should have.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I heard Twilight Struggle described as three hours of damage control, which sounds about right. It's three hours of tense back-and-forth, playing events that might benefit the enemy as much -- or more -- as they benefit you: how can you time it to help them least?

Decisions are interesting and multi-layered: operations points can be spent in different ways, different regions are valuable at different times, each of the historically-based cards is unique and imposes its own requirements, and over all looms the shadow of DEFCON 1 and nuclear war. What I love about wargames and other simulations is the [i]texture[/i]: playing them feels more real, somehow, not like an exercise in mathematics. 

But as someone with an avowed preference for luckless or very low-luck eurogames, it's difficult to enjoy. Insofar as expert play requires memorizing the effects of 150 unique cards, the stage of the war in which they will appear and tracking their place in the deck, I have zero interest in becoming an expert. I am assured that strategy is critical, but there is a lot of luck in the game, from card draws to dice rolls; it takes a degree of experience I do not have to be confident that it is the better player, rather than the luckier, walking away with the victory.

Further compounding the problem is the playtime. Short by wargame standards (where any game playable in a single day, let alone a single evening, is short), three hours or more is a heavy investment -- and I normally say that a game with this much luck is too long if it's over 30 minutes. Sure, it's a tense, enjoyable experience, at least for a while, but after three hours that starts to wear, especially in the likely event that the game's conclusion feels cheap or otherwise unsatisfying.

With experience I might grow to love it, but for now it's a game I admire more than I enjoy. Maybe it would hit the table more often if I only played the Late War scenario...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
TS is an area-control with a smooth and clever card engine game which puts the players in control of one of the at-the-time super powers, either playing with the USA or the USSR, the feeling experienced playing each single card in your hand trying to push forward your strategy, but also can help your opponent's. The struggle is experienced since the beggining of the game. Very well designed game which leads you to live the experience of those years and how the leadership of both countries managed to try to win the cold war. Depending the player's knowledge of the game and its analysis-paralysis, the game can take from 1 1/2 hours to 2 1/2. So if you are eager to know the history and feel as one of the power players of the time and have the time to play it, this a must try.

RATING: 4
Sorry that this game does nothing for me. The randomness is too much. I understand that the "strategy" involves minimizing the risk, but I believe that the outcome comes down solely on whoever gets the best hand--especailly scoring cards. I enjoy other card driven games like For the People and Washington's War since bad hands can be mitigated by decisions made by the player. I don't like how your opponent's event cards go into effect when you play them as OPS. Both Washington's War and For the People have better systems that use the opposing events in your hand.
 On the plus side, the game is easy to play and be completed in around two hours. Kudos also to the VASSAL mod creator who did a great job with the TS module.

Normally mixing aspects of other games doesn't produce a good result, but Twilight Struggle takes aspects of Risk, Go, Poker, and even resource-utilization games like Puerto Rico and mixes them together to wonderful effect all set around the historical theme of the Cold War.

It's definitely a game you appreciate more each time you play it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[GMT Games 2nd (2005) edition] {Cold war; dice-rolling, simultaneous action, combat-card-driven} Twilight Struggle is an interesting war game. It's very thematic! It's an unusual war game that there are virtually no wars during the game but a political influence of the 2 superpowers.

TS is a deep game, yet tactical due to largely card draw.  However, players still have certain control about the cards to be used, esp. leaving useful event to late game.  It has very good player interaction at the event cards and reaction on the board.  One must react to the board quickly to avoid surprise regional scoring.

TS has a long learning curve.  Players need several games to understand the purpose of each action, the relationship / function / timing of the event cards.

TS has luck, esp. in dice rolls. A string of low rolls in realignment and coup attempt can be devastating.  The situation is even worse for coup attempts because you only get one-shot chance.  In addition, bad card draw can be killing; esp. for the US players in early game.  The scoring cards have problems, too ‚Äì I wonder, what can a player do if he/she drew 5 scoring cards in his hand.

The rulebook is one of the nicest rulebooks I have ever read - it's clear and well-structured with detailed examples. Besides, it provides descriptions of the history and includes designers' notes.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.8
I don't usually rate a game if I haven't played at least a dozen of times, but this one was so impressive I had to make an exception.

The game is just awesome. Perfectly balanced.

It has a TON of options, for every card you have in hand, and you have many, you can use it for 5 different actions.

The number of options playable is just amazing. And that is not the best part of the game.

There are 110 unique cards, and each and every one of those has a real world event/person behind it, and the effect of the card if in correspondence with the person/event behind the card.

Further more, the rules of the came like the ability to do coups in Europe in accordance to defcon status, the rules for the space race, everything just feels like the events that were occurring in the cold war. It FEELS like rewriting the history, with every subsequent repercussion of your actions.

I was just amazed.

The reason why it is not 10.0 yet, it's because it is very hard to find someone willing to spend 6 or so hours, just to play this game, and it is very hard to spare 6 hours from your normal day to invest it in playing a game. BUT it is WORTH it, every single minute.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
OK, I'm going to rate this one now having played 3 games of it.

Fun game, plays quickly given the scope of the conflict it simulates.  The best thing about the game (to me) is how nicely the rules engineer the historical shift of conflict between the superpowers from Europe and Asia to Africa and the Americas, with the Middle East remaining significant throughout and Europe being put back into play late.  Very, very good design accomplishment.

The "my Ops, your event" dynamic is also a good one, which makes hand management more interesting than some other CDGs.

Drawbacks?  Some of the events are too cutesy and/or complicated in their effects (Wargames and Missile Envy being good respective examples), but that's a marginal complaint.  A bigger one is that the game can feel a little bit bland--place some markers, count countries, place some markers, etc.  But fortunately the theme is compelling enough and the overlay of the game mechanics is believable enough that most of the time it's still fun.

Overall, I think this is an excellent game about the Cold War.  It plays in a reasonable time frame, and as I said before accomplishes the very impressive feat of modeling the history well with a minimum of bells and whistles.  This game may well replace some of the fiddlier CDGs in my game cabinet.

EDIT:  I'll probably never play this again, and wouldn't choose to play it if I had a choice of other things to do.  So even though I like/have no objections to it, I am going to downgrade it.

RATING: N/A
Too early to comment much. One or two weird issues bothering me.

1) One of the core actions, Re-Alignment, does not seem that useful to me. Neither I nor my opponent used it in Game 1. This seemed strange to me.

2) Knowledge of the deck's specific events seems like it will be crucial. I prefer a setup like Dominion's, where there are a smaller number of special cards out there that you can examine at any time. This sort of situation HEAVILY favors the more experienced gamer.

I realize the "large deck of cards" is a core feature of CDGs and is an important part of maintaining retail value, but I don't like features that specifically reward Playing Game X Many Times.

RATING: 10
A long deep game with an exciting mechanic which means you have to play cards that are good for your opponent whilst trying to make your own way. Give you an authentic feeling of desperation that your opponent is feeling too.
Victory points are measured by how many more than the opposition you have scored. Clever scale.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Outstanding card-driven game that recreates the Cold War struggle for global supremacy between the USA and the USSR. The gameplay is actually very simple, where you play a series of cards each featuring an event based on historical occurrences, in an attempt to extend the influence of your respective super-power across the world. It's more of a challenge to play as the USA as you attempt to prevent an early Soviet victory as they have all the early momentum. As the game progresses though it begins to swing in favour of the USA, providing the USSR hasn't already won. The historical detail that's been poured into the game's design is highly impressive and this results in the gameplay and theme juxtaposing to an unprecedented level for a board game. There's extraordinary depth here and the result is simply one of the finest games out there.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
old library
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is a nice game, which could have been a classic. Unfortunately, it has a few glaring problems that keep it from being as good as it could have been in my opinion (and IMO make it overrated).

1. Card-Counting Galore: All card-driven games allow players to do card-counting. In this game, it is pretty much a prerequisite - if you don't count cards so that you know when those critical scoring cards are coming out (and some critical events), you are at a severe disadvantage to your opponent. Know the deck or lose the game. This is the card-driven mechanic at its worst. 

2. Over-Powerful Cards: There are a number of cards/card combos that are extremely powerful. Some are ridiculously so - especially if the opponent is unlucky when you smack them on him. Again - all card-driven games have a certain amount of dependence on the luck of the draw; but bad card luck in TS will cost you the game against a competent opponent.

3. Critical luck: The game suffers from critical luck in far too many places; i.e., a few critical dice rolls that can essentially ruin your game. Part of the problem is that the game in general relies way too much on dice rolls to determine whether your card actions have any effect - and if you fail significantly of those than your opponent, you will probably lose if your opponent is good - already a problem (but one it shares with many games). But the game o worsen the situation, the game doesn't have luck evening out - in every game you will tend to have 2-3 dice rolls on 1D6 that are absolutely critical to your position and which will swing a lot of points if you fail. Fail those 2-3 central dice rolls while your opponent make his, and you will lose - guaranteed - unless your opponent is incompetent.

All this would be OK if this was a 2-hour game. For a game that will easily run you to 4-5 hours, these are IMO fatal flaws. There are better 2-player card-driven games out there that do not have these weaknesses.

Edit: Updated after playing the electronic edition, and my criticism remains the same. Can be fun to play online, but the time spent is still overly long.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Best 2 player game on the market. Period. The atmosphere is done brilliant, the gameplay is well thought of. 

Some points keep it from being a 10:
1. Not playable vs everyone: non-gamers and most women spring to mind.
2. Rules do have a learning curve. Best if you can find someone to teach you the game.
3. There are a lot of things to be thought of, not everyone likes that.
4. Play time is too much for a midweek evening. Including set up you'll need 3 to 4 hours for it.

Other than that: brilliant game, with subtle strategies you only discover after a lot of plays. Basic game design follows two main tracks: on one hand it's about constantly anticipating on what your opponent is doing. On the other, it's about playing your cards to maximum effect or playing your opponent's cards for minimum effect. Balance that and you'll start to discover the depth of this game.

Can't be silent about the famous "China card"; what an incredible idea to put the intrigues of Mao as a powerfull card that changes hand after it has been used...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I've never been bunch of a boardgamer/conventional wargamer. I was always more of a miniatures wargaming player, and being put off by games like ASL that look cumbersome beyond words.

An older friend had mentioned this game, and the concept intrigued me. I had even cataloged some of them when I worked at a game store for a year. So I contacted him and we agreed to play a game on a Friday night. We played casually and took our time (partly because I was new), and a few hours later we were done. It was a fantastic game. 

It had a reasonably easy learning curve, and has just the right level of complexity. It's not too complex you get bogged down in minutia, but complex enough that it has depth. 

I played as the Soviets, and I put up a hell of a fight with him saying it was one of the tougher games he had played. 

It's fun seeing how the strategies on board develop, because it's not just the cards in your hand, but anticipating following turns, reacting to your opponent, and even perhaps misleading them with your own moves.

As someone born in the later days of the Cold War and *vaguely* remembers the wall coming down it does maintain a sense of the feel of the conflict in a number of ways that those who love history will enjoy, while those who are not well versed in history won't be overwhelmed by the flavor.

It was good enough that I bought a copy for myself the very next day.

As someone who typically doesn't play these kinds of board games (or nearly any), I do highly recommend this game. 

The only recommendation I would make is grab a few extra bags to store counters in so they're more organized.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Player Count 2
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
2p tug-of-war with incredible amounts of tension thanks to the DEFCON track. Deck knowledge is crucial (though you can say that about a lot of card games... TtA comes to mind). A new player without knowledge of the cards (or a basic working understanding of the history of the period) is going to get trounced, plain and simple.

The conceit of having to deal with opponent events is brutal, and knowing how to soften the blow of those events while timing the big events is essential. It's a wicked design. The way the pieces fit together is quite ingenious. 

It's an epic game, and probably tilts toward the "too long for what it is" category. 1960 does similar things in half the time, and Wir Sind Das Volk tackles a similar topic, arguably with better results.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3
I just played it once. I can understand that the game will get better when you know the cards. However, without knowing them, it isn't a strategic game, it's all about luck.

For example, you may spend your china card for placing influence in Japan, just before your opponent play an event that removes all your influence there...

Yes, I know, every game has a learning curve and you can't pretend to make no mistakes in your firsts plays. However, here, in this game, mistakes come not (only) from a poor evaluation of your possibilities, but from the ignorance of the events there exists. In your first game, you have to take tons of decisions, but you don't have any clue, any information, to decide which options are better. Is like playing chess without knowing the rules of some pieces.

So, I should play 5 to 10 times (i.e., 15-30 hours), making random decisions. Then, I'd be able to take decisions, understand my mistakes, improve... well, to play. No way. I'd rather play Agricola or Mage Knight. In these games you can take decisions since your very first play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

- it lasts up to 4 hours

RATING: 5
Looking at a plain global map isn't exciting, and trying to put more numbers in a box than my opponent isn't especially exciting, but that's a bottom line simplification of Twilight Struggle...and how I remember my first very long game. The cards/events didn't really fire my imagination and often were just used for their action point value. These "events" and all of the dice rolling resulted in conflict as abstract as Pandemic or Catan, and no more exciting.
If this game were an hour, and had more detailed battles or some sense of individual growth or adventure or peril, I might enjoy it, but I lost interest halfway through my first game--a game that I was alternately winning and losing depending on die rolls. By the end of that experience, I gave it away--my interest was such that I didn't want to spend another 3 or 4 hours within this highly abstracted (though not hard to comprehend) numbers game.
There are certainly some cool ideas, but mostly it felt like a Risk area control game with cards functioning like additional die rolls more than things that altered how I played or viewed playing.
More than once I imagined the monsters of Blood Rage, Mage Knight, and Cave Evil stomping across this stark map while the soldiers from Ambush!, D-Day at Omaha Beach, and Thunderbolt Apache Leader tore up the terrain...which shows my level of engagement in Twilight Struggle when compared to games that actually engage my imagination.

RATING: 7
Good game with nice card driven mechanism. However, game have few problems. Main problem is that one game can take anything from 30 min to 300 min to play. It's not a problem if you have 300 min time to play but this happens rarely. Second, there is some strong luck element with cards (as always with card driven game). Third, there are cards that give control of single nation to one or the other player ragrdless of how much power the other have. I don't like these cards very much because those cards must be know or they could sift the balance of the game in critical moment resulting to victory of the player that knows the card.

RATING: 8
Fantastic game. It is a bit unbalanced and favours the Soviets in the early game. Also, I feel that it is quite unforgiving. You really have to be focused and keep a lot of factors in check - definitly not a game that you can play lightly, even if the game is relatively short and has simple rules.
Update November 2010: Lowered rating from 9 to 8. Still a great game, but there is no way to deny, that the game is a bit luck-driven and that the player who has all cards memorized has a huge advantage.

RATING: 10
FBG Reindeers gift :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I like this game a lot - it is well balanced and the theme is an integral part of the game. There is a pretty good learning curve to the game. Mechanically, it isn't too bad to pick up, but by learning curve, I mean the cards. Knowing what cards that are in each era, knowing when scoring cards enter the game, knowing where you can avoid wasting precious Ops points are all important and a player that is more familiar with those will easily dominate a player that doesn't. There are some great subtleties to the game that you can only see after a number of plays and if you are constantly beaten quickly, it is hard to learn them. Of course the flip side to that is that there is a lot of hidden beauty and depth here. Every playing is different, even with the same cards and events. Your hand might dictate trying to better your position in a way you never have before.

This is one where the electronic version speeds up the game a lot. On the table, it is not easy to quickly determine that status of an area, nor your chances of any given action - things that are easy in the electronic form. You lose some of the meta game, but being able to rattle a game off in under an hour is a good trade.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
This is a truly phenomenal game.  Yes, there's plenty of luck, (like many 'CDGs') but there's also plenty of strategic depth.  It just drips with theme, it plays pretty quickly (especially using Bruce Wigdor's java implementation, which can be found on wargameroom.com), and has unmatched replayability: after what must be 100+ plays (no, I haven't logged them, but I'm sure it's been that many, even guessing very conservatively), I still keep coming back for more!  I can't imagine saying the same of much else.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.7
A brilliantly crafted war game with an elegant card system. A closed deck where almost all cards (which thematically represent events) will see play, but it's how and when they see play that greatly affects how the game plays out. Sometimes you will need to make tough choices to give benefits to your enemy, but it's how you manage that impact and how you implement the card to also help you. The area control aspect is tension filled, with different ways to try and outdo your opponent in a given area. The DEFCON track also adds a lot of thematic tension. I love how the game begins to shift as DEFCON does, shutting down areas of the map to big change and potentially slowing your opponent's advance. There is so much choice, so many strategic avenues, and the scoring cards even add an element of bluffing that again adds to the thematic 'cold war' tension. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.3
For me, this is plainly the most thrilling board game I have ever played. The theme dominates this mechanicly rather simple game on every level, which I absolutely love. What makes this game my all time favorite though is the high level of suspension which just refuses to flatten down over the course of the game. You never stop facing tough trade-off decisions that have deep consequences in the short as well as in the long run. It can sometimes take 6 hours to finish the Cold War, but they feel like minutes for you never stop being involved. If you have a regular playing partner that likes epic and sometimes very long struggles, just reach for this. You won't regret it! 

Be warned, though: It can be very luck dependent at some times, which can be annoying in a game that long.

Note: My play count on this is way beyond 10 or so, I just didn't regularly log on BGG at this time :)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Twilight Struggle is our Friday night game. Any time my husband and I get a Friday to ourselves, we grab some beer and immerse ourselves in the Cold War. This is the perfect long game, with enough complexity and depth to keep us entertained for hours and probably the best theme integration I've ever see in a game. The VP board is a particular stroke of genius; it ramps up the tension and creates the feeling of a gripping game of tug-of-war. Victory after such a grueling battle is truly sweet. The cards pose interesting strategic decisions, and the rules are surprisingly easy to learn. Overall, a truly great "event" game.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
For whatever reason, it took me a long time to get this on the table. Watching it rise to No. 3 in the BGG rankings certainly let to a lot of anticipation, and also likely contributed to some of the disappointment I felt playing this (second edition) for the first time (late in 2010). Don't get me wrong ... I like the game. I just didn't love it, and really thought I would. I've played (and very much enjoy) 1960: The Making of the President and, as advertised, the games are similar. However, I did not feel the same delicious angst about which cards to play in TS as I did in 1960. And while playing 1960, things always seemed pretty balanced, while in TS it becomes quickly apparent that this is a card game with huge swings of luck. As an example, I played one game (as America) in which I drew four scoring cards in the first two rounds of play. So, nearly one-third of my actions were taken up by forced play of score cards while Russia, which has a huge early edge to begin with, used those turns to further consolidate its position and benefit from the next scoring card. That's a pretty vicious cycle for the U.S., and I can't help but think it could have been handled better by the designer. In the final analysis, I liked Twilight Struggle and will gladly play it again, but I did not find it to be the elite game its ratings would imply and will likely trade my copy.

RATING: 10
USA squares off against The Soviet Union over 40 years to determine the fate of the world in this Cold War classic.  The thing that makes this game so phenomenal in my mind is the tension that comes with every action you take.  The game has a final scoring after 10 rounds, but there are 3 ways to instantaneously win/lose the game before then.  It just creates this fascinating level of tension and punch/counter punch all game long.  Even if you don't like the theme, if you're into more serious games you'll probably like the mechanic.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The title of the game is apt -- playing it is truly a struggle.  Not with the game itself, which has refreshingly simple mechanics that (apart from the event cards) contain few rules exceptions, but a struggle with your competitor.  This is as it should be.  Just an amazing mental tug-of-war every step of the way, with just the perfect amount of luck (and bad luck) to bring the drama.

The theme is perfectly captured as well.

My only issue with the game, and it's really an unavoidable one with this kind of design, is that those who are familiar with some of the more swingy event cards will have a huge advantage over someone with less familiarity.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
If only I could find opportunities to play this more often.  The tension is constant, because you never feel in any control.  There are too many things you want to be doing and you are always forced to make tough choices, and that is even before you add in trying to anticipate and counter what the opponent is doing. I like looking for ways to make the most of the cards you are dealt. The theme stands out and adds extra feel to the game. An excellent challenge.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I've played it three times now and have thoroughly enjoyed each playing. Every card play presents a tough decision and the opportunity for a clever manuever. The theme is spot on, the mechanics smooth, and it inspires as much laughter as tense muttering. I would rate this game even higher if it weren't for the amount of damage a string of bad dice rolls can cause you in the space race, realignments, and certain "Gotcha!" cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
What I really like is the thematic feel of the game plus the history lessons it gives you while playing it. I love the art, the components and the board (Deluxe edition) 

What I didn't really appreciate was the long game time. It was six hours for my first game (and for my opponent it also was almost like a first session). Now, a long gaming time just by itself usually isn't something that puts me off, but a game this length shouldn't depend this much on luck of the draw or wild swings due to either lots of luck or bad luck on the dice rolls. My opponent drew very unfortunate cards for him one round which he almost completely had to play for me. In the end I utterly destroyed him. Maybe it was a superfortunate and highly unlikely constellation for me in this game, but really: in a game this long this mustn't happen. 

After my second game (that took a completely different course) i must say, I still enjoy this, the theme,the anxiousness and the whole presentation of the game. But I'm a little surprised this is the No.1 on the geek. While your regular Top 10 title features planability and economic engine building,this one depends quite heavy on draw of the cards. It's really essential to the game when a card is drawn and who draws it. That means when you get certain cards or if an opponent draws a card that's good for you (and then invests it into the space race). And the dice factor in realignment rolls and coups is also crucial First game I won with the U.S. at the end of the game. Easily, no endgame-scoring was in favor of the Russians! Second game I lost with the U.S. in round 5 of the game. Next, the person I played against tells me he won his next game with the U.S. in round 5, admitting that cards were heavily in his favor. Now there's some really, really wild swings here and usually that would be criticized vigorously. However, TS gets through with it. 
-----
Next game in:let's give it an 8. The tension is nearly unbearable. And once again the session was different. We didn't quite finish but I'm sure it would have come down to the final scoring after round 10.    
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

If I were to rate the design of TS, it would be just shy of a 10. But I'm going by the BGG scale, and this game just isn't for me!

RATING: 6

Long, deep two-player games just aren't easy to get to the table.

RATING: 10
This has quickly become my favorite game.  The depth and historical drama of a war game, but in a very playable package.  Holy crap, do I love the event cards.  I'm a flavor junkie, and they satisfy me oh so very much.  The gameplay (like the Cold War) is tense from start to finish -- there's several solid chances for reversals of fortune right up to the end.

If I were a religious man, I would thank the gods for giving me a wife who really likes this game.  Life is good!

Currently playing the Deluxe Edition upgrade -- love that mounted board!

That said... FAVORITE 2 PLAYER GAME EVER!

RATING: 9
I've only played the game 4 times, and lost every time, but there is a lot more going on here than first meets the eye.  The options available for each player during each turn are remarkable and it isn't just "should I play this for points or for event" -- timing becomes far more important, as does figuring out what possible scoring cards your opponent has and bluffing about your own hand.  The rules may be very simple compared to other, recent card-driven games, but the play is actually more complex.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This game nails everything perfectly. The theme and feel of playing a superpower in the Cold War is spot on, every move feels stressful as you secretly try to navigate a course to victory. The theme is dripping off the cards which are all historical events and are accurately displayed.

The mechanics are just as good, forcing you to play cards in your hand which may trigger events for your opponents. The hand management aspect doesn't get much better than this.

Only complaint is wishing I could play it more often.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Kickstarter

I'm not sure this one fires my imagination. A card game about espionage. It does a good job of bridging the gap between war game and euro game though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I was incredibly surprised how easy it was to convince my wife to play this game. However, it only went so well. I think I should have waited until I knew the game a bit better in order to streamline the instructional portion of the experience. She does not do well with longer games. After the first turn, I could see the look in her eyes that she was nearly done. So, in an effort to exit while she was still having an enjoyable experience with the game, I decided to stop playing and say we'll play it again later. I'll update when the second opportunity presents itself. It may be a while.

::UPDATE:: After my third unfinished game, I'm giving up on TS. I can see what's great about it. It's just not great for me and my gaming situations. I prefer playing with more than two players. I find it to be just a little too tug-of-war in nature, where I pull on my turn, then you pull on your turn, rinse and repeat for a long time. It just never captured me like I know it has so many others. It is going for trade or sell.
[COLOR=#FFFFFF]TAGS: CDG, war game, 2 player, long[/COLOR]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
01/2013 - I got another chance to play this. My appreciation has improved, but I'm also lowering my rating to a 6 due to its length. This is a long game. We played the full 10 turns in 5 hours. I suspect with better knowledge of the cards and mid-war finishes, the 3 hour play time list on the box is realistic. There's was plenty of AP, but it's hard for me to see a way around it for two relative noobs. There's an insane amount of choices and a number of interactions that led us to the forums for answers.

There's also a surprising amount of luck. Single dice rolls for coups, realignments, war cards and space exploration. And then the cards. You can get loaded with your opponents cards, or get humstrung by Quagmire or Red Scare (as the US player). I generally like some luck, but this amount of luck in a longer game gives me pause. With the right mindset, I think you just have to embrace the chaos, and enjoy the challenge.

Any way, all that said, it's still a great game. There's a lot of tough choices. It's particulary grueling trying to plan out the play of enemy cards to minimize their negative effects. I look forward to playing it again...

09/2012 - My first play was underwhelming, but it didn't help that I got creamed very early. Based on its rating and my like of the designer, I will be happy to give it a couple more opportunities.

RATING: 8
+ Wonderful tension throughout the game stemming from the dual nature of the cards and the somewhat unpredictable timing of scoring.

+ Extremely interesting theme - to me. Did not appeal to others I played with.

+ Steep learning curve that seems to reward multiple plays.

Long play time for the complexity level of the game. Would likely come down with repeated play.

- Dice rolling to resolve destabilization action - terrible, frustrating mechanic.

- Terrible component quality. The unbacked paper map was particularly bad.


Traded away because I could not get anyone to play another game with me after the first. Would enjoy playing again should the opportunity arise.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I don't know who it was that said it, but "Cold War in a Box" sums it up. I don't even feel like the word "theme" is even appropriate here... there is no theme, there is just the subject--just the cold war, emulated in card board components and cards, with an abstraction layer ("game") that ties everything together. It's history that seems to be given life through the simple mechanics.

Not short at all as some might suggest. Playable in a night, yes, but you need to dedicate most if not all of that night unless you are well versed in the rules and able to bang out a game in an hour or so. (a night to me is like 2-4 hours tops). It's certainly not long on the wider spectrum, but short is misleading.

I've barely worked my way through the rules but I'm already impressed like going to a fine restaurant, sitting at the bar, watching and smelling them make my food and as it's hitting the plate knowing it will be something truly special. The plate has just been sat down before me, and I'm just waiting to dig in! 

Rating will likely go up.

[05-08-09] Old rating: 8.5.  New rating: 9.  I have now played 1960 about three times more than I have played Twilight Struggle.  I will always get more plays of 1960 in, but I appreciate Twilight Struggle just a bit more.  It's maybe more appropriate to say that I fear Twilight Struggle. I'm not sure it will ever be an all-time favorite, but every single game is memorable.

RATING: N/A
Steam only. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Let me just say that when I heard of twilight struggle I was very sceptical. First it was a war game which I haven't ever tried (unless risk counts), second it was based in the Cold War, which I knew nothing about and I thought couldn't possibly be interesting and lastly that it looked like an over convoluted version of risk. 
Oh boy was I wrong.
I only gave it a second chance after seeing it was gaining almost universal praise everywhere. I thought I'd look into it and found it might be slightly interesting and I also needed a proper two player board game (playing a game meant for 5 with 2 doesn't work very well). I went to buy it and found that it was sold out everywhere and out of print. This only helped its case more. I thought if it is sold out and is number one on bgg then it is doing something right. It took over four months for the board game to go back into print and then to my discovery they were selling it at $100 each. I thought that's a rip, I payed less for Agricola for goodness sake. But after much thought I ended up buying it anyway as I didn't want to regret it further down the track.
When I got home I opened it immediately and read the instructions. All three of my worries disappeared almost instantly afterwards and I actually got excited to play this game. I tried a test run with myself and thought wow this is actually really fun even by myself.
I then tried it with another player a few days after and oh sweet baby Jesus was it glorious. We ended up playing it 3 times that day before we had to stop for a break.

Having said that I thought it was fun in the first game but I got beaten easily and in my mind wasn't worth $100. We then tried a second time switching roles and I got dealt a hand of all soviet cards (I was America). The game then clicked and I smiled, the first time feeling happy I was in a bad position in a board game. I finally understood the game, it wasn't a risk knockoff nor a crappy game with a historical theme, it was really a simulation of the Cold War disguised as a game. Every single event in the game really happened and if the soviets chose to do something slightly differently, like focusing on Iraq instead of Poland, then it would have changed the course of history.

The amount of effort and thought that went into this game boggles me and I am truly amazed at how well it all came together. They managed to make me feel like Stalin in charge of deciding where to place his troops in the world, it made me feel like a person gone back in time to change what events occurred and when, but best of all, it made it fun.

No other game has this much thought and effort put into it, yes there are other more complex, strategic war games out there, but in the end no one's thinking about them as Twilight Struggle is that good.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
The Cold war in 3 hours.

Elegance, great theme, tough decisions. That's all that's needed in the end. TS has it all. It's the definition of easy to play hard to master extremely immersive experience. The fact that it manages to capture the spirit of its theme while remaining politically neutral is a nearly unbelievable achievement for me.

If you are even remotely interested in the cold war or world politics as a concept you're going to love this game. Even if you're not, even if you absolutely hate the idea of simulating violent coups, ardent propaganda, bloody wars, dirty spying and nuclear devastation, chances are that TS may still become your guilty pleasure.

RATING: 8
A game full of tension and of difficult decisions, which I love. The atmosphere of the cold war is beatifully rendered, the actual course of events less so. The Soviets are in particular too strong for the balance of the game and compared to the history of the period (the US was the dominant power and the extent of the "Sovient Empire" is largely superior to reality in the game).

That said, the mechanic of letting the opponent play his associated events is litteraly genius. It renews completely the CDG genre by doing this.

The game, I suspect, has more to do with the "perception" of the Cold War by the United States than with the "real" Cold War, but it is still a great game.

The "Chinese Civil War" variant is great, it corrects in part the balance problem in a historical way. I don't think I'll play without it in the future.

Preferred mode of playing : Chinese Civil War Variant + cartes optionnelles. Cela permettrait √† mon sens des parties plus proches de la r√©alit√© historique avec des menaces plus cibl√©es du c√¥t√© sovi√©tique plut√¥t que le rouleau compresseur qu'on voit trop souvent.

RATING: 5
What I like:

Very historically interesting.


What I do not like

-I hate the card mechanism. The fact that you can be totally ruined by things the game forces you to play. Yes you can remove a few cards with the space program, but if you still have some in your hand, guess what? I'm now gonna spent my turn advancing your situation while you do the same on your turn.
-Way too much randomness for it's game length. I hate when I have to play a game for forever and just have it decided by luck regardless (Much more fun with randomness in shorter/medium length games) 
-Board and gameplay looks and is quite dry


All in all massively overrated, but I do admire and respect the historical accuracy and feel of the game.

RATING: 9
Holy crap!    Really good.  Its true to the theme, as the players feel like heads of state during the era.  Constant paranoia, constant threats.  The rest of the world slowly becomes relevant with advances of technology.  Plays similar to history but not quite, and the not quite is always fun to look at.  Bluffing, reading opponents, thinking and double think, and creating combos.  Everything a good two player game should have.  Easy to sit down and have a relative strategy for round management.  Familiarity with the cards, the player could develop quite the overral strategy too I suspect.  Blissful.   Great theme   great execution = a great time.  I must say I am a truly pathetic US player right now.  The learning curve is fun however, so I can't wait for the next chance. Steep learning curve for the US player.

The Space Race alone is such a cool mechanic.  It so thematic.  It detracts from your development militarily and philosophically, but the prestige involved gives the players benefits for acheiving goals.  That is one example, there are plenty of more clever ideas inside the Twilight Struggle box.  

Theme rarely wins me over.... but in this case.  Wowza!

Of course this has gotten me interested in other CDG's.  I have to quit trying to expand my gaming horizons that make me spend more money.  

Hand Management bliss.

RATING: 10
I've been waiting to give this one a go for awhile now.  A guy in our group picked it up and I got to try it out finally.  This game is everything I wanted out of it.  It's a bit cumbersome to learn but once you got the hang of it really is superb.  I'm sure a lot of people who hate dice will hate this game as so many things depend on a die throw and you can get extremely unlucky.  I saw 5 consecutive failed attempts on the Space Race track in one game. After a few more plays I'm still quite pleased with the game but going to take the rating to a 7 instead of an 8 as by the BGG description I think that's more appropriate.

RATING: 10
Interesting card-driven wargame that I need to try out more to really be able to rate accurately.  I hope to try it again, but can't really justify the price, especially considering the components -- UPDATE: I enjoyed this a lot more the second time.  I've realized it's not really a wargame, but rather an area control game (like El Grande, especially the K√∂nig & Intrigant expansion since you're playing action cards from your hand in the same manner to gain majorities in as manner areas as possible on the board) dressed up in wargame clothing.  I have even added it to my wishlist now, and am considering raising my rating to 9, but will wait until I have a chance to play it a third time.  The luck didn't bother me as much this time because it seemed to balance out more and I focused on the space race less, although there were certainly a few coup attempts or realignment rolls that had surprising or disappointing results.  I'm looking forward to trying this again hopefully sometime soon, although I'd still love a version of this with nicer components.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
About [thing=12333][/thing]:

[b]1) What is it?[/b]
[thing=12333][/thing] is a two players card-driven wargame (some dispute this last part) in which the whole Cold War, from the early war to the late stages of the fight between URSS and USA.

The goal here isn't, however, battles on themselves, but win in the global match. Players are fighting to have presence/control/dominance in each of the continents, doing coups, realigning the political and economical loyalty of countries, spreading influence, racing in the Space War, while trying to really NOT starting a full-fledge nuclear war.

There is a great deal of back and forth, as every card played mess with the board state in some way, from a small nuisance to a complete change of pace and OH MY GOD WHAT HAVE YOU DONE?

[thing=12333][/thing] presents a most solid design, offering completely different play styles and perspectives, accordingly to the nation played. And this is achieved not by giving special abilities or unique decks of card to each side - the pool of cards is the same and so is the rules for both sides.

This battle of wits doesn't play fast (around 180 minutes, but I have seen plays went to almost twice) and has a steep learning curve - not that playing it is terrible difficult, but playing well, and preparing to what will come next, and know (or antecipate) the possibilities for the other side, will take quite a while.

Overall, [thing=12333][/thing] isn't a game one should enter lightly, and but it does offer a strong experience and each game will tell an unique story.

[b]2) How do you play?[/b]
The goal is to reach 20 points during play, or have more points after the final scoring, if the game reaches the end of the final turn in the Late War.

The game is played in several rounds and each round is composed by several turns. In each turn the player must play a card, and most of the the time it will be used it either as an event or for its operation points. If used for the event, the person will do what the text in the card says. If used for the OP, the person will use the number on the card to attempt coups, realignments, increase influence, etc.

Also, each round one card can be discarded in the Space Race.

Finally, some cards will be for scoring. These cards can't be held in hand between rounds - they must be used in the round they are drawn.

Usually the player can keep one card in hand, as the number of turns in a round is less then the number of cards in hand.

If URSS or USA reaches 20 points at any point during the game, the nation that did it will win. If none do during the play, there will occur a final scoring of all the regions, and the nation with the most points will be the winner. It is possible to also end the game by scoring Europe while have Control of it - the nation that controls Europe wins outright.

[b]3) Which are the decisions made during play?[/b]
So many. So, so many. Everything point in the game is truly a decision point. Most revolve around which card to use, when and how. And these have a number of correlations - timming, board state, the connected event, the number of OP, the cards already used and possible cards still in hand, etc - that the tree of decision is huge.

The learning curve is steep, as knowing the deck and the possibilities is key in doing well. Also, since the sides play differently (URSS has more strength early on, USA has more in Late War), is very useful to know when and where to push.

[b]4) What are the good things in the game?[/b]
- Excellent design, enough to entertain for many plays, without the need of expansions;
- The theme has a strong presence alongside the mechanics;
- Plays tend to be tense and are able to create a nice narrative each time;
- High replay value;
- Filled with decisions throughout.

[b]5) Which are the bad news?[/b]
- Language dependent;
- Limited to 2 players;
- A more experienced player might be locked and in either usually playing "soft" and not enjoying the experience as much, or crush the opponent, and likely causing some grief;
- In the several plays before actually being able to deal with the cards and be aware of them and the timming of the game, the luck of the draw and of the rolls will not only bother, but can be decisive.

[b]6) How do you feel while playing?[/b]
Like being alone in a big kitchen when the restaurant is full and the orders keep coming in. You try to juggle everything: spread influence, battle for control of battlegrounds and countries, stay ahead in the military actions and in the Space Race, be in front in points and ready to score well (or prevent a good scoring) in any region of the globe. But the orders keep coming. There is food burning, and you can see where, but can smell the fire, while some meals are getting cold, waiting for you to make put the dressing or the finishing touches, however you simply can't make it there and not take the meat out of the oven.

You want to do it all, but won't be able. Even more, you might accomplish something somewhere, but at the cost of giving an event that will cost you dearly somewhere else. The balance of power is constantly changing, and you want to always be on top when the right time comes, and, yet, this moment may be up to the decision of your adversary.

Where to focus, where to pressure, where to give. It is relentless. 

Tension reigns supreme in every round - not only because of what you can do, but also due to the limited pool of cards, which brings the knowledge that, if you aren't holding a given card until a certain point, it is definitely in your opponent's hand. And also comes from knowing that, at some point, you will have to give some great events to the enemy and score some places you truly don't want to. Not a game for the faint of heart.

And there will be those that will love this - many do. I, sadly, don't.

[thing=12333][/thing] is a pretty good game, great even, however it demands an investment in learning its ways, to climb the learning curve, until one leaves the "luck" part of it, and I simply won't be able to give what it requires from me, as games of this sort is a one, two plays a year around here. Many people in my group that claim to love it can't play even once a year. Therefore, I fear I will always remain in the level of being bothered by a good roll in a realignment, or in a coup, or in the Space Race - specially when I don't achieve the same. The same works for the drawing of cards. Those that have the experience, can work around these problems, reverse the setbacks and get ready to the troubled times ahead. Yet, I'm not there and likely won't ever be, being destined to mediocrity and frustration.

This puts [thing=12333][/thing], which is already a type of game that doesn't particularly attract me (highly competitive for 2 players), in a situation that I can admire the efficient design, the strong thematic flavor, the tense tug of war, and know it simply isn't for me.

Yet, it might truly be for you. If able, give it a try.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
It's probably not fair to rate this game after just one play, but whatever, I'm doing it anyways. My one play so far made me want to play more, to see how much you do is really dictated by the cards and how much is based on experience. I feel like there is definitely a high amount of strategy involved for experienced players, but in my first play at least I caught myself surprised by scoring cards and other opportunities. I feel like I would know much better in my second game what to expect from my opponents and how to make the best of my hands. While it's easy to blame my "bad draws", most of the game definitely felt like there was sufficient control of randomness. The rules weren't as daunting as I imagined, which was a plus. I liked the use of theme, the double-edged sword of most of the cards, and the emerging story. I don't know when I'll ever get to play again, but I look forward to it.

We don't like the central mechanic's frustration--when you use points, you often give your opponent as much benefit or more--combined with the randomness of the cards and the dice. It's very punishing--if you make one mistake or the dice and cards run against you, there can be a rich-get-richer problem. Some games are fun even when you lose; we find this one aggravating. We're giving up on this one indefinitely.

RATING: N/A
modern, 2 player
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Twilight Struggle inherits its fundamental systems from the card-driven classics We the People and Hannibal: Rome vs. Carthage. It is a quick-playing, low-complexity game in that tradition. The game map is a world map of the period, whereon players move units and exert influence in attempts to gain allies and control for their superpower. As with GMT's other card-driven games, decision-making is a challenge; how to best use one's cards and units given consistently limited resources?
Twilight Struggle's Event cards add detail and flavor to the game. They cover a vast array of historical happenings, from the Arab- Israeli conflicts of 1948 and 1967, to Vietnam and the U.S. peace movement, to the Cuban Missile Crisis and other such incidents that brought the world to the brink of nuclear annihilation. Subsystems capture the prestige-laden Space Race as well as nuclear tensions, with the possibility of game-ending nuclear war.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.5
A game that I really wanted to love but ended up hating.

The representation of history is just incorrect, imo. But, putting that aside and accepting its Domino Theory PoV, the actual mechanism for it in the game seems weak.

The war concept is ok, but poorly implemented.  I certainly didn't feel when playing like I had to manage a recurring flashpoint in either the Middle East or between India and Pakistan.

The mechanism for Southeast Asia was reasonable, but should have been applied to Eastern Europe as well, where there was both a definite Warsaw Pact core and periphery.

And so on.  The game design feels very inconsistent, even within itself, and like it really needed another round of development.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Nevertheless one of the best 2 player games with the highest replayability I have encountered. Id give it a 10 in terms of mechanics, but a 6 in terms of the actual experience not being especially pleasant. Very much duplicates the feeling of growing up in the Cold War.

RATING: 8.5
I love the idea of this game. I'm a big fan of Cold War-era politics and spy fiction, so the theme was perfect for me. I love the fact that you're trying to strike a fine balance of reaping your own rewards while softening the punches your opponent's cards force upon you. This game isn't for everyone, however, as it's basically like a 4 hour game of Risk with a heavy political theme. Special mention goes to the Space Race track for being an innovative way to bury potentially-catastrophic cards.

RATING: 7
Fun game, easy for non-wargamers to learn, and explores a historical period that doesn't otherwise have a lot of game coverage. This is one of the only card-driven-games where I think the cardplay really makes sense for the topic, rather than just being pasted on to ride the current CDG fad. 

Update: In the 5 years since I wrote the above, this has gone from being a fringe wargame to being the #1 game on the Geek. I'm not sure I get that, honestly. It's fun, and I still enjoy playing it a couple times a year. But it just doesn't grab me like *that*. But there must be something all those other folks love - including my wife, who requests it more than any other game.

RATING: 9.5
The first game took five hours, with the Soviets winning at final scoring.  Game #2 was an hour shorter, and once again the USSR won in endgame scoring (though the US actually spent some time ahead on the VP track this time.)  For at least an hour afterwards, I could think about little besides "when am I going to get to play this again?"

That's when I knew it was a *great* game.  But there is the little matter of the Soviet advantage.  Well, after six games, I finally got the USA to win,  13 at final scoring (and an Iron Lady discarded to Terrorism away from a turn 9 auto-win).  So far I've managed three US wins in ten games (seven as the US)- one at final scoring, one via Wargames on Turn 9, and one on Turn 10 where the Soviets triggered a suicide nuclear war rather than go to a final scoring where I Controlled Europe.  (Chernobyl plus Tear Down This Wall is the Americans' late-war answer to Red Scare plus Blockade, and then some.)  I have yet to lose as the Soviets, but I'm sure it'll happen soon enough- my opponents just need to play the US some more.

After ten plays in less than four months with no sign of slowing down, I'm upping my rating to 9.5- it's still too soon to be sure I'll love this game forever, but it has been played over and over, and I still do always want to play it more.

...

Now that I've had several chances to play the Deluxe Edition: the new cards are a must, and redress most of the US/Soviet imbalance (it's still easier to play the USSR, and is probably worth bidding 1-2 IPs for, but it's a lot closer).  I will never play with the CCW variant though- the mere possibility of a game with no China Card feels very wrong, and would screw with hand management in very unpleasant ways.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
Perhaps the most balanced card driven game from GMT I have played. Cold war theme sits well and this one allows great replayability. Despite the high score and rank I doubt that this game would please anyone picking it up, anyone into well balanced medium-weight cold war games for two this is the it.

RATING: 10

RATING: 3
If not for the fact that I played this game with a good friend, I would have probably rated it a 2. 
I can't begin to imagine how it ranks so highly on BGG - I would've thought the theme alone would appeal only to a niche audience.  But this 2-player, hugely long, poorly produced box of cardboard chits with an awful 4.7.6 style rulebook straight from the Cold War era itself?  Inconceivable!
With both card draw and dice rolling, the game is very luck based.  Even worse, unlike many good American style games, there's no way of manipulating a bad result through some kind of resource spending or card draft.  The historical events on the cards certainly add to the feeling of the era, but mess with your game play so much, that rather than the leader of a superpower you feel like a mid level bureaucrat with an insane boss.  Hmmm, now that I think about it, the theme IS pretty strong...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
After one play I can see a lot of potential in Twilight Struggle. It felt like there is a good amount of luck in the game, with the dice rolls and random appearance of scoring cards, but I can see how this would improve greatly if both the players know the cards well. Even though I wasn't familiar with the cards at all, I still thought the game was quite tense and a good simulation of the Cold War. I actually won as the U.S. with 25 victory points during the first headline phase after the mid-war cards were shuffled into the deck. The U.S.S.R. player was concentrating on the instant victory for Europe scoring and I barely survived and managed to rack up points in Asia, scoring it twice. I am sure this was just a fluke, though. I am definitely looking forward to trying this again.

RATING: 8
2-player only, a game about the Cold War struggle between the USA and USSR, focused on political influence instead of military tactics. Players with an interest in WWII history will especially love the use of real historical events to sway the board. Some of the cards are impossible to predict and profoundly game-changing, so repeat players will have a decided advantage against newbies.

RATING: 10
Absolutely brilliant game. The theme works really well with the mechanics. It's possible for either player to have a really bad hand in one turn, but that element of luck should even out over the 10 turns a game will usually play. Also my feeling is there's a slight advantage to the Reds in the Early War phase and a slight advantage for the US in the Late War, but it's far from insurmountable for either side. The only real down-side I can think of is that repeated plays will lead to players knowing the places to avoid putting influence as they know an Event could negate all their effort their, which is a shame because of the 'nasty/nice surprise' element of the Event cards when you don't know them all. But I can't really see how that could have been avoided. All in all, I can't see myself ever turning down a game of this, as I know I'll always enjoy it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I might be one of the few people who enjoy 13 Days more.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Wantlist is for upgraded board & cards with expansion.

Area control card-driven game oozing with a strong cold war theme. Two players play Soviet Union vs. the USA and use events or operation points on cards to increase their sphere of influence around the world. Key mechanism is that events must be played when they belong to your opponent, making the game one that centers around damage control - the experience is thus tight and tense. Low component quality for high price is a major drawback to this otherwise excellent game, especially the flimsy unmounted board. Another potential troublesome design choice is the unbalanced nature of the sides - the USSR player has a much greater chance to win outright during the early turns while the US player plays a more defensive game. Overall, the USSR seems to have as much as a 2/3rd chance of winning, especially with inexperienced players. This can be troublesome for a game that can take upwards of 3+ hours to complete. I think I prefer "1960: The Making Of The President" when playing a 2P card-driven area control game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Twilight Struggle is a historical two-player game where players take sides in the 60's cold war between America and the Soviet Union. I've played once and it was a lot of fun and a well-made game. The drawback is that it takes too long, and I don't like games that last over an hour, but the exception is with two-player games, as you can easily quit or adjourn the game to be continued on another day if you get restless or tired of playing.

Not to be confused with the more popular "Twilight Imperium" game which is an absurdly long all-day game that I'd never play, nor with those ridiculous teeny-bopper vampire films.

RATING: 10
Anyone who considers themselves a gamer needs to try this game. Great tension, great theme, bluffing, history and replayability. My only two caveats are the following: (1) It's a typical GMT game in terms of components. The cards are sturdy and the cardboard counters are perfectly functional. But it's not really pretty to look at. (2) While it's easy to learn, it's hard to master. You'll probably need to start by playing other newbies because you won't be much of a challenge to an experienced player.

From both sides, that makes it pretty unsatisfying compared to some better games (Sekigahara, Maria, Napoloeons Triumph, etc.)

Un 7 per l'idea e l'aspetto culturale, giocato invece competitivo perde interesse √® un gioco di carte come un altro.

Luca Iennaco say:

It's not a wargame, but a fiddly area-majority game driven by cards and resolved with dice.
Probably more appealing to wargamers or those not minding if, after 3 hours, the outcome will be determined by a die roll in the last action of the last turn (happened thrice to us).

Theme is original and interesting, but gameplay is very random. You roll dice to: realign, coup, the space race, several events (all the Wars, Quagmire/BearTrap, Summit, Olympics...); that's pretty much everything you can do in the game except for placing influence.
Distribution of cards can screw you (because you get cards of low value or the opponent gets those with high value or you get only those associated with his events or all these together!) or help you a lot (reverse the examples).
Handling the events of the opponents would be the most interesting part, if it weren't often pretty obvious (play last those with effects "until end of turn", use the Space Race, the ONU and the "held option" to neutralize the most dangerous, etc.).
After you know the cards, you'll start to play around them (knowing that Cuba will be taken by Fidel, etc.).
The overall result is that you don't feel rewarded by your decisions, but driven to a random outcome by the dice and cards.

There are some production issues: 
-) you'll need something to replace control markers (e.g. wooden cubes) as they are overlapped and thus cannot be read (alternatively you'll need to inspect stacks of counters every few actions); 
-) it's quite uncomfortable to determine the degree of control you've in each region (and since this is crucial to scoring, you'll need to do it often);
-) some cards aren't clear enough;
-) errata corrige issued about cards and setup (and constantly evolving...);
-) some spelling errors.

Average game length for us: 3 hours.
Expensive. 

2006-05-12*

RATING: 7


UPDATE: Still never been played through. It's a game that needs to be played several times to learn the cards for maximum benefit. Problem is that this takes 3 hours per play so you've got to commit to perhaps 15 hours of play time (five plays) before fully understanding the game. What's more, these 15 hours aren't terribly good fun because you don't know the best strategies. They are an exercise in chit pushing.

There's a real feeling of "If I'm going to commit to spending 15 hours playing a heavy head-to-head game of skill, why aren't I just playing 15 hours of Go or YINSH? At least the 15 hours of learning time would be fun, and I'd be able to find a fair few opponents afterwards.

****

* UPDATE: Has never got played. I'm just never in the mood for this game. If I want a three-hour epic game, I prefer Mage Knight or even Eclipse. It has about six months to get played before it'll get traded.

***

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Less a wargame and more an area control game, this still has some really nifty mechanisms and some neat interplay with the cards.  The way that the different eras of the war are separated into different decks, with the possibilities of events repeating themselves, really captures the historical feel of the Cold War, even if all you're really doing is trying to take over certain regions of the board in time to score them.  It's easy to get caught up in the cards as actions instead of ops points, and that's a sure sign to a loss.  I think there is the potential for a ton of replayability in this game, and I only wish it didn't take so blasted long to play.  My second play of the game lasted 2.5 hours longer than a 3-player game of Through the Ages.

2 plays: 2 players

RATING: 9
[1st edition] Very good blend between a wargame and an area control eurogame, and thematically very attractive. With some hand-made additions/modifications (control marker stones, alternate space race track, errata correction) it rates even higher, but the actual rating that I give is strictly the vote for the game out of the box.

[Deluxe edition] The deluxe edition fixes most if not all problems with sub-par component quality of the previous editions, so it goes up one point in rating (9).

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
There is so much history in this box that I'd probably love it even if the game was mediocre. Luckily, it's not. The design appeals to both wargamers and Euro lovers, card gamers and TCG duelists. The hand management features are fascinating and the random order of events make every game an exciting romp through the alt-history Cold War.

Twilight Struggle is absolutely as good as its rating indicates and I have to say that this is a game that belongs in every heavy gamer's collection.  It  also should be taken for a test drive by more middle of the road gamers since it's not quite as difficult as it looks.

On the other hand, the dice irritate me in a game of this depth, and I feel frustrated by the inability to mitigate a bad hand (a bad card or 2, yes, but I often find myself doing more good for my opponent than they are and vice versa).
