RATING: 9
Quite a game here. Not without a few warts (some cards are neither balanced nor enjoyably quirky), but overall a great success. And...my wife sorta likes it, but her initial glow has faded in proportion with bouts of chaos and luck. The decisions are tough and interesting, but how meaningful they are depends a lot on things outside of either player's control, and sometimes that just isn't fun, esp. in a game of this length (and for casual players, it's long).

Second edition is nice, esp. the new influence counters, which are non-essential, but a nice touch. The map never bothered me, and the card changes are (somewhat unfortunately) pretty minor overall.

Deluxe is also nice, but again, non-essential. The map still wants to warp a bit.  The rounded, thicker counters are better, and of course having some optional cards is a good thing.

RATING: 7
As I have already played Campaign Manager many times (and very much enjoyed it), learning this game was not a huge leap.  There are certainly more choices to make, but that is what makes this game so much more deep.  After first play, I could see Twilight Struggle becoming one of my favorite games due to the direct interaction and many decision paths.  Initial rating: 9

Lots to orchestrate and many different strategies.  Dice rolling adds a bit of randomness, but it still works for me.  More plays now and moving rating to 10.

After some more play, I think the rank will settle at 9.  The dice randomness is a bit of a problem.  I prefer the cube bag used in 1960 as a way to add biases but not complete randomness.  The length of TS is a bit of a turnoff as well.  I'd would generally rather play 4 really good games in the time it takes to play 1 TS game, but really enjoy TS for scratching a particular itch the others do not.

Update: Knocking ranking down ONLY because of the time commitment involved.  1960 gives you a similar play in half the time.

RATING: 7.9
I finally got the chance to play this new number 1 of BGG.
In short: very good but too long !
In detail: the impression is of a very good game, accurate in every detail.
The historical love poured in is tremendeous. If i truly were a history expert i would say it is terribly accurate on the historical side.
Rules are pretty detailed actually but after a while u get the most important points and then u need to play it a lot to shorten the time play, learn all the cards and explore the seemingly infinite way to play.
I kept confusing the coups and the realingments but this is just a problem with me!
The game lasted more than 4 hours and i never perceived to think more than a minute to each move: this is the only big downside of the game. I am not looking forward to playing again for 4 hours to one single game.

I don't think it is the best game around but it surely is a very good one

MODERN ERA/WAR GAME

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I have now played TS a dozen times, with several different people.  It is a 10.  TS is meaty enough to satisfy somebody like me who enjoys real depth in games.  The theme is fascinating - the Cold War was a critical period, and could have gone very badly for the world.  Trying to avoid nuclear annihilation is a key part of the game - if you start it, you lose.  

The mechanics of the game are very simple.  You can teach a newbie and play the game in a three-hour session.  (Which I consider short!)  

But simple rules don't make the game simple.  Dealing with various events popping up all around you - events being played, and your opponent's attempts at coups, etc - keeps you on your toes.  

The scoring card mechanism is very interesting.  The advantage of holding a scoring card (and you hope playing at the right time) is discounted by the fact that you hold one fewer useful card in your hand.  (And having THREE in your hand at once can be BRUTAL!)

A classic.  If the scale went to 11, that's what I'd give it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Best game. Just a little to long to play

RATING: 10
EU Maths Trade 2013
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
What I liked:
-The asymmetry of the two countries and how the US starts at the disadvantage and has to fight just to survive in the beginning.
-The incredible depth of tactics and strategy.  Each card has multiple possible uses, and there are multiple long-term strategies players can take on and off the board.
-Great balance of strategy/determinism and Luck/RNG, leaning more heavily towards the strategy/determinism but plenty enough RNG that you are kept on your toes and second-guessing yourself.

What I didn't like:
-It's intimidating when you first see the game.  The sheer number of components and types of components is a lot to take in and sort through.  
-There is a steep learning curve.  Even having a friend who knows the game teach it to you, I made a lot of mistakes.

TL;DR
Fantastic game, I'm excited to play again.  Expect a steep learning curve, and if it's your first time, watch videos ahead of time and expect it to take a minimum 2-3 hours.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

The back, the forth..ups, downs..sometimes sideways...this is what makes a game for me - fun. UPDATE:As of April 07 I have played this game 9 times. Sure there's a bit of luck with unexpected dice events but ya gotta take the good with the bad..this is a great game at this stage and I'm sure will be destined to be a classic.
UPDATE 200211 I'm going to move this game down fractionally. I still think it's a great game, I think with some of the other recent games I've acquired (Washingtons War, Julius Caesar,Napoleon's Triumph) and some of the goldie oldies (hammer of the Scots, Napoleon 1815) I am often torn whether to play this game or another. My most recent game seemed a close match but I ended it by playing war games in the late war, even though things felf like they were slipping away from me in mid to late game. It seemed like a very deflated way to end a game you've spent 3+ hours of investment by one sole card that says, hey if you've got more than 6 vps lead you win the game (and defcon is at 2).

RATING: 7
Twilight Struggle is good because it does two things well: (1) it covers a dramatically underrepresented niche in the wargaming community, and (2) it does so in a mechanically clever and appropriate manner.

If you want your Twilight experiences to be enjoyable ones, though, be sure to track down players of your own experience level.  Either that, or take the time to learn the cards backwards and forwards before facing a master.

I prefer the maneuvering and combat of block games, myself.  So CDGs only get occasional play, even when they're the cream of the crop.

RATING: 7.5
Played once. I am not familiar at all with card-driven wargames but was eager to try one - especially this one, after having hear much praise, as well as comments regarding how it was not really a wargame. I have been quite satisfied with my first play (even though I lost on turn 8 - but then I was playing against an experienced player). Of course, you need to know the cards to play well (although the theme can help you guess what might happen), but that had to be expected. I am a bit more concerned with the importance of dice rolls - they are not that numerous, which means that a single result can have important consequences (and a few early bad rolls on my side did not help during my only play). Still, I would gladly play it again - I found it was quite enjoyable, even though (or because?) it was different enough from the German-style games I am more familiar with.

RATING: 9
A very good card-driven political influence game.  After my first couple of plays, I was a little annoyed with the game because it seemed like the only way to do well was to know the deck very well.  That may still be true, but I've gotten over it.  The variety of events in the deck is what really evokes the Cold War feel of the game and the constant need to put out fires while pursuing your own agenda.

I played this before I played 1960, and after my first play of 1960, I thought I would like that game better.  A couple more plays of 1960 convinced me that there is more depth and variety in this game than that one.

I own the deluxe edition and think that it is a great version of the game.

RATING: 10
Theme is something that is low on my priorities when it comes to games. Where them is make or break for some people, I can look past a pasted-on theme and enjoy a game for its mechanics and other redeeming qualities. Twilight Struggle is the game that enlightened me to what theme can bring to a game. Despite not caring, the perfect implementation of theme in Twilight Struggle is a masterpiece. On top of theme, the tension and excruciating decisions this game throws at you make it exciting every time.

RATING: 9.25
The historical theme of this game was the greatest attraction for me. My Significant Other and I can tell that the designer(s) have spent a great deal of time researching the historical events that form the backdrop of this game.

That it is a two player game and I usually play boardgames with my Significant Other only was also a plus.

We own the deluxe version of the game and the artwork and finish of the game is fabulous. The quality is top notch.

One aspect of the game that we do not quite like is the amount of luck involved, especially the dice throwing involved to decide the outcome of wars and space race. But that is a small complaint for an otherwise excellent game.

RATING: 8
I'm obsessed with this game!  I must win as the US!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I must preface my comments by stating that I just love 2-player games due to how they are a form of direct head-to-head competition, and there is no other players that could possibly king-make or get in the way. Most of my favorites games also fall into the category of conflict simulations and feature direct conflict.

It's hard to find the words to describe how much I enjoy Twilight Struggle. The theme and tension of the game is just magnificent. It's an instant classic. I'm constantly at the edge of my seat, I don't know how to sneak in a couple ops points in a region without giving away that I'm holding the scoring card, I'm scared my opponent have that one card that will destroy my plans, I manage my hand way more intensely than in any dedicated card management game I've played to date, and the list goes on.

If you don't mind playing a game of direct conflict, if you're at all interested in the theme of the Cold War, then you owe it to yourself to play this game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The 2016 Collector's Edition is gorgeous, but features some annoying mistakes. Hopefully we'll eventually receive the reprinted card corrections.

All the mistakes in the Collector's Edition are tracked here:
https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1526152/tsce-backers-mega-thread

The important ones are the nine misprinted cards:
* Non-Aligned Movement: the card text says "South Amaerica" (i.e. misspelled).
* Stanislav Petrov: the image incorrectly shows Vasili Arkhipov, and it's also missing the asterisk to denote removal.
* Berlin Wall: missing the asterisk to denote removal.
* Mobutu Sese Seko: missing the asterisk to denote removal.
* First Lightning: missing the asterisk to denote removal.
* Don't Wait for the Translation: missing the asterisk to denote removal.
* Brush War: is printed as an Early War card, but is actually a Mid War card.
* Arab-Israeli War: incorrectly printed with the "Remove if Played" text.
* Aldrich Ames Remix: missing the "Remove if Played" text.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
It's a top play for me
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Ganas de que salga en castellano para comprarmelo.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I'm going to tell you why TS is the only game deserving a 10.

The theme is fantastic. It's the most thematic game I've ever played. You're playing through history full of things happening. It's very tense and you feel like living in a cold war era

The strategy and tactics are brilliant. You need long and short strategy. Long, as in you need to know what you want to do for the whole game. Short, as in you need to maximise your dealt card for this round. You want to have adaptive tactics to react against opponent move and ability to manage disasters.

The social interaction is excellent. You can bluff, intimidate, and basically every trick in the book is usable in the game.

Very rarely a board game excell in all three aspect. and TS is the best in all.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Really enjoyed my first play of TS but I'm not sure how much it will get to the table due to its length. 

The enormous board and length of the game really gives you a feeling of the grand scope of two superpowers fighting across the globe. What it does well is dividing the game into manageable chunks for you to process by limiting the timing and ways of scoring points. 

I know a lot of competitive players will tell you that you need to learn the cards to enjoy the game but I didn't find that to be necessary at all. I like "discovering" the events as they come out and feeling surprised by what ingenious things the game had in store for me. This obviously will vary depend on the type of gamer you are and how experienced/cruel your opponent is. 

The phrase "narrative arc" is thrown around a lot but for most games "narrative" is an overly strong descriptor. For TS, it is the only way I could explain why I thoroughly enjoy a game that should, for me, be too long, too fiddly, and mechanically uninspired.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I'm no history buff, but the tension in Twilight Struggle is very much present in every action you take.  It felt like an area control game with multiple victory conditions.  The card-driven mechanic is a gameplay style I appreciate and I think the cards themselves are well designed.  The only downside I can see is that an experienced player who is extremely familiar with the deck will have an overwhelming advantage, and I am curious to find out how the game will hold up after multiple plays, especially with a finite number and variety of cards, will each experience be similar and thus be mechanical after a while?

RATING: 1
This game seems to have most everything I DON'T like in a game.  Limited to two players, overlong, board looks like geography class, loosely based on history where if it plays consistent with history one player's loss should be a foregone conclusion (the USSR lost the cold war, didn't it?).  If I was asked to design the most boring game I could imagine, this would be it.  And it's not like I'm not interested in history-- this game isn't it though, at best it's "alternate" history.  At least Steampunk as alternate history is interesting, cold war alternate history just leaves me, well, cold.  Reading the encyclopedia would be much more fun, and more accurate history too.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Amazing  I've never played a game that so well balances an a-symmetrical challenge. It has elements of chess, poker, bridge, and many other classic games.  But, instead of being just a theme tacked onto mechanics, TS simply IS the theme.  You couldn't separate the mechanics from the brinkmanship that the game emulates.  
I would say that the playtime (at least for my partner and I, who were both new to the game) can actually be quite a bit longer than stated.  However, while your first playthrough may be slow and a bit daunting, once you *get it* (which happens much faster than you'd think when you look at the rule book) it picks up considerably.  
 AND (i know this doesn't matter to most folk), it really REALLY is educational!  I couldn't believe how much more I understood the chronology and mentality and politics of the cold war, by just playing the game.  HALF the rule book is a history lesson - one you don't need to read to play the game, but one you will WANT to read after you've played.  The permutations of historical "what-if"s are so mindbogglingly huge, every game (win OR loose) you'll talk about the game, not in game terms, but as a hypothetical historian might.
GET IT!  
PS, This is NOT a war game.  Not in the way it might look (and be sold to you).  I am not interested in war games at all (gimmy fantasy/ science fiction any day) but this hooked me because, while it is a strategic and tactical game, it is the closest thing to a "passive aggressive" game if there ever wwas one.  No killing, no dramatic action - just a quiet struggle that threatens, like a great thriller, to end in ruin.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Redise√±o P&P

RATING: 8.6

Only downside is it is a bit long to be getting people to play for a 2 player game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
For an overlong Euro that requires deck memorization to be competitive, Twilight Struggle is...not bad. Sparse yet critical die-rolling makes the game swingy, play time is far too long, and it really is only fun if you play it with someone of relatively equal ability, and by ability I mean knowledge of the card deck. But, if you learn it with a friend and play it a lot, Twilight Struggle does reveal itself as a tense, psychological game that's evocative of the Cold War. I love the scope and ambition of the design.

Rather tired of some (dare I say "leftists"?) who think the game represents a "right-wing fantasy" and fail to distinguish between nationalism and conservatism on the right. Not at all synonymous.

RATING: 10
The meanest game in existence that is not unfair or "take that" - the game of constant losing and frustration. The only game around which I had serious argues with my girlfriend. It is mechanically not made for me because I simply cannot, even after more than 70 plays, remember to prepare for some nasty cards that are coming...

Yet, it transfers Cold War events into its abstract numbers with such an elegance, it is thematically so correct and so full (despite necessary reduction to domino theory), and it is, after all - my first game, my first (kinda) wargame... I hate it, and I love it. There is no greater stress than rolling for coup, no greater proud than spreading communism through Africa or South America even though I know I will ultimately loose. 

Edit 25-8-2015: Yes it can be random, or at least dice can ruin one whole game. But more often than not it balances itself throughout the session. Otherwise - it deserves a perfect 10 after all.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Certainly one of the best games ever made. The reason I love this game is the story arc and the gameplay arc that intertwine beautifully. The gameplay arc is the most brilliant. Playing 6-7 cards for 10 rounds in most games would become repetitive, but here not only the tactical consideration how to play or mitigate your dealt hand matters, it also matters which specific round you are playing because of the existence of periodical decks that get shuffled into the draw deck and discarded cards that can make a comeback. On top of what a card can do the context of timing through this gameplay arc becomes equally important. 

The balance of the map and regions is very well done. Each region or battleground has its specific strengths, timing and positional elements, which makes the area control play more than just a push and pull of 'cubes'. 

The game also works really well because the card abilities are well thought out and the designer succeeded to nail the thematical aspect of the cards and so a story arc develops in an interesting way. The different uses of 'card points' to do things on the map and the consideration that you maybe have to trigger a very good ability for your opponent all make up for a considerably in depth decision making on how to manage your hand. 

Knowledge of the cards is a necessity if you want to have a truly competitive game and one of the weak points and big hurdles when you want to draw in new players. But learning and teaching the game on the other hand isn't that difficult. Rules are reasonably light in comparison to other wargames and heavy eurogames. 

Lastly the existence of a defcon tracker and thus the possibility of a nuclear war escalation creates a third pillar for the game. Not only can you fall behind positionally on the map, recklessly playing cards can lead to a loss by triggering nuclear war. This not only creates a constant threat but also gives even more considerations and opportunities to manipulate and control the board position or the opponents play.

About the dice rolls and horrible hands: often have I felt desperate when a die roll failed horribly at a critical moment or when a hand of the worst possible cards gets dealt to you. But in a game such as this that got analyzed to pieces, there needs to be uncertain elements and risks to not make it stale and the difficult situations that the game sometimes throws at your lap is what gives this game a gaming heart and soul that makes you want to come back to it. 

My mind was even more blown when recently a Chinese way of playing the game vs the 'positional area control style' came to light. Not often does it happen that in a game, which got analyzed to pieces like this one, a new strategic philosophy of playing is successful. 
   
Note : this game also has the best developed boardgame app with flavourful atmosphere and speeches included. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I'm torn on this game. It does have good depth and I think that it really gives the player an accurate feel of the theme. However, I just find it a bit on the boring side (as I said, represents the theme well, 'Cold War stand off'). The games I have played (6 or 7 total) seem to follow a certain call and response pattern. Player one does this, player two undoes what player 1 did. Player one does something else, player two then counters that move etc etc. I'll still gladly play it but I certainly don't think it is worthy of being the number 1 game nor even top 10.

RATING: 7

When playing, don't underestimate the power of those onesey-twosey VP cards.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The best two-player game I've played up to date.  What keeps this one going for me is the level of tension that ratchets up during the course of play as you respond to your opponent's actions and figure out how to defuse the hand you've received.  And tempo. Boy is tempo important and hard to manage.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Really looked forward to my first play. Was rather disappointed. Made 6-7 rolls on Space track, success on 1-3 or 1-4, missed all but one. Could keep up a bit due to cards, but was always 1-2 steps behind. 

One turn I started with 5 scoring cards in my hand, meaning I could watch my opponent do free (unopposed) moves for nearly a full turn. 

Game needs a number of plays to learn choke points and crucial cards, if you're willing to invest that time. I'm not.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I like the setting and what the game wants to do, but I just don't like the game.
The cards are random and which cards you draw has a huge effect, as do the die rolls; on the other hand, it takes three hours and then due to these factors the result mostly comes down to luck (which you can try to mitigate with some strategy).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
so tense, so entertaining, so different on every single play.
just amazing!
